HEADLINE: Report Urges Japan to Raise Taxes

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 16

 BODY:
Underscoring the effects of a rapidly aging population, low birthrates and skyrocketing fiscal deficits in Japan, the prime minister's tax advisory council released a report on Friday that strongly suggested tax increases are necessary if the country is to avoid financial disaster.
The Tax Commission recommended lowering the minimum income level at which taxes begin, raising sales taxes and forcing even the 60 percent of Japanese corporations that report losses to pay local taxes based on their size rather than their profitability. 
 It noted that corporate tax rates have fallen to levels comparable to those in the United States and that Japan's income tax revenue is among the lowest in major industrialized countries. At 5 percent, Japan's sales tax is also one of the lowest among its economic peers, the report said.
The report poses a problem for the Japanese government, which has struggled for the last decade to get the economy back on its feet after the burst of the asset bubble that marked Japan's heady ascent in the 1980's.
"We think Japan faces a policy bind -- no matter what you do, you wind up creating problems in other areas," Vincent J. Truglia, co-head of sovereign risk at Moody's Investors Service, the credit ratings agency, told Bloomberg News on Friday. Moody's is considering another downgrade of Japan's credit rating.
The report is not binding. But the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's tax panel, which makes policy, has in the past made its revisions to the tax code in line with the Tax Commission's reports.
The implications of the report are sobering. Higher individual taxes would hurt spending, which accounts for some 60 percent of economic activity here at a time when policy makers are heavily relying on consumption to fuel Japan's sputtering economic recovery.
That will no doubt come under discussion on Monday when the Bank of Japan's policy board meets. Economists have placed even odds that the board will vote to increase interest rates, abandoning its policy of maintaining rates at virtually zero.
But the prospect of higher taxes combined with rising interest rates would most likely choke whatever economic revival is under way. An increase in the consumption tax a few years ago slammed the brakes on what was shaping up as a mild economic recovery, a memory that remains especially painful for the Liberal Democratic Party.
In fact, the report is somewhat embarrassing for the party, which criticized the opposition Democratic Party for suggesting during parliamentary elections last month that taxes must rise.
The report's recommendations stand in stark contrast to steps other countries are taking to reduce the tax burdens on their citizens.
The same day that the Tax Commission released its report, Germany enacted a package of tax reforms intended to enhance the competitiveness of its industries.
That package is likely to push Germany's neighbors to adopt more liberal tax policies, which would leave Japan to buck the trend alone among the major industrialized nations.
But Japan's problems, while not singular, are more exacerbated than those of its biggest trading partners. The Japanese population is aging far more rapidly and its birthrate falling more rapidly than in any other country, and its efforts to spend its way out of a decadelong economic downturn, rather than adopting more painful structural remedies, has left it with the highest deficit of any industrialized country.
Japan's tax revenue covers less than half its expenditures, and thus the Organization for Economic Development estimates that Japan's debts will exceed its gross domestic product by almost 18 percent this year. In contrast, Germany's debt stands at 63 percent of gross domestic product and the United States' at 51.7 percent.

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
Ebony Ends Publication in South Africa

BYLINE: By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: DURBAN, South Africa, July 16

 BODY:
The South African edition of Ebony magazine, introduced nearly five years ago in the afterglow of the country's triumph over apartheid, has shut down after failing to find profits or many readers.
On newsstands around the country, a fewleft-over copies of last month's issue are all that remains of Ebony South Africa. 
 Leaping aboard the post-apartheid bandwagon, Ebony's American publisher, Johnson Publishing, had hoped to bring an institution of African-American culture to the coffee tables of South Africa, a country with enormous economic promise but still wrestling with the legacy of white domination and the struggle for black equality.
But prosperity has been slower than expected in reaching the black majority. For Ebony South Africa, that meant a retail market with still too little interest in advertising to black consumers and a magazine industry with little room for a publication celebrating a level of success that few black people here can yet conceive, let alone achieve.
In South Africa, blacks number about 34.6 million out of a total population of 44.7 million, according to the University of South Africa's mid-year estimate. But millions of them are unemployed and the majority of them are poor, a problem that has worsened in recent years as job losses in government and industry have increased.
Circulation peaked at 23,880 during the first half of 1999 before dropping to 22,477 during the second half of the year, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations South Africa.
Even at its highest circulation, the magazine never pulled in enough advertising, said Christopher D. Benson, a vice president of Johnson Publishing.
"We didn't see that it was going to improve, and we just had to make the hard decision," Mr. Benson said in a telephone interview from Chicago. "I think it's a function of the commitment that we had to the project that we held on as long as we did in the face of mounting losses."
Moreover, according to some industry observers here, the magazine never quite found the necessary balance of American and African content.
"What they were turning out was more of an American Ebony with a touch of South Africa rather than a South African Ebony with a touch of America," said Fraser Mtshali, the editor in chief of Bona. Based in Durban, Bona is aimed at black readers and is the nation's best-selling lifestyle magazine. "They were seeing South Africa through American eyes."
Ebony South Africa's final cover story, on the soccer star Lucas Radebe, was a revealing example, Mr. Mtshali said. Despite his popularity, Mr. Radebe is old news, Mr. Mtshali said. Without some tantalizing new tale about the athlete, there was little to attract the average South African reader, he said.
Inside the last issue of Ebony South Africa were stories about the American singer Toni Braxton, the American jazz great Louis Armstrong and American athletes running into trouble with the law. There was also a feature on Nelson Mandela and his wife, short profiles of South African musical greats and a mix of health and romance items.
Mr. Benson, the Johnson Publishing executive, said Ebony South Africa, which had a local staff directed by an American editor and took some of its articles from the American edition, tried to capture the interests and nuances of the South African audience. "We were constantly evaluating it, through readership surveys, to find out what readers were looking for," he said. "I think the magazine reflected that."
Bona, which is published in English as well as in three indigenous languages, is looking for the same successful, free-spending black people in their late 20's and early 30's that Ebony South Africa was aimed at. But Mr. Mtshali said his magazine also tried to embrace younger and older readers as well.
The cover of the July issue of Bona advertises stories on "Soccer's New Heroes," a "Wake-up Call From God" for a South African singer and a "Baby That Took Five Years to Be Born."
"Our market is broader," Mr. Mtshali said. "We're more family oriented." And yet, even Bona, which has been around for more than four decades, has watched its circulation fall to just under 178,000 during the second half of last year, compared with 271,230 four years earlier.
With the economy growing only modestly here, the media sector is struggling to hold onto what share of the market it already has.
Tribute, a glossy that aims for the same affluent audience that Ebony South Africa was going for, has seen its circulation drop from just over 16,000 in 1994 to slightly more than 10,000 during the second half of last year.
"I don't think there's been the kind of black aspirational success that had been hoped, and that has to have had an effect on publishing," said Kerry Swift, who in the late 1970's was an executive editor of Drum, a magazine that made its name as the literary conscience of the struggle against apartheid. Subsequently, Drum became a more conventional life style magazine that now has a weekly circulation of about 137,000 -- down several thousand from its heyday 20 years ago.
"The market really hurts," said Mr. Swift, who is now a director for Core Media Holdings, a South African company that publishes the local editions of publications like PC, an American computer magazine owned by Ziff-Davis. "But I think there are much deeper cultural factors at work, too."

HEADLINE: Money, Jobs, Big Cars: How's an Irishman to Cope?

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: DUBLIN

 BODY:
Ireland's economy has been growing faster than any other in the Western world, and the country whose master playwright, Sean O'Casey, once said, "I'd rather be inspired by idleness than bullied by 'busyness' " now has some of the hardest-working citizens in Europe.
For the first time in its history, Ireland has a problem with too much money, not too little -- with too few people living here, not too many. 
 The subject of what to keep, what to shed and what to adapt for modern times is on lots of Irish minds as the country -- a proven force in developing sustaining myths to overcome failure, poverty and melancholy -- turns to coping with the novelty of prosperity.
"You have tourists giving out about us that we've lost our courtesy, that we don't have time to talk to one another anymore, that our Irish identity is slipping away," said Maureen Gaffney, head of The National Economic and Social Forum, a consultative group partly funded by the government. "We're very disturbed by that, and I'm not a Cassandra, but I think we have the vibrancy here to handle it."
From the cranes that lumber across the Dublin skyline to the traffic jams that pile up along the Liffey as early as 6:30 a.m., progress is intruding. With so many opportunities at home, Ireland's young professionals no longer leave and those that did a generation ago have now come back. But one disruptive consequence of this happy turnaround is a 20 percent-a-year spiral in the cost of housing that is pricing the middle class out of city living.
The look of new Dublin pubs seems to have more to do with the East Coast of the United States than the West Coast of Ireland. Typifying the trend, a former flower stand just off the landmark Ha'penny Bridge has been turned into a minimalist cafe called Pravda with Cyrillic lettering design features and a menu featuring Thai wraps, tortillas and spicy chicken wings.
There are 20,000 job openings, and an estimated 200,000 more coming up in the next five years that will have to be filled by foreigners. Executives are often out of town on recruitment trips, and businesses have dropped their earlier insistence that applicants speak English.
Yet in a development that is bringing shame to Ireland, the country that sent millions of people abroad as poor immigrants is proving inhospitable to needy outsiders who are arriving here. Despite the jobs in Dublin going wanting, asylum seekers, who now number 1,000 a month, are being dispersed around the country and barred from working. "We thrived on tales of the Boston Brahmins and 'No Irish need apply,' " said Maurice Hayes, a member of the Irish Senate and chairman of The Ireland Funds, the country's largest charity. "Now we think the only immigrants we want are people who otherwise would have gone directly to Silicon Valley."
Car sales are up 40 percent this year over 1999, and traffic congestion projected for the year 2010 has already arrived, but highway construction to accommodate all the new vehicles lags. Rural areas even 40 miles out of Dublin are becoming bedroom communities, with country lanes pressed into service to handle the new commuting class. "Nobody thought ahead about this, and you can't just go out and buy a mile of road down at Woolworth's," said Colm McCarthy of DKM Economic Consultants Ltd.
Public services in particular are suffering from underfunding and a lack of planning, and their downtroddenness stands out starkly against the shine and efficiency of the booming private sector. Last year, nurses went on strike for higher wages.
"Our nurses were working so hard they were really and truly bent," said Mary Tynan, 48, the head emergency room nurse at Beaumont Hospital. Describing the nurses' desperation, she said the value of the house she bought for $12,000 in 1979 was now $265,000, and people on public salaries could not afford to buy homes anymore.
Inflation is running at 5.2 percent, three times the average of the other 10 countries that have adopted the euro currency and therefore a centralized interest rate. That rate today is 4.25 percent, at least four points lower than where analysts say the Irish central bank would peg it if it were still operating independently. While participation in Europe over all has been enormously beneficial to Ireland, bringing subsidies that helped spur the boom, the government finds its hands tied in coping with inflation without the customary rate-increase mechanism at its disposal. "It's like playing tennis without a racket," Mr. McCarthy said.
With inflation threatening to overtake negotiated wage increases of 5.5 percent, union leaders are questioning the national business-labor agreement that since 1987 has brought wage restraint in exchange for job growth. An emphasis on computer literacy and information technologies, however, is creating a permanent underclass as it spreads affluence, and the abundance of things is spawning what Senator Hayes called relative deprivation. "People who were poor now have more to eat," he said, "but they don't have a television, and everyone down at the pub is talking about what they saw on TV."
Social habits are changing, breaking down traditional patterns of association. "You used to be part of an extended family or a village," said Brendan Keenan, 55, business editor of The Independent. "Even after you came to Dublin, you were a Corkman or a Galwayman, and that's who you socialized and drank with. Now you might have one set of friends at work and another at home. And home isn't around the corner. It might be in a suburb."
The government has attracted admiration for its success in steering the process that has brought the promise of an end to a century's sectarian conflict in Northern Ireland, but it is squandering its reputation through disclosures from tribunals of cronyism and corruption that still permeate Ireland's public life.
Frank Madden, 38, of Ballsbridge Motors in one of Dublin's upscale neighborhoods, is a salesman with a prospering clientele who want to swan around in eye-catching cars and stock their garages with extra ones from the sports and convertible lines. "When I began in this business, people bought cars as a necessity," he said. "Now they buy them as indulgences."
Mr. Madden is making more money than he ever dreamed possible, and his company will move 6,000 Mercedes-Benzes off its jammed lots this year. "Ten years ago," he said, "we'd have had a celebration if we sold 600."
But seated in his busy showroom, he was not in a party mood. "I'm here from 8 in the morning to 8 at night, and I can genuinely say it's not healthy for me or my family. I cannot be the husband and father I want to be at night after days like these, and I hear my colleagues around the floor say the same thing. We don't feel self-rewarded by the good times we're in."
There is a consensus that the two biggest changes in Ireland are the fall of the Roman Catholic Church as social arbiter and the rise of women as active participants in society. Brendan Kennelly, a leading poet and professor of modern literature at Trinity College, Dublin, said the most important development in Irish letters was the emergence of talented women among writers. "From being adored symbols on pedestals, women have come down to become articulate voices, no longer passive receivers of homage but expressive of their own problems and the problems in the culture," he said
One of Ireland's new generation of outspoken women is Ivana Bacik, 32, who as the Reid professor of criminal law at Trinity occupies the same post once held by the current president of Ireland, Mary McAleese, and by her predecessor, Mary Robinson. "I grew up in Cork in the 1970's, and Ireland was a horrible place to be," she said. "People are misconceiving the past. There has always been huge poverty and huge hypocrisy, but now you can talk openly about them. When I was a student here in the early 1990's, it was radical to be in favor of even giving information to women."
The boom has happened so speedily that some people are not yet convinced that it is here to stay. "Irish history has been one of uninterrupted failure since the beginning of the 19th century, and this has impinged on our psychology," Mr. Keenan said. "The big question for many people now is when is it going to end, because they remember that everything else eventually went wrong. The question for them is not what are the consequences, but where's the catch?"
Mr. Keenan believes that it will last. "It's simple," he said. "In the euro zone, having a young, well-educated population is like having oil."
Another reason Ireland seems to be weathering the rapid and profound cultural shock of the past decade reasonably well is the solidarity built up over centuries from being small, compact, homogeneous and deprived. "Say what you will about the Catholic Church," Senator Hayes said, "there was something important for us in having been told over and over of being all together and equal before God."
Fintan O'Toole, a columnist and author who travels to New York once a month to do theater reviews for The Daily News, credited Ireland's particular ease with America. "Ireland is a culture besotted with American images," he said. "What's happened with all this American investment is that you have come to us, and instead of making us change, it gives us a way to continue with our old life."
Ireland was not as comfortable with its stereotype as it pretended to be for its own survival, he said, and there is little nostalgia for the misty past.
Mr. Keenan said: "No one wants dear old Ireland back. Dear old Ireland was nice for the tourists, but not for us."
There is also little gloating at how well things seem to have worked out. "There is real pleasure in the fact that economists and politicians now come over here to find out how we did it and in the realization that we are world class because we were always considered second rate," Mr. Keenan said.
Ms. Gaffney said she thought that the Irish today drew strength from the unity gained, paradoxically, from having been dispersed around the globe. "'We were supposed to represent our country as well as ourselves and not just competently but with skill and confidence," she said. "There was a tremendous emphasis on the presentation of ourselves to the world."
Ireland got through hard times on this ability to compose its own narrative, and that same talent may keep it secure and distinct through the good times. "You know, in Gaelic, when you greet someone, the actual words mean, 'What's your news?' " Mr. Kennelly said. "We live on stories. I always think of that phrase, 'I am the way, the truth and the light.' You see, the truth comes second; it's the way that matters. It's how you tell things. And that is the oldest Irish tradition."

HEADLINE: John Pastore, Prominent Figure in Rhode Island Politics for Three Decades, Dies at 93

BYLINE: By RICHARD GOLDSTEIN 

 BODY:
John O. Pastore, the first Italian-American to be elected as a governor and sit in the United States Senate, and a dominant figure in Rhode Island politics for three decades, died on Saturday at a nursing home in North Kingstown, R.I. He was 93.
"Rhode Island is the smallest state in the union, and I am the smallest governor in the United States," the 5-foot-4-inch Mr. Pastore once told a group of German editors visiting the Statehouse in Providence. When he went to Washington, he became the smallest senator. But in his 26 years in the Senate, he established himself as a formidable presence, a liberal Democrat regarded as a fierce debater with a booming voice and a firm grasp on the issues of his day. 
 He staked out a specialty in nuclear power matters as chairman of the powerful Joint Committee on Atomic Energy and in 1963 provided important backing for the Kennedy administration's controversial treaty with the Soviet Union barring nuclear tests in the atmosphere.
In waging a successful fight for ratification, Senator Pastore displayed his flair for the dramatic. During the debate he flung open his jacket and struck the left side of his chest. "I say to those who have doubts about this treaty that I want them to open their heart and look into their consciences," he implored fellow senators. "I want them to realize what they might be doing. If by their vote they destroy and kill the treaty, God help us! God help us!"
His son, John O. Pastore Jr., a cardiologist, of Winchester, Mass., was secretary of the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War when the Boston-based organization, jointly founded by American and Soviet physicians, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1985.
Senator Pastore gained national recognition for his oratory while serving as keynote speaker at the 1964 Democratic National Convention, a choice that reflected President Lyndon B. Johnson's bid for support from the industrial states of the East, but also a tribute to his ability to rouse an audience.
His voice rising and falling to great dramatic effect, his fists pounding, Mr. Pastore drew roars from the more than 5,000 Democrats at the Atlantic City Convention Hall as he denounced Senator Barry Goldwater, the Republican nominee, as a captive of "reactionaries and extremists." The response to Mr. Pastore's speech was so enthusiastic that he enjoyed a brief consideration for the vice presidential nomination that eventually went to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey.
In addition to heading the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, Mr. Pastore held posts on the Commerce and Appropriations Committees, as well as the Senate Democratic Policy Committee, making him one of the Senate's most influential members.
He led a bitter but losing battle to block the politically restrictive McCarran-Walter Immigration Act that passed over President Harry S. Truman's veto and played an important role in passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act barring discrimination in public accommodations and cutting off federal financing of discriminatory programs.
Senator Pastore was floor manager of legislation suspending equal-time provisions of the Federal Communications Act to bring about the televised Kennedy-Nixon Presidential debates in 1960. As chairman of the Senate's communications subcommittee, he sometimes took a conservative stance on social issues. In the late 1960's and 70's, he denounced what he viewed as excessive violence and sexual content in television programming.
The son of an immigrant tailor, left fatherless at age 9, he epitomized the self-made man. "I always felt there were two strikes against me, and to succeed I had to do a better job than anyone else," he said.
Mr. Pastore, who served as governor of Rhode Island from 1945 to 1950 and who never lost an election, entered statewide politics when Italian-Americans were voting in increasingly significant numbers in urban areas and using their growing economic strength to provide financial backing for political candidates they favored.
For a man whose rise reflected inroads by Italian-Americans on political gains made by Irish-Americans, John Orlando Pastore had an intriguing birthday. He was born in the largely Italian Federal Hill section of Providence on St. Patrick's Day -- March 17, 1907.
Mr. Pastore's father, Michele, a native of Potenza in southern Italy, supported his wife, Erminia, and their four children with his tailor shop. But Michele Pastore died suddenly in May 1916 while his wife was pregnant with their fifth child. Mrs. Pastore went to work as a seamstress in a department store while John cared for the three younger children.
Mrs. Pastore made sure her children were well-dressed and well-mannered, and young John developed a penchant for fastidiousness. "When he cleaned house, he moved every stick of furniture," his mother would remember. His impeccable dress would become a hallmark in his public life -- he changed his shirts in the middle of the day if they bore the slightest signs of wear.
In 1927, while working as a $15-a-week claims adjuster for an electric utility company, Mr. Pastore enrolled in evening law school classes offered by Northeastern University of Boston at a Providence Y.M.C.A. In 1932 he set up a law office in the basement of the family home, but with the Depression in full force, he attracted few clients.
One Sunday in 1933, Mr. Pastore waited outside St. Bartholomew's Church until Tommy Testa, an important local politician, came out. "I'd like to go into politics," Mr. Pastore told him. Mr. Testa, who would recall how "I liked Johnny's manner," helped him obtain the Democratic nomination for the Rhode Island General Assembly, and he was elected to two-year terms in 1934 and 1936.
Mr. Pastore then gained an appointment as an assistant state attorney general, and by the early 1940's his oratorical skill was winning over juries in criminal cases. One day a young woman named Elena Caito was passing by a courthouse while Mr. Pastore was prosecuting a case. As Mr. Pastore's son told the story long afterward: "The transom over the door was open. She could hear this booming voice coming out, and she asked one of her brothers, 'Who is that?' So they got introduced." In July 1941, they were married.
In 1944, Mr. Pastore was asked to run for lieutenant governor, a part-time position, on the statewide Democratic ticket headed by Gov. J. Howard McGrath. The Democrats won, and then Mr. Pastore got a huge break, succeeding to the governor's chair in October 1945 when Mr. McGrath was appointed solicitor general in the Truman administration. Mr. Pastore was narrowly elected to the Statehouse in November 1946, but two years later he gained a second term with ease.
Although he was the first person of Italian descent to be elected governor, he was not the first to serve in a statehouse. Charles Poletti, a son of Italian immigrants who had been lieutenant governor of New York State, served as governor in December 1942 to complete the term of Gov. Herbert Lehman, who resigned to direct American war-relief efforts in Europe.
A liberal on social-welfare matters, Mr. Pastore, as governor, worked with business interests, pushing through a sales tax, rather than relying solely on corporate income taxes, to pay for public improvements neglected during World War II. He maintained a popular touch, eating lunch with Statehouse employees in their cafeteria, and he was adept at cultivating the press.
In November 1950, Mr. Pastore was elected to the United States Senate to fill out the unexpired term of Mr. McGrath, who had moved from the solicitor general's post to the Senate, then resigned to become President Truman's attorney general. In 1952, Mr. Pastore was elected to the first of his four full terms in the Senate.
Arguing his points on the Senate floor, Mr. Pastore was not averse to wagging a finger under another senator's nose, and he impressed his Senate colleagues mightily when he got the better of the bearish senator from Oklahoma, Robert Kerr, a fierce debater, in an encounter on the floor.
Although his oratory could be flamboyant, his personal appearance was conservative -- his grooming meticulous, his black hair slicked back, his salt-and-pepper mustache kept trim.
Mr. Pastore, who retired from the Senate in 1976, is survived by his wife and son; two daughters, Francesca Pastore and Louise Harbourt, both of Springfield, Va.; two sisters, Elena Valente of North Providence, R.I., and Michelina Mentasti of Florida; seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.
Through his Senate years, Mr. Pastore earnestly pursued weighty issues. But he could also poke fun at himself.
He once observed that nuclear fallout might bring bizarre changes. "Mutations!" he thundered. "Perhaps they'll make Pastore 6 feet tall."
And he expressed gratitude that his parents had Anglicized his first name. "If they had called me Giovanni," he said, "my initials would be G.O.P."

HEADLINE: In Los Angeles, Tears, Confusion and a Resolution to End the Violence

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 16

 BODY:
Helen Austin was late for work the other day, something that almost never happens. She spent the morning at the beauty shop, crying and praying with her hairdresser.
"Her only son was killed going to work three months ago," Mrs. Austin said at Save Our Future, the neighborhood center where she volunteers. "She's having a very hard time. She's lost 30 pounds." 
 Mrs. Austin's eyes were still red and puffy an hour later. In her hand she held a crushed ball of tissue and a poster announcing a reward for the young man's killer.
But Mrs. Austin wasn't just crying for her friend. She was also crying for her own family -- two of her grandchildren have been killed over the years. And she was crying for her community of south Los Angeles, which in the last several months has been bloodied, along with many other parts of the city, by a wave of violence and killing, a scourge that many here thought was fading fast.
"I think we're starting to see the start of another epidemic," said Billie Weiss, executive director of the Violence Prevention Coalition of Greater Los Angeles. "It's starting to look like the early 90's again."
In more than two dozen interviews this week with teenagers, middle-aged ex-gang members, mothers of murdered children, social workers, elected officials, neighborhood advocates, police officers and a woman whose disabled brother was shot to death the day before the interview, people here said they were afraid and baffled by the rise in violence and just as determined to stop it.
"There's no quick fix," said Gary Honore, who speaks to youth groups about the perils of the streets and has buried a daughter, a brother and a sister slain in the last decade. "But if we don't start today, there won't be a tomorrow."
After years of dropping crime rates across the city and county, there have been 266 homicides in Los Angeles this year, a 30 percent increase from a year ago. About 42 percent of the killings have been gang-related, according to the Police Department. But no one knows for sure what is causing the surge, beyond the usual suspects of drugs, turf and too many bored and desperate young men -- and some women -- able to get their hands on too many powerful weapons.
"What I know is that it has got to stop," said a Los Angeles City Council member, Mark Ridley-Thomas, whose district has been hard hit by the violence. "It seems to be coming on rather ferociously."
Mr. Ridley-Thomas is pushing the City Council to allocate $5 million in emergency money to create summer jobs and violence-prevention programs, which have been struggling because of lack of money, he said.
"We've had as many as 13,000 summer jobs in the past," he said. "Now, it's down to 3,500."
Even in this booming economy, jobs for teenagers and for ex-convicts like Melvin Farmer, 43, are hard to find in the inner city, despite being so crucial in stopping the violence, many people here said.
Mr. Farmer, a longtime gang member, has been in and out of prison for nearly 20 years. He was last in prison three years ago. He came out determined never to return and today is vice president of the National Alliance for Positive Action, a neighborhood and youth advocate group.
"I've been out three years, and I can't find a job because of my record," Mr. Farmer said. "I might go two or three days without eating. There are a lot of temptations out here, but I'm never going back to that life. It would kill my mother."
At one of at least three anti-violence meetings held last week across the city, a Los Angeles County supervisor, Yvonne Brathwaite Burke, said finding jobs for ex-convicts should be a priority because so many are beginning to return to the streets.
Last Thursday morning, another anti-violence meeting was held, this time in the City Council chambers. As dozens of people filed into the chamber, Anthony Wingate, 46, was being helped to his chair in front of his building in South-Central Los Angeles. Mr. Wingate was partially paralyzed 12 years ago after being shot in a robbery, his sister, Natalie, said. He sat in the chair every morning, greeting passers-by.
Shortly before 9 a.m., a man walked up to Mr. Wingate's neighbor, Clifton Adams, 24, and shot him to death. Then he turned on the only witness in sight, the crippled man in the chair.
"My brother couldn't run," Ms. Wingate said. "He was handicapped. He had to be carried to the bathroom. He didn't deserve to be killed like that."
The next day, a red candle left on the stoop as a memorial to Mr. Wingate had melted over the sidewalk like blood.
"That ain't his blood," a relative said. "But that's some of his brains in the grass."
Such stories don't faze lanky Kenneth, a 17-year-old who attends an after-school program for troubled teenagers called People Who Care. "It's always more killing when it's hot," Kenneth said. "I might get killed myself. Three days back, my friend got shot in the hip. I just know it's a possibility every time I wake up."
Kenneth is about the same age as the slain sons of the three friends who founded Justice for Murdered Children, LaWanda Hawkins, Vicky Lindsey and Rita Norwood. They founded the group four years ago because they felt left out of the system and because the killers of their children were never caught. The group tries to pressure local police departments to investigate inner city homicides more aggressively.
"There are therapy groups we could have joined," Mrs. Hawkins said. "But we wanted something else. We wanted justice for our children."
Back at Save Our Future, Mrs. Austin said she wanted justice for her friend's son, too. She got some tape to put the reward poster up at the south Los Angeles center, which offers neighborhood life skills and employment training. The center was founded by Mrs. Austin's stepdaughter, Charlotte Austin Jordan, to honor her murdered children.
Mrs. Jordan's 13-year-old daughter, Jamee, was killed in 1988, a victim of mistaken identity. She was shot 15 times. "That started my crusade," Mrs. Jordan said. In 1996, her son Corey, 25, was shot and killed by a 41-year-old gang member. "Corey had two children and one on the way," Mrs. Jordan said. "The baby was born two days after we buried my son."
The men who killed her children had been in and out prison since they were young teenagers. "Nothing in prison happens to help them change," she said.
Mrs. Jordan has a 15-year-old son who asked her, "Am I going to die like that, too?"
"I couldn't just say no," Mrs. Jordan said. "All I could say was that I will do everything I can to make our community safe for him."
In the meantime, she moved her family to the suburbs, "so my son could have his childhood back."
As she talked, a former gang member named Hakeem, 29, and his brother Mookie, 14, came in. Hakeem is the same age Mrs. Jordan's son would be if he were alive, and she has practically adopted him. He calls her Mom. His own mother was killed in a drive-by shooting several years ago while he was locked up for a murder, committed when he was 13.
Mookie is dressed in baggy pants and is wearing a black bandanna on his head. "In order to stay out of trouble, you have to change the way you dress," Mrs. Jordan said to him.
Mookie looked at the floor.
"He's just like my little cousin who got shot in his neck and his back," Hakeem said. "Now he's paralyzed. He's just 15."
Hakeem sounded angry and sad.
"I shot and killed someone," he said. "I know violence ain't the answer. I don't want my little brother to be like me."
Mookie likes to go swimming, but the neighborhood pool is controlled by rival gang members. "First we fight," he said. "Then we swim."
When his cousin was shot by one of the boys who claim the pool, Mookie immediately thought revenge. It is the easiest thing in the world to get a gun in his neighborhood. But he didn't. "Because of my brother," he said. "He told me it wasn't the way. And I don't want to get locked up for the rest of my life."
Mrs. Jordan smiled. At least for a day, someone was listening.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1607 words

HEADLINE: UTILITIES TRYING NEW APPROACHES TO PRICING ENERGY

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
As air-conditioners hum this summer, and experts issue dire warnings about electricity running short, a growing number of utilities are varying the price of power based on supply and demand to make sure there is enough to go around.
The approach is a decidedly novel one for electric utilities, which have mostly set prices for power without regard to fluctuations in energy use. And it is inducing companies and individual consumers to change how they use power and think harder about what electricity is worth to them at different times. 
 Wisconsin Electric Power is one of the utilities with a new approach to pricing power. The company usually has no trouble meeting demand when temperatures rise in the summer. But during the second week of May, usually the slack season for power use, between the winter and summer peaks, the utility had closed many generating stations for maintenance.
So when the temperature in Milwaukee hit an unseasonable 90 degrees, Wisconsin Electric saw a power shortage looming. One possibility was buying electricity from another company on the open market, but because other utilities were also caught short, that would have cost 10 to 20 times the usual price.
Instead, the utility called one of its biggest customers, the Cleveland Cliffs iron ore mine, in Michigan's Upper Peninsula. How would the mine feel, dispatchers asked, about taking the afternoon off -- and being paid for it?
At first the answer was no. But then plant managers looked at the pile of crushed ore coming out of the milling machines, and realized that if the machines shut down for the rest of the day, no shipments would be delayed. After some quick negotiations, a deal was struck: Wisconsin Electric would pay the mine $82,000 to shut down its ore crushers.
"That was a heck of a good deal," said Richard A. Abdoo, the chairman, president and chief executive of Wisconsin Electric. His company would be paying Cleveland Cliffs about 30 cents a kilowatt-hour not to use electricity, or about six times what Wisconsin Electric charges industrial customers for a kilowatt hour. But it was cheaper than buying power on the open market.
Wisconsin has gotten more sophisticated since May, gathering the beeper and fax numbers of 80 of its biggest customers. On hot afternoons, it can alert them to log on to its Web page, where it offers them cash -- the amount varies, much like the price of a restaurant's lobster special -- to reduce consumption at certain hours.
There are no statistics on the number of utilities using new methods to manage energy demand, but more and more companies seem to be doing it. In Connecticut, Northeast Utilities is installing Internet-controlled thermostats in 50 houses, which it can use to bump air-conditioner settings up by 4 degrees when it needs the power, in exchange for a $200 payment to each homeowner for the summer. And around the country, utilities are installing radio-controlled switches on central air-conditioners and swimming pool pumps to turn them off at peak hours.
For years, electricity has been sold under a system that is worthy of the old Soviet Union: a kilowatt-hour has a fixed price, and you can have as much as you want until it runs out; then there isn't any for anybody.
Allan Schurr, vice president of Silicon Energy, which writes software for the Internet-controlled thermostats, compared the traditional system to an airline that keeps a flock of planes by the gate in case a crowd suddenly wants to fly somewhere. "We don't have a reservation system," he said.
Not troubling customers with the fluctuations of price worked fairly well under the old regulated system. A kilowatt-hour, which the utility typically sold for 8 to 10 cents, often cost 2 cents but hardly ever more than 12. Now, electricity is often bought and sold wholesale, with no regulation, and the cost can temporarily soar to $6 a kilowatt-hour. No utility can buy much at that price, resell it at 5 or 10 cents, and still make a profit. Some utilities can pass those costs through and spread them among their customers, but everyone's costs would be much lower if customers had a choice to cut consumption when prices became exorbitant.
The new pricing structure, with rates varying by the hour, will take some getting used to. "A lot of people are going to say, I don't want to face this," said Eric Hirst, a consultant on electric industry reorganization. "But others are going to say, I can make money by cutting consumption here and increasing consumption there."
Pricing by the hour has no impact on energy efficiency -- the amount of work done per kilowatt-hour -- but it does improve reliability, he said, because it will minimize power failures.
Some utilities are reluctant to let customers know they do not have enough power on hand to handle every contingency, preferring to sell as much power as possible and pass along occasionally extraordinary prices.
"Frankly, there are not a lot of production operations that keep a lot of inventory around these days," said William T. McCormick Jr., chairman and chief executive of CMS Energy, the parent of Consumers Power, of Michigan.
And customers can be reluctant.
"We don't like to take a plant up and down if we don't have to," said David L. Gardner, a spokesman for Cleveland Cliffs. But on that day in May, it worked out that a shutdown entailed little waste of manpower. "It was a win-win situation," he said.
Cleveland Cliffs is one of many Wisconsin Electric customers on an "interruptible" contract, which allows the utility to pull the plug in an emergency. But this was not an emergency, just a time when the economics favored rewarding the mine to shut down.
The utility has signed up 81 major customers this spring, with a total demand of 40 megawatts (enough to power 1,000 homes), who are prepared to bid for power interruptions. It hopes to sign up customers using an added 30 megawatts, though it is not yet sure how much of that will be volunteered when it needs relief. But the amount could be a significant fraction of demand on a bad day. Last year, the maximum amount of power required simultaneously by all its customers reached 5,975 megawatts.
In a blunt, low-tech way, utilities have tried for years to cut peaks in demand for power, which they call peak load. Potomac Electric Power, which serves the District of Columbia and some Maryland suburbs, has persuaded about a third of its 600,000 residential customers to join a "kilowatchers club." In exchange for a monthly credit of $9 on their bill, the utility has installed a second electric meter for their air-conditioners. It can shut off the air-conditioners by radio control for 13 minutes every half-hour. Some customers, in exchange for a $22 monthly payment, have meters that can shut off their air-conditioners altogether. Last year, demand for Potomac Electric's power peaked at 5,927 megawatts, but the kilowatchers can shave 271 megawatts if necessary. Potomac Electric typically uses the radio control 5 to 10 days a year.
Northeast Utilities, in Connecticut, also reduces demand for its electricity for air-conditioning, but in a more sophisticated way.
At the end of June, David and Elizabeth Yu, of Unionville, Conn., accepted a $50 payment from their utility, Northeast Utilities, to let Northeast replace the thermostat that runs their air-conditioner.
Central air-conditioners in houses like the Yus' -- a 16-year-old, four-bedroom Cape -- draw about 3 kilowatts; raising the thermostat 4 degrees cuts the number of minutes they run each hour by about 30 percent, said Michael W. Townsley, a Northeast manager who oversees conservation. If the family had the thermostat set at 74, for example, the utility could reset it to 78.
Most of the year, the power saved costs only a few cents an hour. But now that Northeast buys its electricity on the open market at peak hours, the price can change fast. Hence the value of fiddling with the Yus' thermostat from a central office.
"When supply and demand are very tight, you're going to see tremendous swings," Mr. Townsley said. "In the morning the price might be down around 2 cents, later, $1 a kilowatt-hour. What that says is, there are some potential economic opportunities there."
Many companies are marketing radio-controlled switches that will turn off an air-conditioner or a pool pump. But the thermostat, developed with the Carrier Corporation, has a more subtle impact on the household.
The Yus' new thermostat calls in four times a day for instructions. If the family lets the utility control the temperature, Northeast will pay them another $150 on Oct. 1. But if Mrs. Yu finds the house uncomfortably warm, she can override the setting. Each time she does so, though, Northeast will deduct $15 from that bounty.
"The financial incentive is not that much," Mr. Yu said. "It'll just get absorbed into the budget." But, being a gadget-lover, he is attracted by the device itself.
Mr. Yu is at work during the hours that Northeast is most likely to adjust their thermostat. But Mrs. Yu, who is at home with the couple's three children, said, "It'll be interesting to see how it changes our lives during the peak hours."
Like all utilities, Northeast already has precise historical data on how much power customers will demand at any given level of temperature and humidity; now it wants to know what that demand curve looks like when price is a factor.
"Our interest is primarily reliability, when supply and demand tend to be outside of equilibrium," Mr. Townsley said. "But that's also at the time when the economics come in."

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 816 words

HEADLINE: TODAY: TAXES -- CAMPAIGN 2000;
Channeling the Revenue River

 BODY:
If there is anything as inevitable as death and taxes, it is the fact that the presidential candidates will be debating tax policy. Certainly the differing proposals by both Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore to cut taxes will keep the issue before the voters. Later in the campaign, we will be looking at the details of their plans. But at this early stage, we feel it would be useful to define some broad principles that ought to govern the choice of potential tax cuts. The threshold question that needs to be asked is whether tax cuts of any kind are the best way to bring about economic growth as well as progressive policy goals like expanded health care.
If there is to be a tax cut, it should make the tax code more simple, fair and progressive. Progres-sivity is a time-honored principle often forgotten in the political debates. But since the beginning of this century, Americans have consistently embraced the principle that calls for the wealthy to pay proportionately larger shares of their income in taxes. The tax system became less progressive after the tax cuts of President Ronald Reagan and more progressive after tax increases under Presidents George Bush and Bill Clinton. The latest Treasury estimate is that the top fifth of American families accounts for 56.7 percent of American family income but 65.1 percent of total federal tax revenues. The top 1 percent accounts for 14.8 percent of total income and 20.1 percent of tax revenues. These rates do not make for an excessively progressive tax system. 
 Some argue that higher taxes on the wealthiest taxpayers -- particularly the marginal income tax rate of 39.6 percent and the estate tax -- are destructive of the incentive to create more wealth. But raising the highest income tax rates on the wealthiest families in 1993 did not deter them from increasing their wealth throughout the decade.
Beyond the importance of progressivity, fairness dictates that taxpayers in similar categories be treated equally. But this principle can be difficult to put into practice. Many in Congress argue that it is unfair for a married couple earning the same income and filing a joint return to pay more in taxes than an unmarried couple filing separately. This bipartisan group wants to eliminate the so-called "marriage penalty." Doing so, however, would lower taxes on families with higher incomes.
The tax code is filled with quandaries like this one. A certain amount of inequity is inevitable in the tax code. Two families with the same income, living across the street from each other, might pay dramatically different amounts of taxes depending on which took advantage of tax breaks for health care, child care, education or tax-free investments. A major step toward simplicity was taken in 1986, when several layers of credits, deductions and loopholes for special interests were stripped out of the tax code so that all taxpayers could enjoy somewhat lower rates.
In the years since then, however, many more tax breaks have been introduced. Faced with a Republican Congress, President Clinton has been a master at expanding the role of the federal government, not by spending programs but by tax credits for child care, education and other activities. Now both Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush have moved in the direction of more tax breaks. The Texas governor calls for new tax credits for long-term health care, education, health insurance, charitable giving and adoptions. Mr. Gore proposes tax credits for health insurance premiums, after-school care, college tuition and retirement savings. All these proposals make the tax code more complex, adding to the billions it already costs taxpayers simply to prepare their forms. Rather than indiscriminately handing out more tax incentives, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush should consider simplifying the code and achieving the lower tax rates they think the voters are demanding in an across-the-board but progressive way.
Tax cuts, in the final analysis, should be tested on whether they eat up too much of the federal surplus, leaving little money for other needs. They must not be weighted toward the wealthy, like the repeal of the federal estate tax that has now passed both houses. They should keep the tax code equitable and be set up in a way that the working poor can use to their advantage.
The logic for large tax cuts is that the surplus "belongs" to American taxpayers and should be returned to them before being used for more federal spending. What that formulation leaves out is that the federal debt also belongs to the taxpayers, and so does the obligation to think about huge future costs, including the retirement security of the current work force. Assuring that the next generation will have the education and skills to keep the economy growing, and a clean environment to live in, is also an obligation that belongs to the taxpayers.

HEADLINE: Stricken Camden Is to Become a Ward of the State

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J., July 13

 BODY:
The sewers are backed up at Seventh and Elm Streets again, and pools of scummy liquid are collecting in the collapsing gutters and rutted street in front of the Bible Tabernacle Church.
It stinks. 
 The Rev. Heyward Wiggins of Bible Tabernacle is there, talking about his hopes for his stricken city, now that the state has given up on Camden's local government and is set to begin the first city takeover in the state's history, amounting to the imposition of a benign but absolute dictator. It is also to be the biggest city takeover in the country since the Great Depression.
"If you ask people what they want, they would say they want Camden to be comfortable to live in again," Mr. Wiggins says. "They would say they just want to sit on their front porch without someone harassing them or sneaking in the back door. They want the streets cleaned and the sewers fixed. They don't want big things. They want little things."
But delivering services, little or big, is just what Camden's city government has been unable to do. Done in by government corruption, poverty and the flight of manufacturing industries, it has been functionally bankrupt for more than a decade, kept afloat with cash from Trenton, which now pays for 70 percent of the municipal and public school budget. In this city across the Delaware River from the chiseled, historic skyline of Philadelphia, not one residential street has been repaved for years, and 16 percent of the buildings are abandoned. The high school dropout rate is 50, 70 or 80 percent, depending on whom you ask, and the infant mortality rate (27 deaths per 1,000 births in 1996) is three times that of the suburbs whose borders lie less than a mile from where Mr. Wiggins stood.
More than 200 open-air drug bazaars are in operation, but there are only 80 city police officers on duty at one time. In March, Milton Milan became the third Camden mayor in 20 years to be indicted on corruption charges.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman toured Camden in 1996 and looked around in despair. "I thought to myself, 'There's no way you can raise a child here,' " she said at the time.
So this week, Mrs. Whitman handed the Legislature her Municipal Rehabilitation and Economic Revitalization Act, which would strip power from the mayor, City Council and regulatory and licensing agencies in Camden and put it all in the hands of one person, a chief management officer appointed by the state.
The Legislature is out of session now, but is expected to pass the bill with minor changes when it reconvenes in the fall.
The manager would have the power to break contracts, ignore Civil Service rules in hiring and firing, issue or revoke licenses and direct all appointments and spending decisions. The manager's only obligation to the public would be to consult with a state-selected board of local citizens and to hold two public hearings a year.
The reason, said Ulrich H. (Al) Steinberg, director of the division of local government services, is that Camden's city government has simply ceased to function.
"It's like quicksand," Mr. Steinberg said in an interview. "You look in the books for something and you find there's no solid footing. There is paper and there are words, but they are empty. There's no basis for what they say." These days, state agencies bypass the city government and deal directly with a shadow government of nonprofit social and housing groups to bring everything from new housing to day care to health care to Camden's 85,000 residents.
There have been three other takeovers of bankrupt cities and incompetent or corrupt city administrations in recent years, but Camden's is the biggest of them all. Michigan took over the tiny Detroit suburb of Ecorse in 1986; Massachusetts took over the Boston suburb of Chelsea, population 35,000, in 1992; and Illinois has been operating East St. Louis, population 39,000, since 1994.
Chelsea's takeover resulted in a revamped city charter and was an unqualified success. The results in East St. Louis and Ecorse are mixed. The cities are still struggling.
Harry Spence, until recently the vice chancellor for operations of the New York City public schools, was the receiver, or manager, for Chelsea for three years. New Jersey officials have consulted extensively with him. In an interview, he said that when things were as bad as they were in Camden, a takeover was the only way to go.
"Piecemeal intervention is not enough to draw the necessary confidence either from the citizens themselves or from outsiders to come in and invest in new development," Mr. Spence said.
"When you leave the government structures in place, you allow the existing cadre of elected officials and their cohorts to take up all the space, to maintain a continued sham of democratic process," he added. "You have got to break open space for new people to enter, because at this time the chances of any rational member of the Camden population, for a hero to step in, are so slim that they not going to happen."
But Camden is mostly black and Hispanic. The idea of a white governor like Mrs. Whitman and a Republican administration in Trenton abolishing self-government in a mostly minority city resonates in threatening ways among city leaders. This racial disparity confronted state officials with their most delicate task, of alliance building inside the city before they could let the hammer fall.
Gwendolyn A. Faison, president of the Camden City Council and a black woman, practically levitated out of her seat with anger when word came down, during a Council session this week, that the takeover bill had been introduced.
"My father was beaten off the courthouse steps in Clinton, North Carolina, just for asking to register to vote," Mrs. Faison declared. "To register! Do they think we are going to give up the right that my people fought for and died for?"
But it is a measure of Camden's desperation, and of the state's careful cultivation of local allies, that the city's grass-roots leaders, including black leaders, think exactly that.
Camden is home to some of the most bumptious Democrats in the state -- it was the cradle of former Gov. Jim Florio's career as a political fighter -- but years of preparation by the Whitman administration have won over the core of the city's civic leadership, minority and Democratic as it is, to the idea of a state takeover.
On June 13, two major church groups, Camden Churches Organized for People, a mixed group of Roman Catholic Hispanic and black congregations, and the all-black Concerned Black Clergy, filled St. Joseph's Pro-Cathedral on Federal Street with 1,500 residents to invite the state to take over their city.
In exchange for the support, the state agreed to a manifesto presented by the church leaders that describes the city's ills and lists timetables for solutions: demolishing 362 condemned buildings within one year; shutting down 200 drug markets within three years; and creating a timetable for raising the graduation rate from Camden high schools to 70 percent, among other things.
Sean Closkey, the head of St. Joseph's Carpenter Society, which rehabilitates houses for low income owners, said it would be a mistake if other New Jerseyans, who enjoy a booming economy and never need to creep through Camden's blighted streets, think people here are not aware of the magnitude of their choice.
"You lost the ZIP code lottery and now your chances of dying are three times higher because you were born here," Mr. Closkey said. "That's when you start to wonder when the principles of democracy are trumped by questions of social justice. If we are given the right to rule without the tools, is that democracy? People here are asking those questions. They may not be asking them in Summit or Short Hills, but they are here."
Many members of the nonprofit church groups that already act as a kind of surrogate government will presumably fill out the 15-member advisory board the new city manager is required to create and consult. This reliance on religious leaders riles those in the City Hall faction who are losing their power.
"It's a church-run coup d'etat," said Luis Pastoriza, the Camden municipal clerk. "We're going to have a faith-based government, like the ayatollahs." Mr. Pastoriza stands to lose his municipal job as a result of the takeover.
The Rev. James E. Fitten, president of Concerned Black Clergy, has watched the political power of Camden's black community shrink, first with the election of the city's first Hispanic mayor in Mr. Milan, and now at the prospect of a state takeover. He lives in an ornate, lovingly restored 19th-century brick row house on Chambers Avenue, just down from Cooper Hospital. Yet half of the houses on his block, including one adjoining his, are boarded up, and the quaint cobblestone street is an obstacle course. He faces the issues behind the takeover every day, he said.
"I understand all of the arguments," Mr. Fitten said. "But we need people in government who are competent and truthful, and who have the proper skills to guide the community. They're going to have my neck for saying it, but I just don't see those things in this city right now."
For all the disagreements between City Hall and the takeover proponents, there is no disagreement about what Camden needs. Church people, City Hall leaders and state officials say that Camden's problem can only be solved by market-driven solutions, principally by attracting middle-class residents and the businesses that cater to them.
"I don't think that Camden ought to be a warehouse of the poor," said Msgr. Robert McDermott of St. Joseph's. "I think Camden ought to have its share of middle-class people, people who can afford to pay taxes, who would make the school system better, and who would render certain parts of the city better places to live."
Mr. Steinberg, the state's takeover specialist, looks at Philadelphia's cityscape rising spellbindingly across the Delaware from Camden's nearly empty riverfront and wonders why no on has discovered it as a place for investment yet. Back on Seventh Street, in front of Mr. Wiggins's Bible Tabernacle, Benny Lopez, recently of Brooklyn, was thinking along the same lines.
"They've got to make this place pretty," Mr. Lopez said. "With a better environment, you get better people, and with better people, you get more businesses. Like New York."

HEADLINE: In Harlem, Loans Without the Sharks

BYLINE: By JUAN FORERO 

 BODY:
In his 16 years of business in West Harlem, Dario Pichardo has run a restaurant, a car service and a beauty salon. And when he has needed money to keep his businesses afloat, Mr. Pichardo said, he has not hesitated to go to loan sharks, despite sky-high interest rates and the implied threat of violence for unpaid debts.
"You have to get loans where you can, personal loans, and that can be expensive," said Mr. Pichardo, 46. He explained that he has little alternative since banks have regularly denied his loan applications. "It's a painful method for getting money. For a small businessman, it can hurt him quite a bit and drain from the few benefits that he has." 
 Now, Mr. Pichardo, a Dominican immigrant, is thinking about a loan for his latest venture, Anoranza D'29 Restaurant on Amsterdam Avenue, which opened in September. Although his place is crowded at lunch hour with diners hungry for sancocho stews, garlicky chicken and other Dominican dishes, Mr. Pichardo said he needs $5,000 to replace the water-stained drop ceilings, the chipped floor tiles and the cheap-looking Formica tables. And he wants to add some classy touches, like a bar and a brass banister.
But this time, Mr. Pichardo said, he hopes he will get help from a Washington Heights credit union that is scheduled to open a second branch today at 1631 Amsterdam Avenue near 141st Street, between Cabrini Car Service and a Blimpie outlet.
The financial institution, Neighborhood Trust Federal Credit Union, is one of the more successful of the 30 community-based credit unions in New York City. Since it opened in 1997, it has accumulated $5 million in assets, about double the amount of the deposits in most neighborhood credit unions. Based in a former bank on Fort Washington Avenue and 178th Street, the credit union has provided services to residents who once kept their money under mattresses and went to loan sharks when they needed money.
The 3,000 members of Neighborhood Trust can open no-fee checking accounts with a minimum of $100. They can apply for low-interest loans for amounts from $500 to $10,000 to expand tiny businesses like home-run day care centers and beauty parlors. Neighborhood Trust even employs a full-time teacher who runs free classes for neighborhood residents interested in learning how to keep a budget, how to understand the mysteries of credit or how to run a small business.
"I think they've done a lot of things right; there are a lot of things to emulate," said Clifford Rosenthal, director of the National Federation of Community Development Credit Unions, a nonprofit organization that provides management support to credit unions.
Mark D. Levine, who runs Neighborhood Trust, said expanding into West Harlem made perfect sense because of the area's dire need for financial services. The median family income in the neighborhood is $12,849, and an estimated 51 percent of adults do not have a banking account, according to Neighborhood Trust's business plan.
"There are only two bank branches for over 75,000 people," said Mr. Levine, 31, a Maryland native who taught at a public school in the Bronx before starting Neighborhood Trust with other former teachers and community leaders. "And so in has come an entire industry of check-cashing stores and pawn shops and loan sharks that are, in a sense, filling the gap but doing it in very exploitative ways."
Like many people in low-income neighborhoods across the city, large numbers of residents of West Harlem have never dealt with a bank. Many have shunned banks because the costs are too high; banks typically charge monthly fees on checking accounts if the balance falls below $3,000. Others do not have enough identification to open accounts or feel alienated by banks.
The Rev. Ronnie L. Faison, pastor of Traveler's Rest Baptist Church on Amsterdam Avenue, said many of his parishioners have been eagerly awaiting the credit union since officials from Neighborhood Trust told them weeks ago that the new branch would be coming to their area.
"Most people go out of the area for financial services, or they have their own little setups, home safety vaults," explained Mr. Faison. "It means a great deal to have something like this right here."
Ramon Murphy, co-owner of Natali Supermarket on West 143rd Street and president of the 2,000-member Deli Grocery Store Owners Association, said the absence of established financial institutions and the inability of small business owners to secure loans has led many to turn to loan sharks, or "prestamistas," as they are known to Dominican shop owners.
The loan sharks, he said, charge exorbitant weekly interest rates that can turn a $5,000 loan into a $20,000 payback. And it is not unheard of, he said, for a small business owner to lose his shop to a loan shark because he cannot make the payments.
"The service we need is a bank that integrates itself into the community, so the small businesses can borrow," said Mr. Murphy, who owns two bodegas with Arsenio Mendoza. Both have strongly supported the arrival of Neighborhood Trust.
Milton Balcacer, a businessman who lives in Washington Heights, knows the pitfalls of counting on prestamistas.
Before joining Neighborhood Trust two years ago, Mr. Balcacer said, he never kept track of earnings, expenditures or inventory for his store, Milton Variety, on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx. He also turned to loan sharks when he needed $14,000, a move that cost him $28,000 by the time he repaid the initial loan and the interest.
Now, Mr. Balcacer said, he is running his business smoothly. He completed a course for entrepreneurs run by Neighborhood Trust and learned how to keep his books in order and watch the bottom line. Recently, he received a $3,500 loan, which he is repaying in 18 months at 8 percent interest.
"I'm running a better-organized business," he said. "I'm progressing. Before, I would throw my money in my pocket and never keep track. Now, what little I make from sales, I put my earnings in the bank."

HEADLINE: In America;
Global Cooling

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
So what can we do about global warming?
First, keep in mind the goal, which is to bring the potentially catastrophic warming under control by curtailing the release of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases into the atmosphere. 
 Ordinary people can help immediately by becoming more energy efficient. Stop using the familiar incandescent light bulbs and replace them with compact fluorescent bulbs, which last much longer and use only a quarter of the energy consumed by conventional bulbs.
Compact fluorescent bulbs are significantly more expensive, but because they last so long (up to 10 times the life of a standard bulb) and use so little electricity, they are substantially cheaper in the long run.
Next, when shopping for an appliance -- a refrigerator, a dishwasher, an air-conditioner -- select the one with the highest energy efficiency rating. There will be a sticker on the appliance, telling you how much energy it uses. Pay attention. There can be a difference of 30 percent to 40 percent or more in the amount of energy consumed by appliances with comparable features.
Even more important is the choice you make in the car or truck you buy. Motor vehicles are responsible for about a third of the carbon dioxide emissions in the United States. The vehicles that are the most fuel efficient emit the least carbon dioxide. (Fuel economy and carbon dioxide emissions are inversely proportional. If you double fuel economy, you cut carbon dioxide emissions in half.)
According to the research and advocacy group Environmental Defense, if you buy a new car that gets 10 more miles per gallon than your old car, the amount of carbon dioxide reduction realized in one year will be about 2,500 pounds.
So buying a car or truck that suits your needs and is fuel efficient is a big help.
Honda and Toyota are bringing so-called hybrid vehicles onto the market in the U.S. Hybrids are cars that combine an internal combustion engine and a battery-powered electric motor. They are mid-sized cars that are achieving twice the fuel economy of conventional cars.
Dr. Paul Epstein, associate director of the Center for Health and the Global Environment at Harvard Medical School, summed the matter up as follows: "The issue is not so much what we are doing, but how we power what we are doing. That's the first step."
Over the long term, the requirements are far more ambitious. Ideally, over the course of the next 100 or so years, a transformation will take place and most energy will end up coming not from fossil fuels like coal and oil, but from clean energy sources -- the sun, the wind, hydrogen and non-polluting fuel cells.
"To get there at a cost that's affordable will require substantial technological development," said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, the chief scientist of Environmental Defense.
To move from our pollution-choked present to a future in which climate change is not a mortal threat will take more than that all-important first step of an enlightened citizenry buying cleaner cars and more efficient appliances. Tough action by Congress and the president is needed, and soon. And international cooperation, with enforceable agreements covering both industrialized and, ultimately, developing nations, will be crucial.
Among other things, the federal government can offer subsidies and other incentives to reduce the cost and foster the use of existing clean-energy technology, and to encourage the development of ever more efficient new technologies. And the government can -- and should -- develop more sophisticated strategies like emissions trading and more stringent requirements for reducing carbon dioxide emissions everywhere.
Global warming is the most serious problem we face in the 21st century. Last week an intensive analysis by a respected geologist at Texas A&M University suggested -- as most scientists have been saying for some time now -- that human activity, not natural factors, is the primary cause of the warming.
We caused the problem and we have within our grasp a variety of potential solutions. To ignore those solutions, to be aware of them but not make use of them, is not just profoundly destructive, it's suicidal.

LENGTH: 448 words

HEADLINE: War Without End in Sri Lanka

 BODY:
Few ethnic conflicts in the world are more savage than the war in Sri Lanka, an island nation off the southern tip of India. Since 1983, more than 60,000 people have died, many times the number killed in Northern Ireland. The fighting has so resisted outside efforts to mediate that Michael Ondaatje, in his powerful new novel "Anil's Ghost," refers to it as "a Hundred Years' War with modern weaponry." Since the spring, the war has heated up again with an anti-government offensive by separatist Tamils in Sri Lanka's north. But there has also been a positive development. The United States, India and other countries are increasingly united in trying to bring an end to the fighting.
In the 1970's, Sri Lanka was often hailed as a model of stability, democracy and economic progress in the third world. But for many decades, Sri Lanka's Tamil minority bristled under discriminatory policies of the government in Colombo, which is dominated by the ethnic Sinhalese majority. With covert help from India in the 1980's, a Tamil insurgency seeking independence in the north and east made extensive military gains. India came to its senses and kicked the Tamil rebels off Indian soil and sent its own troops to Sri Lanka. The troops were later withdrawn, but Tamil rebels retaliated by murdering former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in 1991. 
 The northern city of Jaffna, once captured by the rebels, is controlled again by the government, but in the last two months 30,000 government troops have been besieged by the new Tamil offensive. The obvious way to stop the fighting would be to establish some sort of federation on Sri Lanka, with autonomy for Tamil areas. The government has accepted the idea but not gone far enough in its devolution proposals. Tamil rebels cling to their goal of independence. Moreover, the main rebel group, known as the Tigers, has killed off and wiped out rival moderate groups.
A mediation attempt by Norway made some progress earlier this year, but the offensive by the Tigers has put the possibility of talks on hold. One good sign is that President Chandrika Kumaratunga of Sri Lanka has been working with the main opposition party to agree on a set of new Tamil autonomy proposals. These need to be fleshed out, but the unity attempt is a step forward.
It may not be possible to restart the negotiating process until it is clear who will control Jaffna and the surrounding peninsula in the north. But all sides should recognize that there can be no military solution to Sri Lanka's troubles. The terror, assassinations and army clashes have gone on so long that, as Mr. Ondaatje writes, the original reasons have been all but forgotten. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Acquisitions Occur At Several Agencies

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOT 

 BODY:
Several agencies are making acquisitions for undisclosed terms.
The McCann-Erickson World Group in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, bought two agencies. One is Adair-Greene Inc. in Atlanta, which specializes in health care advertising. Adair-Greene, with 150 employees and billings estimated at more than $140 million from clients like Boehringer Ingelheim, will operate as an autonomous unit of Torre Lazur McCann Health Care Worldwide, the health care advertising division of the McCann World Group. 
 The other McCann World Group acquisition is Diamond Promotions in New York, a promotion agency with revenue of about $2 million from clients like American Express and Gateway. Diamond will be merged into the New York office of Momentum Worldwide, the event marketing and sales promotion division of the McCann World Group.
Edelman Worldwide in New York is buying Callahan Creative in New York, which has billings estimated at $6 million for clients like PBS and Ann Taylor. Sarah Callahan, 31, will continue as president and creative director at Callahan, which will be renamed Blue Worldwide.
And Maxxcom Inc. in Toronto, part of the MDC Communications Corporation, acquired a majority stake in TargetCom in Chicago, an agency specializing in direct marketing and relationship marketing, and two TargetCom units: Bangzoom in London and San Francisco and Etelligence in Chicago and St. Louis.
The three TargetCom agencies have about 60 employees and estimated capitalized billings of $100 million from clients like Bally, The Chicago Tribune, Lucent and 3Com. Management will remain unchanged, including Jay Miller, chief executive at TargetCom.

HEADLINE: Summing Up: Is Our House Divided by Race?;
Jews and Race

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "How Race Is Lived in America": 
 The Jewish Council for Public Affairs, a network of national and local Jewish public affairs organizations, has just completed a two-year study of race and public policy based on the views of scholars, public officials and community activists who offered a range of ideological and political viewpoints.
These are among its findings: Jews largely support affirmative action that considers race among many factors. Also needed are effective antipoverty programs, true justice in the courts and quality public education. At the local level, members of the Jewish community are taking part in interracial socialaction coalitions engaged in projects that foster literacy, youth mentoring, low-and moderate-income housing, and economic development. What we learn from Judaism and Jewish history impels us to work to build a just society. Our vision is of a country that is inclusive and open, ensuring equal rights and opportunity for all.
 
LEONARD A. COLE
Chairman, Jewish Council
for Public Affairs
New York, July 7, 2000
