HEADLINE: Wowing Them With Excess in the Hamptons

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 16

 BODY:
To take the temperature of excess in the Hamptons this summer, join Jay Lieberman in the shower of the 12,000-square-foot house that he hopes to sell for $8 million, preferably to someone who will pay cash.
Mr. Lieberman, a builder, has taken a seat in the shower stall of the "his" bathroom in the master bedroom. He proudly points to a shower head that is 10 inches in diameter and is capable of caressing the human body with 22 gallons of water per minute (about nine times the maximum flow allowed in New York State, but unlikely to result in any legal woes). That super-size spritzer costs $800. But it is merely an appetizer for what awaits across the hall in what Mr. Lieberman calls "the last word in bathrooms." 
 The "hers" bathroom has a skylight, radiant heat in the floors, wiring for satellite television. Like the "his" bath, the showpiece here is in the shower: an all-exposed, hand-machined, hand-polished, nickel-plated, thermostatic mixer with overhead shower and hand sprayer on a cradle. It costs $3,000.
"There isn't anything in this house that I did not pull out all the stops for," Mr. Lieberman boasts. "Whoever takes this house will be a client with a lot of money who walks in and says, 'Wow!' "
Based on the frenzied pace of speculative construction here this summer and the frazzled lives of workers doing the building, the Hamptons have never before been invaded by so many rich people wanting to be wowed and demanding that it happen fast.
The invasion has driven construction costs to record levels, seduced builders, architects and even carpenters to build houses on "spec," choked roads with commuting workers and encouraged subcontractors to insist on bonuses merely for showing up on time. It also has enriched and exhausted nearly everyone willing to drive a nail, paint a wall or dig a swimming pool.
Mr. Lieberman's house ranks among the most expensive ever built in the Hamptons without a contracted buyer. Part of the reason it is so expensive is what goes on in its 9 1/2 bathrooms. Each bath, excepting the maid's, has faucets imported from England that cost an average of $2,000 each. The company that made them, Barber Wilsons & Company Ltd., does faucets for the Queen of England and for Steven Spielberg.
"You can't price yourself out of this market," said Carmine Cornacchio, owner of Cornacchio Electric here in Southampton. He and his crew of 20 electricians specialize in custom wiring for houses selling for $2 million to $3 million. Such houses, Mr. Cornacchio said, usually include high-tech devices that, for example, allow an owner stuck in traffic on the Long Island Expressway to turn on the hot tub with a cell phone.
Echoing the sentiments of many architects, builders and subcontractors in the Hamptons, Mr. Cornacchio said that this year it has become all but impossible to put off mansion-hungry clients by charging outrageous prices.
Several subcontractors said they are making record profits, and a few have used the windfall to buy big-ticket toys, like airplanes. But they also said it would be bad business to talk publicly about their new wealth. Steven Gaines, who lives in the Hamptons and whose best-selling book "Philistines at the Hedgerow" (Little Brown, 1998) chronicles the hijinks of rich residents, said his plumber now owns a plane. Mr. Gaines said, however, that disclosing the plumber's name would mean that he would have to find somebody else to fix his toilet.
John Tortorella builds swimming pools for the rich and famous in the Hamptons. His clients have included Billy Joel, Peter Jennings and Kathleen Turner. This year, he said, has been the busiest and most lucrative of his 19 years in the swimming-pool trade. But he said overwork is making him question the meaning of success.
He is exhausted, his employees are exhausted, and still the orders for bigger, more costly and more complicated swimming pools keep rolling in. Five years ago, he said, a $200,000 pool was considered "pretty huge." Now, his company, J. Tortorella Swimming Pools, is rushing to complete five pools, the cheapest of which will cost $1.5 million.
"Now we are talking 'backyard concepts,' with a pool, a spa, a pergola, a stone bridge, wrought iron gates," said Mr. Tortorella, who has begun to design his biggest pools along historical themes like the lost island of Atlantis, ancient Egypt and Stonehenge.
"Everybody used to talk about the go-go 80's like they were so wonderful," he said. "Well, the 80's were like child's play. It is ridiculous now. The amount of time and stress that my people have had to put up with is inhuman."
The minting of millionaires in Manhattan is far outpacing the supply of skilled labor and good property in the Hamptons, according to local government officials on the East End of Long Island.
As the number of prime lots dwindles, the chief building inspectors in the towns of Southampton and East Hampton said, million-dollar houses are being built near town dumps and on misshapen or poorly drained parcels of land.
"People are building on properties now that they wouldn't have even looked at 10 years ago," said Don Sharkey, the chief building inspector for the Town of East Hampton. "In a couple of years, we are going to run out of buildable parcels."
The shortage of land, combined with local moratoriums on some kinds of subdivisions and the possibility of far more restrictive development rules in the near future, have helped push home prices this year to levels that stun veteran real estate agents.
"We have seen the biggest-ever across-the-board quarterly jump in home prices in the Hamptons," said Diane Saatchi, president of Dayton-Halstead Real Estate, which publishes a quarterly report on home prices in seven markets in the Hamptons. Figures for the first quarter of 2000 came out last week.
They show that in the Village of East Hampton, summer home to the likes of Mr. Spielberg and Martha Stewart, the average price of houses has jumped in the last three years to $2.1 million from $1.2 million. More than two-thirds of that increase occurred during the first quarter of this year, according to the report.
Ms. Saatchi, voicing an opinion shared by many builders and architects, speculates that the boom is fueled by continued strength in the stock market and by aging baby boomers in Manhattan who find themselves with buckets of excess money.
"They have gotten to a point where they are in their prime earning years, their kids are through college, and they need houses that are big enough to accommodate several generations and kids from multiple marriages," said Ms. Saatchi, who has been selling real estate in the Hamptons for 14 years.
Whatever their reasons, buyers are spreading so much money so fast that the craftsmen in the Hamptons are at risk of drowning in a flood of trickle-down economics. The unemployment rate in Southampton hit a record low of 2 percent this spring. For skilled labor, New York State employment officials said, the jobless rate in the Hamptons is about zero.
"The East End of Long Island is the tightest skilled-construction market in the United States, without compromise," said Daniel McMillan, regional vice president of Trade Source, a company in Greenwich, Conn., that recruits and places craftsmen in construction jobs around the country. "We have hired a former Navy recruiter to go around the Hamptons and talk to anybody who is wearing work boots and driving a pickup."
With more jobs than workers to fill them, Trade Source two weeks ago began offering a free carpenter's course to recent high school graduates. The first class was convened in an office building in the Suffolk County hamlet of Bohemia, about an hour's drive from the Hamptons.
"I figure that if I improve my skills, I can bump my wages from $15 to at least $25 an hour out in the Hamptons," said John Vitale, 23, who showed up for the course. "The money is definitely out there."
To keep pace with demand, a number of Hamptons builders have begun hiring immigrants from Central America to frame houses, shingle roofs and build swimming pools.
"They broke out of the landscaping business about two years ago, and now they are rising through the trades," said Al Tuff, a builder in Bridgehampton who employs recent immigrants and who said his business would shut down without them.
Miguel Velasquez, a Salvadoran immigrant who has been in the United States for six years, earns $23 an hour and works 12 hours a day, seven days a week, for Mr. Tuff, who also employs Mr. Velasquez's two sons, Carlos and Victor, both in their early 20's. They, too, usually work 12 hours a day, seven days a week.
"There is just too much work," Mr. Velasquez said.
Elected officials in the Hamptons are struggling to find ways to slow the pace of development, and a few are conceding that local governments have all but lost the fight.
"For the last decade, we have been building houses at a rate of a house every single day," said Jay Schneiderman, the supervisor in the Town of East Hampton. "We have added probably 20,000 people to our summer population without changing any significant infrastructure. That is creating tremendous stress on the quality of life in this area. It has not been a balanced approach."
Mr. Schneiderman said that town governments, even with millions of dollars to spend on buying up vacant land, are finding it difficult to persuade speculators to sell.
"A builder would rather build a spec house," Mr. Schneiderman said. "He knows that the profit he'll yield will far exceed what he'll make selling us vacant land. That makes it difficult to preserve vacant space."
Mr. Lieberman, builder of the $8 million house with the pricey shower heads, said: "Even I realize that there is a certain amount of property that should be preserved. Things are obviously getting difficult."
Difficult or not, Cindi Crain, a former magazine editor, said she is going ahead with her dream house, which she is planning to build on two acres of land she bought for $1 million in 1998.
Ms. Crain, 31, who has family money (Crain Communications, publisher of Advertising Age and Crain's New York Business), said she has been warned repeatedly by friends about the impossibility of getting a house built on time and within a budget.
She has been forced by soaring design and construction prices to raise her budget for her planned 6,000-square-foot house to about $3.5 million from $1.5 million.
She intends to elude the pain of summer in the Hamptons by sticking to back roads, staying away from overcrowded restaurants and never commuting from Manhattan on Fridays or Sundays.
And why is this worth $3.5 million?
"You really feel the sea out here. You suck in the sea air," Ms. Crain said. "You can still chill out in the Hamptons, if you know what you are doing."

HEADLINE: With New York's Apples in Ruin, Growers Fear for a Way of Life

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

DATELINE: MILTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
Usually, when hail descends on the picturesque apple orchards of the Hudson Valley, it strikes fitfully, wreaking havoc on a farmer's field of Empires, say, but sparing his McIntoshes. But this spring's hail was different.
Two storms pelted newly formed apples with jagged balls of ice on more than 7,000 acres, and as the apples have grown, the tiny bruises have turned into ugly divots. Two thousand of those acres were so badly hurt that farmers are abandoning them entirely this season. In all, some 2.09 million bushels, about a third of the crop, are expected to be lost in what farmers say is the worst crop damage in memory. 
 "The wind was so strong that it drove the hail into the apples like bullets," said Jeffrey D. Crist, a fourth-generation apple grower who said he had no choice but to let the deformed apples in his orchard here drop to the ground this fall.
In earlier times, apple farmers would curse Mother Nature and hope for better luck next year. But a number of economic forces -- from depressed prices resulting from a worldwide glut of apples to spotty insurance coverage to demands for flawless fruit -- have pushed the Hudson Valley farmers to the brink. Many are wondering aloud whether the 10-minute hail bursts in May and June will be the straws that finally break them -- and in the process alter an austere landscape of gnarled trees and open sky forever.
Indeed, as the apple growers band together to ask the federal government for direct cash assistance of $20 million to cover their losses, they are talking as much about open space and suburban sprawl as about agriculture, speaking a language that resonates with politicians, tourists and the many owners of weekend houses here in Ulster County, the second largest apple-producing county in a state that is second only to Washington in apple production.
A dozen or so farmers met this month with Representative Benjamin A. Gilman in an orchard in Orange County south of Milton, a hamlet just west of the Hudson about 70 miles north of Midtown Manhattan. The growers evoked a potential consequence of their financial crisis in apple-producing counties like Ulster, Orange, Columbia and Dutchess, where a wave of new building has swept through in the last decade.
"Do we just go home and call our Realtor or do we hang in there?" Roderick Dressel of Dressel Farms in New Paltz asked on a crisp, breezy day that felt like fall. "We're asking for a one-time Band-Aid to keep our industry going, to preserve open space and to prevent it from all going to traffic and septic tanks."
In 1985, 104 farms covered 11,629 acres in Ulster County. By 1996, the most recent year for which statistics are available, the number of farms had fallen to 63 on 8,632 acres. The decisions now being made by apple growers like Anthony Porpiglia could accelerate the trend. Having lost 60 percent of his apple crop to the May 18 hailstorm in Ulster County, Mr. Porpiglia says he cannot borrow money, even at the low interest rates available to farmers in a declared disaster area. Instead, he is looking to one of his eight orchards to make him whole.
"Our debt load is tremendous, and we don't want to get any deeper," Mr. Porpiglia said. "We have an orchard -- 35 acres in Ulster Park in the middle of a development. We're thinking of selling it. It's a valuable piece of land."
Experts in farming practices say that when more than a third of the apples in an orchard are damaged, it does not pay to harvest the remaining good ones.
"The pickers are paid based on volume and there's really no way to slow a picker down so that he would turn over each piece of fruit and examine it, said Michael J. Fargione, an educator with Cornell Cooperative Extension, a program of Cornell University that provides research information and educational programs to farmers. "Even a small ding is enough to have that fruit rejected by a grocery chain."
Gov. George E. Pataki asked the United States Department of Agriculture on June 18 to declare large sections of the Hudson Valley a disaster area, as well as some two dozen counties across the state where heavy rains damaged a number of other crops. But the federal agency has yet to do so.
Many farmers say they would not be eligible for the low-interest loans available through the disaster program anyway. Farmers must first be turned down by their regular lenders in order to qualify for loans, but banks are more than happy to lend to growers who have ample collateral in the form of valuable land.
In the meantime, farmers who carried hail insurance are having a tough time collecting on their claims. The insurers argue that hail-damaged fruit can still be used for the juice market. But the juice market is so weak that the cost of harvesting the bruised apples would exceed the price paid for the fruit.
"The cider market is $1.20 a bushel and it costs $4 a bushel to pick it," said Russ Bartolotta Jr. of Klein's Kill Fruit Farms in Germantown, N.Y., across the Hudson River in Columbia County. "Economically, you're committing suicide to go in there and try to salvage. You're going to throw good money after bad."
A bushel of apples sold for fresh fruit rather than juice would have brought a farmer $6 in 1995. Today, the same bushel brings $3.50, apple growers say. Farmers say, too, that walking away from an apple orchard for a season does not free them from maintaining it. "You still have to mow and trim the orchards and spray so certain insects and fungus don't get in there," said Mr. Bartolotta, who estimates that 90 percent of the apple crop was ruined on his family's 320 acres of orchards. "There are things you have to keep doing so next year's crop won't be affected."
A few factors have made apple farmers in New York State particularly vulnerable to a setback like hail damage. The apple industry has suffered from depressed prices in recent years, the result of a worldwide overproduction of apples and exports of cheap apple-juice concentrate to the United States from China. In addition, a key export market for the United States -- Southeast Asia -- wilted after the economic crisis there. And the continuing consolidation among retailers has strengthened the hand of stores in demanding lower prices from farmers.
Industry experts say that this year's hail damage should not affect consumer prices because of the general oversupply of apples from across the United States and abroad.
The apple farmers now find themselves in the role of activists, organizing meetings, faxing fact sheets, collaring any politician who will listen. When Representative Gilman, a Republican, came for his tour here, there was a table set up alongside the orchard with the evidence: tree branches from other farms bearing pockmarked fruit. "We're doing things we're not accustomed to doing," said Mr. Crist, who counts 150 of his 600 acres of apples a complete loss.
Legislation is pending in Congress that would provide $115 million to apple farmers nationwide to compensate them for market losses and crop damage from previous years. In June, President Clinton signed the Agricultural Risk Protection Act of 2000, a $15 billion relief package for producers of a variety of crops that will, among other things, reduce the cost of crop insurance. But how much of that money will eventually make its way to the Hudson Valley, where Hurricane Floyd caused damage last fall, is uncertain. And none of the money would offset the losses from this spring's hail.
Steve Clarke, a 55-year-old apple grower whose family farm dates to 1817, knows the global economics of apple production as well as anyone, but he is now focused on his own finances. Still farming alongside his 82-year-old father, Leonard Clarke, and bringing along his 24-year-old son, Brad, Mr. Clarke has 60 acres of useless apples outside his front door here -- half his apple crop.
He says he will have to borrow $50,000 to $60,000 to maintain his orchards, pay his bills and meet his payroll. "We don't have the reserve or cushion to say we're going to take it out of that," Mr. Clarke said. "The business just hasn't been that good the last four years. Ten minutes of hail is going to cost me about three years of my life."
Like other apple farmers in the Hudson Valley, Mr. Clarke is asking for an emergency infusion of cash from the federal government, assistance that Mr. Gilman said he would try to get. In asking for that subsidy, Mr. Clarke is unabashedly tapping fears that open land north of New York City is quickly disappearing to development.
"We're just at the very reaches of commuting from New York City and as Orange County fills up and Dutchess fills up, there are going to be more pressures on the land," he said. "Are people willing to pay to maintain open space? That's something that needs to be debated."

HEADLINE: Books by the Chapter or Verse Arrive on the Internet This Fall

BYLINE: By LISA GUERNSEY 

 BODY:
The Frommer's guide to France may be made up of chapters and maps, but most readers know it as an indivisible and coherent whole: a book.
This fall, that book and a few hundred others will take a new form on the Internet. They will be sold in component parts -- chapters, maps and even paragraphs -- that can be mixed and matched. Readers will be invited to create customized books by picking pieces of content a la carte from an array of already-published guides at, say, $5 a chapter instead of $20 a book. Buyers will have the option of receiving their books electronically or ordering them printed, bound and delivered to their door. 
 The customization is possible because of a deal announced last month between an online service called iUniverse and IDG Books, the publisher of the Dummies guidebooks, Frommer's travel guides and Cliffs Notes. With IDG's permission, iUniverse is creating a digital system that enables pieces of every guidebook to be assembled on the fly.
The partnership is one of the first steps toward a new editorial marketplace that some publishers and technology companies have been envisioning since the dawn of digital media. And it is the latest challenge to the traditional definition of a book. Under this model, books have not only turned into streams of electronic bits that are downloaded to hand-held devices or printed on demand. They have also turned into databases -- pools of digital information that people can extract and combine on their own terms.
"Imagine that you are going on a trip," said Patricia Schroeder, president of the Association of American Publishers and a former member of Congress. "You may want a couple chapters of a travel book, a couple chapters of a cookbook," adding that readers probably do not want to carry each of those books for just a few chapters.
Now imagine going into a bookstore and asking to buy only those chapters. "They are going to look at you," she said, "and say, 'What?' "
On the Internet, that request is not so crazy. "The online world is uniquely suited to providing this kind of highly targeted, highly customized information," said David Sidman, director of new publishing technologies for John Wiley & Sons. Four years ago, Mr. Sidman helped to develop tools that enabled scientific journals to be delivered online, article by article. Today, he said, selling content this way "represents a tremendous new revenue opportunity for publishers of all kinds."
Travel books, textbooks, cookbooks and how-to guides will be some of the first books chopped into interchangeable parts, according to officials at publishing and software companies experimenting with the concept. In fact, some publishers are already offering bits and pieces of content for downloading to hand-held devices like Palm organizers. And although no one is talking about chopping up narrative books, like novels, anthologies of short stories could be distributed this way.
"We're so close we can just smell it," Ms. Schroeder said. "This is all going to be very doable, very soon."
But before pages and chapters will be available for the picking, several issues need to be addressed. For example, turning books into what the industry calls "disaggregated content" could destabilize the economics of publishing, something that most established publishers are loath to do. What happens, they ask, if people stop buying whole books in favor of a few popular chapters?
John Kilcullen, chief executive of IDG Books, does not think that will happen. Although he has not yet set prices for the material that will be available this fall, he said some chapters might be given away as promotional materials and other prices might be set proportionally, so that a 25-page chapter of a 100-page book would cost about 25 percent of the book's list price. Other sections, he added, could cost almost as much as the book itself, particularly if they are in high demand.
Even so, authors might not be thrilled about having their work sold in pieces or packaged with the work of others. Many recent contracts include broad provisions for electronic rights, publishers say, but few mention the possibility of selling pieces for mixing and matching. Some agents and publishers are already gearing up for new negotiations over modular content.
William Gladstone, the founder of Waterside Productions, an agency representing many authors in the series of Dummies books, is encouraging writers to sign contracts that permit publishers to sell content in pieces. He is betting that writers will earn more royalties that way. "I would advise them to be cooperative," he said.
Another hurdle involves technical barriers. If a book is going to be chopped into digital pieces for mixing and matching, those pieces need to be technologically compatible with parts of other books. And to make those pieces searchable across databases, companies will have to establish a standard means to identify the piecemeal content, just as the International Standard Book Number, or ISBN, enables books to be catalogued, tracked and bought quickly.
Until standards are set, publishers are faced with "a rat's nest" of problems, said James Lichtenberg, president of Lightspeed, a consulting company for the educational publishing industry. "You have to have very clear definitions," Mr. Lichtenberg said, "things like 'this means a photograph,' 'this means a map.' "
Most of the progress so far has come from the realm of education and research. College professors, after all, have been mixing chunks of editorial content for decades by assigning "course packs" that are typically compilations of photocopied pages from magazines, anthologies and nonfiction books.
Now, with advances in copyright-protection software and the recent drive to create electronic books, many publishers have embraced the idea of selling individual chapters from multiple academic books.
McGraw-Hill was one of the first to do so; it created a database called Primis that enables professors to choose from 180,000 pages of material spanning 20 disciplines. For example, a professor can build a book that includes "Notes of a Native Son" by James Baldwin and see that the selection adds $1.75 to the cost of the book. Other building blocks cost more, like 83 pages of "The Turn of the Screw," by Henry James, priced at $8.55.
Prices are usually dependent on the popularity of the items and how much McGraw-Hill may have to pay for reprint permissions, said Ginny Moffat, vice president for marketing and custom publishing at McGraw-Hill Higher Education. Features like color pages bump up the costs, too.
Another large textbook company, Taylor & Francis, will soon be offering a database for building books. It announced last week that it had signed a deal with Versaware, a publishing-technology company that has developed its own customization system. The books could be delivered to students over the Internet as files for printing or downloading to hand-held devices, said Harry Fox, Versa ware's chief executive. Or they could be printed and bound nearby, then shipped to the college bookstore.
Manish Chopra, a graduate student at the University of Michigan, is one reader who says he would appreciate the chance to buy books in pieces, rather than whole. He recently visited a Borders bookstore to find "Consulting Demons," a book on corporate consulting by Lewis Pinault. A friend had recommended that he read the early chapters, which dealt with recruiting tactics.
"This book was like $30 hard cover," Mr. Chopra said, "and I was like, I don't know if I want to buy it, because I was only interested in the first four chapters." Instead, he stayed in the bookstore, spent several hours reading the chapters, and put the book back on the shelf.
If he had been given the chance to buy those chapters for a few dollars, he said, he would have done so. "It's always the case that you don't need all the information," Mr. Chopra said. But if you could buy it in pieces, he said, "that would be a great tool."

HEADLINE: Talk of Lower Expectations As Mideast Deadline Nears

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: THURMONT, Md., July 17

 BODY:
As the Camp David summit meeting moved closer to a supposed deadline of President Clinton's Wednesday morning departure for Japan, the White House remained officially committed to reaching "an agreement" before then and talks shifted into high-drive for a crucial 48-hour period.
But some American, Israeli and Palestinian officials today began deliberately lowering expectations for a breakthrough, even suggesting that additional summit meetings may be needed. And the White House left ample room for interpretation in its goal, since "an agreement" could include anything from a more modest declaration of principles to a full-blown accord between the two sides. 
 Although American officials previously said quietly that President Clinton's itinerary could be modified, the White House continued to declare today that he has no intention of delaying his trip to a meeting of the leaders of the leading industrial nations in Okinawa or of sending Vice President Al Gore in his place.
"The plan is to complete the process before the president goes," said his spokesman, Joe Lockhart. Later, Mr. Lockhart added: "You will know we are following the schedule when you see the president walk up the steps of the plane, wave and the door close."
Several Middle East experts, however, including officials on all sides, find it hard to imagine that the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, could modify a well-documented personal history of pushing things to the wire. And in Mr. Arafat's case, that could mean an ultimate deadline not of Wednesday but of Sept. 13, by which he has pledged to declare a state.
Some experts envisioned the leaders taking a break of a couple of weeks before reconvening for a continued summit meeting. But others said that this would be highly risky because it would expose what has been a completely secret, blacked-out negotiation to the leaks, misinformation, disinformation and political pressures of Israel and the Palestinian territories.
"It's feasible to do that, to break off and then return," said a senior Israeli official. "But I'm not sure it's a good idea to let the energy dissipate. The rumors and false assumptions could lead to terrible results."
Yitzhak Herzog, Israel's cabinet secretary, who is in Washington, said: "It's clear that both parties must seize the moment, not only the moment, but literally the day. We should be thinking of Wednesday as a once-in-a-lifetime chance."
Still, the Israelis have been putting out the word that Prime Minister Ehud Barak "is not going to stay forever at Camp David," and expressing frustration that, in their view, Mr. Barak has taken "giant steps" toward Mr. Arafat while the Palestinian leader has remained unyielding.
"The Palestinians are not showing flexibility and are not going the extra mile," said Yuli Tamir, Israel's dovish immigration minister who is serving as an Israeli spokeswoman in Washington. "I think they are pushing Barak to cross his red lines, and I think they are making a mistake. He will not change his mind."
Although Mr. Clinton has professed to be more optimistic than at the start of the summit meeting last Tuesday, Mr. Barak is "more on the pessimistic side," Avraham Burg, Israel's Parliament speaker, told Israel Radio today.
Other Israeli ministers and lawmakers who spoke to the prime minister expressed similar impressions.
The Palestinians, who voiced unusual optimism late last week, today hit a peak of frustration, although it may have been short-lived. One Palestinian official who is not inside Camp David said that the Israelis seemed to be retreating on expected concessions. In talks leading up to the summit meeting the two sides had hammered out understandings on several key issues, understandings that may be reconfiguring themselves in the course of the current talks.
The Palestinians have told the Americans that they do not plan to stay beyond Wednesday, the official said. Indeed, one senior Palestinian negotiator, Abu Mazen, who is the Palestine Liberation Organization's senior official after Mr. Arafat, faces a personal deadline. His son, Tarek, is getting married in Ramallah on Thursday, and the whole Palestinian team is invited and planning to attend.
With Wednesday looming, the pace and intensity of the negotiations have quickened, and the teams worked until about 5 a.m. before breaking and resuming at midday. All three leaders are night owls, known to thrive in the post-midnight hours.
Israeli and Palestinian officials outside the talks say that a kind of high-tension fatigue is setting in. Mr. Lockhart said, "Coming back continually to the same issues with the same people, that kind of environment is not always the best for the warm and fuzzies."
Israel Radio reported tonight that while key differences remain on the thorniest issues of Jerusalem and the right of return of refugees, progress has been made on some relatively minor issues like water and the environment. Side talks are being held at a small college in Emmitsburg.
But an American official there said that the side talks can only get so far without knowing the parameters of a core agreement, and Israeli and Palestinian participants who have longstanding professional relationships have been drafting and re-drafting individual paragraphs about some of those side issues, like civil affairs and economic relations.
Rather than twiddle their thumbs, some Palestinian officials involved in the side talks have opted instead for long afternoons shopping at the Pentagon City mall in Virginia where many are staying, the American official said. (Some have been seeking wedding presents for Tarek Abbas, Abu Mazen's son.)
Mr. Barak summoned a former director general of the foreign ministry from Israel, Reuven Merhak, who is also an expert on Jerusalem. He has been stationed at Emmitsburg since arriving. But Israeli analysts took his arrival as a sign that Mr. Barak wanted to have close by an analyst who has thought through all the solutions for sharing the holy city, including what Mr. Burg referred to recently as "shrinking and expanding" Jerusalem -- annexing Jerusalem suburbs in the West Bank to Israel while relinquishing Palestinian neighborhoods.
The news blackout has held remarkably well through seven days, which most take as a good sign that no one wants to blow up the process. Inside Camp David, though, the delegations have ample access to American newspapers and 60 or 70 television channels, Mr. Lockhart said.

Tycoon Quits Russia Parliament

President Putin arrived in Beijing on the first stop of an Asian tour intended to revive his country's faded diplomatic role in the region and build what could become a Chinese-Russian axis to counter American influence. A11
 
Searching for Survivors in Manila
Rescuers continued to dig through the remains of a mountain of garbage that collapsed in the Philippines last week, smothering hundreds of squatters. About 200 bodies have been recovered. Residents estimate that up to four times that number may have died. A6
 
Assad's Inaugural Speech
Bashar al-Assad delivered his inaugural speech as president of Syria. He focused on repairing his country's ailing economy and gave no sign that he would be any more flexible than his late father in negotiating a peace accord with Israel. President Assad officially began a seven-year term after taking the oath of office. A10
 
Nazi Slave Labor Compensation
The United States and Germany signed an agreement to compensate forced laborers from the Nazi era. German government and industry leaders agreed to contribute equally to a $5 billion fund to compensate the laborers. In exchange, President Clinton pledged that the United States will do what it can to block class-action lawsuits brought against German corporations. A3

Terror Suspect to be Extradited

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 629 words

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton's Credible Response

 BODY:
It is a sour coincidence that Hillary Rodham Clinton should be accused of using anti-Semitic language while negotiations are under way at Camp David that represent the best chance in decades for a comprehensive peace settlement in the Middle East. But in another sense, this juxtaposition of domestic politics and foreign policy provides an opportunity to examine a serious underlying principle. There is no doubt, in our view, that Mrs. Clinton, if elected to the Senate, would be a firm supporter of Israel's security, its aspirations for peace and its economic vitality. We say that without imputing any weakness on these issues to her Republican opponent, Representative Rick Lazio. Our intent is simply to say that this is one of those campaign moments when voters need to look at long-term policy prospects rather than the controversy of the moment.
To be sure, Mrs. Clinton's handling of matters important to New York's Jewish voters has been fraught with controversy since the start of her candidacy to succeed Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a fellow Democrat. But her early gaffes were not as shocking as depicted by detractors who want to see her lose part of a constituency that is essential to any Democrat in a tight statewide race. Mrs. Clinton's 1998 remark that she would favor creation of a Palestinian state is now not far afield from current Israeli and American policies. Both governments are open to establishment of such a state as part of the Camp David negotiations. Her appearance with Yasir Arafat's wife, Suha, last year, while awkward, was nonetheless handled in a way that did not disrupt sensitive negotiations between Israeli and Palestinian leaders. The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, was among those defending Mrs. Clinton. 
 The current complication centers on the report in a new book about the Clintons' marriage, "State of a Union," by Jerry Oppenheimer, that she used an anti-Semitic slur in an argument with the manager of her husband's losing Congressional campaign in 1974. Those not present can never be absolutely certain about what was said at the campaign headquarters that day. But the circumstantial evidence inclines us strongly toward believing Mrs. Clinton when she says she never used such language. The alleged remark took place only a few years after Mrs. Clinton's expansively humanistic commencement speech at Wellesley and soon after she had worked in a sophisticated legal environment for the impeachment of a president, Richard M. Nixon, who did use anti-Semitic language. Mrs. Clinton by her own admission has a volatile temper, but this kind of language seems out of keeping with her philosophy and a well-documented history of public remarks and private political conversations.
The latest Quinnipiac University poll shows Mrs. Clinton getting 54 percent of the Jewish vote to 34 percent for Mr. Lazio. In order to win, she probably has to come close to the 76 percent gained by Senator Charles Schumer in 1998. Her decision to abandon her usual no-comment mode in favor of a passionate, almost teary response to the allegation of anti-Semitic language was a sound one. President Clinton's decision to step into the fray, while understandable as husbandly concern, was probably less helpful to the political task confronting Mrs. Clinton. Her problem extends beyond any single constituency group.
This is going to be a grindingly brutal campaign. From now on, Mrs. Clinton will be under continuous pressure to assert her independence from her husband and to fight her own fights. She also has to explain her policies and reveal her personality to an electorate that does not know her well. In this instance, we think she made a convincing case that she did not use the language ascribed to her.

HEADLINE: INSIDE

 BODY:

Prozac Debate Revived
Two psychiatrists have renewed the debate about Prozac and similar drugs by suggesting that they pose a risk of neurological side effects, with long-term use causing brain damage. SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F1 

Syria's New President
In his inaugural speech, Bashar al-Assad focused on repairing his country's ailing economy and gave no sign that he would be any more flexible than his late father in negotiating peace with Israel. PAGE A10
 
Move Against Putin
Boris Berezovsky, Russian tycoon and politician, said he would leave Parliament and form an alliance of big business and regional politicians to curb President Vladimir V. Putin's growing power. PAGE A10

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Chase's Jersey City Site

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Chase Manhattan Bank will break ground tomorrow in Jersey City for two buildings that will house more than 2,000 of its workers now based in New York City. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Mayor Bret Schundler are among the officials planning to attend.
Chase is to occupy the buildings with 1.2 million square feet, by January 2002, said Michael B. Friedman, a spokesman for the LeFrak Organization, the developer. 
 The bank's headquarters remain on Park Avenue in Manhattan. It has about 20,000 employees at several locations in New York City. Chase has said it could not reject the "overwhelming economic package from the state of New Jersey."

HEADLINE: Trying a New Shoe on for Size;
Can Owners of Skechers Learn From Their Mistakes?

BYLINE: By KRUTI TRIVEDI 

 BODY:
Michael Greenberg, the founder and president of the trendy shoe company Skechers U.S.A., is so determined to put out his company's message that he follows a written outline when he recites a list of recent feats.
Skechers (pronounced SKETCH-ers), he says slowly and deliberately between glances at the crumpled bit of paper in front of him in the company booth last month at the Fashion Footwear Association of New York exposition, is now the third-most-popular brand among teenagers, after Nike and Adidas. Company sales, he adds, jumped 40 percent last quarter compared with a year earlier; and as retailers are becoming choosier about which shoe brands to stock, both Lord & Taylor and Athlete's Foot have just signed on. 
 "If there was a Gap of footwear," Mr. Greenberg, 37, said, "I believe that Skechers would be that company."
Mr. Greenberg's dogged focus shows as much about his ambitions as about his determination to leave behind what many analysts see as a nagging past.
Currently, Skechers U.S.A. Inc., based in Manhattan Beach, Calif., seems to be something of a find. As the shoe business slowly revives from its recent slump, the small, eight-year-old family-run company is leading the charge. Its winning formula is simple: Skechers makes lower-priced versions of popular shoes like the latest high-performance Nikes and dressy loafers by Kenneth Cole. And its stock has been among the market's best performers this year.
That meteoric rise, however, followed a steep decline after Skechers's initial public offering in June 1999 -- a sign, analysts say, of concern that the company has some uncomfortable parallels with the last Greenberg family project, L.A. Gear Inc., one of the retailing industry's most spectacular collapses.
"The Greenbergs are going to have to prove that Skechers is not L.A. Gear," said John Shanley, a senior vice president at Security Van Kaspar who once followed L.A. Gear.
It was Robert Greenberg, Michael Greenberg's father, who founded L.A. Gear and is widely blamed for its implosion. And while Michael Greenberg founded Skechers -- as a distributor for Doc Martens footwear -- and is its public face and spokesman, his father is the company's chairman and chief executive.
The elder Mr. Greenberg sold everything from wigs to roller skates before he stumbled on the idea that would make him famous: a modestly priced hybrid of performance and fashion shoe that women could wear while doing aerobics. L.A. Gear's revenues shot up from $70.6 million in 1987 to $900 million in 1990, making it the third largest in the country, after Nike and Reebok.
But in a path that is almost unheard of for companies that flirt with the billion-dollar mark, L.A. Gear fell apart almost as quickly as it had grown. The stock, which hit a high of $50.125 in 1990, had tumbled to $11 by 1992. The company eventually filed for bankruptcy protection.
Analysts say L.A. Gear expanded too quickly. While the company had been successful with stylish aerobic shoes, by 1991 it was offering customers 500 different styles of shoes and apparel. The expansion was poorly timed, occurring as the strongest growth in the shoe industry was in men's athletic shoes -- a market that L.A. Gear, perceived as a women's and children's shoemaker, never could capture. The result was a retailer's nightmare: crate-loads of inventory in a still-weak economy.
Legal problems also plagued the operation. L.A. Gear signed a marketing deal with Michael Jackson in 1989 in an attempt to win over men; when that strategy failed, the company entered a lengthy breach-of-contract suit-countersuit tussle with Mr. Jackson. Both Nike and Reebok also fought legal battles with L.A. Gear, contending that the company had illegally used their patented technology. All the suits were eventually settled.
Robert Greenberg and five other executives were the subject of five shareholder securities fraud suits filed in 1990 and 1991. The class action suits contended that members of L.A. Gear management had issued public documents containing "materially false and misleading statements" about the company that led to L.A. Gear's stock becoming "artificially inflated," according to the settlement papers. The defendants eventually settled for a total of $29.8 million without admitting or denying guilt.
After losses began to mount and the company's credit line was cut, Robert Greenberg was forced to sell a 30 percent minority stake worth $100 million of preferred stock to Trefoil Capital Investors, an investment fund founded by Roy Disney, nephew of the late Walt Disney, and cede much of his control of the company. The Trefoil team eventually ousted him in January 1992 and dismissed Michael Greenberg, then an L.A. Gear national sales manager, soon after.
Trefoil bailed out in late 1997, after failing to turn the company around. Under PCH Investments, which currently controls the company, L.A. Gear entered and emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1998 a much more modest operation.
Michael Greenberg insists that his family was unfairly disparaged over L.A. Gear's tumble. "We didn't get that company to $900 million by accident," he said. If given the chance, he added, his family could have saved the company.
In response to the inevitable comparisons with L.A. Gear, Skechers officials say their company is closely monitoring its growth, will license rather than make apparel and is just as popular with men as with women.
Michael Greenberg founded Skechers -- street slang meaning frenetic teenagers -- in 1992, just months after leaving L.A. Gear. He convinced his father and David Weinberg, a former L.A. Gear executive whom he describes as a "member of the family," to join his company in October 1993. Three of his brothers are currently vice presidents at Skechers; a fourth manages the Skechers Sport brand of sneakers.
The company's sales grew steadily, as the Greenbergs capitalized on the shoe industry contacts they made in their years at L.A. Gear to make sure that Skechers displays were given prime retail space.
Investors, however, were wary. When Skechers went public in June 1999, the company had reduced its asking price and the number of shares it offered. Even so, the stock lost value in its first day of trading. "When a company prices at $11 and then opens trading at $10.50, that's generally kind of a sign of weakness," said Omar Sacirbey, a senior editor at The IPO Reporter.
Robert Greenberg declined to comment. But Lloyd Grief, a close acquaintance of the family and president of Grief & Company of Los Angeles, the investment bank that took L.A. Gear public in 1986, said, "I think he was stunned with his stock's original reception."
Investors' fears seemed justified when, just as its predecessor had, Skechers ran into both inventory and legal troubles. Soon after the initial offering, the company reported losses for the third quarter of 1999, the period that is generally the strongest in the shoe industry because of back-to-school sales. The company had too many shoes in the retail channel and floundered when its platform sneakers fell out of style, problems eerily similar to those that had plagued L.A. Gear.
"When you have that kind of situation, especially when it comes so soon after doing a public offering, institutions are very wary," said Harry Katica, vice president for research at Prudential Securities, one of Skechers' underwriters.
Then, in December, a group of shareholders sued, contending that the company had misled investors by not disclosing in its initial filing that it was having legal problems with R. Griggs Group. Griggs, the maker of Doc Martens shoes, sued its former business partner five days after the offering, saying that Skechers had pirated its designs for men's boots. Skechers stock, which had been heading steadily downward, fell to its all-time low of $3.25 in January, after the company announced that two more shareholder suits had been filed. A total of five suits have now been filed; the consolidated lawsuit is pending.
"The lawsuit is completely frivolous," Michael Greenberg said in a prepared statement. "Skechers vehemently denies violating any of the security laws and believes all disclosures were made on a timely basis."
Now, the Greenbergs' luck may be beginning to change. In March, the company settled with Griggs and announced that 1999 net sales rose almost 14 percent from 1998, to $424.6 million, despite the unusually poor third quarter. The next month, the shares finally reached their initial public offering price. Then, in May, Skechers announced a blowout first quarter. All this good news has led many analysts to believe that Skechers may indeed be able to step out from behind the L.A. Gear shadow.
Skechers, with its 900 styles, is doing a good job executing its strategy of being "everyone and everything" in footwear, said David Turner, an analyst at Ferris, Baker Watts.
The company's newest styles, like its Energy gym shoes, have reignited interest among teenagers. They have gone from being on the "uncool" list last fall to the "cool list" this summer, said Kevin Ume, president of element Holdings Inc., a marketing firm that specializes in research on the buying habits of teenagers. During the back-to-school sales season, Skechers will even be displayed at the high-visibility area in Lady Foot Lockers where the mall meets the store, a coveted spot usually reserved for Nike.
And right behind the teenagers are the investors, who seem willing to forget the past. "Skechers has not been on our coverage list but in the last couple months it's just popped up," said Allison Boswell, president of Allison Boswell Consulting, a group that surveys shoe buyers. "They were considered one of the top three fashion trend setting brands. They were also named as a brand that would be expected to have very high back-to-school increases."
Michael Greenberg notes with a broad smile that the company's stock is well above its initial price. The shares closed on Monday at $16.375, a high.
Such successes are seen as vindication by the Greenbergs, who are dreaming big again. "I think Wall Street understands one thing, and that's show me the numbers and deliver," Michael Greenberg said. "I think they're getting on board."

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 1; Workplace

HEADLINE: To Shirkers, The Days Of Whine And Roses

BYLINE: By EVE TAHMINCIOGLU 

 BODY:
For more than three months, Kevin Meeker, owner of Philadelphia Fish and Company, a restaurant and bar, put up with a cook whose obsession with the stock market often took his mind away from the soup. The 22-year-old employee checked his Motorola shares every half-hour on his pager and periodically slipped out to the dining room to get the bartender to turn on CNBC.
Not so long ago, Mr. Meeker says, he would have warned the cook to knock it off and fired him if he did not comply. But not in this job market. Instead, he turned a blind eye to the goofing off, and says he would probably still have the man on the payroll if he had not quit on Mother's Day after being asked to work beyond his eight-hour shift. 
 "I think the attitude among workers right now is, 'I could always go and get another job,' " Mr. Meeker said. "Now, that cook's working for another restaurant around the corner."
Checking on stock prices is the least of it. Increasingly, employees are testing the boundaries of the American work ethic as employers, hammered by recruiting and training expenses and fearful that they will be unable to fill job openings, make allowances for just about every form of misconduct. Offenses like frequent tardiness or absenteeism, apathy and even insubordination that would have merited a pink slip a few years ago are now being shrugged off as inconveniences.
The new management rule of thumb, it seems, is that a warm body is better than no body.
Take Suzan Windnagel, director of human resources for a credit union in San Jose, Calif. A woman who worked for her was frequently late, gave customers incorrect information and just did not feel like learning new computer skills.
If not for the tight labor market, Ms. Windnagel says, she would have dismissed the slacker within four months. Instead, she spent a year and a half counseling her, lecturing her and desperately trying to train her. Nothing worked, and, finally, she had to let her go.
But she says she is neither surprised nor particularly upset about the sloppy work habits she sees around her these days. "Workers, not bosses, have the upper hand," said Ms. Windnagel, who has been a human resources manager for 22 years. "Managers today know how hard it is to recruit people, so they put up with more. I don't blame workers at all."
Most people still put in an honest day's work, of course. It is just that the lazy, the rude and the nonproductive have an an easier time of it.
Doug Peterson, vice president for human resources at the Shape Corporation, an automotive supplier in Grand Haven, Mich., for example, says most of the company's 1,000 workers are productive and disciplined. Yet Mr. Peterson acknowledges that he harbors under-performers.
"Have we held on to people where in years past, we would have fired them?" he said. "The answer is yes."
The reason for the leniency is that at any given time, the company has an average of 40 unfilled jobs.
Because skilled trades are such tough positions to fill, Mr. Peterson said, he tolerated for nearly a year a hot-tempered staff electrician who often threatened co-workers. The company tried to counsel him and even signed him up for anger-management training, but finally dismissed him. "Five or six years ago, we would have not put up with that," Mr. Peterson said. "The person would have been gone immediately."
To combat worsening tardiness and absenteeism, he said, Shape has chosen the carrot over the stick. Last year, it decided to give workers 17 hours of personal time off a year on top of their vacation days -- and to pay them $10 for each of those hours they do not use. "We're giving incentives for people to be at work," he said.
Adaptec Inc., a maker of software and computer components in Milpitas, Calif., illustrates the starkness of the change taking place in the workplace. Six years ago, almost one-third of the people who left the company had been fired, according to Rick Olivieri, the director of compensation and benefits. Today, that proportion is down to 2 percent. "It's a real war for people out there right now," Mr. Olivieri said.
But leniency carries risks, warns DeAnne Rosenberg, author of "Hiring the Best Person for Every Job" (John Wiley & Sons, 2000). Most notably, accommodating shirkers can hurt office morale, she says.
Ms. Rosenberg cites the case of a home-health care administrator in Boston who yelled constantly at her co-workers, fobbed off work on colleagues and treated clients disrespectfully. Over eight months, 10 co-workers complained to her supervisor, but he refused to reprimand her, much less fire her. "He kept saying: 'It's a hard labor market. At least the little she does, she does,' " Ms. Rosenberg said.
Ultimately, the co-workers took matters into their own hands. They came in on a weekend, packed up the administrator's belongings and moved her desk and chair to another floor, she said. When the administrator came to work on Monday, they pretended she was not there and talked about her as if she had gone to another company.
She quit that day.
Obnoxious behavior is one thing. Illegal behavior is another.
Mark Spring, a labor and employment lawyer in Sacramento, Calif., says that executives at one of his client companies, a national book and music chain, merely gave a written warning to a manager who had ordered two subordinates to move a marijuana plant from his office to his home during work hours, he said.
In another case, a bank slapped the wrist of an employee who had been caught downloading pornography from the Internet, revoking his Internet privileges for 30 days and sending him to a sensitivity-training course.
Both the book and music chain and the bank exposed themselves to potential litigation by their inaction, Mr. Spring said.
Referring to the bank employee, he said, "If this had happened in the early 90's, he would have been fired because of the recession and because at the time everyone was nervous over sexual harassment."
Barring blatant wrongdoing, though, many companies are pursuing the path of least resistance.
"If a slacker comes in to work at 10 a.m. instead of 8 a.m., maybe the company needs to rethink that worker's schedule," said Erisa Ojimba, compensation expert for Salary.com, a salary-resource Web site based in Wellesley, Mass. "Maybe they're not their most productive before 10 a.m."

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 4; House & Home/Style Desk

HEADLINE: Had a Reservation. Honest.

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL 

 BODY:
THE original author of "Thou Shalt Not Lie" never anticipated Nobu. Or Pastis. Or Cafe des Artistes.
Specifically, the lying is about reservations, like "I made it a month ago" (often heard at Joe Allen, which accepts them only a week in advance) or "My secretary set it up this morning" (often heard at Nobu, which its manager politely terms "usually impossible"). 
 During the last year or so, restaurateurs all over the city say, lying has spiraled out of control. People want what they want when they want it, and, well, if they didn't plan in advance, they're just going to show up and demand it. And they're not only looking for something as modest as a table for two. Parties of 12 are walking in the door unannounced, brandishing a major sense of entitlement.
"It happens in an economic boom," said Clark Wolf, a restaurant consultant based in Manhattan. "When all the really big Hamptons estates are sold, New Yorkers need another place to compete."
And it really is a competition, with top restaurants like Babbo and Nobu booking one month in advance, and many more accepting reservations no more than a week ahead. Of course, for some people, it's sport to show up unannounced and see what they can get away with. When they cheat and win, the thrill is complete. Then again, there are others who are simply lazy.
"I just forgot to call and do it," one liar told me.
She appeared anyway with a friend after the theater one night at Joe Allen, insisting she had called. She was seated.
"Lying happens several times an evening," said Sara Collins, a manager and maitre d'hotel at Nobu. "We have a very good reservations system, and inherent in the system are controls about who's telling the truth. Oftentimes, a group of eight will stand in front of me and in the thick of it they can't answer the right questions. The ones who are lying always come in ready to fight. They think they can intimidate us, and since I'm a woman they think I'll ultimately buckle and be afraid of them."
She sighed. "They think it's a great thing to brag that they just walked into Nobu and got a table, because the restaurant has become a cult thing, if you will. People know how difficult it is to get in here."
You might think that a really smart liar would take a different tack and try to charm the staff, rather than alienate it. (Charming liars who are willing to wait get better treatment than their nasty counterparts, restaurateurs admit.) But the ones who start off nasty, they say, are dead giveaways.
"If the name is not in the book and the people are not the least bit polite, all signs point to guilty," said Mike Cetta, the owner of Sparks Steakhouse. "Though you've got to play it by ear. The good news is we have 684 seats. If we have a table, we'll seat them."
Some liars reveal themselves more quickly than others. Jenifer Lang, the managing director of Cafe des Artistes, who is married to its owner, George Lang, recalled: "A couple came in once without a reservation and they were very loud, saying, 'Jenifer and George Lang are really close friends of ours.' George and I were standing right there in front of them." She laughed. "It happens a lot."
Stephane Gerbier, the general manager at Pastis, has had similar experiences.
"The ultimate line is, 'I'm a friend of Keith's,' " he said, referring to the restaurant's owner, Keith McNally. "Much of our staff has worked with Keith in the past, so they tend to know his friends." He sighed. "But we're trained to be agreeable. It's not a kick for a us to find a liar."
Another way some people lie their way through a restaurant's door is to skip playing pals with the owner and go for the big time: using real celebrities.
"Last week, someone called who said he was coming in with Tom Cruise and they wanted to be served late," Ms. Lang said. "They preordered their dinner and we made special arrangements to stay open. They showed up an hour late and came in without him."
Did anyone say anything? "No, we're in the hospitality business," she said philosophically. "We also had Howard Stern last week. He was a 75-year-old man who came in with his wife."
Jerry Della Femina, who owns Della Femina in New York and East Hampton, had an even more unnerving experience. "I called Alison's by the Beach to make a reservation last week," he said, "and I said who I was and the woman asked, 'Are you really?' It turned out that a few weeks ago someone called and said it was me with a party of eight, and even though the restaurant was really booked, they spent an hour reconfiguring everything. Then in walks a short fat guy with lots of hair."
Mr. Della Femina is notoriously bald.
Needless to say, a stunt like that will work only once, though for some, once is enough.
"I think people feel restaurants are fair game, and when they're in the Hamptons they're even more fair game," Mr. Della Femina said. He recalled an incident that his staff named the Happy Birthday Barbara Scam, which was a reservation for a birthday dinner for 12 on a Saturday night in the middle of the summer. The group requested a custom birthday cake, which the restaurant special-ordered.
"Three or four days later," Mr. Della Femina said, "the baker called to say that Laundry had put in an order for a cake for 12, East Hampton Point ordered a cake for 12 and Nick & Toni's ordered a cake for 12. These people were going to literally stiff one of us. We stopped our order that day and the people never showed up. Later, we found that they had also tried booking at the Palm that night but had been turned down. I'm not even sure where they wound up. But that's beyond being cynical."
Also hovering in the beyond-cynical category, said Tom Piscitello, a maitre d'hotel at Babbo, is the new rash of self-styled concierges. "That's what they call themselves, but what they do is broker tables for money," he said. "They learn a restaurant's booking system, secure tables and sell them to other people."
"We've heard all of the stories people can come up with," he went on. "There are no new ones." One of the ways the Babbo staff weeds out storytellers is to assign reservation numbers. But Mr. Piscitello stressed: "We try to bend over backwards to accommodate people. If someone wants to eat here, they will. They'll just wait."
Fair enough, if a liar's got the time and inclination. But at theater district restaurants, for example, the schedule is not as flexible, since the dinner hour begins at around 10 p.m. or later. (Pretheater lying has a very low glamour quotient: after the show is when the actors tend to eat and bring their famous friends with them.)
Angus McIndoe, a maitre d'hotel at Joe Allen, says he can expect an influx of up to 20 people at one time at 11 on a Saturday night. "What bothers me most is when people come in then and lie," he said. "They try to intimidate the staff while they hold up everyone else who did things honestly. The people who do it feel it's O.K. to do it. But I can never say, 'Are you lying?' to a customer, and I can't insinuate that because there is always a .01 percent chance that we've made a mistake. So, I tell them, if we have a table, you'll get it. We treat them like a walk-in."
Of course, a restaurant like Joe Allen, which is a traditional hangout for people in show business, is not the best place for a liar to stage a scene. As Mr. McIndoe said: "If it is a Saturday night at 11 o'clock and a celebrity regular comes in, I'm going to seat him first. I'm not going to make Al Pacino wait at the bar for a table."
And that's the whole point, isn't it? Because after all the lies have been tried -- the lies on the phone and the lies at the door -- at the end of the day, one thing is clear. He really is Al Pacino. And you're not.

HEADLINE: Covent Garden Chief to Lead Kennedy Center

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
Michael Kaiser, the New York theater and ballet manager who helped rescue Royal Opera House at Covent Garden in London from a financial crisis, is about to be named president of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a Kennedy Center official said today.
Mr. Kaiser, who announced last month that he was returning to the United States, said then that he would leave Covent Garden at the end of the 2000-01 season, but the Kennedy Center official said today that Mr. Kaiser was scheduled to start his duties here on Feb. 1, well before the end of next season. 
 The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that the appointment is to be announced formally on Wednesday after the center's board formally votes its approval and that Mr. Kaiser would not be available for comment until then.
As chief executive at at Covent Garden, Mr. Kaiser virtually eliminated the budget deficit and created a permanent endowment. When he announced his resignation he said the decision to quit was "the most profoundly difficult" of his career, adding, "But for personal reasons it is time for me to return to my home." After hearing of Mr. Kaiser's decision, Sir Colin Southgate, the Royal Opera House's board chairman, said, "We owe him a huge debt of gratitude."
Mr. Kaiser will succeed Lawrence J. Wilker, who announced in April that he would leave his post at the end of the year and, following the path of many other executives these days, would join a new Internet venture.
Mr. Wilker's announcement came a week after Nathan Leventhal said he would leave his job as president of Lincoln Center. That created the unusual circumstance of the nation's two leading performing arts centers recruiting chief operating officers at the same time.
Mr. Kaiser, the official said, told the search committee, "I was the world's worst board member because I was meddling all the time, and that's when I realized it was what I wanted to do."
After he realized that he wanted to make arts administration his career, Mr. Kaiser sold his business consulting firm and, the Kennedy Center official said, "started cold at the Kansas City Ballet and worked his way up."
Mr. Kaiser was also executive director at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and American Ballet Theater, helping restore those companies to financial health.
Mr. Kaiser, 47, told the search committee that he was a lover of the performing arts who was raised in a performing arts family. His grandfather was a violinist with the New York Philharmonic, and one of the earliest memories he has is of spending every Saturday at the orchestra's rehearsals.
The presidency of the Kennedy Center is the No. 2 post, behind the chairmanship, which puts him in day-to-day charge of the center's operations and performances.
"It is a demanding job, with 3,300 performances a year," said James A. Johnson, chairman of the Kennedy Center, when Mr. Wilker's resignation was announced. "There are six or seven stages operating in an evening when everything is full."
Mr. Leventhal's salary at Lincoln Center was $525,000 a year and Mr. Wilker's at the Kennedy Center was $325,000. The Kennedy Center official said that Mr. Kaiser's salary was still being discussed and that it would be competitive with similar positions in the performing arts.

HEADLINE: A Gallery In Harlem Beats the Odds;
Out of the Mainstream, A Contemporary Art Space Continues to Surprise

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
In the fall of 1998 Christian Haye, a New York poet and art critic, opened a gallery of contemporary art in Manhattan. He called it the Project and presented an impressive lineup of artists from the Americas, Europe, Africa and Asia, many of them making local solo gallery debuts. Among them was Paul Pfeiffer, who went on to become a star of this year's Whitney Biennial and the recipient of that museum's first $100,000 Bucksbaum Award, currently the world's largest award for a visual artist.
In a city where competition for attention-grabbing talent is keen, the Project seemed to be on a winning track. But it was also bucking serious odds, New York has hundreds of art galleries; they open and fold all the time. Start-up backing can ensure at least short-term survival; Mr. Haye had none. And if prime location is everything, his venture had a major handicap. It wasn't situated within one of Manhattan's downtown art precincts. It was in a former disco on West 126th Street in Harlem. 
 Mr. Haye's solution was to turn being out of the way into a mark of distinction. "Everything about his gallery is a surprise," said Thelma Golden, deputy director for exhibitions and programs at the nearby Studio Museum in Harlem. "On the block it blends into the other buildings. Then you go inside and see the poured concrete floors and white Sheetrock walls. He shows international artists where you might expect to find only African-American artists. He brings a contemporary art world sensibility, but he's also deeply invested in the neighborhood."
What inspired Mr. Haye to open his gallery in Harlem? "In a sense, Chelsea," he said in a recent interview. He was referring to the city's now-not-so-new commercial art center in the far West 20's, in recent years a bleak stretch of storage buildings and garages until its overnight transformation into what some people see as an instant art mall.
"I wanted to be in a neighborhood with some history," Mr. Haye said. "SoHo was over. Williamsburg was already taken. Harlem was the natural choice. The area is overly politicized and has always been an economic battleground. But no place has more narrative than here."
Art has always been part of that narrative. Legendary figures like Aaron Douglas, Augusta Savageand Jacob Lawrence once lived in Harlem. High-profile contemporary artists like Ghada Amer, David Hammons and Nari Ward work in the area today. The Studio Museum, established in 1968, has a worldwide reputation as a center for African-American culture and is now expanding its physical plant and its programming.
"My great-grandmother came from Barbados to live here many years ago," said Mr. Haye, 30. "I've done a lot of traveling, and anywhere you go in the world people say: 'You're from New York. Are you from Harlem?' Everybody knows about it, though almost as if it were a virtual space. They don't know what the reality of it is."
That reality is notably upbeat at the moment. A commercial renovation is changing the face of 125th Street, bringing in Starbucks and Disney and with them presumably more visitors, including tourists. All of this may benefit the Project itself, which in February moved to new quarters a few doors from its original site after the ex-disco, on which Mr. Haye had a month-to-month lease, was sold to a social services agency.
The forced move was just one more learning experience for Mr. Haye, with little cash and almost no experience in running a gallery. Born in Queens, raised on Long Island, he enrolled at New York University when he was 16 to study comparative literature but dropped out fast. "I had problems with academia," he said. "There's something about the power structure between students and teachers that doesn't work for me."
He worked in publishing, then as a receptionist at The New York Review of Books. "Even when I was a teenager all I ever wanted to do was sit down and read and write book reviews," he said. He became briefly involved in the Nuyorican Poets Cafe in the East Village after hearing Amiri Baraka read there, and got a job with the Jack Tilton Gallery in SoHo, though that didn't last long. "I just don't play well with others," he said.
While at Tilton, he was living in the East Village in an apartment above the poet Steve Cannon, who had founded the literary and art magazine Gathering of the Tribes. Mr. Haye edited two issues and started writing about pop culture for other magazines like Bomb and Frieze, a contemporary art journal published in London.
In 1994 exasperated by what he viewed as misguided critical responses to black artists (and upset with the provocative "Black Male" show at the Whitney, organized by Ms. Golden and which he considered wrongheaded), he turned his attention to art criticism. "I thought, 'Well, I'm not an art critic, but I'm sick of reading this stuff.' Then I found myself writing more and more about art, which isn't what I set out to do."
He spent the next three years traveling, mostly in Europe, networking intensively and looking at work in art fairs and biennials as well as in institutional programs. "I basically opened a gallery to show artists I'd been wanting to write about," he said. So far, he added, no artist he has invited to show with him has turned him down.
After scouting around Harlem, he found the abandoned disco. With the help of friends, he put up interior walls on the first floor himself. He decided to use the basement as additional exhibition space, leaving it more or less as he found it with tropical landscapes picked out in glitter on black-painted walls.
No one who visited the Project that year is likely to forget it. There was no heat. And when a midwinter installation by the Scandinavian artist team of Michael Elmgreen and Ingar Dragset entailed knocking a hole through the wall of the building, the inside temperature was biting.
Usually two solo shows were on view at a time; the mix was visually varied and conceptually unprogrammatic.
"The early 1990's was an ideological time," he said. "It was the message, not the medium that mattered. Now the pendulum seems to have swung the other way, and I guess I'm swinging with it."
Young artists like Bulent Sangar from Turkey and the Korean-born Kim Sooja (much noticed at last year's Venice Biennale) appeared along with maverick Americans rarely seen in New York, like the performance artist William Pope L., who a few years ago tied himself to the door of a midtown bank with a string of hot dogs and handed out money, and the California-based Daniel J. Martinez, known for the "I can't imagine ever wanting to be white" admission tags he designed for the 1993 Whitney Biennial.
The final show in the space was work by Romuald Hazoume from Benin, who arrived a month before the opening to collect local materials for his sculptures. It was Mr. Hazoume's first visit to the United States.
"The third day he was here," Mr. Haye recalled, "he said to me: 'Christian, this is really strange. I've met so many people from Benin here. And I don't have to speak English. I can just speak French all day.' I said: 'Well, this is Harlem. What do you expect?' "
After that show closed last July, the gallery was homeless for several months until its reappearance at 427 West 126th Street, a compact two-story former bar. Mr. Haye has also brought in a new director and partner, Jenny Liu, whose background is almost as varied as his. A Harvard Law School graduate with a background in linguistics and psychology, she has a degree in art history from the Institute of Fine Arts in New York and has worked as an assistant director at 303 Gallery in Chelsea.
The exhibition program continues to be lively. On view through Aug. 27 are the sound-based installations by Nadine Robinson and Stephen Vitiello, both of whom made strong impressions in the "Greater New York" exhibition at P.S. 1 this spring. (Through the summer the gallery will officially be open only on Sundays, 12 to 6 p.m., though Mr. Haye and Ms. Liu are often on the premises and welcome drop-in visits.)
September will bring a show Mr. Haye describes as "devoted mostly to pornography," with work by Shu Lea Cheang and Matthias Vriens, creative director of Gucci. Two young California artists, Art Domantay and Kori Newkirk, will follow. Mr. Pfeiffer is being given both floors of the gallery for a solo in November.
The gallery has attracted some backing since it opened, but, Ms. Liu said with a mild note of wonder, it largely supports itself through sales, which have recently ranged from a $400 drawing to a $100,000 installation. Openings are well attended and foot traffic has picked up.
"At the beginning we got maybe two people a day," she said. "Now we sometimes have 15 or 20, which is nothing at all for Chelsea but a lot for here."
Ms. Liu and Mr. Haye have high hopes for the expansion of the contemporary gallery scene in the neighborhood, which also includes two spaces that predate the Project's arrival and share its broad agenda: Gallery X at 23 West 129th Street and the nonprofit Gallery M at 123 West 135th Street. "We keep hearing rumors that other galleries are moving up here," Ms. Golden said, "and if they do it will be because of what Christian has done. His energy is infectious."
But Mr. Haye, who lives in an apartment near the Project, says he wonders whether the mainstream downtown art world will really follow his lead.
"I run into people from the New York art world all the time in Europe," he said. "They can find their way to Berlin, but they can't find their way to Harlem because it's too far away. It's not really about the distance, though. It's about mental image. People still ask me if it's safe here. It's so close to where a lot of people are, but it's a different world."
