HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Jobless Rate Milestone

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Unemployment in New Jersey dropped to 3.4 percent in June, the lowest rate in three decades, and economists said it indicated virtually full employment statewide.
Mark Boyd, the state labor commissioner, called the rate a sign of a spectacular economy, pointing out that for five of the last six months, unemployment was below 4 percent. 
 The June rate was the lowest since the 3.3 percent mark set in March 1970. The record low is 3.2 percent, set in January 1970.

HEADLINE: Hey, Walkman: Time to Face the Music on a Chip

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
LESS than two years ago, the first handheld MP3 player was introduced, at a time when downloadable digital music was still a mystery to just about anyone who wasn't a college student or a basement-bound techie.
That first player, the Rio 300 PMP, has now spawned its third generation, the Rio 600, as sleek and curvy as its predecessor was boxy and bland. And it is only one of a new wave of consumer-friendly digital players, aimed not at the early adopters, the tech-hungry minority who will buy anything as long as it is shiny and showy and it beeps, but at the mass market, the rest of the gadget buyers, the ones who do not like a complicated instruction booklet. 
 The goal is nothing less than overtaking the cassette player and the CD player as the standard for listening to music on the go.
"The critical fact in the technology market right now is tailoring the product to consumer interests, rather than acting as if consumers' lifestyles and listening habits can be made to adapt to a singular device," said Mike Reed, vice president of marketing for S3's Rio division. The new mantra among consumer electronics executives and designers is ease of use, ease of use, ease of use.
Designers at the newly founded Nike Techlab, a sort of Skunk Works for Nike Inc., in Beaverton, Ore., called the approach "simplified logic."
And audio-player designers say they are reworking software as well as trying to improve the hardware, particularly the quality of the sound (still, on average, too tinny) and its volume (in most cases not yet approaching that of a common CD player) and storage (a paltry hour of music using the MP3 format and about twice that using the newer Windows Media Audio format). But for a few exceptions, they have a way to go.
For now, the players still depend almost exclusively on personal computers as a way to download digital music, which makes the audience smaller than that for tapes or CD's. But 45 million American households have personal computers, according to Forrester Research, so there are a lot of potential customers.
Legal issues about copyright still plague the downloading of music from the Web. But the industry is coming to terms with the idea that downloadable music will increasingly be a fact of life for consumers, and it is working with computer and electronics companies to develop better ways to offer music online that also protects copyright.
EMI Recorded Music announced earlier this month that it is releasing some of its songs using Liquid Audio, a digital format seen by many as being one of the more secure in the industry. And the makers of digital players are developing not only new hardware, but also new forms of memory and new systems that do not depend on personal computers for getting the music.
Forward Concepts, a research company in Tempe, Ariz., forecasted that the market for portable digital players will swell to 15 million in 2003 from a projected 3 million users this year. And young people view downloadable music as just another way to listen to what they want to hear. In a survey this spring by eBrain Market Research, a service of the Consumer Electronics Association, 57 percent of consumers 15 to 21 years old said they had played MP3 music files. Among those who had listened to MP3 music, most, according to the survey, found its sound comparable to that of a typical stereo.
So far, the appeal of personal digital players has rested on several factors: small size (the Sony VAIO Music Clip is slightly larger than a hefty fountain pen); completely skip-proof music playback; and the user's freedom to put any combination of songs on them. All of that can be done without cassette tape, compact discs, minidiscs or audio DVD's whirling away inside of them.
The new players, due this summer and early next year, share those features and add new ones. Prices range from about $170 to $300. And some are so simple to use that they would not require extensive thumbing through a voluminous operating manual to learn how to turn the thing on. (That's once you get the music downloaded from the Web or copied from CD's.)
The flattened-egg-shaped audio player called the Personal Sport Audio (PSA) Play, the result of a collaboration of the Nike Techlab and Rio, has its controls -- play, stop, forward and back -- on its smooth face with symbols for key functions so highly raised that users can press them through the fabric of their pockets.
Curtis Milander, marketing manager for the Nike Techlab, calls the approach blind design. "You don't have to look at it to operate it," Mr. Milander said. The PSA Play is scheduled to be available later this summer.
The MiniJam by InnoGear, scheduled for release Aug. 1, is packed into a small module that plugs into a Handspring Visor handheld computer. Once in place, the device is ready to store and play MP3's.
Engineers at PortalPlayer, a Santa Clara, Calif., developer of audio hardware and software, say they are building systems that will allow portable players to record digital music directly from a source, like a CD player, without the need of a computer.
Currently, almost all portable digital players must be plugged into a computer that either downloads music in a compressed format like MP3, which is the most popular, or the computer can translate music from CD's into a format like MP3, a process called ripping. The files are then copied and moved to the memory of a portable player.
"What we are saying is that with our technology, all you have to do is press the Record button on a player," said Michael J. Maia, vice president of marketing for PortalPlayer.
In the future, said Ron Boire, senior vice president of portable audio for Sony Electronics, personal digital players may be equipped with BlueTooth technology, an international standard that would allow devices like computers, electronic organizers and mobile phones to exchange information using radio waves. It would let consumers wirelessly load music into their players.
"The goal is to make the technology as seamless and transparent to the user as possible," Mr. Boire said.
S3's Rio said it shipped 500,000 players between November 1998, when the first Rio player was introduced, and February 2000. By the end of this summer, Mr. Reed said, that figure is expected to double.
But industry executives and others who follow the industry agree that if portable digital audio players are going to find a mass market -- customers other than those between the ages of 16 and 24 -- the players are going to have to offer mass appeal.
The first stumbling block -- storage -- is being tackled on several fronts.
Practically all portable players store music on solid state memory chips, including Compact Flash, Smart Media cards and Sony's Memory Sticks.
While solid state memory chips are small, run noiselessly and are reliable, they are also expensive and appear to be growing more so as demand begins to outstrip supply, manufacturers say.
One frustrated executive at an American consumer electronics manufacturer said he had traveled to Asia in an unsuccessful search for a company that could make and then sell the hardware components for a digital audio player to his company for $1. The reason? Much of the cost of a player, which is passed to consumers, is consumed by the cost of memory.
A digital player with adequate memory -- for at least a half-hour of playback -- that costs less than $100 has eluded the marketplace.
Most players are sold with 32 megabytes of embedded, often called "onboard," memory. A 32-megabyte memory card costs about $100. And the rule of thumb is that a player, like Samsung's Yepp player, requires about a megabyte of memory for every minute of recorded MP3 music (at near-CD-quality sound).
Adding more music requires more memory for storage, and the cost starts to climb steeply, said Craig Rathbun, the worldwide director of Clik technology for Iomega, maker of disk-based removable storage devices like the popular Zip and Jaz cartridges.
The 32-megabyte memory cards used in audio players are "essentially $100 half-hour albums," Mr. Rathbun said. Iomega is taking a different approach by adapting its Clik drives to digital audio players so that they may use the 40-megabyte Clik disks to store and play music.
Clik disks are not solid state and introduce moving parts into the players. But they are cheaper than solid state memory, Mr. Rathbun said.
A 40-megabyte Clik disk can cost as little as $10. They are also rugged, Mr. Rathbun said, as he held a handful of the half-dollar-size Clik disks, each containing a different genre of music.
This month, the first digital player using Clik technology, the Rave MP 2300 by Sensory Science, reached the market. Iomega officials said seven players with built-in Clik drives by other manufacturers -- including one by Iomega itself -- are expected to be available before the end of the year.
Rio is exploring alternatives to expensive, solid-state flash memory for storing music in its players.
Currently, the Rio 600, which is the first player to seamlessly play music encoded in the MP3 or Windows Media format, comes with 32 megabytes of memory. A more feature-laden Rio 800 is expected later this summer, with 64 megabytes of included memory.
Rio has also taken a novel approach to the question of expanding the storage capabilities of its audio players. Earlier models like the Rio 300 and Rio 500 use, as most players do, a slot in which an expansion memory card can be inserted, boosting the player's overall capacity to play more music. But such designs are limited, making it difficult to add more than a 64-megabyte card to the 32 megabytes already built into the player.
The new Rio players are designed with what its engineers call a backpack. It is a slip-off and slip-on back that contains the player's memory and power supply. The Rio 600, which costs $169, comes with a backpack with 32 megabytes built in and a single AA battery to power the unit.
An additional 64-megabyte backpack comes with a rechargeable battery. And Rio, in partnership with I.B.M., will soon release a backpack that will house a 340-megabyte I.B.M. Microdrive. Also in development is a Rio backpack equipped with a new 500-megabyte drive by DataPlay.
While executives at S3's Rio division said they were not ready to discuss the cost of the backpacks with the minidrives, they said the emerging memory technology helps to make their new Rio players "future-proof."
And because the disk-based storage devices spin only to retrieve a song before playing it from small embedded memory, they do not greatly tax battery life or make players more susceptible to skipping when moved or bumped.
"I think we are turning the corner with the release of the Rio 600 and other products in the family," Mr. Reed said, and added that Rio is looking beyond the youth market.
S3's Rio division, as well as a number of other consumer electronics companies, is also preparing to release a line of home-based digital audio players that resemble conventional stereo components. The newly released SongBank SL CD Memory System by Lydstrom not only plays and records CD's, but can also convert their content into a digital format and save iton the $800 machine's hard drive.
"When you look at the ways that people listen to CD's today," Mr. Reed at Rio said, you can pretty much count on us to replace that CD technology in the future with our technology."

HEADLINE: Is the Customer Ever Right?

BYLINE: By KATIE HAFNER 

 BODY:
BRENDA WINEGARDNER has been having a nightmare that is increasingly familiar to most consumers. In it she wanders between reality and virtual reality, from voice mail to e-mail to customer service counter, trying to get her computer fixed. But it's not a dream.
Since January, Ms. Winegardner, who operates a Web-based gift shop and mail-order business from her home in Monte Rio, Calif., about 60 miles north of San Francisco, has been battling CompUSA's customer service department because, she said, the Hewlett-Packard personal computer she bought there regularly slows down, then crashes. 
 "I got hives from the stress," she said after a recent visit to the store's real-world customer service counter, pointing to a telltale splotch on her cheek. She has often lain awake until 3 a.m. The hours she has spent on hold, not just with the store, but also with CompUSA's corporate headquarters and with Hewlett-Packard, she said, are too numerous to count.
When she does reach a human, she said, she encounters rudeness, incompetence or plain indifference. It's the unpleasantly real version of a well-known sketch from the 1970's British television show, "Monty Python's Flying Circus." In the skit, a man tries to return a dead parrot to a pet store and encounters a clerk who insists that the parrot is "resting."
Ms. Winegardner has had to struggle to have her complaint heard, she added, even though she sprang for CompUSA's $349.99 Premium Gold Service when she bought the computer. The card guaranteed unlimited access to technical support for three years.
Ms. Winegardner's experience is far from unusual, and CompUSA is no different from many other stores. Customer service that fails to satisfy is increasingly common. As measured by the American Customer Satisfaction Index, compiled at the University of Michigan, customer-service satisfaction has dropped overall since 1994. American consumers are more unhappy with the service they are receiving for nearly every sector of the economy measured by the index, including the computer industry, hotels, airlines, telephone companies and automobile manufacturers. There are many causes, but one that is widely recognized is technology itself. Phone systems and Web sites that are supposed to help can turn into infuriating mazes.
"This is a rough time for customer service," said Bob Chatham, a Forrester Research analyst who follows customer service.
One reason, he said, may be a general decline in civility, but he also pointed to technological advances in customer service, or customer care, as it is known in industry parlance. For example, he said, automated phone answering systems can send a caller into a loop, provoking the same explosive anger usually reserved for tailgaters, slowpokes and that idiot with the cell phone driving in front of you.
And the Web is often no help. For instance, Mr. Chatham said, "I got an auto-response e-mail once from AT&T Wireless that told me to call the call center."
"It's a fascinating paradox," said Laurel Pallock, an investigator who runs the complaint mediation program in the San Francisco district attorney's office. "Here we are in this predicament because of technology, the very thing that is supposed to keep us from being in this predicament."
Until recently, Ms. Pallock was the host of a weekly television program on consumers' issues. "I've gone on the air and said, 'You guys who own these companies, why don't you listen to your own customer service voice mail and see if you can get through to yourselves?' "
But even Ms. Pallock is not exempt from criticism. She was a guest on a local radio show recently when a man called in to complain about the automated phone system in Ms. Pallock's office. She apologized on the air, agreed that the office's phone system was "horrible," called him afterward to give him her direct line and set about fixing the problem.
Add to the phone rage what Mr. Chatham describes as still more dysfunctional aspects of today's customer service systems. More often than not, he said, customers' records on a company's Web sites are not linked with those maintained for the agents working by telephone.
"There's a self-inflicted phenomenon going on here. Companies got all excited about this technology, so they put it up without thinking about how it relates to everything else they do. Once they opened that Pandora's box, it launched this whole litany of problems."
But there is another, less technical, explanation for the decline in service. Mr. Chatham cited the overall labor shortage, which has forced companies to hire less qualified workers for what are already low-paying, largely thankless jobs.
"Would you look forward to coming to work if you had to spend the day talking to irate cusotmers?" he asked.
As a result, turnover on customer service desks runs as high as 100 percent per year, he said.
One author has even suggested that dissatisfaction has to do with customers' experiences with good service. Dr. Leonard Berry, a professor of marketing at Texas A&M University and author of "Discovering the Soul of Service" (Free Press, 1999), agreed that service was not good. "I give service in America a C minus," he said.
But at the same time, Dr. Berry added, people's expectations for service are rising. "We want better service even though we think we'll get worse service," he said. "And part of the reason is because we have experienced excellent service enough to know that it's possible."
Whatever the explanation, there seems to be no dispute about the reality of the decline. Complaints to the Better Business Bureau have risen sharply in recent years, said Ron Berry (no relation to Leonard Berry), senior vice president of the Council of Better Business Bureaus in Arlington, Va. Even so, Mr. Berry added, only a small percentage of disgruntled customers actually file formal complaints to bureaus.
Rachel Barany, an educational consultant in New York, is a conspicuous exception. In March, she bought a Sony VAIO notebook computer at Data Vision, a computer retailer in Manhattan, but she was unable to get the computer to work properly. After several rounds of phone calls and repeated trips to the store, she sent off a raft of letters and cc's to the Better Business Bureau, Sony, The New York Times, Data Vision and American Express, whose card she used to pay for the machine.
Finally, last month, Data Vision allowed Ms. Barany to exchange her computer for a less expensive I.B.M. Thinkpad. The difference in price was issued as a store credit.
But Ms. Barany is unhappy with the store credit. She wants a refund.
Every dispute has at least two sides. Jim Garson, a vice president of Data Vision, said that there was nothing wrong with Ms. Barany's laptop and that all it needed was a software patch for the internal modem. He said that he had offered to install the software for her but that she had declined. By allowing her to trade for the newer computer, he said, he took a loss on the old one.
"I don't take back a notebook three months later, especially when there's nothing wrong with it," he said. "How much more customer service can you give?"
Mr. Garson said many of the complaints against his store were unfounded. One customer called Mr. Garson to say she had bought an Olympus camera a year ago and seldom used it, so she wanted to return it, he said. "I said: 'Ma'am, there's nothing I can do. Try to sell it on eBay.' " She complained to the Better Business Bureau.
Some consumers do not feel satisfied unless they make themselves heard. Julie Kennedy, a corporate lawyer in San Francisco, is a customer service maven if ever there was one. On the phone, she always presses "0" immediately to reach a human. She shops only in stores that will give refunds, and she has no qualms about firing off a letter if she is dissatisfied. "I think there's a social contract that goes beyond courtesy," Ms. Kennedy said. "You pay someone money and you expect to be valued. It ticks me off when I find people so oblivious to that principle."
But Ms. Kennedy also makes a point of sending a letter when she stumbles upon excellent service.
Two years ago, Ms. Kennedy called United Airlines to reserve a flight to Ireland, using her free miles. Dodging the thicket of blackout dates made the task look formidable until she found an agent as interested in making the trip work as she was.
"He was trying everything," she said. "I was on the phone with him for over two hours. He tried every date, every time, and I got to use my free tickets." She sent a letter of praise to the airline.
Another consumer who keeps careful watch over the service he gets is Jim Hobby. He has a professional interest in the subject as well: he is vice president of customer client care at Gateway and has spent 25 years in the customer service business, including time at American Express and Federal Express.
"My kids call me the client from hell," he said. "They say when they're out with me and I get this look, they run, because they know someone is going to get my lecture on what customer service should be."
What customer service should be, he said, is a collection of thoughtfully placed "pleases" and "thank yous," combined with careful listening. These are known as soft skills. "It's showing that you care and you want to work with the customer," he said.
Service via live chat is growing in popularity, Mr. Hobby said, and so is the use of e-mail for such interactions. Gateway has also simplified its automated phone system in response to what Mr. Hobby described as a great deal of customer frustration.
Complaining is getting easier in some places. Many companies that emphasize customer service, like American Express, now let customers dispute charges on line.
The Better Business Bureau has seen a rise in the number of online complaints it gets. And a growing number of sites dedicated to filing gripes are cropping up online.
One such site, called uGetHeard.com, allows consumers to send both gripes and praise. Complaints are followed by efforts by uGetHeard.com to resolve the disputes. The average resolution is small -- around $50 -- but the gratification for the customer is beyond measure, said Michael Chen, the site's chief executive.
Mr. Chen said he was inspired to set up the site after a particularly unpleasant experience he had last spring at a private mailing center in the San Francisco Bay Area, where he went to mail a package. After paying, he grew nervous when he saw that no one was wrapping the package, so he decided to do it himself.
But when an employee demanded that he pay for the sealing tape he was using, he protested. After a while the manager emerged from the back. "She said: 'You're really irritating. We're too busy to deal with you,' " Mr. Chen recalled. "I've never been spoken to like that."
That was all the impetus he needed.

HEADLINE: Okinawans Hope Economic Meeting Puts Focus on Art Missing Since War

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Leaders on the Japanese island of Okinawa plan to use the eight-nation economic summit conference there this week to help speed the recovery of cultural property that disappeared from homes, public buildings and religious shrines when American soldiers seized the island in 1945.
To date, more than 100 artworks -- including ancient Buddhist temple bells, statuary and sacred manuscripts -- have been returned by American veterans, their heirs and, in at least one case, forcibly by the United States Customs Service. But one scholar, Peter Kleinen of the German Institute of Japanese Studies, recently reported finding nearly 800 objects of Okinawan origin in the holdings of 21 American museums. 
 Since many of these artworks were put on display after World War II, scholars believe they were looted during and immediately after the fighting.
One of the most cherished objects still missing is the ancient headdress worn by the Ryukyu kings who ruled Okinawa until the island was annexed by imperial Japan in 1879. The headdress is a silk, helmet-shaped crown studded with pearls, gold, jade and other precious stones. It has not been seen publicly since 1945.
Last month a delegation of six City Council members from Nago, where the economic meeting is to begin tomorrow, flew to Washington and gave President Clinton and other administration officials a council resolution calling on the United States to "investigate the whereabouts of our lost cultural assets and take relevant steps for their return."
Mikio Yabu, the leader of the group, said at a stop in New York, "We hope the summit conferees will pay attention not only to international economic issues but to the restoration of cultural losses from Okinawa."
Speaking by telephone from Naha, Okinawa's capital, Shizuo Kishaba, chairman of the semi-official Ryukyu-American Historical Research Society, who has played a major role in returning stolen objects to Okinawa, took a more forceful position.
While stopping short of predicting that President Clinton would face a hostile demonstration when he arrives in Okinawa, Mr. Kishaba said, "The president knows what we are seeking, and if he arrives empty-handed it will certainly sour our relationship with the United States."
The State Department, in response to an inquiry, issued a statement saying, "We recognize the deep concern of the people of Okinawa about artifacts missing since the end of World War II." The F.B.I., the statement said, has offered to list missing items in a database available at www.fbi.gov/majcases/arttheft/ art.htm.
Missing items are also being listed in the national stolen art file, accessible only to law enforcement officials, the statement said.
A State Department spokesman, however, said that it was unlikely that the American delegation would actually bring any of the artifacts this week.
In World War II priceless artworks were seized by soldiers in both the Pacific and European theaters and sometimes justified as war trophies. The issue of unreturned works still troubles relations between Germany and Russia. For American servicemen and women theft from conquered territories was prohibited by the Articles of War, No. 93.
Mr. Kishaba said that many American servicemen who stole objects from Okinawa in 1945 later sold or donated them to American museums. "The result is that Okinawan treasures are scattered across the United States," he said.
The Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass., has a group of six ceramic and pewter objects sold for $75 in 1947 by Cmdr. Carl W. Sternfelt, an American intelligence officer who served on Okinawa during the war.
Records of this sale are particularly significant, Mr. Kishaba said, because he and many others believe that Commander Sternfelt, who died in 1976, also took the royal Ryukyu headdress in 1945.
Much of Commander Sternfelt's loot was confiscated by United States Customs agents in 1953 and returned to Okinawa later that year in a ceremony celebrating the centennial of Matthew Perry's historic visit to Okinawa.
Commander Sternfelt's son, Robert Sternfelt, of Scituate, Mass., denies that his father ever possessed the headdress and said that his father voluntarily surrendered the booty he brought home from Okinawa.
Christina Hellmich, a spokeswoman for the Peabody Essex Museum, said, "If we are presented with evidence that Commander Sternfelt stole the objects now in our possession, we would repatriate them."
Another point of contention is a 10-inch flat stone from Okinawa incised so as to suggest that it may have been used as an ancient sundial or a navigational instrument. It is now in the collection of the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology in Philadelphia.
Mr. Kishaba believes the stone was taken by an American soldier after the war and wants it returned to Okinawa, but Gregory L. Posschl, curator of the Asian collection of the museum, said that the provenance of the object was uncertain and that it could not be returned unless Okinawa's rightful ownership was established.
"We have no desire to keep things that don't belong to us," Mr. Posschl said. "But we have to go through a process that is both rigorous and fair to determine the validity of these claims."
In 1945 Okinawa was the scene of the largest land, air and sea battle in history, and the focus of Japan's desperate resort to kamikaze attacks.
The 81 days of fierce fighting that began on Easter left 12,000 Americans dead or missing and 72,000 wounded, more than twice the numbers from Guadalcanal and Iwo Jima combined.
Japanese losses were even greater. The Japanese death toll soared to 120,000 combatants and more than 150,000 civilians.
Few structures on the island were left standing, and looting by American soldiers -- commanders as well as enlisted men -- was widespread.
"A frenzy of souvenir hunting was part of the terrible strangeness of that battle," said George Feifer, author of "Tennozan: The Battle of Okinawa and the Atomic Bomb" (Houghton Mifflin, 1992). "The Marines risked their lives to tear a photograph off of a wall or even to grab a pair of sneakers."
Mr. Kishaba said, "We were in danger of having our culture erased."
Members of the delegation spoke emotionally last month about their sense of loss. Kazunori Nagayama said learning to play the sanshin, a classical Okinawan stringed instrument, had inspired his interest in Okinawan cultural history.
When he plays his 80-year-old sanshin, he said, he dreams of ancient court life where such instruments were played in the presence of the royal family.
"But my dreams are frustrating because we have so little to remind us of our roots," he said.
Morio Kohama, 42, said he had learned about the history of Okinawa from his father, who is 86. "But I have no proof, nothing I can hold in my hands, of the truth of what he is telling me."

HEADLINE: LINCOLN CENTER FESTIVAL REVIEW;
Sounds of Almost Wordless Songs

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

 BODY:
The beauty of a diverse and multifaceted festival is that little connections pop up, too modest to qualify as full-blown themes and surely not planned as such. Two such connections arose on Tuesday evening, when Lincoln Center Festival 2000 introduced its three-part Meredith Monk retrospective, Voice Travel, featuring Ms. Monk as composer and conductor, with "Solo Landscapes," a program at the New York Society for Ethical Culture.
The first half consisted of unaccompanied songs, chiefly "Songs From the Hill," 11 pieces from 1976 inspired by the landscape and lore of New Mexico. These are vocal utterances in Ms. Monk's patented style, virtually devoid of intelligible words and made of shaped syllables, plosives, hums, even mere breaths. 
 In the sixth song, "Silo," Ms. Monk's amazingly flexible voice took on the color and disembodied wail long associated with electronic music; the piece would hardly have seemed out of place in the festival's Electronic Evolution series, just ended. In the eighth song, "Bird Code," Ms. Monk played a big, squawking specimen; the piece seemed an odd deviation from all the bird song (mostly, more cultivated) being heard in the festival's series devoted to music of Messiaen, which ends tomorrow.
With the range of sounds Ms. Monk can produce, she probably could have connected just as well to any other music the festival might have put forward. (As it is, a listener who missed the opera "Writing to Vermeer" can only guess how Ms. Monk's flirtations with Minimalism in ensemble works still to be heard may relate to Louis Andriessen's there.) The songs also conjured bugs (croaking or quirkily singing), old women and ghosts, depicted in all manner of articulation. In the last song, "Jew's Harp," Ms. Monk proved a virtuoso on that mouthful of an instrument, even singing along.
The second half of the program added piano. Ms. Monk accompanied herself in rudimentary fashion in more or less similar songs or was accompanied by Nurrit Tilles in bigger songs, ending with the most recent, "New York Requiem," a tribute to AIDS victims, from 1993. Ms. Tilles also played the "St. Petersburg Waltz," a piano solo of 1994.
Ms. Monk everywhere impressed with her versatility and imagination if not always with terseness and economy. In the end it all seemed a bit much of the same thing.
What today seems remarkable about the early works ("Porch," from 1969, and the songs of the 70's), at a time when "avant-garde" has become synonymous with "edge," is their consistent sweetness and innocence. In quantity they occasionally cloy (especially, for a listener allergic to cats, in the meowing).
More varied angles on Ms. Monk's music are promised in the remaining programs: "Expeditions in Concert," with chamber orchestra, tomorrow at Alice Tully Hall, and "Monk Perspectives," with film, on Sunday at La Guardia High School. And keep an ear out for others of those little connections.

HEADLINE: Coke, Lauding Its Strategy, Says Results Beat Estimates

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Declaring that its six-month-old "think local, act local" strategy was working in some parts of the world, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings slightly beat analysts' expectations, mainly because of savings from a sweeping reorganization this year.
Net income fell to $926 million, or 37 cents a diluted share, from $942 million, or 38 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 5 percent, to $5.62 billion from $5.33 billion, mostly because of price increases in some countries and improving economic conditions in others, the company said. 
 Excluding charges of $191 million, or 5 cents a share, for the reorganization, in which 5,200 employees were laid off, and 2 cents a share to reduce inventory of concentrate, profit was $1.2 billion, or 44 cents a share. Analysts had expected the company to earn 41 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
The inventory reduction, in which Coke stopped selling concentrate to bottlers that had bloated inventories, was announced in January as part of Coke's efforts to rebuild its global business. That was when Coke officials also said they would decentralize many of the company's operations and put more authority into the hands of local management.
One money manager questioned the inventory charge, saying it was not accompanied by a dollar amount on the company's income statement and therefore could not be properly analyzed by investors.
"They are trying to give themselves credit for business they did not do," said James S. Chanos, who runs the Kynikos Fund. "To say that their business would have been X if they had been able to ship the concentrate that they shipped and booked last year is an unbelievable example of accounting arrogance. Where is the audit committee?"
A Coke spokesman, Rob Baskin, said the charge amounted to $80 million. "We don't have it as a line item because it is a reconciling charge," he said. "We are noting that we did not ship that concentrate in the second quarter of this year. We did ship it in the second quarter of 1999."
The company said its volume, measured in cases of soft drinks, grew 7 percent in the quarter, including volume growth from the Cadbury Schweppes brands acquired last year. Without the Cadbury brands, volume rose about 5 percent.
Local marketing efforts in Germany, where a campaign is directed at German teenagers, produced volume growth of 9 percent, the company said. Germany is Coke's fourth-largest overseas market. In the United States, where Coke's biggest bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises, said on Tuesday that volume would be flat or rise just 1 percent this year, Coke plans an intensive marketing effort in the second half of this year. The company will also introduce certain brands regionally, like Fanta, and emphasize "pervasiveness" of its products in places like convenience stores and offices, said Coke's president, Jack L. Stahl.
Douglas N. Daft, the chairman and chief executive, told analysts during a conference call, "I'm happy with the improving trends in the business, and to see and feel and touch the improvement in the mindset of our people around the world."
Investors lifted shares of Coke $2.31.25, to $60.50.
Analysts seemed positive, too, though they noted that Coke's second quarter last year was one of its worst, including a big product recall in parts of Europe.
"I am more encouraged than I was after the April meeting," said Jennifer Solomon at Salomon Smith Barney, referring to a meeting in New York where Coke's senior management presided over a five-hour marathon of commercials and presentations on marketing efforts around the world that generally fell flat.
Mr. Daft said then that he expected volume to increase 5 to 6 percent this year, and 7 to 8 percent over the long term. In the conference call yesterday, he and other Coke executives said they were "comfortable" with those projections.
Several analysts questioned Mr. Daft about possible changes in Coke's bottling system. With the emphasis on local decision making, some analysts expect Mr. Daft to break up some of the larger bottlers or find alternatives to what one called the "pan-regional" system now in place, in which Coca-Cola Amatil, based in Sydney, Australia, oversees operations stretching from there to the Philippines, and Coca-Cola Enterprises, based in Atlanta, has 74 percent of Coke's business in the United States and five Western European countries.
In response, Mr. Daft outlined what he called "a broad-based, broad-front approach to what is a very complex issue," saying that technology and an emphasis on building relationships were enabling changes in Coke's dealings with its bottlers. At another point in the call, he said that volume growth would mean improved results for Coke and the bottlers, which he described more than once as "interdependent."

HEADLINE: An Indochina Flashback: Old Tremors Rock Laos

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 14

 BODY:
The Asian economic crisis has claimed this tiny Communist nation as its last, its poorest and its most obscure victim, and -- perhaps as a result -- Laos has suddenly been hit by an unaccustomed shudder of unrest.
A series of unexplained bomb blasts, an improbable cross-border raid by a hapless band of insurgents and a brief political demonstration -- the first in decades -- have raised the political temperature in this quiet and tightly controlled nation. 
 And now, in the one place the Indochina war never ended, reports have surfaced that Vietnamese security forces have become active again, if only in a supporting role, in tamping down a flare-up of fighting by ethnic rebels.
In this land of secrets and strongmen, no one outside the inner circle seems to know what is going on, and indeed there may be no one explanation for this troubled moment.
But some analysts say that, as in some other Asian nations, the economic squeeze may have heightened a variety of grievances. Last year inflation hit 150 percent and the currency, the kip, fell to a tenth of its value, the steepest collapse in the region.
The exception may be the ethnic insurgency, which never quite died after the Communist victories in Indochina in 1975. It mostly involves the Hmong hill tribesmen, descendants of the anti-Communist fighters who helped carry out America's "secret war" in Laos, still stirred to action by local grievances as well as by wartime commanders who fled to the United States two decades ago.
The Hmong (pronounced mung) still operate in the mountains of northern Laos, where the North Vietnamese built most of their supply line, the Ho Chi Minh trail, and where American bombers dropped more tonnage than in all of Vietnam.
"This is a leftover of the Indochina war, which everyone tries to forget," said Sunai Phasuk, a Thai expert on Laos at Chulalongkorn University in Bangkok. "There are those who left for foreign countries who still have their relatives in Laos and are supporting them with every possible means."
The reports of Vietnamese military involvement are sketchy, unconfirmed and hotly debated by analysts here and abroad. But they are supported by eyewitness accounts from foreigners who work in the mountains that border Vietnam, along with official reports of stepped-up government and military contacts between the two nations.
The Vietnamese are currently building a military hospital in the area of conflict.
Dr. Sunai said military analysts in neighboring Thailand estimated that a Vietnamese troop presence rose to 10,000 or more late last year.
But Carlyle A. Thayer, an Australian expert on the Vietnamese military, said any Vietnamese presence probably involves a long-standing deployment of troops from the Interior Ministry rather than an incursion by the armed forces. "At most it is advice and supplies and equipment and people on the ground to observe and report back to Vietnam," he said, noting that Vietnam has its own concerns in keeping its mountain tribes quiet along the porous border.
"Since late last year, or earlier, the Hmong armed groups have been giving the Lao Army hell," he said. "They've raided and grabbed payrolls and grabbed weapons. They've ambushed columns and shot down a helicopter."
The Laotian government also blames the Hmong for at least five small explosions here in Vientiane and elsewhere -- at a restaurant, a bus station, a marketplace, a hotel and on a bus -- that caused a number of injuries.
But most foreign analysts doubt that the Hmong were involved, seeing the recent unrest as diffuse and without central coordination. No one has claimed responsibility for any of the bombs, and some of them may be copycat affairs involving personal or business disputes.
One event reported by an Asian diplomat did seem intended to send a message. Gunmen are said to have stopped a rural bus, removed its passengers, set it alight, photographed it and disappeared.
A cross-border raid on July 3 seemed to be the clearest attempt to capitalize on the political uncertainties of the moment. About 60 rebels armed with assault rifles and grenade launchers crossed the border from Thailand, attacked a customs post, took hostages, released them and were gunned down by government forces. At least 5 were killed and 28 were captured when they retreated into Thailand.
According to Thai reports, the raiders had a document linking them to Crown Prince Soulivong Savang, the heir to the now-defunct Laotian throne, who fled across the Mekong River after the Communist victory and is now lobbying for support in the United States and Europe.
"I suspect that this was an attempt to exploit the general level of unhappiness in Laos," said Martin Stuart-Fox, a professor of history at the University of Queensland in Australia who has written a history of Laos. "It's the old network of resistance that was being supported by the Thai military and by an expatriate Lao network in the United States and France and Australia and is trying to resuscitate itself."
More than 250,000 Hmong now live in the United States, as well as tens of thousands of lowland Lao.
If the economic crisis is the underlying theme to these various incidents, it may have sharpened a variety of agendas.
According to one theory, the bomb blasts could be an attempt by a faction of the ruling clique to discredit another in advance of a party congress expected early next year.
Another theory is that anyone with a point to make may want to be heard before Dec. 2, which is the 25th anniversary of the end of the war in Laos and the takeover by the Communist Pathet Lao government.
That relatively low-key end to the war -- the American Embassy shut down for just one day -- came half a year after the traumatic Communist victories in Vietnam and Cambodia in April 1975.
Laos has since reverted to its role as a buffer state between Communist Vietnam and China and the surging capitalist economies of Southeast Asia. If Laos becomes unstable, one diplomat said, "the most frightening thing would be the reviving of some cold war traditions, with China and Vietnam backing Vientiane, hoping to keep away the stronger influence of the Thais."
Laos, one of the world's 10 poorest countries, has become a little brother to Vietnam, following its failed Communist policies for a decade and then, like Vietnam, opening up its economy at the start of the 1990's.
When the economic crisis struck the region in 1997, Laos was at first insulated by its isolation and poverty. But with its economy heavily dependent on Thailand, it soon lost most of the investment and markets it did have.
Just about the time Thailand was beginning to recover, Laos crashed. The 80 percent of its five million people who live on the edge of poverty in the countryside remained relatively untouched -- as poor as ever.
But civil servants, like teachers, nurses and bureaucrats, saw their pay shrink to almost nothing and many abandoned their jobs.
Among these people, said a European diplomat, "there is growing unhappiness. There were hopes a couple of years ago that people's lives were going to improve and that their children would have a better future. That's just not here anymore."
A leading foreign expert on Laos saw this as the major source of potential unrest and, possibly, of change. "There was a social contract in the early 90's," he said. "That contract depended on people's lives getting better. I think the theme is what I call the undoing of the social contract, and the question is whether the government can knit it back together, and it doesn't look as though they're doing a very good job of it."
He added: "When there is an economic contraction like this, and the pie at the top starts getting smaller, the possibility is that members of the elite start getting fed up. The only way things will come apart is when particular groups get squeezed out of the action."
But outside the power structure, the European diplomat said, "there is nothing here to take its place, no civil society, no democratic opposition, nothing. This country is totally repressed."
Thus, to diplomats and aid workers who live in Laos, the most astonishing -- and poignant -- event was an aborted demonstration last October that involved at least 50 university students and teachers, of whom at least five remain in detention.
This was the one echo Laos has seen of the pro-democracy movements that have swept the region. In an open letter, the protesters called for respect for human rights, the release of political prisoners, a multiparty political system and elections for a new National Assembly.
Little more is known about the demonstrators or their fate. More than in any other Communist nation, even the Soviet Union of the past, diplomats here throw up their hands in confusion over the nation they are observing.
"It's still vague and murky," said one of them. "That's my best assessment."
In a peculiar headline the other day, the government newspaper Vientiane Times seemed to be similarly at a loss. "The truth is out there . . ." read the headline, and stopped. The article beneath it offered little clue.

HEADLINE: Decline in Computer Shipments Lifts Trade Gap to $31 Billion

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit widened slightly more than expected in May, to a record $31.04 billion, as both exports and imports declined for the second straight month, new figures show.
A decline in shipments of computer parts and other electronic goods helped drag down exports 1 percent, to $85.7 billion, the Commerce Department said today. Imports slipped 0.3 percent, to $116.8 billion, but the weakness largely reflected fewer shipments of automobiles. Imports of consumer goods like televisions, toys and VCR's continued to be robust in May. 
 "The combination of strong domestic demand and a strong dollar means we're pulling in consumer imports at a record pace," said Robert Dederick, an economic consultant with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "The economic expansion continues to roll along."
The deficit grew 1.8 percent in May from April's imbalance of $30.5 billion, which was revised up from the a previous estimate of $30.44 billion. The May data put the shortfall on track to reach more than $350 billion for all 2000, up one-third from last year's record $265 billion. Businesses are now starting to stock up on imports for the start of the school year and the holiday season.
The chronic trade deficit has caused some economists to worry about the outflow of dollars. If an economic slowdown also causes a withdrawal of overseas investment in the United States, the dollar could weaken, raising import prices and aggravating inflation, they say.
By country, the merchandise trade deficit with Japan fell to $6.9 billion in May from $7.3 billion in April. It was $5.2 billion a year earlier. The deficit with China rose $6.3 billion in May from $5.8 billion in April and $5.2 billion in May 1999.

HEADLINE: Earnings at United and American Beat Expectations

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Earnings at the nation's two largest airline companies, the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, and the AMR Corporation, owner of American Airlines, handily beat Wall Street expectations yesterday. But the good news was tempered by United's warning of weaker earnings in the current quarter, igniting a large sell-off of airline stocks, led by UAL.
In addition, US Airways, the No. 6 carrier, said its profit plunged 41 percent, excluding one-time gains, while T.W.A., which has continued to elude profitability despite the travel boom of recent years, narrowed its losses more than analysts had predicted. 
 The strong showing by United and American came after similar reports by Continental Airlines and the low-fare leader Southwest Airlines on Tuesday. "If the economy is slowing down, we don't see it in the airline business," said Tom Horton, AMR's chief financial officer.
Operating profit at UAL rose 17 percent, to $408 million, or $3.47 a diluted share, compared with $349 million, or $2.86 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 13 percent, to $5.11 billion from $4.54 billion in 1999. Analysts had expected the company to earn $3.24 a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
United said that it had benefited from higher fares and a 6.8 percent increase in passenger traffic in the quarter, led by a 21 percent increase in the Asia-Pacific region. That more than made up for the surge in fuel prices, which is an airline's second-biggest expense after labor, thanks to an aggressive hedging program that locked in fuel costs before the big price increases.
But United also suffered from several operational headaches in the quarter that gave it the poorest on-time record and most flight cancellations among the big airlines. Executives blamed unusually poor weather, the air-traffic control system and the refusal of many pilots, who are angry about the slow pace of contract negotiations, to fly overtime.
Rono Dutta, UAL's president, said that the pilot action cost the company $50 million during the quarter. United has cut thousands of flights and is adding more time into its schedule to try to reduce cancellations and delays. Mr. Dutta said that revenue would continue to be strong in the current quarter but that the reduction in capacity along with higher fuel and wage costs would result in earnings between $2.60 and $3.20 a share, lower than analysts were expecting.
The news caused shares of UAL to plunge $5.9375, or 10 percent, to $53.3125 on the New York Stock Exchange.
AMR reported a 32 percent surge in profit, excluding extraordinary items, to $285 million, or $1.75 a share, compared with $216 million, or $1.36 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 10.4 percent, to $5 billion from $4.5 billion last year. Analysts had expected AMR to earn $1.57, according to First Call.
American also benefited from hedging its fuel costs, saving $105 million during the quarter, Mr. Horton said. He said that the airline also gained $10 million to $15 million in additional revenue by attracting passengers displaced by cancellations at United, its main competitor.
In addition, American faced an easier comparison with results in the quarter a year earlier, when its bookings were weakened by the aftermath of a pilot sickout that crippled its operations. And a recent decision to remove seats from most of its airplanes to give passengers more legroom helped increase its average fare.
Revenue at US Airways rose 6.4 percent during the quarter, to $2.43 billion from $2.28 billion in 1999. But profit fell to $80 million, or $1.17 a share, compared with $136 million, or $1.83 a share, in 1999, excluding one-time gains. Analysts were expecting US Airways to earn $1.36 a share.
Passenger demand was strong at the airline, which agreed in May to be acquired by UAL for $4.3 billion, but it was hurt more by the rise in the cost of fuel than were United and American. US Airways said that its fuel costs rose nearly 63 percent during the quarter, or $102 million, whereas American said its fuel costs rose only 37 percent. In addition, US Airways lost some lucrative business passengers who shied away from the airline because of the threat of a strike by its flight attendants.
Rakesh Gangwal, the chief executive of US Airways, told analysts that the airline was focusing on winning back business travelers. But he predicted a further decline in unit revenue in the third quarter and another hit from higher fuel costs.
T.W.A. also had record traffic during the quarter. Revenue rose 10.3 percent, to $954.9 million from $866 million. But the struggling airline, which does not aggressively hedge its fuel costs, was still in the red. T.W.A. said that it lost $4.2 million, or 8 cents a share, compared with a loss of $5.3 million, or 17 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Still, analysts had expected the airline to lose 33 cents a share during the quarter.
T.W.A.'s last profitable quarter was two years ago.

HEADLINE: Higher Fuel-Product Prices Barely Affecting Consumers

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
Facing higher fuel prices, motorists are guzzling less gas -- but only slightly less.
The American Petroleum Institute said today that deliveries of gasoline in the first half of 2000 were down about 0.7 percent, ending a long period of growth. Deliveries in 1999 ran 2 percent ahead of 1998, which itself was 3 percent ahead of 1997. The industry group reported a similar drop in use of all oil-based fuels, which went down 0.8 percent, the first decline in five years of economic expansion. 
 The data also showed that supplies of home heating oil were far lower than usual, but Bill Richardson, the energy secretary, said today that he was making progress toward establishing a reserve of heating oil in the Northeast.
The data from the industry group showed that despite the fact that prices have risen nationally by 60 or 70 cents a gallon, and more in the Midwest, the effect on consumption was small.
And for some consumers, it is accomplished with minor lifestyle adjustments.
Dennis Virag, an automotive consultant who commutes 40 miles each way from his home in Toledo, Ohio, to his job in Ann Arbor, Mich., said in an interview that he now sets the cruise control on his Mercury Villager minivan to 72 miles an hour instead of 80.
He figures that the change costs him about five minutes and saves him about 5 percent of the four gallons he needs for his daily commute.
Other drivers must be slowing down, too, he said: "I was keeping up with traffic in the past, and I'm keeping up with traffic now."
Experts expect that few people will make radical changes. At the National Automobile Dealers Association, Paul C. Taylor, the chief economist, said that a family planning a 2,500-mile driving vacation in a midsize S.U.V., like a Chevy Blazer or a Ford Explorer, rated at 20 miles a gallon, would use 125 gallons. If the price of fuel this summer is 50 cents higher than last, that would cost an extra $62.50. "That's about two stops at a fast-food restaurant for a family of five," he said.
At the American Automobile Association, Geoff Sundstrom, a spokesman, said, "We've predicted record summer travel." And as for everyday travel, he said, "For most people, driving is not an optional activity."
"This notion that people are just sort of driving aimlessly around in their car, and when gas prices go up they can stop driving, is quite mistaken," Mr. Sundstrom said.
The drop of 0.7 percent since last year does imply a significant choice for conservation, though, because the number of vehicles is rising by about 4 million a year, reaching 209.5 million motor vehicles at the end of last year.
In contrast to gasoline, deliveries of residual oil, used by industries that can often substitute natural gas if that is cheaper, declined by 17 percent in the first half of the year, the petroleum association said. Deliveries of jet fuel rose, pushed up by robust air traffic. And domestic oil production continued to decline, hitting a 50-year low, despite a tripling of crude oil prices, to the range of $34 a barrel recently, compared with around $10 last year.
The industry group also said that heating oil inventories were sharply lower now than at this time last year, but they said that the significance of this to prices this winter was not clear, because more than 90 percent of heating oil used in a winter comes from production during the winter.
About 40 industry executives met with the Mr. Richardson this afternoon to discuss heating oil and the two-million-barrel reserve that President Clinton ordered the agency to create earlier this month.
Red Cavaney, the president of the petroleum institute, said that the reserve might make no difference in total supplies, because its existence would dissuade private businesses from stockpiling fuel.
"They see no upside, recognizing that the government is probably going to sell it off at some point," he said.
But Mr. Richardson said, "I believe I've convinced them that it's for emergency purposes only, and that we have no intentions of using it to manipulate prices or discourage them from increasing their inventories."
"The government doesn't want to be in the heating oil business." he continued, "all we want to be able to do is respond in the event of a shortage or a severe price spike."
Energy department officials said that the reserve was too small to discourage private inventory-building. They said there was lots of surplus tank space in the Northeast, which they would lease for heating oil storage, bartering for the lease, and for the heating oil itself, with crude oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve on the gulf coast.

HEADLINE: Citigroup and Chase Post Earnings That Exceed Expectations

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN

 BODY:
Citigroup, the biggest financial services company, earned more than $3 billion for the second consecutive quarter, despite a sharp drop in the performance of its Salomon Smith Barney securities unit. At Chase Manhattan Bank, the No. 3 United States bank, the drag on earnings came from its investments in private companies.
Both companies reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that were higher than a year earlier and exceeded analysts expectations. Citigroup shares rose $1.3125, to $68, on the news, while Chase shares slipped 25 cents, to $50.6875. 
 Strong growth in its consumer businesses around the world helped Citigroup increase its net income 23 percent, to $3.005 billion, or 87 cents a diluted share, from $2.45 billion, or 70 cents a diluted share, in the second quarter of 1999. That profit was down significantly from Citigroup's first-quarter profit of $3.6 billion, which was the biggest quarterly profit any company has reported, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. Analysts expected earnings of 83 cents a share.
Earnings at the Salomon unit were down 33 percent from the first quarter and up just 5 percent from the period a year earlier, at $641 million. Salomon was hurt by the downturn in stock market activity and a slowing in bond trading, caused in part by rising interest rates.
Sanford I. Weill, Citigroup's chairman and chief executive, noted that the Smith Barney brokerage unit took in $24 billion in new money from United States customers in the quarter, surpassing the $11 billion its bigger rival, Merrill Lynch, reported.
"Looking at what some of our competitors did, relative to the size of our sales force, we did excellent," Mr. Weill said.
Unlike Merrill, which said this week that it would cut 1,800 jobs in its brokerage unit, Smith Barney has no layoffs planned, Mr. Weill said. "We run a very efficient retail brokerage business," he said. "We like to run it on a steady-as-you-go basis."
Mr. Weill said that rising interest rates had not posed a problem for Citigroup's consumer lending businesses. "We continue to see in the U.S. very strong credit quality trends with delinquencies continuing to decline," he said. "Writeoffs are at the lowest level in five years."
Citigroup said it would split its shares on a 4-for-3 basis next month.
A few blocks away at Chase headquarters, executives sounded upbeat even though Chase's earnings fell 22 percent, to $1.09 billion, or 85 cents a diluted share, from $1.39 billion, or $1.06 a diluted share, a year earlier. Excluding one-time charges, Chase earned 95 cents a share, beating analysts estimates by 12 cents.
Chase officials attributed most of the decline in profit to the falling value of its private equity investments. Chase had private equity gains of just $298 million, down from $513 million a year earlier.
"That's a real reassuring number that showed that even in a tough, dislocated market, they can protect their reported earnings," said Judah Kraushaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch.
Investors are more concerned about the bank's expenses rising faster than its revenue, Mr. Kraushaar said. Chase has spent a lot of money hiring people and buying companies to add heft to its investment banking business and, he said, the "question for investors is can they stay on top of the investments and turn it around quickly?"
Marc Shapiro, Chase's vice chairman, tried to reassure investors that spending would not outpace revenue growth for long.
"We don't have what I call a field-of-dreams strategy that says we will spend all of this money and hope that one day the revenues will come in and pay for it," he said. "We intend to pay for things on a pay-as-you-go basis."

HEADLINE: Clinton the Broker Puts the Other Summit on Hold

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
Bill Clinton today was a president caught between two summit meetings, one in Camp David dealing with the oldest and thorniest problems in diplomacy, the other in Japan approaching the newest and vaguest issues of global inequity.
The meeting on the Maryland mountaintop was grueling, but Mr. Clinton was not going to leave while there was even a glimmer of hope that he might achieve a legacy-enhancing breakthrough in the pursuit of Middle East peace. 
 And for him, the Group of 8 meeting in Okinawa, in southern Japan, has less to recommend it -- save for the fact that he would be the star and the issues, from bringing the Internet to developing nations to funding a global battle against AIDS, resonate with the themes he has tried to place on the international agenda.
Mr. Clinton's mind this week has clearly been on the older issues, not the newer ones he came to office promising to tackle. In fact, he has yet to be briefed on his role at the meeting beginning on Friday of leaders of seven leading industrialized nations, and with Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers preceded Mr. Clinton to Japan to warm the president's seat and reassure the Japanese that he would be there eventually. Traveling with him was the chief person organizing the American part in the talks, Lael Brainard, who was to have briefed Mr. Clinton on Air Force One.
"So we'll wing it," one White House official said.
Meetings of the group are notoriously disjointed, but the agenda for this session is particularly scattered.
Leaders will discuss the "digital divide" between those nations taking advantage of the information revolution and those that are not; coordinated approaches to the spread of AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria; and even a United States-backed proposal to create an international school lunch program.
"You can't say the issues are unimportant, but they are a laundry list and some of them don't meet my criteria for being the top global concerns," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics.
Two years ago, for example, the leaders promised to focus on remaking the international financial system until safeguards were in place to prevent another economic crisis like the one that struck Asia in 1997 from radiating around world markets.
But a recovery shortened the group's collective memory, and while modest progress has been made, one would have to dig far into the fine print to find that discussion on this year's agenda.
On the national security front, the meeting will grapple with more standard issues -- terrorism, the spread of nuclear weapons, turmoil in Africa, Chechnya and the Balkans. But those conversations tend to be as scripted as the summit communique, a reason that Mr. Clinton appeared far less eager to meet his fellow leaders than to play out his role as potential Middle East peacemaker.
That forced Mr. Clinton to postpone a meeting with the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, whose days are considered numbered because of his party's poor showing in an election last month.
But Mr. Clinton also skipped one of the unique aspects of this meeting -- a gathering of the leaders of developing countries such as Algeria, Nigeria, South Africa and Thailand, all of whom have long complained that they are excluded from the elite club of large economies. Mr. Summers will see them instead, but the smaller nations are bound to view Mr. Clinton's no-show as a snub.
Mr. Clinton plans to hold meetings with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and a session with Mr. Putin that is expected to address Mr. Clinton's looming decision on a national missile defense system.
"The president, I'm sure, will want to take advantage of having the leaders there to discuss the issues that are facing him," said James Steinberg, deputy national security adviser. "I think that he will indicate that he is going to take into account the concerns that have been addressed," particularly "four basic variables of cost, threat, technical feasibility and the impact on overall security."
Mr. Clinton's late arrival shows how much has changed since his first step into global diplomacy, also in Japan. It was July 1993, and world leaders took turns beating up on Mr. Clinton for the size of the American budget deficit and Washington's failure to stabilize the world economy.
This time, America's economy is supreme and Mr. Clinton arrives as the indispensable peacemaker.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan and U.S. Reach Trade Pact on Telecommunications

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 19

 BODY:
With its ownership of nearly all telephone lines that go into Japan's homes and businesses, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone has long enjoyed a virtual monopoly in this country. Today, however, a United States-Japanese trade agreement was reached that would likely make telecommunications services in Japan far more affordable, competitive and diverse.
The agreement came after nine days of intense negotiations and averted a major trade battle between Japan and the United States on the eve of a global summit the Japanese are hosting. American trade officials, who have been pressing loudly for increased access to the $140 billion Japanese market, called it a huge victory. 
 Its central feature is cuts in the fees that N.T.T. charges other telecommunications companies to use its domestic network, which covers 98 percent of the lines to all customers.
For other telephone companies, the agreement will lower the costs of linking up with N.T.T. by an average of 35 percent in two years and by at least 40 percent over three years, said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative.
Those charges have been consuming roughly 40 percent of the revenue of N.T.T.'s competitors stifling competition to provide telecommunications services in the world's second-largest economy.
"Japan has been placing a tax on the information age by the way it regulates N.T.T.," said Richard W. Fisher, Mrs. Barshefsky's deputy, in an interview. "It's therefore a tax on competition, and that tax is going to come down substantially now."
While Japanese officials said the agreement was only modestly different from a proposal they had made in January, their American counterparts noted that it provided for significantly deeper cuts than the 17 percent reduction Japan had offered previously. The agreement also accelerates the timing of the cuts so they mostly happen over two years instead of Japan's original offer of five years.
Perhaps more important, Japan agreed to reconsider its methods of setting the fees paid by N.T.T.'s competitors to use its network, which should have a more widespread effect on reducing fees and enhancing competition in 2002 and thereafter. But perhaps the most significant element of the deal is how it came together. That process ruptured longstanding relationships between regulators and politicians and N.T.T., and those rifts may lead to sweeping changes in regulatory structure here and in the structure of N.T.T. itself.
"By how many percent interconnection fees are cut and whether it takes place over two or three years is not really very important," said Harumasa Sato, a professor at Konan University in Kobe and a telecommunications policy expert. "The important thing is that it may lead to fundamental reform of regulation that will create fair competition in this market."
The broader scope of the agreement came about in part because of the way the United States trade representative's office fought for it. United States negotiators moved the debate out of the confines of the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, which regulates telecommunications, and into a broader public view.
Thus, while past United States-Japanese trade fights over issues like film distribution, car parts and flat glass had failed to capture the imagination of ordinary citizens, the public took a major interest in this fight, and Japanese politicians noticed.
Mr. Fisher embarked on a calculated campaign to make the issue relevant to consumers in Japan, doing numerous interviews with the Japanese media, using easily understood examples of why high connection fees hurt Japan's prosperity.
He repeatedly bemoaned that only 10 percent of Japanese elementary and middle school students could connect to the Internet because charges were so high. He asked why his daughter paid less than $9 a month for Internet service in the United States while her Japanese friend in Tokyo paid eight times that amount.
"Why should a Japanese girl be at such a disadvantage to an American girl?" he asked over and over again.
He made his case, apparently, because, with the exception of only one newspaper known for its strong conservative editorial view, Japan's major dailies all supported sharp reductions in connection fees.
Japanese industry also spoke out. The business federation known as Keidanren, which represents Japan's giant, blue-chip organizations, argued for lower connection fees, and Hiroshi Mikitani, the founder and president of Japan's biggest e-commerce site, Rakuten Ichiba, commissioned a study about the impact of the fees on Japan's ability to harness the information technology revolution, which he then personally used to advocate lower charges.
N.T.T.'s Japanese competitors weighed in on the side of lower rates, as did European and American companies attempting to break into the market. Even some of the companies under the N.T.T. umbrella, which also pay fees for connecting with the lines owned by the regional telephone companies that are their cousins, complained.
The concerted effort worked, and around the beginning of the year, influential politicians began to question the postal ministry's arguments for only modest reductions in the connection fees.
Mindful that its position on fees was now politically unacceptable, N.T.T. officials offered to accede to United States demands in exchange for pledges from sympathetic politicians that they would work to abolish the N.T.T. Law, which restricts the company from entering other types of businesses.
That proposal appealed to Hiromu Nonaka, who is perhaps the most powerful politician in Japan and the secretary general of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. Among his many roles, Mr. Nonaka serves as the leader of a large group of politicians with strong ties to the postal ministry and to N.T.T.
And in the end, Mr. Fisher said, it was Mr. Nonaka who struck the deal on connection fees that emerged today. Mr. Fisher said the breakthrough came when Mr. Nonaka invited him and other United States officials, including Ambassador Thomas Foley, to a Tuesday morning meeting. It began with a 20-minute monologue by Mr. Nonaka on the role that telecommunications plays in a modern economy.
"He gave me a very erudite and extremely thorough discussion about how Japan needed to come into the I.T. age and needed to restructure N.T.T. to do that," Mr. Fisher said.
One hour after the meeting ended, Mr. Fisher said, the postal ministry called the embassy and asked for a meeting that resulted in the agreement.
