SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 34; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1225 words

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
When Horses Could Roam The Heavens

BYLINE: By Wendy Moonan 

 BODY:
The Scythians, the fierce nomadic tribes of Central Asia that swept as far west as the Danube from the eighth to the fourth century B.C., did not limit themselves to plundering Europe. Skilled horsemen, they rampaged across ancient Eurasia as far east as China. "Their country is the back of a horse," Herodotus wrote.
The Chinese did not like what was happening. "The Chinese finally realized that those who controlled the cavalry controlled the world," said Jim Lally, a Manhattan dealer in Chinese art. "It was a whole new technology." So they formed their own mounted cavalry. 
 "The most important Chinese appropriation from its nomadic neighbors was horseback riding and mounted warfare," said Bill Cooke, director of the International Museum of the Horse at the Kentucky Horse Park in Lexington, Ky. So, Mr. Cooke said, "to explore the significance of the horse in the unification of China and in the exchange of culture with the Western world along the Silk Road," he organized "Imperial China: The Art of the Horse in Chinese History." The exhibition runs through Aug. 31.
Four years in the planning, it is one of the largest shows of Chinese artifacts ever seen in the United States. It includes more than 350 artifacts valued at $100 million, with terra cotta tomb sculptures, a reconstructed chariot with its original bronze fittings from about 200 B.C., horses in carved jade, gilded bronze and porcelain, and colorful scroll paintings.
By 307 B.C., Bill Cooke said, King Wu Ling of the State of Zhao, near the present-day northern border of China, issued an imperial decree that soldiers stop wearing their long robes and adopt nomadic dress so they could ride astride in battle just like their enemies. The soldiers protected their homeland, and before long the horse became an object of great affection in Chinese culture.
In fact, the horse has had a special place in China's social, religious, economic and military life ever since the Chinese domesticated it for meat, milk and hides about 3000 B.C. "Throughout China's long and storied past, no animal has impacted its history as greatly as the horse," Mr. Cooke said.
The Chinese believed the "heavenly horse," like the dragon, was capable of flight, even of carrying his rider to the "home of the immortals" in the next world. The noble horse inspired ancient philosophers, poets, writers and artists.
Although the Chinese were not the first to ride horses, they are credited with perfecting two of the most significant inventions in terms of world history: the harness and the stirrup, which ultimately became as important as China's two other fabled creations, paper and gunpowder.
In the exhibition are some of the earliest life-size sculptures of Chinese horses and their riders. Excavated from a tomb in Shaanxi province in 1977, a cavalryman and his horse are part of the terra cotta army commissioned for the tombs of the Qin dynasty (221 to 207 B.C.). The unglazed horse is saddled up, with studs and tassel decorating his saddle. His master leads him by the reins. The cavalryman wears a tight cap, a short robe, an armored vest, tight trousers and boots. The duo is among 116 cavalrymen and horses discovered in the same excavation.
By the time of the Han dynasty (206 B.C. to A.D. 220), Chinese emperors realized the need to import horses of superior stock to beat back the barbarians' ever more daring raids. "China's very survival relied on its equestrian prowess," Mr. Cooke writes.
Obtaining better horses by importing them was not easy, however. In the second century B.C., Emperor Han Wudi sent an expedition to Turkmenistan (then called Ferghana) to buy that region's prized Akhal-Teke, an ancient Eurasian breed of desert horse that was tall, fast, strong and required little food or water. (It is thought to be the forerunner of the English thoroughbred.) The Chinese called them "horse of heaven" or the "thousand-li" -- that is, a horse that could run 1,000 li -- a li is about a third of a mile -- without tiring.
The ruler of Ferghana refused to sell his horses and killed the envoys. The emperor decided to take the horses by force. He sent 6,000 cavalrymen and 20,000 soldiers to Ferghana. The campaign was a disaster. Half the force died in the mountains and deserts en route; the rest were badly defeated in battle. They straggled home two years later, only to face a furious emperor.
Undaunted, the emperor decided to send yet a larger army. As Mr. Cooke explained, this expeditionary force of 60,000 soldiers and 30,000 horses went West with a herd of 100,000 cattle to sustain them.
After a 40-day siege of Ferghana, the Chinese collected 3,000 horses, 2,000 of which perished on the return journey. It turned out that only 50 of the captured horses were of the prized breed.
Nonetheless, the subjugation of Ferghana persuaded other tribes to cooperate with the Han rulers, ultimately resulting in the opening of the Silk Road. Thereafter, the Chinese traded silk and tea for horses.
The artistic depictions of horses most associated with China are the magnificent terra cotta horses of the Tang dynasty (A.D. 618 to 907), which remain treasured works of art in the West today.(The record price for one is $6.1 million at Sotheby's London in December 1989.)
To the Tang, the horse was not only a military necessity but also a status symbol. The Tang used horses for battle, hunting, dressage and polo. Women were allowed to ride. One particularly charming figure in the show is a painted female tomb figure on horseback. She sports a wide-brimmed black hat and a red flowered jacket. Her yellow horse has a red mane and red spots like a modern appaloosa.
"For the Chinese, who were a sedentary civilization, the horse was a source of joy and pleasure," Mr. Lally said.
Asked about another Tang horse with a female rider in the exhibition, this one glazed in rare blue as well as green and gold, Mr. Lally said: "The flying-hooves stance is unusual. These horses are from the great artistic center Xian, which was to Tang China what Paris was to Napoleonic France." Xian is near the site of the terra cotta army.
Torkom Demirjian, director of the Ariadne Galleries in Manhattan, pointed out the quality of the Chinese bronze horse trappings in the show. Mr. Demirjian sells some Tang horses, but he is a specialist in Scythian and Thraco-Scythian objects, including horse trappings. He noted the similarities, saying, "The Chinese had extensive relations with these nomadic peoples long before we think they did." He is so impressed with the workmanship of his gold Scythian horse and chariot trappings that he is taking them to Paris to sell at the Biennale des Antiquaires in September.
Mr. Cooke said 80,000 people had visited the Kentucky exhibition since it opened on May 1. He said arrangements with Chinese officials have been problem-free from the start. When he first went to China to discuss doing a show, he was introduced to Zhang Ting Hao, director general of the Administrative Bureau of Museums and Archaeological Data of Shaanxi province, at a banquet. He told Mr. Zhang his ideas, and Mr. Zhang replied that he had written his master's thesis on the role of the horse in Chinese history. "That was it," Mr. Cooke recalled. "In 24 hours, we went from an idea to a 10,000-square-foot installation.'

HEADLINE: Earnings at Gillette Were Up 2.1% in the Second Quarter

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 20

 BODY:
Gillette, the world's largest maker of razors, said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 2.1 percent on increased sales of its Mach 3 blades in the United States.
Profit from continuing operations rose to $296 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with $290 million, or 25 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 2 percent, to $2.25 billion from $2.21 billion. 
 The results matched analysts' estimates, according to First Call/ Thomson Financial.
Gillette, which also makes of Duracell batteries and Right Guard deodorant, said it was continuing talks to sell its Paper Mate, Waterman and Parker pens' business to Newell Rubbermaid. Shares of Gillette had declined after the company said it would retain its Braun appliance unit. Gillette declined to say whether it had received any offers for Braun. In the latest quarter, Braun's profit more than doubled, while sales rose 11 percent.
A loss of $427 million, or 41 cents a share, from the pens' business, which Gillette listed as a discontinued operation, resulted in a net loss of $131 million, or 13 cents a diluted share. In the quarter a year earlier, profit from the pens' business of $10 million, or a penny a share, resulted in net income of $300 million, or 26 cents a share.
Gillette fell $1, to $32.3125.
Gillette warned in May that sales would be only slightly higher than those in the period a year earlier because of the euro's 11 percent drop against the dollar the last year. Gillette has been hurt the last two years by slowing economies and currency declines in Asia, Latin America and Europe.
Sales of razors and blades, Gillette's biggest business, which accounts for most of its profit, rose 8 percent in the quarter on higher Mach 3 sales in Europe and North America.

HEADLINE: Higher Rates Are Slowing Housing Starts

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Housing construction fell to its lowest level in more than two years last month, responding to the Federal Reserve's string of interest rate increases, government figures showed today.
Builders began work on new homes at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.55 million units in June, down 3 percent from the level in May, the Commerce Department reported. The rate last month was down 1 percent from the June 1999 rate of 1.56 million units. 
 The decline left housing starts at their lowest level since May 1998, when the seasonally adjusted annual rate was 1.54 million units.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that it was inevitable that home building, which is highly sensitive to interest rates, would markedly slow down.
"There is no way to avoid the fact that we have ups and downs" in the housing market, Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee as he presented the central bank's midyear economic report to Congress. "It was inevitable, in my judgment, for housing to quite considerably slow down."
The housing market has been an engine of the vibrant economy. Even with higher interest rates, activity has remained healthy.
The Fed's rate increases are intended to slow the economy gradually to a pace that the central bank regards as more likely to be sustained without igniting inflation -- a rate between 3.5 and 4 percent. In the first quarter of the year, the economy grew at a 5.4 percent rate.
In a second government report, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing claims for unemployment benefits last week fell 9,000, to 311,000.
The housing report showed that new building permits -- a barometer of future activity -- for single-family homes fell to a rate of 1.11 million, down 3 percent from May and the lowest level since December 1997.
New building permits for all types of housing were unchanged in June at 1.51 million, suggesting that future construction activity may slow.

HEADLINE: Easing Back on Tax Cuts

 BODY:
No longer campaigning for the Senate, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani now seems to be directing his full public energies to running New York City. Such renewed focus could bode well for the city's fiscal stability. The mayor who once said he loves cutting taxes, a particularly good stance for a Republican candidate, has now said that he needs to scale back this year's promised tax cuts. A look at the city's potential deficits shows that he is on the right track.
Mr. Giuliani argues that the budgetary equation has changed since he proposed in January to eliminate the city's personal income tax surcharge. He says that state legislators, eyeing the city's fat surplus during an election year, have made expensive demands about how the city must use it. But if the State Legislature was up to more than its usual mischief, the city's rate of spending growth is also more than twice the rate of inflation. Moreover, the city's borrowing has increased so much that the state had to raise its approved debt ceiling. With such strains on the city's budget, Mayor Giuliani should also consider ways of paying down the municipal debt as part of his effort to scale back future deficits. 
 The mayor should not be swayed by those Democrats who suggest that his revenue estimates are too conservative, thus making the projected deficits unreasonably large. Mr. Giuliani put it well when he addressed the New York State Financial Control Board on Wednesday. Tinkering with the numbers, he said, would be "a dangerous game." At present, his administration estimates unusually large budget deficits and lower revenue estimates that, in effect, presume a dip in the city's current boom-time fortunes.
To cut these deficits, the mayor wants to stall or skip the tax cuts, including those negotiated with the City Council and the Legislature. He also plans a hiring freeze. Both moves represent fiscal responsibility, as long as crucial city services are not reduced. The mayor says that when he leaves office after next year, he wants the city to be in better financial shape than it was when he arrived in 1994. That is a sound objective.

HEADLINE: Take the Marines Off Okinawa

BYLINE: By Jacob Heilbrunn; Jacob Heilbrunn writes often about American foreign policy.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Clinton's arrival in Okinawa today for the Group of 8 meeting of big industrial nations calls attention to something beyond the international economic issues that the leaders there will discuss: the debate about whether the time has come to end the American military presence on Okinawa.
The Okinawans who have used the visit of the world leaders as a stage for demonstrating in favor of American withdrawal are protesting acts like a hit-and-run incident involving an Air Force staff sergeant and the molestation of a 14-year-old Okinawan girl in which a marine was accused. The Japanese government, however, shows no interest in a removal of the Americans, because Japan's defenses are bolstered by the American base. 
 In the United States, however, the issue is most often framed as a debate between isolationists who want us to get out of Asia and champions of maintaining our presence in Okinawa as a sign of American resolve in that part of the world. Both have it wrong. The United States can afford to pull its troops out of Okinawa with no loss of our commitment to Asian security. In fact, America's position would be enhanced.
A decade after the fall of the Soviet Union, the challenges to America in Asia are a Chinese military buildup, the China-Taiwan conflict and North Korea. Yet in Okinawa, 20,000 marines remain as a relic of the cold war.
Supporters of the status quo argue that the marines on Okinawa could help move supplies in the event of a war in Korea or Taiwan and that they provide ready reinforcements for possible rapid deployment to other regions, like the Persian Gulf. The Clinton administration codified this consensus in the 1995 Nye report, when it declared that America would keep a minimum of 100,000 troops in Asia until at least 2015, explicitly including the 20,000 on Okinawa in that total.
The truth is that the United States can not only retain but improve upon these goals by removing its forces from Okinawa. Over the past decade the Pentagon has been moving toward a new strategy based on getting American troops to global hot spots by sea and air, a strategy known as maritime pre-positioning force. International seas offer complete and expeditious freedom of movement, and the Marines already have the equivalent of a division stationed on ships around the globe. The Navy is also working to improve the replenishment of ships already at sea with missiles, cannon rounds, bullets and fuel. The marines in Okinawa might be redeployed to bolster this strategy.
There are disadvantages, after all, in keeping them where they are. Okinawa is what is known as an unaccompanied tour, which means the marines cannot bring their wives. The small Okinawa base also has no room for large-scale battle training.
More fundamentally, as the military expert Paul Bracken points out in his recent book, "Fire in the East," maintaining a string of bases in Asia has rendered the American military dangerously vulnerable to chemical and ballistic missile attacks. The United States, he says, needs to restructure the military to allow it to operate at greater distances from home and become "less reliant on vulnerable forward bases."
One step would be to shift the basing of fleets so that destroyers can remain permanently stationed in the Pacific rather than trundling to and from the West Coast. Facilities in Japan are already being built up, Guam could be expanded, and most intriguingly, Vietnam might be willing to consider leasing Cam Ranh Bay back to the United States, especially as it fears growing Chinese military strength.
In an era of tight military budgets and limited manpower, such measures would improve the speed with which American firepower can reach Asia, and they would have none of Okinawa's drawbacks. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Federal Reserve Chairman's Testimony

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, presented his report on monetary policy to the Senate Banking Committee yesterday. Following are excerpts:
For some time now, the growth of aggregate demand has exceeded the expansion of production potential. Technological innovations have boosted the growth rate of potential, but as I noted in my testimony last February, the effects of this process also have spurred aggregate demand. It has been clear to us that, with labor markets already quite tight, a continuing disparity between the growth of demand and potential supply would produce disruptive imbalances. 
 A key element in this disparity has been the very rapid growth of consumption resulting from the effects on spending of the remarkable rise in household wealth. However, the growth in household spending has slowed noticeably this spring from the unusually rapid pace observed late in 1999 and early this year.
Some argue that this slowing is a pause following the surge in demand through the warmer-than-normal winter months and hence a reacceleration can be expected later this year. Certainly, we have seen slowdowns in spending during this near-decade-long expansion that have proven temporary, with aggregate demand growth subsequently rebounding to an unsustainable pace.
But other analysts point to a number of factors that may be exerting more persistent restraint on spending. One they cite is the flattening in equity prices, on net, this year. They attribute much of the slowing of consumer spending to this diminution of the wealth effect through the spring and early summer. This view looks to equity markets as a key influence on the trend in consumer spending over the rest of this year and next.
Another factor said by some to account for the spending slowdown is the rising debt burden of households. Interest and amortization as a percent of disposable income have risen materially during the past six years, as consumer and especially mortgage debt has climbed and, more recently, as interest rates have moved higher.
In addition, the past year's rise in the price of oil has amounted to an annual $75 billion levy by foreign producers on domestic consumers of imported oil, the equivalent of a tax of roughly 1 percent of disposable income. This burden is another likely source of the slowed growth in real consumption outlays in recent months, though one that may prove to be largely transitory.
Mentioned less prominently have been the effects of the faster increase in the stock of consumer durable assets -- both household durable goods and houses -- in the last several years, a rate of increase that history tells us is usually followed by a pause. . . .
Because the softness in outlay growth is so recent, all of the aforementioned hypotheses, of course, must be provisional. It is certainly premature to make a definitive assessment of either the recent trends in household spending or what they mean. But it is clear that, for the time being at least, the increase in spending on consumer goods and houses has come down several notches, albeit from very high levels.
In one sense, the more important question for the longer-term economic outlook is the extent of any productivity slowdown that might accompany a more subdued pace of production and consumer spending, should it persist. . . .
To be sure, if current personal consumption outlays slow significantly further than the pattern now in train suggests, profit and sales expectations might be scaled back, possibly inducing some hesitancy in moving forward even with capital projects that appear quite profitable over the longer run. In addition, the direct negative effects of the sharp recent runup in energy prices on profits as well as on sales expectations may temporarily damp capital spending. . . .
As I have already noted, to date costs have been held in check by productivity gains. But at the same time, inflation has picked up -- even the core measures that do not include energy prices directly. Higher rates of core inflation may mostly reflect the indirect effects of energy prices, but the Federal Reserve will need to be alert to the risks that high levels of resource utilization may put upward pressure on inflation. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Investors Weed Out Thorns From Greenspan's Message

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Are investors looking at Alan Greenspan through rose-colored glasses?
They may have done just that yesterday, focusing on all the positives of the testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman before the Senate Banking Committee and sending stock and bond prices sharply higher and interest rates lower. 
 The Nasdaq composite index jumped 3.2 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.4 percent, led by a 12 percent surge in I.B.M. after it reported strong second-quarter profits late on Wednesday.
What investors and analysts saw, to their surprise, was Mr. Greenspan offering encouragement for the view that the central bank would be able to slow economic growth enough to contain inflation, without risking a recession and, possibly, without any more interest rate increases.
"What has captured the markets' attention here is that Greenspan has raised the possibility that the Fed is done," said Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates.
Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said the Fed's aggressive stance of last spring had mellowed. "The tone is one of a Fed that is going to be in a watchful, waiting mode, but doesn't see any catalyst for acting," he said.
But investors may be too optimistic, and this could trip up markets in the days ahead, when the euphoria created by a mellow Alan Greenspan wears off.
First, even some Wall Street analysts who were surprised by Mr. Greenspan's optimism still say more Fed rate increases will be needed in the future to finally slow economic growth to a manageable, noninflationary pace.
While the chances of a rate increase in late August, when Fed policy makers next meet, are diminishing, Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, expects at least one more rate rise before the central bank is finished.
But there may be an even bigger problem lurking for investors if Mr. Greenspan's remarks bring a lot of bulls back to the stock and bond markets. Strong rallies in both markets, on the belief that the worst of a yearlong series of Fed increases is over, could make slowing economic growth much more difficult and require more increases than now expected. Stocks rising to new highs could set off a burst of consumer spending -- through what is known as the wealth effect -- of the kind that has reignited economic growth the last several years. Declining interest rates will help spur both businesses and consumers.
"If we were to rally 15 percent or 20 percent from here, that would negate some of the Fed's tightening pressure," Mr. Berner said.
Because of this threat to a successful slowdown, or soft landing, "most of us didn't expect him to be this market-friendly," Mr. Crandall said. "This was the surprise."
Mr. Greenspan also warned that a soft landing for the economy was not assured. But that message seemed to be drowned out yesterday by the market applause for Mr. Greenspan's unexpected optimism.
In the stock market, the Nasdaq index jumped 128.93 points, to 4,184.56, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 13.61, or 0.9 percent, to 1,495.57. The Dow rose 147.79, to 10,843.87. I.B.M., which had announced a 12 percent earnings gain, accounted for half the Dow's rise. I.B.M. rallied in after-hours trading on Wednesday, but that did not show up in the Dow until yesterday, when the stock rose $12.84, to $117.
In the bond market, prices were higher as yields, which move in the opposite direction, fell. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note fell to 6 percent, from 6.15 percent on Wednesday, while the price rose 1 3/32, to 103 19/32. The yield on the 10-year note has been fighting to move back below 6 percent for five weeks. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.81 percent from 5.91 percent.
One significant monitor of concern about Fed rate increases did ease yesterday. The yield fell on the futures contracts on the federal funds rate, the central bank's short-term interest rate target, for August, October, November and December.
In his testimony on monetary policy, Mr. Greenspan pointed out several factors restraining consumer spending, including rising consumer debt, rising oil and gasoline prices and the flat performance of the stock market so far this year. And he said that this consumer slowdown, if it continued, might be enough to bring economic growth down to the noninflationary pace Fed officials want. That is somewhere around 3.5 percent, well below the 6 percent pace of last year's fourth quarter and this year's first.
"Should this favorable outcome prevail," he said, "the immediate threat to our prosperity from growing imbalances in our economy would abate."
But Mr. Greenspan also warned that it was too early to declare victory. "It is much too soon," he said, "to conclude that these concerns are behind us. We cannot yet be sure that slower expansion of domestic final demand, at a pace more in line with potential supply, will persist."
In past years, the economy has reaccelerated after slowing in the second quarter, a fact that Mr. Greenspan mentioned. The next key economic report is the Employment Cost Index, which measures worker compensation and is one of the Fed's favorite inflation barometers. It will be released Thursday.
The next several days ought to indicate if investors have become Fed-happy. The stock and bond markets have often responded nicely on the day some positive news is released, only to settle back after investors realize that they -- and the Fed -- still need to see more positive data before they know they are out of the woods. But if investors conclude too early that they are out of the woods, their optimism, and the rallies it creates, may put them back in again.

HEADLINE: The Fed Chief's Treatment;
Slower Growth, but Don't Rule Out Rate Increases

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that there was not yet enough evidence to conclude that the economy had slowed to a noninflationary pace, and he left the door open to further interest rate increases as soon as next month.
In testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan delivered an on-the-one-hand, on-the-other-hand assessment of the economic outlook, noting clear signs of slowing in recent months but warning that growth could rebound and that inflation by some measures appeared to be creeping up. 
 Given the uncertainties, Mr. Greenspan said, it was "much too soon to conclude" that the threat of a destabilizing surge in prices and wages had receded. His remarks suggested that Fed officials would continue to focus on incoming economic data before deciding whether to raise short-term interest rates again at their next meeting, on Aug. 22.
Stressing that the economy was still characterized by a combination of steady growth, low unemployment and an expanding trade deficit, he said the Fed would "need to be alert to the risks that high levels of resource utilization may put upward pressure on inflation."
But even as he kept his options open, Mr. Greenspan indicated that he saw no need for a prolonged series of rate increases that might leave the economy flirting with recession. Asked if achieving price stability would require the Fed to drive the unemployment rate up toward 5 percent from its current level of 4 percent, Mr. Greenspan said he did not think so.
"I think the evidence indicating that we need to raise the unemployment rate to stabilize prices is unpersuasive," he said. He quickly added, however, that he was not sure and the issue was the subject of considerable debate among economists and Fed officials.
With much of the steam having gone out of Wall Street in the winter and spring, Mr. Greenspan hardly mentioned the stock market, which he had singled out early this year as a prime source of the imbalances in the economy that could lead to higher inflation.
Investors, perhaps being overoptimistic but apparently relieved that Mr. Greenspan had not explicitly called for higher interest rates, sent stock prices up. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 147.79 points for the day, to finish at 10,843.87. The Nasdaq composite index closed at 4,184.56, up 128.93.
"There was relief in the markets because he said nothing very severe in terms of future rate increases," said Richard J. DeKaser, chief economist at National City Bank in Cleveland. "But in terms of what he actually said, he left his options completely open."
The central bank has raised its benchmark short-term interest rate by 1.75 percentage points, to 6.5 percent, in six steps the last year. After growing at a torrid pace earlier this year, the economy cooled off considerably, but the Fed has left the financial markets guessing whether the slowdown has been sufficient for it to declare an end to this cycle of interest rate increases.
If analysts and investors were hoping for a clear answer from Mr. Greenspan today, they were disappointed. Because his testimony was intended to reflect the thinking of the Fed's entire policy making committee, what they got instead was a glimpse at the debate within the central bank about the economy's path and how many more rate increases, if any, it would take to squelch the emerging inflationary pressures and assure the continuance of the long expansion.
Growth in general and consumer spending in particular have "slowed noticeably this spring from the unusually rapid pace observed late in 1999 and early this year," Mr. Greenspan said.
From one perspective, he said, it would be a mistake to put too much stock in the slowdown, since previous episodes of cooling during this business cycle have been followed by sharp accelerations in growth. But from another viewpoint, he said, there are bits of evidence that this slowdown could be longer-lasting.
The stock market is no longer rising at a rate that would lead consumers to spend freely. Households are burdened by rising debt levels. Higher oil prices are putting the brakes on the entire economy. And after buying homes, cars, refrigerators and other big-ticket items at a prodigious pace for the past several years, consumers could be expected to take a break.
Mr. Greenspan did not say which camp he puts himself in. But he said that the real question might prove to be what happens to the economy's improving efficiency if the slowdown proves to be real, and on that score he gave an optimistic assessment.
In the past, slowdowns in growth were often accompanied by a falloff in the growth rate of productivity, or output per hour of work. As productivity drops, inflation tends to rise, putting pressure on the Fed to continue raising rates.
But if productivity growth should remain strong as the economy slows, it would help keep inflation in check, giving the Fed more leeway to hold down rates. Mr. Greenspan said the evidence is that productivity is holding up well.
"So far there is little evidence to undermine the notion that most of the productivity increase of recent years has been structural and that structural productivity may still be accelerating," he said.
Mr. Greenspan appeared before the banking committee under an agreement that calls for the Fed to continue reporting twice a year to Congress on monetary policy despite the expiration of a legal requirement to do so.
The written report he submitted today forecast a slowdown in growth this year from the 5.4 percent annual pace of the first quarter, with gross domestic product for the year projected to run at 4 to 4.5 percent.
But the report also included a more pessimistic inflation forecast than that the Fed provided to Congress in its last report, in February. It projected that inflation this year would run at a 2.5 percent to 2.75 percent rate, compared with 1.75 percent to 2 percent under the old projection. Although the report said inflation would decline to 2 to 2.5 percent next year, it warned that at those projected levels inflation would have edged up from where it was in 1997 and 1998, when it was consistently under 2 percent.
"Such a trend, were it not to show signs of quickly stabilizing or reversing, would pose a considerable risk to the continuation of the extraordinary economic performance of recent years," the report said.
Fielding questions from senators, Mr. Greenspan repeated his call for Congress and the Clinton administration to use the federal budget surplus for debt reduction rather than for tax cuts or spending increases. The surplus, he said, provides an important buffer should the economy run into trouble.
Asked about the health of the banking system and its ability to weather a recession, Mr. Greenspan said the system could "resist fairly significant economic disruption without a major problem," although he said he was concerned that some banks have grown too lax in assessing credit risks.
The Fed chairman said he was concerned about the expansion of the trade and current account deficits. But he said the United States had not had any problem financing those deficits with investment from abroad because the country offered higher rates of return than anywhere else.
In response to a question, he criticized legislation sponsored by Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee, that would link China's access to American capital markets to the Chinese government's record on the spread of weapons and weapons technology.
In particular, he said, the legislation would be ineffective because capital markets essentially operate without borders and if Chinese companies were unable to raise money in New York, they would be able to borrow in dollars in London or Paris.

HEADLINE: Plywood Air Pollution Case Is Settled for $93.2 Million

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency and the Justice Department announced today that a plywood manufacturer with 13 factories in four states had agreed to a $93.2 million settlement over air pollution violations, the largest settlement based on pollution from factories.
The accord means that the environmental agency has settled pollution cases in the last few years with companies that make up more than half the wood products industry. In a sector-by-sector campaign to enforce the terms of the Clean Air Act, the agency has also reached agreements with diesel engine manufacturers, but it is still battling with refineries and with coal-burning power plants. 
 The settlement with Willamette Industries Inc., a plywood and building materials manufacturer based in Portland, Ore., with plants in Arkansas, Louisiana and South Carolina as well, follows settlements with Louisiana-Pacific, Georgia-Pacific and Weyerhaeuser; the government is still pursuing Boise-Cascade.
In addition to a civil penalty of $11.2 million, Willamette will spend $8 million on environmental projects, and $74 million on new pollution-control equipment, government officials said. Carol M. Browner, the E.P.A. administrator, said that the company had saved money for years by not installing equipment to reduce emissions but that with the settlement, "the economic benefit has been captured in the penalty, and then some."
In a statement, Duane McDougall, the company's chief executive officer, said the company had reached the agreement "to resolve certain historic air permit questions." Willamette will install emission control equipment that is "well beyond what is required," he said.
The E.P.A. says factories that emit pollutants into the air must have permits to make changes in the plants. Ms. Browner said, "These guys didn't even say they needed a permit." Mr. McDougall said that Willamette had consulted with state authorities as it made changes to its factories over the years and had been told that no permits were required but that the environmental agency had "revisited these decisions based on a revised interpretation of long-established standards and practices."
The company's defense is similar to the one still being raised by electric utilities companies that the agency last year accused of not seeking permits for changes they had made to their plants.
Willamette makes plywood and composite panels. The adhesives used to bond sheets of plywood together, or form composites, give off pollutants, volatile organic compounds, that react with nitrogen compounds in sunlight to form smog.
Under the settlement, the company will install equipment to reduce emissions of the compounds, as well as cut emissions of small particles and carbon monoxide. The company will spend money to improve municipal sewer systems, acquire parkland and build ethanol fueling stations to encourage companies that own fleets of vehicles to use clean fuel.

HEADLINE: Plans to Build Paper Recycler In South Bronx Are Called Off

BYLINE: By JUAN FORERO 

 BODY:
From the time the Bronx Community Paper Company was conceived, the paper-recycling venture was viewed as a model of urban manufacturing: an environmentally friendly company that would employ 400 full-time workers and create $200 million a year in revenues in a neighborhood hungry for an economic lift.
After six years of increasingly costly construction estimates, the recycling plant, which would have provided newsprint to the city's newspapers, is now dead, said its developer, Morse Diesel International. 
 "I think we originally were pretty excited about doing a project of this magnitude in New York City, with such a strong publisher base and the close availability of fiber," James MacDonald, development director for the Manhattan company, said yesterday in an interview. But he added, "We had to accept reality, that it couldn't be done in the current market and in the current market conditions."
The news was no surprise to Bronx leaders, who for years had seen plans for the plant falter because of the developer's inability to secure economical financing for the project on 22 acres of the Harlem River Rail Yards on the borough's southern tip. The construction would have cost $400 million, but interest and other costs would have raised the bill to $700 million, company officials said.
The plan, formed by a leading environmental group and the Banana Kelly community development group, also had detractors: some local churches and businesses charged it would increase air pollution.
Morse Diesel and Harlem River Yard Ventures, which manages the 96-acre rail yard for the Galesi Group, the leaseholder on the property, blamed rising interest rates for the project's downfall.
"You're talking about a financing feat that was difficult at best, and the way the bond market was turning it just wasn't feasible," said Anthony Riccio, senior vice president for Harlem River Yard Ventures.
Charles E. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, which had been working with the New York City Economic Development Corporation to provide $300 million in tax-exempt bonds for the project, said company officials also told him this week that a volatile paper market played a role in the decision to kill the plant.
The paper mill was to have been part of what has been promoted as one of the largest industrial projects in New York City in decades, the redevelopment of a once-bustling rail yard abandoned after 1971.
In 1990, Francesco Galesi won a 99-year, tax-free lease from the State Department of Transportation andset out to develop the plot near the Triborough Bridge. Today, a plant to house new presses for The New York Post is being built, and a waste transfer station and a two-mile long rail link are operating.
"The paper mill has sort of been on the railroad tracks for a long time; I guess it couldn't dodge the train this time," said the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer. "This would have been a really good fit, but it was not to be, and it was not to be for a whole host of reasons, not because of someone's intention or actions."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
From Dormant Armory to Middle-Income Rentals

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
An empty wreck of a building since the late 1980's, the Clermont Armory in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has sprung back to life over the last 15 months as a rental apartment complex for middle-income tenants.
When the $14 million rehabilitation project that officials call "adaptive reuse" is completed by September, the 127-year-old former armory at 171 Clermont Avenue, among the oldest in the state, will have 110 studio to three-bedroom units. They will be in two five-story wings atop a one-story base created behind the facades of the original armory and overlooking an interior courtyard. 
 There will be 11,000 square feet of ground-floor commercial space, which has been leased to the Community Partnership Charter School, as well as parking for 113 cars on the ground and basement levels of the huge structure, which stretches from Clermont Avenue through to Vanderbilt Avenue between Myrtle and Willoughby Avenues.
The apartments, averaging 507 to 1,208 square feet, some with balconies, are being leased to people with annual incomes of $30,000 to $80,000, depending on family size, at rents of $850 to $1,750 a month. The project is being developed by a partnership between Hesky Brahimy and his brother, Samy, who are principals of the IBEC Building Corporation, and John Frezza, president of the Strategic Development and Construction Corporation. Both companies are based in Brooklyn, as is the project's architect, Robert Scarano & Associates.
The Clermont Armory project is part of New York City's New Opportunities Program, sponsored by the city's Housing Development Corporation. Under it, the housing corporation provides developers with mortgages at favorable interest rates to help spur construction of middle-income housing.
Since the program began in 1998, 27 projects with 1,900 residences have been or are being created. Eight are in Brooklyn and many, like the Clermont Armory project, are bringing new uses to abandoned buildings. Others include a 100-year-old former furniture warehouse at 139 Emerson Place in Clinton Hill that has been transformed into 50 rental apartments, and an 1840 hat factory at 597 Grand Avenue in Prospect Heights that has been reshaped into 52 rentals.
"The beauty of such projects," said Russell A. Harding, president of the city's development corporation, "is that they not only help re-establish places like Clinton Hill, Fort Greene and Prospect Heights as attractive, affordable places for working families to live, but preserve some special buildings in the process." He said 10 more projects with 600 units were expected to receive financing by the end of the year.
Vivian Becker, executive director of the Pratt Area Community Council, a nonprofit community development group in Fort Greene, described the old armory as "a very visible and blighted building" and its renovation as "a long overdue project, which we support."
The developers of the armory project received a $10.34 million first loan with an interest rate of 7.5 percent from the city housing corporation, as well as a $2.2 million second loan with a 1 percent rate, "which made the project financially feasible," Mr. Frezza said. The partners also invested $1.7 million of their own money, and the European American Bank guaranteed the $12 million construction loan.
The armory was built in 1872 to house the 23rd Regiment of the National Guard, and its 130-by-180-foot drill hall, with its barrel-shaped ceiling, was then the largest built without pillars or obstructions in the United States, according to the State Office of Military History. It was extensively reconstructed in 1911, though the drill hall was not affected.
The building functioned as an armory through 1964, when it was taken over by the city, which used it as a warehouse until 1986. After that, the old armory sat dormant, becoming the target of vandals, who stripped it of, among other items, its copper roof gutters and drains, leaving it vulnerable to damage from rain.
When the developers bought the building for $300,000 at a city auction in 1995, it had gaping holes in its roof and boarded-over windows.
The next challenge, said Robert Scarano, the architect, "was to come up with a scheme that was sympathetic to the existing structure." Original details of the existing facade were incorporated into the design, he added.
That included retaining the outline of the building's Clermont Avenue pediment, which frames a Romanesque arch lined with mullions, to form a front atrium that leads to an open-air garden and then to the main entrance. The original gray masonry facades facing Clermont and Vanderbilt Avenues remain, though parts have been covered with yellow- or buff-colored stucco, and red accents have been added for contrast. Three of the wrought iron trusses that spanned the old drill hall were left exposed to the sky.
Inside, Mr. Scarano said, the building was gutted and reshaped into apartments. Apartments in the two wings have ceilings just over nine feet high, and features like hardwood floors and dishwashers. The building, with initial occupancy to begin next month, will have a 24-hour doorman.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Commercials By Bush Camp Go on the Air In 4 Key States

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
Concentrating on four states that political strategists say could tip the electoral balance this fall, the Bush campaign yesterday began running its first major television commercials of the general election, a kind of sunny prologue to the Republican convention that begins in 10 days.
The three commercials, produced by the campaign's own advertising agency, Maverick Media, went on the air in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Florida and Washington State in what Ari Fleischer, a campaign spokesman, described as a "multimillion-dollar ad buy." Bush officials would not say how long the commercials would run, or whether more states might be added. 
 But the choice of television markets was an instant subject for dissection by Gore campaign officials, who pointed to the inclusion of Florida as a sign that some crucial states which might normally be safely in the Republican column were viewed by the Bush campaign as in need of some media triage. Florida's governor, Jeb Bush, being the brother of the presumptive nominee, gave them additional fodder.
"I think that documents the fact that Florida is really in play," said Chris Lehane, the Gore campaign press secretary. "Right now, it's a virtual dead heat."
Though Florida's 25 electoral votes went for the Clinton-Gore ticket in 1996, over the past three decades the state voted more typically for Republican presidential candidates. Republicans hold the majority in the state's Congressional delegation, and Florida is the first former Confederate state to have a legislature under Republican control.
Tony Welch, a spokesman for the Florida Democratic Party, said newspapers in the state had put the television advertising investment by the Bush campaign and the Republican National Committee at about $1 million. "You don't spend a million dollars in a safe state," Mr. Welch said.
Aides to Vice President Al Gore would not say whether the campaign would respond rapidly with commercials of its own. Up to now, spots featuring the presumptive nominees have been run exclusively by the Democratic and Republican national committees; the Democrats alone are expected to have spent about $25 million by the time they open their convention in Los Angeles next month.
Mr. Fleischer said that the 30-second spots were designed to reinforce presidential qualities of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. "The theme running through the ads is leadership. Now is the time in American history we can exercise bold leadership willing to unite America."
Indeed, the commercials concede a point that Mr. Gore has made a cornerstone of his campaign this summer, that the country is enjoying an unparalleled era of prosperity. The Bush campaign argues in the advertisements that the national economic upswing should be the foundation for a shift to Republican leadership committed to solving complicated problems like how to shore up Social Security and raise standards in schools.
In one spot, titled "Hard Things," Mr. Bush looks into the camera and says, "This is a moment in history when we have a chance to focus on tough problems. It's not always popular to say, 'Our children can't read, or Social Security needs improving, or we have a budget surplus and a deficit of values.' But those are the right things to say."
Another characterizes the election as a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity "to do something good with it all." Echoing the declared themes of the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia, it asks, "Shouldn't the president unite, not divide, and renew America's purpose?"
The warmest and fuzziest of the spots features close-ups of a newborn's foot and a montage of ordinary people in what the commercial makers call "found" moments. Over footage shot this month in the New York area, a narrator declares, "a lot of new Americans arrived today. They were neither Republican nor Democrat. But someone held them close and hoped. Be healthy. Learn a lot. It takes leadership to give everyone a shot at the American dream."
While political spots are sometimes tested with focus groups before being put on the air, these were not, said a Bush adviser who spoke on condition of anonymity. But in market surveys of voters, the adviser said, "consistently, for some reason, Bush scores overwhelmingly higher than Gore on the question of strong leadership."
Greg Stevens, who made the commercials for Senator John McCain of Arizona during the primaries, said the Bush campaign's selection of states for the media buy was "probably smart," in that "if they can block him in Florida, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Washington, Gore can't win."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Warnaco Warns on Profit And Investors Punish Stock
Warnaco, the maker of intimate apparel, said that it would miss earnings estimates by a wide margin, the third time it has missed projections in the last year. The company said operating earnings for the 2000 fiscal year would be 26 to 36 cents a share, almost $1.50 less than Wall Street analysts had projected.
Irate investors sent Warnaco shares down $1.8125, to $4.9375. They are now down nearly 60 percent this year, and off 89 percent from their high of $44 in 1998. Page C2. 

Movies Added to Music Dispute
Expanding their legal attack on the exchange of copyrighted works on the Internet, the motion picture and music industries sued to shut down Scour.com, a venture backed by Michael Ovitz that the industries contend permits not just free trading of copyrighted music files but of movies. In invoking the film issue, the lawsuit adds a wrinkle to a dispute that has focused largely on music. C2.
 
Merger of Railroads Is Called Off
The largest rail merger in North American history was formally scrapped as the railroads involved -- Burlington Northern Santa Fe and the Canadian National Railway -- complained about regulatory interference and shippers remained convinced that they have not seen the end of the consolidation that has so far left just a handful of major freight railroads to serve the United States and Canada. C2.
 
Mechanics Cause Trouble for United
United Airlines, already reeling from the refusal of many of its 10,000 pilots to work overtime, is now facing similar difficulties from its 15,000 mechanics, whose contract with the airline expired on July 12. C6.
 
Bertelsmann Plans to Buy CDNow
Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, will buy CDNow, the struggling online music retailer, for $117 million in cash. The deal will give Bertelsmann a recognized brand in online music sales as it attempts to expand its electronic commerce business. C4.
 
A Guiding Hand for Mexico's Leader
Luis Ernesto Derbez, a World Bank manager who had served in Africa, Asia and Central America, has become a leading adviser to Vicente Fox, the president-elect of Mexico. C3.
 
Eminent Copywriter Joins Artustry
Helayne Spivak, a well-known copywriter who has worked at several large agencies like Ammirati Puris Lintas, J. Walter Thompson and Young & Rubicam Advertising, is joining David Sklaver and his partners at the Artustry Partnership in New York, a shop that provides creative and strategic services to advertisers seeking to work outside the realm of traditional agencies. Ms. Spivak, 48, will be a creative partner, joining the three executives who founded the shop in fall 1998. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.
 
Housing Construction Declines 3%
Housing construction fell 3 percent in June, to its lowest level in more than two years, responding to a string of interest rate increases, government figures showed. C8.
 
Profit Doubles at America Online
America Online posted a 115 percent gain in fourth-quarter profit, slightly beating the expectations of analysts, who said the results were solid but contained few surprises. C4.
 
Sun Microsystems reported profit that exceeded forecasts, lifted by continued strong sales of servers that help power the Internet. C2.
 
Earnings Fall at Mattel and Hasbro
Mattel and Hasbro, two of the largest toymakers, said that second-quarter profits fell as sales slowed and an increase in the value of the dollar hurt earnings from overseas. C6.
 
Gillette Posts 2.1% Gain in Profit
Gillette said that its second-quarter earnings rose 2.1 percent, on increased sales of its Mach 3 blades. Its shares fell after the company said it would retain its Braun unit. C6.

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Attacks Lazio Over Position On Loan Limit

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Suggesting that her opponent cared more about wealthy campaign donors than about constituents, Hillary Rodham Clinton attacked Representative Rick A. Lazio yesterday for trying to kill legislation in 1998 to expand a program that helps first-time home buyers obtain mortgages.
Mrs. Clinton questioned why Mr. Lazio had objected to the legislation, since it was intended to benefit people in more expensive areas, including Mr. Lazio's district on Long Island, by raising the limit on the size of mortgages guaranteed by the federal government. The program, run by the Federal Housing Administration, assists first-time home buyers or those with shaky credit. 
 Mr. Lazio had vigorously fought the legislation, saying that it was an unacceptable intrusion by government into private industry. The program competes with private mortgage insurance companies, which charge fees to guarantee mortgages.
Mr. Lazio and a few other senior Republicans were able to scale back the measure before it passed. Less than a month later, Mr. Lazio collected a total of $23,500 in contributions from six of the nation's largest private mortgage insurance companies. The Lazio campaign said recently that the donations were not related to the fight over the loan limit.
In an interview, Mrs. Clinton maintained that Mr. Lazio had betrayed his constituents by opposing a higher loan limit, and said that she would have championed the proposal. "His opposition meant that if he had prevailed, fewer people in Long Island and in the rest of New York would have been able to afford a home."
Asked about the donations to Mr. Lazio, which were reported in The New York Times yesterday, she said, "We are going to have to let New Yorkers reach their own conclusions about what that means."
Bryan Flood, a spokesman for the Lazio campaign, disparaged Mrs. Clinton's comments. "No one has done more for affordable housing in New York than Rick Lazio as chairman of the subcommittee on housing," Mr. Flood said. "He authored and led the fight for a number of landmark public housing and affordable housing bills. He has an outstanding record. The real question is, where has Hillary Clinton been and what has she done for homeownership in New York?"
The jousting over Mr. Lazio's record came as both campaigns continued to feud over the contents of fund-raising solicitations.
A new letter signed by the chairman of the Republican State Committee, William Powers, says Mrs. Clinton is an "ambitious, ruthless, scheming, calculating, manipulating woman," and later refers to her as an "angry woman whose political views are so far to the left, she has left common sense behind."
"She's been at the front and center of every Clinton-Gore scandal and this has been the most seedy, shameless and corrupt administration in American history," says the letter, first disclosed yesterday by The Associated Press. Mr. Powers also refers to Mrs. Clinton's daughter, Chelsea, noting that Mrs. Clinton did not send Chelsea to school in New York.
It was the second strongly worded letter from the state party attacking Mrs. Clinton to surface this month.
Mrs. Clinton has been a powerful lure in fund-raising letters, with Republicans across the nation invoking her name in an effort to generate money from people who dislike her. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Lazio's predecessor as Senate candidate, set a fund-raising record in part by tapping into this sentiment.
At a news conference in Albany, Mr. Powers said the language in the letter was not anti-woman, and was an accurate portrayal of Mrs. Clinton's character. He said he was not concerned that the letter would backfire. "I've never seen a response to direct mail like we're getting from her," Mr. Powers said.
Mrs. Clinton's spokesman, Howard Wolfson, attacked the letter. "While Rick Lazio smiles for the cameras in public, his Republican allies quietly send out insult-filled letters behind closed doors," Mr. Wolfson said in a statement. "It's time for the hypocrisy to stop. These negative letters signal that Rick Lazio and the G.O.P. have no intention of running a campaign on the issues."
After Mr. Giuliani withdrew from the Senate race in May, saying he needed to concentrate on treatment of his prostate cancer, he pledged to help Mr. Lazio. The Giuliani campaign now says it has returned about $3 million to donors, with instructions to make it easy for them to send the money to Mr. Lazio. It is not clear how many have heeded the request.
Bruce J. Teitelbaum, a senior political adviser to Mr. Giuliani, said the campaign had $3.8 million left and added that Giuliani advisers would be meeting with senior state Republicans in the coming weeks to determine how Mr. Giuliani could use his political operation to help Mr. Lazio and other Republicans.

HEADLINE: Africans Fault Rich Nations On Aid to the World's Poor

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 20

 BODY:
With leaders of the world's industrialized countries gathering in Japan for their annual meeting, a handful of major third world nations took center stage today and lambasted the richest nations on behalf of the world's poor.
At a news conference in Tokyo on the eve of the Group of 8 summit meeting, which is being held in Japan's southern island of Okinawa, leaders of South Africa, Nigeria and Algeria -- three of Africa's largest countries -- said the major powers had been too slow to act on debt relief and other issues vital to economic growth in the third world. 
 "It is no longer a question of what we should do," said Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, after he and the third world leaders met with the industrialized leaders. "We all know what we should do. The question is do we have the political will."
The news conference was sponsored by Jubilee 2000, a coalition of charities calling for debt relief for the poor. Mr. Obasanjo is head of a so-called Group of 77, a political coalition of underdeveloped countries, and is also head of the movement of nonaligned nations.
The comments by Mr. Obasanjo, and similarly spirited remarks made by Presidents Thabo Mbeki of South Africa and Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria, were among the few flickers of controversy in a minutely planned diplomatic ballet as delegations from the leading industrial nations -- the United States, Japan, Britain, Italy, Canada, France, Germany -- joined delegates from Russia.
Mr. Obasanjo and his African peers accused the industrialized powers of selfish shortsightedness in their dealings with the third world, where demands to repay heavy debts prevent the poor nations from spending money on vital services like health care and education.
The anger of the third world presidents was underscored by reports that the industrialized nations would speed debt relief for Russia during the three-day meeting in Okinawa.
Mr. Mbeki said that in addition to debt issues, representatives of rich and poor nations had discussed increasing foreign direct investment in Africa, Africa's access to foreign markets, and the transfer of information technology and biotechnology to Africa, among other things. "It is a range of things that are interrelated, and it is important that the G-8, when they address these questions, address all of these questions," he said.
The African leaders were not met separately by the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, as they had requested. But Mr. Mori did preside over a meeting between them and leading officials of the industrialized nations, and included them in a dinner tonight.
The third world leaders also met with executives of several international technology giants, including Sony and Cisco.
After the talks, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, standing in for President Clinton, who was arriving late because of the Israeli-Palestinian talks at Camp David, Md., said significant ground had been covered by the two sides. Among the proposals agreed upon were the expansion of debt relief programs beyond the poorest, most heavily indebted countries that had been eligible. They also agreed that the next round of World Trade Organization talks would be devoted to the problems of poor countries.
Sounding a somewhat skeptical note, Mr. Mbeki said the third world must await the outcome of the summit meetings before gauging how determined the rich nations are to provide more meaningful assistance on the problems of poverty and disease. "The question of what they will say, that can only come at the end of the Okinawa meeting," he said.
At their last summit meetings last year, the world's richest nations announced with great fanfare a $100 billion debt relief package for 40 of the world's poorest countries. But almost none of the money called for has been disbursed.
The Clinton administration narrowly averted embarrassment over this issue when the House of Representatives voted only last week to finance Mr. Clinton's request for Washington's $262 million share in providing debt relief.
Again this year, the industrialized nations are promising a number of major initiatives at their summit meeting, and the plans are as sweeping as they have ever been. The meeting itself has been billed as the "information summit," and has set as one of its goals reducing the so-called digital divide -- access to the Internet and other information technology -- between rich and poor countries.
Toward this end, Japan has pledged to donate $15 billion during the next five years to poor countries to help them spread Internet access and develop information technologies.
Major goals have also been announced in health care. The industrialized leaders have reportedly agreed on setting a target of 25 percent for reducing AIDS infection among 15- to 24-year-olds in the third world by the year 2010.
Of all the people who carry the virus that causes AIDS, 70 percent of them live in Africa.
Here again, Japan has pledged large sums of money -- $3 billion -- to battle AIDS and tropical diseases like malaria in the developing world.
This week, Washington, too, announced an AIDS initiative for 24 African countries, which will provide them with $1 billion in loans annually to pay for medicine and other treatment to fight AIDS.

HEADLINE: Sun-Drenched Okinawa Is an Uneasy Place to Meet

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: NAGO, Japan, Friday, July 21

 BODY:
Of the many locations Japan considered for the annual summit meeting of the world's leading industrialized nations, this resort town in the country's southernmost island, Okinawa, seemed a most dubious choice.
Okinawa, a backwater province plagued by a tragic past, lacked the infrastructure and know-how needed to mount an international event of such magnitude. Relations between Tokyo and the former island kingdom have never been good, and the islanders have long demanded the removal of the vast American military bases that constrict their lives. 
 In the past, meetings of the leading industrial nations in Japan have been held in Tokyo. But the late Prime Minister Keichi Obuchi, who died of a stroke in May, insisted on staging this meeting here, hoping to bolster Okinawa's weak economy and make some amends for decades of abuse and neglect by Japan and the United States.
With the Group of 8 meeting opening today, many Japanese and American officials are regretting Mr. Obuchi's well-intentioned choice and fretting about the potential for mishap and mayhem in what is ostensibly a sun-drenched paradise.
"I guess you can say that we are all on pins and needles," said a Japanese official. "Although we feel ready for the summit, there is a sinking feeling in our stomachs that it will either go off without a hitch or there could be great chaos."
To the unknowing eye, Okinawa is a haven: a subtropical slice of striking beauty, rich in coral reefs, lush forests, pristine beaches and blue-green waters.
But trouble lurks not far beneath this shimmering surface. The recent arrest of a United States marine accused of molesting a sleeping Okinawan schoolgirl has heightened outrage among islanders who have vowed to disrupt the summit meeting with massive demonstrations. Today, about 27,000 angry people formed a human chain around United States' Kadena Air Base to protest the presence of American troops on the island -- a major embarrassment to the decorous host nation.
President Clinton is the first American president to visit Okinawa since it reverted back to Japan from the United States military in 1972. Later today, the president is scheduled to make a major speech at the peace monument on this island, which at the end of World War II was the scene of fierce fighting between the United States and Japanese troops in which nearly one-third of Okinawa's population was killed.
Japanese security forces, which have deployed 22,000 officers from across the country to Okinawa, are bracing for a possible repeat of the violence that erupted during international trade meetings in the United States in the past year.
And the meeting's organizers have expressed fear that Okinawa, Japan's poorest and least-developed prefecture, cannot handle the thousands of foreigners who are expected to attend the conference. Forecasts of nightmare traffic, power and telephone failures, overbooked hotels, and seasonal typhoons abound.
Before Japan annexed Okinawa in the early 1600's, the island was the seat of the Ryukyu Kingdom, which was closely linked to China and had diplomatic and trade ties with Korea and Southeast Asia. Because of their multicultural links, Okinawans have their own art forms, dialect, cuisine and way of life that are distinct from the homogeneous rest of Japan.
"It's the door to Asia for Japan," said Ryu Yamazaki, the Foreign Ministry spokesman. "We wanted to introduce the world to this unique culture which is part of Japan."
The islands, which have a population of 1.2 million, are home to about half of the 45,000 United States military personnel in Japan. Okinawans maintain that they bear an unfair burden because their island, which is less than 1 percent of Japan's total area, contains 75 percent of the United States military facilities in the country.
The island also has its share of social problems. Okinawa's unemployment rate is twice the national average. It has Japan's lowest household savings rate and lowest per-capita income, and highest teenage pregnancy and divorce rates.
One reason to bring the meeting here was to persuade islanders to accept a much-disputed plan to construct a new United States Marine Corps helicopter base off the coast of Nago. The new heliport will replace the Futenma Air Base, which is set to be returned to Japan.
While Okinawans welcomed the closing of the old air station, which was a major nuisance to local residents, they adamantly oppose a new American military base. But the allure of acting as host to the summit meeting, with its economic benefits, proved sufficient to help persuade local Okinawan officials to accept the relocation plan.
"One cannot deny the political benefits of putting the summit in Okinawa," said Yukio Okamoto, a former Foreign Ministry official who served as an adviser to past Japanese governments on the Okinawa issue.
"However, the main reason was to bring a new era of thinking to the Okinawa mentality," Mr. Okamoto said. "Okinawa has been shackled by past history and unable to move forward like the rest of Japan. Mr. Obuchi thought the summit would be a very important turning point in the island's history."
Many Okinawans have mixed feelings: They are delighted that the conference will focus worldwide attention on them and their culture, but are worried that the meeting will be seen as a quick fix for their longstanding problems.
Although the islanders' dislike of the American bases is clear, many expressed great pride that the three-day conference has come to town.
"After the summit Okinawa will no longer be a question on 'Jeopardy,' " said Noriko Takada, a convenience store clerk. "The world will know us."
Across the island, government offices, businesses, private homes and taxi cabs are displaying the flags of the eight nations attending the meeting. The central government has spent hundreds of millions of dollars to construct new conference halls, widen roads, refurbish parks and install new telephone lines.
"It's a great thing for world leaders to come here and learn about the Okinawan reality," said Yashikazu Tamaki, an Okinawan assemblyman. "It's good for Okinawan children because it will give them a sense of pride and encouragement."
"But I am worried that leaders like President Clinton will come to Okinawa and make a speech thanking Okinawans for accepting the military bases," Mr. Tamaki said. "That would be like rubbing salt into the wounds of Okinawans, because the reality is, we don't want the bases."

HEADLINE: Clinton Tries to Ease Anger At U.S. Troops in Okinawa

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: ITOMAN, Japan, Friday, July 21

 BODY:
President Clinton jumped from one delicate diplomatic matter to several other ones today as he arrived for an economic meeting of world leaders and immediately tried to make amends to residents of Okinawa fed up with the heavy American military presence on the island.
"We will continue to do what we can to reduce our footprint on this island," Mr. Clinton said this morning at a seaside memorial devoted to the more than 200,000 Japanese, Americans and others who died in 1945 during the fierce fighting of the Battle of Okinawa. "We take seriously our responsibility to be good neighbors, and it is unacceptable to the United States when we do not meet the responsibility." 
 Before flying here, Mr. Clinton left the Middle East peace talks unfinished back in Washington and aides signaled on his arrival that he was eager to return to Camp David. They said he might scale back his three-day trip here, for the annual meeting of the Group of 8.
All the same, Mr. Clinton tried to reassure the Japanese, who have poured money and attention into the summit meeting, that it was an important gathering that merited his 14-hour trip. Mr. Clinton is to join the leaders of Japan, Italy, Germany, France, Britain, Canada and Russia for a series of closed-door meetings.
Mr. Clinton's visit was the first for an American president to this sliver of land since the United States returned Okinawa to Japan in 1972. Mr. Clinton arrived during a particular rocky time in relations between Okinawans and the approximately 26,000 American troops stationed in their midst.
Okinawans, who lived under United States occupation for 27 years, have long complained that that they suffer from the heavy military presence. There are 37 United States military facilities in Okinawa, representing all the services and taking up tens of thousands of acres. Recent incidents involving wayward soldiers have added to local fury.
Mr. Clinton pointed out that the United States has begun consolidating bases on Okinawa, a process that residents complain has been far too slow. The president also emphasized the role Okinawa has played in ensuring stability in the region.
"I know that the people of Okinawa did not ask to play this role, hosting more than 50 percent of American forces in Japan on less than one percent of its land mass," Mr. Clinton said.
But some Okinawans said the president did not go far enough in his speech. "He didn't say anything concrete," complained Ryo Tengan, 28, a civil servant who was hoping for a presidential announcement of an immediate reduction in troops.
Zenko Nakamura, 53, an activist who is fighting the relocation of an American Marine base, said, "I'm disappointed that the president didn't mention what Okinawans care most about -- sexual crimes committed by American servicemen."
In advance of the summit meeting, the United States military banned its personnel from drinking alcohol or leaving their bases after midnight, a curfew that followed a hit-and-run accident involving a staff sergeant stationed at the Kadena Air Base.
Before that, the highest-ranking United States military official in Okinawa issued an apology after a marine was arrested on charges of entering a house and molesting a 14-year-old girl who was sleeping there.
Mr. Clinton's visit was reminiscent of an earlier stop by another American president almost four decades ago. While the island was still under United States control, President Dwight D. Eisenhower stopped briefly in Okinawa on June 19, 1960, during a tour of Asia and faced the same anger displayed for Mr. Clinton.
Huge crowds of locals turned out to see Mr. Eisenhower, and 1,500 of them began a snake dance to protest the presence of American troops and the failure to return the island to Japanese control.
Mr. Eisenhower ignored the demonstrations in his remarks, calling the American presence a "splendid example of the mutual benefits that result when people of good will work toward the common goal of peace and friendship in freedom."
Mr. Clinton spoke this morning from Cornerstone of Peace Park, a memorial to the soldiers and civilians of Japanese, American and Okinawan ancestry who died here.
Carved into a granite wall on a seaside bluff, which Mr. Clinton toured with the governor of Okinawa, Keichi Inamine, were the names of 234,183 victims.
"The Battle of Okinawa was warfare at its most tragic," Mr. Clinton said. "This monument built in its memory is humanity at its most inspired. For here, no grief goes unrecognized. While most monuments remember only those who have fallen from one side, this memorial recognizes those from all sides, and those who took no side."

HEADLINE: A Bridge Across the Rio Grande

 BODY:

To the Editor:
George J. Borjas (Op-Ed, July 18) writes that Mexican workers should have only limited access to the United States labor market. 
 Why is it that a worker who was born in Nogales, Sonora, is a less deserving human being than her cousin who had the good fortune to have been born just across the border in Nogales, Ariz.?
Our own ancestors were mostly economic refugees whose arrival undoubtedly beat down the wages of the preceding waves of unskilled workers. Why do today's "huddled masses" merit any less opportunity?
 
J. HUSTON MC CULLOCH
Columbus, Ohio, July 18, 2000
 
The writer is a professor of economics and finance at Ohio State University.
