SECTION: Section 5; Page 11; Column 4; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 3239 words

HEADLINE: To See Japan, Try Rail Pass And Ryokan

BYLINE: By PERRI KLASS; PERRI KLASS is an assistant professor of pediatrics at Boston University School of Medicine.

 BODY:
THE most triumphant moment of the whole trip to Japan occurred on the grounds of the stupendous 16th century "white heron" castle of Himeji.
There, with the castle towering above us, we encountered three men dressed as samurai, and my 4-year-old son, Anatol, knew his Japanese dreams had come true. Using gestures, the three samurai invited the American child to pose with them, and even put a sword in his hands, while his two siblings snapped photos. For the rest of the trip, Anatol mentioned casually, many times a day, that he had met real samurai, and held a real samurai sword. 
 It started with the frequent-flier tickets. My older children had two weeks of school vacation, and we had this vague idea of going somewhere exciting. But where do you take a 10th-grade boy (Orlando), a sixth-grade girl (Josephine) and a 4-year-old, not to mention two well-meaning and reasonably well-traveled parents? We had initially thought of Greece -- all that classical heritage, lots of ruins to climb on. Everyone was fairly enthusiastic about that, though the older kids were wary about being taken to too many museums.
It turned out that for our miles we could get only three tickets to Athens. But I was told about a special sale on tickets to Tokyo, and we had enough miles for five free tickets.
We discussed this with our usual thoroughness: "Japan?"
"Cool!" said Orlando, the 16-year-old. And we booked the tickets. (It subsequently turned out that we had been given incorrect information about this "sale" and were not actually entitled to the tickets, but Delta honored the offer.)
As a family, we have no special connection to Japan. Orlando has a brown belt in karate and can count to 10 in Japanese. That and a certain familiarity with "The Mikado" was about the sum of our cultural and linguistic expertise. We worried about the language barrier and the possible expense -- our goal was a decidedly budget-level trip.
Before we left, we bought Japan Rail Pass vouchers, giving us unlimited train travel for one week.
We also booked just one hotel room for our first three nights in Tokyo, using a brochure from the Japan tourist office in Manhattan that listed the members of the Japanese Inn Group throughout the country. This consortium of inexpensive Japanese-style inns provides mostly ryokan accommodations -- you sleep on futons, you often share a bathroom, and you take off your shoes before entering the inn. I called one of the inns in Tokyo and talked with a helpful man who spoke a little English and said he had a room big enough for the five of us.
And so we flew from Boston via Atlanta to Tokyo, a fairly easy flight, though a long one. We watched a bunch of movies. Ate meals at what seemed like random moments. Orlando and Josephine studied the phrase books, occasionally informing us; we learned, for example, that an unmarried woman over 25 used to be referred to as "Christmasu Cakie" because nobody wants to eat Christmas cake after Christmas.
Parentally, we suggested practicing greetings and numbers and directional words. And when in Tokyo, we found our way onto the cheap train and then the subway to our hotel, the Ryokan Kikuya, where there was indeed a big room waiting for us with four folded futons. Each hotel we stayed in in Japan assumed that a 4-year-old would sleep with his parents, and Anatol obliged, cheerfully occupying the space on the futons between us until by morning he had wiggled between the mattresses and onto the tatami mat floor.
We spent two days in Tokyo, sightseeing as hard as we could. The subway system lived up to its reputation: complicated, at times amazingly crowded, spotless and unbelievably efficient. There are some subway maps with only Japanese characters, some with English names for stations; at major stations there are attendants who can answer questions. We got pretty good at using the vending machines to buy tickets, and at following the signs from line to line.
Up early one morning, we took the subway to the Tsukiji district to see the famous fish market, in the process getting a taste of Tokyo rush hour, complete with its gloved "pushers" stuffing people into the trains. The fish market was overwhelming: what seemed like miles and miles of fish from bins of the tiny to huge slabs of the gigantic. We found food ready to eat in the city market nearby: round, fresh octopus fritters; skewers of grilled eel; cold sliced omelet with duck meat.
We wandered in the neighborhoods of downtown Tokyo, visiting the Sony building in the Ginza district, where we tried on glasses that projected videos in front of our eyes and played very advanced PlayStation games (well, some of us).
We visited the Tokyo National Museum in Ueno Park and admired Buddha statues and painted screens (well, some of us). Our hotel was in the Asakusa area, one of the older Tokyo neighborhoods, and right nearby was the seventh-century Sensoji, the oldest temple in Tokyo. It is approached down Nakamise Dori, a lane of what you would have to classify as Japanese temple tchotchke shops. We bought hot little cakes flavored with green tea, and Orlando got his fortune told in the temple, shaking a box until a stick fell out, then matching the number on that stick to a little drawer and extracting a paper fortune, complete with English translation.
And then we activated our rail passes, having previously exchanged the vouchers at a special office at Tokyo Station, and for the next week we zipped around the island of Honshu, obeying the universal rail pass imperative of making it pay by traveling as much as possible. The trains were almost all Shinkansen, the famous bullet trains. From Tokyo to Kyoto, then on to Nara, Hiroshima, the castle town of Himeji, the mountain village of Takayama, and finally, the historic resort city of Nikko.
AS soon as we arrived in a new city, we would reserve train seats to the next city, communicating with the officials in the train office by pointing to the trains we wanted on the timetables and showing our passes. Sometimes they spoke some English; they were always patient, and the little pasteboard reservation cards they gave us always turned out to be for the right trains at the right times on the right tracks.
We reserved hotels by calling ahead to the next city as well; the Japanese telephone system was easy to use with the phone cards we bought along the way. We slept extremely comfortably on the ryokan futons, usually paying just over $100 a night for the five of us, although we were traveling in low season. Japanese yukata (robes) were provided, as were thermoses of green tea, and we were made to feel very welcome.
These are not the elegant traditional ryokan inns that feature Japanese antiques and beautifully arranged meals, but they generated a certain kind of family togetherness and good humor as we tried to remember the rules about shoes (leave your own at the entrance and put on slippers, leave the slippers at the door to your room, and be sure to change into toilet slippers when you visit the bathroom).
In Kyoto one morning, we started out to sightsee in the rain, and the proprietress of the Ryokan Murakamiya insisted on supplying us with umbrellas, one apiece, taking great care to select the appropriate umbrella (size, color, importance) for each family member.
We visited Nijo Castle, built by the first Tokugawa shogun, Ieyasu. The building, constructed of cypress and decorated with painted wall panels and screens, is famous for its nightingale floors, which "sing" when you walk on them -- a security measure that made it impossible to sneak up on anyone.
At Kinkakuji, the Temple of the Golden Pavilion, we wandered in the temple garden, admiring the pavilion in its lake setting. There were many Japanese high school students, in uniform, and it turned out that their assignment was to practice English by finding foreigners and conversing with them. Since foreigners were in short supply, each member of our family patiently went through several rounds of the set questions. All the students were reading from the same script: May I ask you some questions? What do you think of Kyoto? Shall we take a picture together?
Also in Kyoto, we visited Ryoanji Temple, where the famous Zen rock garden in all its harmony of rock and sand survived the energy of our family's visit. At Nara, the site of the first permanent Japanese capital (in 710), there were sacred deer in Narakoen park; you buy special "deer cookies" to feed them.
Another rainy day, in Hiroshima, was oddly divided between the memories of the atomic bomb and the pace of the modern city that has risen since 1945. We started with a visit to the Peace Memorial Museum in Peace Memorial Park, with its careful re-creation, in models and pictures, of what the city looked like before the bomb was dropped, and then after. The exhibit has been expanded to take more cognizance of the course of the war prior to 1945, in particular of Japanese military activities and war crimes in Asia.
We walked across the park to the cenotaph, the flame burning beneath it, and Anatol rang the peace bell. We saw the thousand cranes statue in honor of a young leukemia victim and, across the river from the park, the skeletal A-Bomb Dome. In the afternoon, we were wandering in a vibrant city, through streets and streets of arcadelike shopping districts and restaurants, thinking inevitable thoughts about human resilience and rebuilding.
In Takayama, after a beautiful ride through the mountains on a special train with enormous windows, we visited old wooden houses. At the morning pickle market along the river, all kinds of unusual mountain vegetables were for sale in pickled form, and samples on toothpicks were freely offered.
Oh yes, we ate. The food was terrific everywhere in Japan. Among the five of us, there is a range in what you might call adventurous seafood eating -- Josephine, who is 10, eats pretty much everything, even if it's still moving. The rest of us are ranged a bit behind her. But everyone liked the food -- big bowls of noodle soup, sushi, shabu-shabu one night at an all-you-can-eat joint where you just kept bringing your tray back and getting more raw meat and vegetables to cook.
In Hiroshima, the local specialty is okonomiyaki, a complex omelet involving vegetables and meat and seafood and Worcestershire sauce. We found our way to okonomiyaki stands, dozens of them, where we sat at a counter, watching a highly skilled cook put our omelets together. All over Japan, we patronized the many excellent French pastry shops for breakfast, and I discovered my ideal breakfast confection: a large flat pastry topped with flakes of dried fish and seaweed. I still yearn for it.
We also did very well at conveyor belt sushi establishments, where you sit at stools along a counter and take plates of whatever interests you off the moving belt; a spout on the counter dispenses green tea; someone counts up your empty plates to calculate your bill. One night, we also tried robatayaki, little dishes of food cooked to our order and served to us on a long wooden paddle: sardines, snails, pork skewers, pumpkin. Everywhere in Japan there are window displays of plastic food, showing you exactly what you'll get. We quickly got over any embarrassment about leading the waitress outside the restaurant and pointing at the window.
In fact, we pretty quickly got over all embarrassment about everything, even the 10th grader and the sixth grader, who have been known, in their home country, to be mortified by any public utterance made by a parent or sibling.
IN Japan, it was just too obvious that we were the completely clueless, linguistically impaired strangers that we were. It became a family joke: whenever we beckoned the waitress out into the street to look at the plastic food displays, one of the children would hiss loudly, "Now they're going to think we're tourists!"
Our last major stop before returning to Tokyo was Nikko, 90 miles north of Tokyo, site of the tombs and shrines of the first Tokugawa shogun and his descendants. There we spent the day seeing shrines and admiring the colorful and ornately carved architecture of the shrines and gates set among the cedar groves. These buildings are very different in style from the other temples we visited; they teem with animals and figures and colors, ornate and elaborate and liberally gilded.
We had reserved rooms at the grand old hotel, the Nikko Kanaya, founded in 1873. We had asked for their cheapest rooms, with no private bath, but they kindly upgraded us. In the evening, we gave ourselves a taste of grand hotel life. We descended on the main dining hall and ate local rainbow trout, grilled with soy sauce, and Larry and I had sake. We wandered the halls of the hotel, looking at photos of former guests, of roadsters and ice skating parties, of registers signed by everyone from Helen Keller to Eleanor Roosevelt to Charles Lindbergh to Indira Gandhi.
And then it was back to Tokyo for a couple of days, with that odd sensation of coming back to a completely foreign city that now seems oddly familiar and comforting. We let Orlando lead us through the electronics district of Akihabara, where the neon was nonstop and the video games were wall to wall, took the elevator to the top of the Metropolitan Government towers for the view over Tokyo from the 45th floor, visited the enormous Takashimaya Times Square department store. And finally home, where the first order of business was to develop the pictures of Anatol with the samurai so he could relive the moment as often as possible.
We ended up using one of those pictures as the invitation to his fifth birthday party. That moment -- with his hand on a real samurai sword, posing with three men whose language he could not speak, and the white heron castle looming above them -- may have been a high point of his year, if not his life to date. It was a moment when travel and history and story all came together, and the strange and exotic opened up to include him and welcome him in.
 
And it doesn't have to cost a year's salary
 
Resources
The Japan National Tourist Organization's office is at 1 Rockefeller Plaza, Suite 1250, New York, N.Y. 10020; (212) 757-5640. It will furnish information and mounds of literature about hotels and transportation.
We relied heavily on a directory we found at the tourist office put out by the Japanese Inn Group (members.aol.com/jinngroup), whose ryokan are as economical and hospitable as the booklet describes.
Japan rail passes can be bought only outside Japan by those who hold non-Japanese passports. The passes are available at travel agencies in the United States; the national tourist organization can provide names of agencies that specialize in Japan. Vouchers are sold for a one, two, or three-week pass, which is exchanged at a Japan Rail Pass office at a station in Japan. (There also is one at Narita Airport outside Tokyo, if you want to start your pass immediately upon arrival.)
The passes make train travel in Japan affordable, although the costs change weekly. Last week a one-week pass cost $367 for first class and $275 for coach (by comparison, a round-trip ticket from Tokyo to Hiroshima was $470 first class and $362 coach, and a round trip to Kyoto was $364 first class and $264 coach). A two-week pass cost $594 first class and $438 coach.
Children ages 6 to 11 travel for half price, with any two children 5 and under riding free if accompanied by an adult. A nongovernment agency that sells passes is the Japan Travel Bureau at 810 Seventh Avenue (between 52nd and 53rd Streets) in Manhattan. It's wise to call in advance on the latest prices (212) 698-4919.

Kinkakuji temple, 1 Kinkakuji-cho, Kita-ku, Kyoto. Open every day 9 to 5 (last admission at 4:30). Adults $3.70, children 7 to 15 $2.80, free under 7.
Himeji Castle, 68 Honcho, Himeji, Hyogo Prefecture. Open daily except Dec. 29 to 31; hours from 9 to 5 June to August and from 9 to 4 September to May (last admission one hour early). Adults $5.60, children 5 to 15 $1.85, free under 5.

What to Read
We carried Frommer's Japan guide (Macmillan, 1998) as well as Lonely Planet's Japan (1997). We also took a pile of Japanese-themed books, some new, most not. In addition to Roland Barthes's "The Empire of Signs" (Noonday, 1983) and "Dave Barry Does Japan" (Fawcett, 1993), we had several works of history and sociology, but what we really read was fiction, and it added a great deal to the trip. This included James Clavell's "Shogun" (Dell, 1976), Arthur S. Golden's "Memoirs of a Geisha" (Vintage, 1999), Yukio Mishima's "The Golden Pavilion" (Vintage, 1994), and Junichiro Tanizaki's "The Makioka Sisters" (Vintage, 1995).
And, of course we read aloud Anatol's book, "Sayonara, Mrs. Kackleman" (Puffin Books, 1991). This beautifully illustrated work by Maira Kalman follows a brother and sister on their trip to Japan (to avoid a piano lesson), and we were all delighted whenever we came across an experience that matched one in the book. SECTION: Section 2; Page 29; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1452 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
A Dutch Moment of Genius in Its Full Glory

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

DATELINE: AMSTERDAM

 BODY:
A TINY country that over a short period produces artists of the stature of Rembrandt, Vermeer, Frans Hals, Jan Steen, Jacob van Ruisdael and Pieter de Hooch has good reason to wax proud over its golden age of painting. Indeed, the Netherlands is doing so yet again with "The Glory of the Golden Age," a "best of" exhibition of Dutch 17th-century art that is being held at the Rijksmuseum here through Sept. 17 to celebrate the museum's 200th anniversary.
The Rijksmuseum is itself, of course, a monument to the golden age and, as such, has been able to provide around half of the items in the show (with Rembrandt's "Night Watch" the pivotal work in the exhibition, just as it is the iconic painting of the permanent collection). But for this occasion, to complement its own masterpieces, it has also borrowed essential works from other Dutch museums as well as from collections elsewhere in Europe and in the United States. 
 In the main part of the exhibition, some 200 paintings, sculptures and works of decorative art have been organized both chronologically and around themes, some obvious ("Sky and Water," "Masters of Landscape," "The Delft Light"), others more quirky ("Whims and Drolleries," "Extravagantly Decked Out," "Deceptively Realistic").
Until July 16, 96 drawings and prints were also presented in a dimly lighted gallery on a lower floor, but their fragility prevented their being displayed through September.
The package is impressive: with such raw material, how could it be otherwise? But the show's organizers have also done their bit. By placing sculptures and decorative arts in the same area as paintings, they underline how different art forms were flourishing simultaneously. And with the thematic hanging, they demonstrate how many different schools of paintings were busy at the same time, from portraiture to landscapes, from still life to genre painting.
Yet perhaps most crucially, the show offers a salutary reminder that, for all the renown of Rembrandt, Vermeer and their like today, it was not artists who created the golden age. Rather, it was a special moment in Dutch history, characterized by political enlightenment and economic prosperity, that generated a veritable boom in artistic creation.
In other parts of Europe, art was still reflecting the power of kings and popes. In the Netherlands, it mirrored the emergence of a new kind of civil society, one largely run by and for its Protestant mercantile burghers.
Even more remarkably, for more than 30 years until the Treaty of Westphalia in 1648, the Dutch Republic, as the United Provinces of the north became known, was fighting to consolidate its independence from Spain, which had inherited the Netherlands from the Holy Roman Empire. Yet even during this time, its fleet was establishing new colonies and opening new trading routes that turned Amsterdam into an opulent port city: its population jumped from 50,000 in 1600 to 200,000 in 1650. And with prosperity came a demand for fancier homes and art to put in them.
Amsterdam, which drew Rembrandt from his native Leiden, was at the center of artistic activity, but it was not alone. Haarlem, Utrecht, Delft and Dordrecht, as well as Leiden, had important guilds of artists, in many cases working independently of one another. For example, in Utrecht, which remained largely Roman Catholic, a tradition of religious paintings was kept alive by painters who had studied Caravaggio in Rome. Elsewhere, paintings were everywhere except churches -- in town halls, guild houses and private homes.
Thus, relieved of the need to paint royal portraits and biblical scenes, many artists became unconscious chroniclers of the social history of the era. Important burghers, with their black satin suits and frilly lace collars, were natural subjects, but so also were maritime battles and elegant cityscapes. Domestic interiors, in which the nouveaux riches took special pride, were presented with revolutionary realism, with the paintings on their walls duly reproduced. Indeed, with still lifes decorating every self-respecting home, it was an enviable time and place to be an artist.
"Thousands of painters of varying talents were active during this century, producing several million paintings altogether," Jan Piet Filedt Kok writes in an introduction to this exhibition's catalog. "The production of decorative art -- ceramics, glass, silver and furniture -- achieved new heights, too; only sculpture lagged behind at first."
"The Glory of the Golden Age" starts by introducing the "New Faces" of Dutch portraiture through Thomas de Keyser's "Syndics of the Amsterdam Goldsmiths' Guild" (on loan from the Toledo Museum of Art in Ohio) and Hals's bucolic "Marriage Portrait of Isaac Massa and Beatrix van der Laen." This leads to the "Extravagantly Decked Out" section, where carefully painted accessories, from leather gloves with gold thread, pearls and sequins to delicate lace headwear, are both examples and symbols of wealth.
"Deceptively Realistic" is of course dedicated to still lifes, with Ambrosius Bosschaert's "Bouquet of Flowers in a Vase" of 1618 reminiscent of the tulipomania that gripped the Netherlands in the early 17th century (until the speculative bubble burst in 1637).
But the fascination with still lifes went far beyond flower arrangements: with just a handful of works, the exhibition illustrates the virtuosity of painters who took special pride in portraying, say, cheese or fish or feathers or oysters, in each case as a realistically as possible.
SEEMINGLY EVERYDAY" is particularly interesting since it mirrors the ambivalence that the Protestant Dutch felt about their own affluence ("The Embarrassment of Riches," as Simon Schama entitled his acclaimed book on the Dutch golden age). Painters evidently enjoyed showing people having a good time, but they justified this by suggesting they were warning of the perils of decadence. "In Luxury Beware" by Jan Steen, for instance, shows a party in full swing, while the bare-breasted women and drunken men in Nicolaus Knupfer's "Brothel Scene" could be portrayed in the Calvinist Netherlands only as an admonition against immorality.
Subsequent sections -- there are 23 -- underscore how, at the same time as they kept one eye on the market, Dutch painters of the period were also interested in exploring new techniques. For instance, chiaroscuro -- the strong use of light and shadow -- was initially borrowed from Caravaggio, but the Delft painters took it further, creating a more natural sense of drama. Vermeer's mastery of this technique can be seen here in "The Glass of Wine," on loan from the Gemaldegalerie in Berlin, and in the Rijksmuseum's own "Kitchen Maid."
Yet for all the array of treasures proffered by the golden age, the exhibition cannot escape the dominating presence of Rembrandt and Hals. Three Rembrandts on loan to the Rijksmuseum -- "The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicholas Tulp" from the Mauritshuis in The Hague, "Flora" from the Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg and "The Wedding of Samson" from the Gemaldegalerie in Dresden -- show the broad range of his techniques. Similarly, in the section called "Militia Companies," paintings of citizens' military units by other artists point up the remarkable composition of Rembrandt's "Night Watch."
The section dedicated to Rembrandt and Hals includes numerous portraits by both men, but their styles can best be contrasted in two large oils that hang side by side: Rembrandt's 1662 "Syndics," owned by the Rijksmuseum, and Hals's 1664 "Regents of the Old Men's Almshouse in Haarlem," on loan from the Frans Halsmuseum in Haarlem. While Rembrandt's painting of five burghers and a servant from the drapers' guild offers six detailed and well-lighted portraits, Hals's seven regents -- dressed in black against a black background, with only their faces, hands and white collars immediately visible -- reveal how he achieved his effect with a few hurried brush strokes.
Scattered throughout the exhibition are stone and marble sculptures (mainly busts of worthy burghers), embroidered chairs, wooden cabinets, glass and silver goblets and a good selection of Delft pottery.
Most unusual, perhaps, is an 11-foot-tall copper candelabrum made by Joost Gerritsz in 1640 and donated that same year by the Dutch East India Company to Japan's shogun as part of a successful campaign to curry favor with the Japanese ruler: from 1641 until early in the 19th century, the Dutch enjoyed a European monopoly of trade with Japan. The candelabrum, now permanently on display in a complex of tombs and temples at Nikko in Japan, returned to the Netherlands for the first time for this show.

PUB-DATE: July 23, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 3556 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Architecture's Claim on the Future: The Blob

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
DARWIN is in the air. Mark C. Taylor, a theology professor at Williams College who writes frequently on architecture, brought this to my attention earlier this year. I was saying I wanted a break from my Freudian-Marxian routine. Taylor leaned closer. "Darwin," he said, sounding like a doctor prescribing a pill.
Meanwhile, Adam Phillips, whose DNA strands should be studied by medical science for the key to higher intelligence, has come out with "Darwin's Worms" (Free Press), a book about the parallels between Darwin's thinking and Freud's. Add the popularity of "Survivor," top it with the mapping of the human genome, and you have something more than hula-hoops. You have survival of the fittest hula-hoops. 
 Computer technology is rapidly changing the environment for architects as well as for businesses and nations. How are they adapting to it? In what form will architecture survive?
The Venice Biennale's Seventh International Architecture Exhibition, which opened last month and runs through Oct. 29, is right in step with these evolutionary times. It features the latest strain to emerge in architecture in recent years: "blob" design, so-called, produced with the aid of computer animation software. Biomorphic and invertebrate, with seldom a trace of the T-squares most architects long ago abandoned, blobs look like things you would expect to see rising from an electronic version of the primordial ooze. As if to signal the origin of a species, previously lurking in the depths of the Lagoon, the Biennale rounds up blob projects by Greg Lynn, Lars Spuybroek, Ben van Berkel and Caroline Bos, Jesse Reiser and Uneko Umamoto, Hani Rashid and Lise Ann Couture, and other pixel prodigies. Lynn, in particular, was ubiquitous. It was trilobytes, trilobytes, everywhere you turned.
Venice is an ideal setting for examining architecture in Darwinian terms. The city is a pageant of survival and adaptation, of triumphant resistance to climate, conquest and time. Even in Ruskin's day, Venice was an inhabited skeleton. The city's economic and military power had mutated into a pink and gray romance. Its more recent rebirth as a center of art and tourism prefigured the transformation now taking place in cities throughout the post-industrial world.
Architecture, too, has lately come to resemble the inhabited shell of an extinct beast. Architects are heirs to the heroic tradition of pyramids, temples and cathedrals. Yet many of the most talented among them are lucky if they are hired to design a loft. There has never been more building in the world, nor a lower ratio of architecture to junk. Architects now are day-trippers in their own domain.
This year's Biennale should lift their spirits. Usually, this event is the poor, abject cousin of the Art Biennale, the glitzy career fest with which it alternates every other year. This year feels different. The European press turned out. The cameras and notepads seemed to confirm architecture's increasing prominence on the cultural map. Compared with the Art Biennale, it remains an event where ideas matter more than dollars. It appears that in the year 2000, a certain cachet has attached itself to ideas. People may be awakening to the fact that it takes ideas, as well as money, for great cities to survive.
Organized by the Roman architect Massimiliano Fuksas, this year's Biennale is called "The City: Less Esthetics, More Ethics." New Yorkers may find it hard to get behind this proposition. Unless theme park lampposts are your idea of frisky urban design, it will probably not occur to you that New York is suffering from aesthetic overload. Fortunately, the show contradicts its theme at every turn. Congestion, pollution, urban decay, homelessness, even xenophobia and racial intolerance -- social conscience here gets the high art treatment. Welcome to Italy, where every fashion editor carries a Marxist membership card in her Prada purse.
Ethics are wearing bright colors this season. That's the fashion message at the Italian pavilion, the main attraction in the village of national pavilions laid out in the Giardini, the city's public gardens. Visitors enter through a gantlet of monitors displaying famous talking-head architects shot against vivid pink, orange, green and blue electronic backgrounds. The heads look so aged against the pop-up video colors. They must be addressing issues of great ethical import. Never mind. The volume is too low to hear them.
Meanwhile, in the Arsenale, the ancient naval yard where Venice launched the ships that patrolled her maritime empire, there stretches an immense video wall, two stories high and several football fields long, representing la Citta. To a snappy soundtrack, streaming video images hurtle by -- scenes from the global metropolis projected by cameras stationed in two dozen cities. Crowds wait at Asian intersections to cross streets bathed in neon. Trains whoosh past shantytowns. Night falls over a nameless skyline. Waves crash. Desert dunes billow. Heaven knows how these natural features got into the city. The idea must be that the city is getting into them.
I went to Venice with a question in mind. There are now two generations of architects below the age of 50. Are they developing new forms of practice?
Ours is not an era when the government, private patrons, professional organizations or the press can provide architects with cultural connective tissue or unite them behind common causes. In the cities, our most talented architects are spinning freely within professional vacuums of their own devising. Their ethic is that of shipwrecks: every office for itself. No wonder architects have been so ineffectual in confronting the pressures of global urbanization. To reckon with the monoculture, the shape of practices will have to change more radically than the shape of buildings. Flexible working relationships must be built across geographic and corporate borders. At least, I see no other way out of the present moral impasse.
The national pavilions are signposts pointed in the wrong direction. It feels so dated, in the era of mass tourism, the Internet and the E.E.C., to wander through this display. Fortunately, nationalism is not a major problem afflicting architecture today. Jet lag is a bigger issue. Architects spend as much time on planes as State Department envoys. Their far-flung projects are agents of cross-cultural fertilization.
This idea was evident throughout the Biennale, but nowhere more clearly than in the Austrian Pavilion, of all places. Organized by Hans Hollein, the presentation focused on Vienna but highlighted recent work by non-Austrian architects, including Zaha Hadid, Greg Lynn, Peter Cook and Colin Fournier. An elegant installation in dove gray, white and black, the exhibition included a large map of project sites. The map conveyed the message that cities can foster solidarity among architects, not only in matters of style, but also in resistance to stupidity.
The message was clearly aimed at the nationalists among us. It was even more explicit in a separate gallery, an "Area of Tolerance," that presented architect-designed agitprop posters attacking Austria's Jorg Haider and his anti-immigration policies. But the main part of the show offered a more lasting polemic. With graceful understatement, it suggested that city lovers are an embattled species. We have more in common with one another than with the rest of our respective nations. The ethical fiber that binds us is the cosmopolitan belief that the function of a city is to refuse everything less than the best.
Elsewhere, Hollein has contributed a project of his own design. "Dencity" is a floating raft that holds a contemplative garden inspired by Ryoanji, Kyoto's celebrated temple garden of rock and sand . East and West, war and peace, water and land: these surrealist juxtapositions compose a haunting meditation on the architect's role in a shrinking globe.
The German show is shocking. The exhibition focuses on Berlin, logical for the first Biennale held since the government returned there. The theme is the capital's transformation over the last catastrophic century. One gallery displays huge black and white street maps that track the city's development at 10-year intervals. In the second gallery, we segue smoothly from moral neutrality to moral equivalency. The wall is hung with photographs of Berlin landmarks as they are transformed or destroyed, by wars hot and cold. Captions are limited to name, address and year. This presentation confuses chronology with history. The result is that history is brutalized.
IF I hadn't known that Arata Isozaki was the Japan Pavilion's commissioner, I would have thought the project on view there was the handiwork of Madame Butterfly's marriage broker. Titled "City of Girls," the project was organized by Kazuko Koike and designed by Kazuyo Sejima and Ryue Nishizawa. The theme is gender. Specifically, it presents the Japanese adolescent female as a model of sensibility for the 21st-century city. The architects see her as a figure not yet fully indoctrinated by cultural tradition. Her response to beauty and ugliness is visceral.
To Western eyes, the display looks as dubious as it sounds. The entire pavilion, and a large swath of the garden around it, has been whitewashed, including the trunks of trees. The floor, on several levels, is lined with white gravel. It is noisy and hard to walk on. A square of gravel is planted with rows of tiny plastic daisies. Very cute. A second square has been excised from the floor, creating a well you can peer into. People walk around down there beneath a cantilevered section of the building. Ahh. From the ceiling hangs an overcoat, titled "Mother," designed by Kosuke Tsumura for homeless women. Oh! Oh!
But this work does not fit neatly into Western grids of comprehension. I enjoyed the mixture of sentimentality and sophistication, but felt that I was missing a lot, as you do when you travel to any foreign city. In the era of monocultural familiarity, that sense of strangeness is not only to be savored but also to be trusted.
My favorite work is a perfectly straightforward rendition of the Biennale's theme. Designed by two young Finnish architects, it is a small floating park set within the cargo hold of a rusting freight barge. Moored off the quay of the Arsenale, the barge is partly filled with the city's sludge (the effluent has been treated and doesn't stink). The sludge is covered with a thick layer of gravel, from which rises a small stand of oaks. The leaf crowns are partly visible from the quay, but you can't see the park itself until you climb a gangway to the deck of the barge. From there, you descend another gangway into the trees. Benches line the sides of the barge. A crane, looming above like an enormous sculpture, heightens the serenity of the place. The key to the project is the relationship between two exterior spaces, one enclosed by walls, the second given scale by the crane.
The project retrieves the modern concept of the architect as problem solver. You can see it as a prototype for a community garden on an industrial waterfront, but what is mainly on view is an intelligence that can be applied to different conditions. The fusion of public space, sustainability and visual imagery can take many forms.
Heightened awareness can be ethics enough. This is the moral foundation of Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio's work. They build on it here with a project displayed at the show of international work at the Italian pavilion. "Pageant" is a seven-minute computer animation loop on corporate logos. Using black figures on a white field, the loop lines up the icons of the usual monocultural suspects: Disney, Nike, Baby Bells, Texaco, Shell, McDonald's.
This, too, could be considered an example of blob design, as each logo morphs into the next, an endlessly mutable contrast in black and white, signifying nothing. Of course, the power of this nothingness is immense and growing. What ultimately won't be branded? It is astounding to recognize how much nothing we now hold in our heads. The consumerist blob is inside us, competing for market share.
ArchLab, the offering at the United States Pavilion, raises the ghost of the Ugly American, that figure of cold war fun. Members of the European press, among others, have interpreted the show's massive deployment of computer technology as a flashy display of imperial power in the post-cold war era. No doubt computer and military hardware are equivalent on some plane. But I saw the ArchLab as an urbanist, not a nationalist manifestation.
Organized by Max Hollein, Hans Hollein's son and a senior staff member of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation in New York, the project brought together students and faculty from two architecture schools, Columbia University and U.C.L.A. The two groups were assigned different wings in the pavilion, a red brick kiosk of Jeffersonian aspirations, where they worked for four weeks in full public view.
John Hockenberry, the NBC correspondent, was quoted recently in Sony Style on the difference between real innovation and technological illusion: "Innovation changes lives; illusion offers empty promises." Perhaps architecture schools can't afford to patrol the line between innovation and illusion too fiercely. Thought cops could inhibit freedom of research. But the laxity creates an environment in which many illusionists come to believe that they're actually sawing the lady in half.
Hani Rashid, the team director of the Columbia group, has been working the hocus-pocus angle for some time. With his partner in the New York-based Studio Asymptote, Lise Ann Couture, he has cornered a modest niche as a maker of hybrid designs that supposedly fuse architecture with computer technology. As I see it, the only fusion going on here is the old one of smoke and mirrors.
On one monitor, a stick figure gymnast tumbles toward the viewer, morphing the surrounding space into gray ripples. This is supposed to signify the advent of Moving Man, a contemporary replacement of Vitruvian Man, the measure of all things classical. But what we actually saw was a classical, axial cartoon with wavy-gravy walls. Computers could be an invaluable tool for exploring the kinesthetic sense, but this project didn't scratch the surface. The visuals were sexy but vapid.
Another room contained a giant pipe cleaner construction, executed in glowing blue wires. You couldn't get inside it. The wires, which were rigid, were supported by grids of transparent fishing line. I asked Rashid about the grid. I thought the point of using this software was to get away from grids. "This is the grid in a computer model. It shows what it would be like if you were inside the screen." But in a computer model, the grids are curved. And if we were inside the screen, we would be inside the model. "That's a technical limitation." Perhaps. But it's a limitation that others, like the Ocean group from Scandinavia, have got beyond. Also, this model doesn't move. "But it does. See? It vibrates against the blue background. It draws on the tradition of Op Art." Oh. Silly of me not to notice that.
Rashid is a very talented fellow. And I don't doubt that one day we'll all be spending lots of time in virtual space. What's missing here is a sense of real, historical time. Cities are still social condensers. Bodies still require bricks and mortar structures. If they don't concentrate on developing new forms in the material city, today's architecture students could end up as low-level technical consultants at Industrial Light and Magic.
Greg Lynn, who led the U.C.L.A. team, is not yet an innovator. He has still to make the major breakthrough many in the architecture world are expecting of him. But Lynn's experiments with software-driven design are more than technological illusion. U.C.L.A.'s presentation, titled "The Embryonic House," was the more solid -- and Darwinian -- of the two.
Lynn's assignment was simple: be fruitful and multiply. Using Alias Wavefront's Maya software program, the students produced an open-ended essay on the theme of abundance. Given guidelines for a single-family dwelling, their task was to develop variations. The complex, curvilinear computer images they produced were sent to an adjacent model shop where a jig-saw cut them into wood and plastic modules. These were then fashioned into scale models and displayed, along with the modules and computer renderings, in a gallery. The purpose of this exercise is to transfer the blob from the still largely virtual to the physical.
RUSKIN would have loved this. So, I suspect, would Paco Rabanne. One of the designs on view recalls Rabanne's metal disc dresses from the 1960's. It lacked only a fluorescent Dynel wig and a splash of Metal to complete the retro ensemble. And you didn't have to be told that it was in the Pop Tart tradition. But this was a Platonic performance. Ambition was within shouting distance of achievement. Lynn pushed the students to venture further than he has gone in his own work.
It has been said that despite the emphasis on variation, blob designs all look the same, and that blob designers haven't fully reckoned with the realities of construction. I see this work as a genuine mutation, a natural response to the displacement of bricks and mortar by virtual space. It is not possible, at this point, to know where this response might lead. But Lynn is encouraging his students to emulate nature: to throw a bunch of combinations out there with the expectation that some of them will survive and mutate further in an environment that is also rapidly evolving.
ArchLab's format was a mutation itself. I can't recall a presentation that placed greater emphasis on process, not to mention one that incorporated architects into the display. I didn't see the interaction I had hoped for between the East and West Coast teams. Each kept pretty much to its own game. Still, the latent competition between Rashid and Lynn underscored the idea that New York and Los Angeles had volved into the east and west sides of a single metropolitan condition.
The Biennale's strongest message is that this interurban linkage will accelerate at the global level. A struggle has already emerged between large corporate offices and independent "star" architects, operating as independent contractors with skeletal staffs, who are available for hire much like actors or choreographers. The star system is not going to wither away. There will be more and more stars. They could become a counterculture to the monoculture, or they could become the icing on its cake. Enlightened clients will hire them. What they will bring to the table is risk. Risk is their brand. Clients will demand the brand as they recognize that risk is a more valuable commodity than safety, even in purely commercial terms. The blob may turn out to be more significant as a metaphor for this development -- a logo for risk -- than for the formal qualities of blob designs.
That is the first answer to the question I took to Venice. (An extended treatment of these concepts can be found in Ben Van Berkel and Caroline Bos's book "Move," a manifesto published last year by UN Studio and Goose Press.) A second was suggested by a Venetian friend, Franca Coin. Ms. Coin is president of the Venetian Foundation, the outfit that runs most of the city's major museums. She lives in the Palazzo Barbaro, a Grand Canal mansion of fabled cosmopolitan pedigree. Henry James stayed there for five weeks in 1887, and later used it as the setting for "The Wings of the Dove." I ran into her a few hours after she'd paid a visit to the United States Pavilion.
"They're here! They're here!" she exclaimed, with a look of delight. I assumed she was referring to the pavilion's new breed of wired-up, net-surfing artists, more talked about than seen in a rear-view mirror city like Venice. Ms. Coin was talking about that, in part. But she was more impressed by the ethnic diversity of the students: not just that one was black, or another Asian, but that she couldn't tell, just from looking at them, what their racial ancestry was.
I would have overlooked this if my friend hadn't mentioned it. New Yorkers are supposed to take racial diversity for granted. We tend to think it's racist to take note of someone's race. But there are times when overlooking race amounts to denying reality, including one's own.
Returning to New York, I ran into Ms. Coin at the airport. She was off to Greece. I noticed that she had taken the names and phone numbers of some of the students. She said she wanted to invite them to lunch when she got back. "We are starved for conversation about today," she said.
So are we, it struck me, as I headed to the gate. In New York, the conversation about today -- about architecture, about race, about contemporaneity itself -- has been squelched since the 70's, never more brutally than in the past seven years, as the reactionaries have dug in their heels. This has been suicidal as well as unjust. Diversity is the greatest asset of cities worldwide as well as the common thread between us. More ethics. More aesthetics. More genetics. The splicing of these strands will continue well beyond the Biennale.

HEADLINE: COUNTY LINES;
One Man's Faith in Destiny

BYLINE: By ROBERT WORTH

 BODY:
HAL BECKOFF is that rare thing in the quiet towns of Westchester: a prophet. "I believe the veil has been lifted from my eyes so that I can see," he said in the Mamaroneck apartment where he lived with a friend for most of the last two years.
Mr. Beckoff, who is 60 and unemployed, does not hear voices or see visions, and he has never suffered from mental illness. He is not a member of any church or organized religion. But he believes that he has discovered the truth about God and the Bible, and has written up his beliefs in a book titled "Mystery of God Revealed." 
 It is his second book. The first, self-published several years ago, is also titled "Mystery of God Revealed."
"It was such a good title, I couldn't resist using it again," he said. But the new book represents his latest thoughts about God's mysteries, which he believes could change the world.
If all this sounds a little unusual for Westchester, so is Mr. Beckoff's life story. After a solidly middle-class career as a legal typist in Manhattan, he was unable to make the shift to using a computer at work. The firm he worked for, Garbarini & Scher, was patient with him for years, and finally began docking his pay. He left, and when his savings ran out he struggled unsuccessfully to find a new job. Finally, he was evicted from his apartment and was on the verge of homelessness almost two years ago.
He was taken in by Robert Suval, whom he had met when both were working as extras on the film "The Siege," and who lives in an apartment owned by his parents in Mamaroneck. Mr. Suval, who grew up in New Rochelle, has had his own struggles with work. He sells ice cream from a truck seven months a year and works part time in a pizza parlor the rest of the year. He was married and had two children, but his wife left him, he said, because he was unable to provide a home for her.
Mr. Beckoff and Mr. Suval represent the kind of downward mobility that has become all but invisible in recent years, at least in wealthy communities like Mamaroneck. The economic boom of the past decade has created the illusion that anyone can find work, making life harder -- or more humiliating -- for those who are falling out of the middle class.
And in a sense, Mr. Beckoff's religious beliefs -- like those of many prophets before him -- represent an effort to transcend the struggles of his life. The mystery he claims to have discovered in the Bible can be boiled down to one word: reincarnation. He believes that we will all have a chance to redeem our failures in a future life, or many future lives.
Mr. Beckoff is the first to admit that he is no scholar and that his discoveries are sheer intuition. "God does some truly outrageous things," he said, like causing people to suffer in famine and war. "But if you impose reincarnation on the Bible, you can see how God can tell people to do such horrible things -- they will have to face that karma somewhere down the line." For the last year and a half, Mr. Suval and Mr. Beckoff have spent much of their time discussing God in Mr. Suval's apartment.
Mr. Suval, who was raised Jewish but does not attend any synagogue, said he had found Mr. Beckoff's faith inspiring. "Being with Hal, I was able to see a way of being saved -- I can see a way to go out with my head held up high, even though I didn't have any accomplishment," he said.
Unlike Mr. Suval, Mr. Beckoff never doubted that his failures were providential. When he did not find work he did not despair. "I realized I was being held back, that I was not supposed to find work. Instead of hitting my head against the wall, I decided God wanted me to trust."
In fact, Mr. Beckoff's trust in God may have gone too far. In early May he left Mamaroneck for a homeless shelter in Manhattan. "I know something is going to rescue me," he said in an interview a few days before he left. "I know my book is meant to get out there. I know I'm protected."
So far, he has not found a job, but he has found friends at the homeless shelter where he has been living at 41st Street and Ninth Avenue. And his faith in his destiny has not wavered.

HEADLINE: Q&A/Senator Joseph I. Lieberman;
Seeking a 3rd Term (And Maybe More?)

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL

 BODY:
SENATOR Joseph I. Lieberman recently came back to his old Stamford neighborhood to officially announce his intention to run for a third term representing Connecticut in the United States Senate.
But in kicking off his bid for re-election in the backyard at his 85-year-old mother's house, Mr. Lieberman could not quell growing speculation he is on a short list of high-profile Democrats who will be seriously considered as a running mate for Vice President Al Gore at the party's Convention Aug. 13-17 in Los Angeles. 
 A centrist Democrat who stunned former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. when he beat him by 10,000 votes in 1988, Mr. Lieberman has gained a national reputation as one of the stronger moral voices in the Senate.
Mr. Lieberman, who is an Orthodox Jew, was the first Democrat to publicly criticize President Clinton for his "morally reprehensible" behavior in the affair with Monica S. Lewinsky -- though he voted against removing the president from office.
In the United States Senate, Mr. Lieberman, 58, became the ranking Democratic member of the Governmental Affairs Committee in January 1999. Since 1995, he has been chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council.
Mr. Lieberman served as majority leader of the Connecticut Senate for six years during the 1970's and as the state's 21st Attorney General from 1982-88.
Recently, Mr. Lieberman raised concerns in a highly publicized letter to United States Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt over an issue of growing concern to Connecticut residents -- the petition process for Native American tribes seeking federal recognition. Mr. Lieberman, who attended Yale, also has a strong interest in the environment, having helped to establish a Long Island Sound office in the Environmental Protection Agency, promoting a national wildlife refuge along the Connecticut River, and helping to strengthen federal Clean Air standards.
Recently, Mr. Lieberman took some time out during one of his regular "diner stops" in New Haven -- the city where he lives with his wife, Hadassah -- to have a bagel and a cup of coffee and talk about his 30-year political career and future. Following are excerpts of that conversation.
 
Q. Considering your recent announcement of seeking a third term in the United States Senate, what are you most proud of accomplishing during your first two terms?
A. Perhaps the most remarkable transition that has occurred during the past 12 years is to watch the economy of this state and country. We have gone from real deep recession to the boom period we're in now where most people are living better lives than before. I am also proud of strides we have made in environmental protection areas, keeping our defenses strong, and having been an advocate for the Connecticut defense industry and jobs.
Q. There are still many people who haven't benefited from the economic boom. What can be done to help them?
A. One of the key goals of the next period of our history will be not only be to continue the strong economy and sustain economic growth, but to make sure that some of the people who have been left out of the rising tide of our economy are included. You do that with better public education and a much more aggressive program of job training and re-training, for people who are unemployed -- to match them up with the jobs that do exist.
Q. You have been heavily involved in environmental issues. What are the most important environmental issues facing Connecticut?
A. The two most pressing environmental priorities for Connecticut are cleaner air and water. Smog remains a serious problem for us in Connecticut. We still haven't met our goal of going a full year with satisfactory air quality measured by levels of the six worst pollutants in the air. Reports say 41 percent of Hartford school children have asthma -- the highest rate in the country.
It's equally important that we address a major threat to our water supply -- the gasoline additive MTBE, which is potentially toxic and has leaked into our ground water supply and has contaminated the water we drink and bathe in.
Q. There has been a lot of speculation about the vice presidency, that you are on a short list of potential running mates for Vice President Al Gore. What have you heard about your chances?
A. Obviously I'm honored to have my name mentioned for the vice presidency and I would have to seriously consider such an offer. It makes my mother proud just to be mentioned as a possibility. But I don't expect it to happen. Right now the only office I intend to seek this year is re-election to the U.S. Senate.
Q. You are an Orthodox Jew. Is the country ready for a Jewish vice president, or even president?
A. I think this is a remarkably tolerant country at this time. I honestly don't think any candidate for national office will lose because of his or her religion, race, gender, or nationality. I think the public is so fair and sophisticated they are going to judge candidates for national office based on his or her qualities and capacity to do the job.
Q. If elected vice president, would your duties in any way be curtailed by being an Orthodox Jew, for example not being able to work on Saturdays or high holy days?
A. I have always tried to separate pure politics on the Sabbath, which I don't do, from governmental responsibility. It seems to me my religion, as I understand it, not only permits me to fulfill important work associated with being a public servant, but actually requires me to do so because people are depending on me. I don't see that as an issue at all.
Q. What led you to so strongly criticizing President Bill Clinton for his involvement with Monica Lewinsky?
A. It was one of the hardest decisions I've ever made in my public life because President Clinton is a friend and I have tremendous admiration for him for the job he's done as president. But I was so upset by what he had done and the fact he hadn't leveled with the American people. I felt it wasn't going to get better until somebody who was his friend and supporter came publicly with honest and open criticism.
Q. You knew Bill Clinton in the early 1970's when you first ran for elected office in the State Senate and he was a student at Yale. Any recollections about the president at that time?
A. In 1970, when I first campaigned for office, I was the reform candidate running against the incumbent Democrat, and most of the political organizations -- most of the grown-ups -- were supporting the incumbent. I had a bunch of kids working for me.
In the middle of that campaign, Bill Clinton, then a Yale law student, walked into my headquarters and offered to help. I do remember him and we always kept in touch after that.
Later, I think I actually may have been the first Democrat to come out and support him.
Q. Why did you support Bill Clinton so early in his presidential campaign?
A. Most importantly we agreed on ideas, that the Democratic party had to move back to the center and had to express new ideas instead of following policies that were two, three and four decades old and no longer working either for our party or for the country.
Q. In your latest book published this year, "In Praise of Public Life," you strongly defend public service and write about how important it is to serve. Does it dismay you there are so many Connecticut legislative races this year that are uncontested? Is it apathy or are people afraid to challenge incumbents?
A. It concerns me a great deal. I am very surprised at how few state legislative races in Connecticut are uncontested this year. I think that is partly an expression of the broader problem of people generally being less interested in politics or political involvement. But I think a lot of these legislative districts have become pretty strongly included toward one party or the other, so people in the out party don't want to run.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 12; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1401 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Foundering Ocean Township Mall Is Bulking Up

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: OCEAN TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
FOR much of its 23 years, the million-square-foot Seaview Square shopping center here has been overshadowed by the area's older and larger Monmouth Mall, five miles north in Eatontown.
Last month, however, new owners bought the foundering shopping center, at the juncture of Routes 35, 66 and 18, and plan to convert both the way it looks and the type of stores that give it its character. The cost is estimated at $67 million, including the $17 million purchase price paid to the seller, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of Manhattan. 
 The mall is being converted into what merchandising specialists call a "power center," which is defined by the International Council of Shopping Centers in Manhattan as an open-air retail strip with at least 250,000 square feet and three or more large discount specialty outlets, or so-called big box stores. Seaview Square's conversion to such a center will be made through a process called demalling: replacing most of a mall's smaller stores by large tenants, eliminating its common area and turning it inside out so that its stores face the road.
Ocean Township officials have rezoned the Seaview Square site for the conversion. And Starwood-Heller L.L.C., the new owners, will retain the two active anchors -- Sears and Value City, with 200,000 square feet each -- and convert them to free-standing buildings. The more than 3,000 existing parking spaces will also be retained.
But the mall's remaining 600,000 square feet will be razed. That space includes what had been a third anchor, a 180,000-square-foot building that was a Stern's, and a separate movie theater, as well as some 40 smaller stores, about half of which are vacant. The remaining retailers lease their stores on a month-to-month basis and will relocate, according to Starwood-Heller, which is a joint venture between G. Heller Enterprises of Edgewater, a developer of residential, office and retail properties, and the Starwood Capital Group of Greenwich, Conn.
The owners will demolish the old mall once all approvals from the township are secured, which is expected this fall. Construction of the new center will follow in the next year.
As now envisioned, the new center, which will keep the Seaview Square name, will have three big-box retailers, including Target, a discount department store, and Lowe's, a hardware store. Both have signed on to lease land on the site for 150,000-square-foot stores, which they will build themselves, said Gene Heller, a partner at Starwood-Heller.
There will also be a supermarket of up to 60,000 square feet, a central food court and about a dozen smaller stores, totaling 150,000 square feet. Annual rents are expected to be $13 to $20 a square foot. Future plans may also include a 400,000-square-foot office structure, if a tenant to occupy the building can be found.
"The existing mall is nearly desolate," Mr. Heller said. "But the cost to buy so large a piece of land at the intersection of three highways was a good value and a good start. We think added value can be accomplished here."
Those prospects please Terrance D. Weldon, the mayor of Ocean Township, who said the mall was the largest taxpayer in his 14-square-mile community of 28,000 people. Over the years, as the mall lost its tenants and panache, he said, successful tax appeals by the owners cut the revenue to the township from more than $1 million a year in half. Once the mall is converted, Mayor Weldon said, estimates are that the lost annual tax revenue will be restored.
Many retail brokers said Seaview Square's chances of success this time were enhanced for several reasons. Among them is that the population in that eastern section of Monmouth County has increased enough over the years to support more stores, said Jonathan Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization TCN, a real estate services company in Woodbridge.
A demographic study done by Equitable showed that as of 1998 there were 144,000 people with an average annual household income of $61,614 living within a five-mile radius of Seaview Square.
Its conversion is also taking place as the state's economy is healthy and the retail market relatively strong. "Though retailers are expecting sales to be down 1 to 2 percent this year, the numbers will still be good," said Ted Kraus, who heads TKO Retail Advisors, a consulting firm in Mercerville. He said the weakness was due to a leveling off of the consumption frenzy of the last few years. Still, he said, rental rents are rising and the overall retail vacancy rate in the state is less than 3 percent.
The planned conversion of Seaview Square makes sense, Mr. Kraus said, because it reuses a large tract of suitably zoned land, a dwindling commodity in the state. And the popularity of such "power centers," he added, continues to be fueled by the expansion of big-box retailers like Target and Lowe's.
Matthew Harding, a vice president at the Levin Management Corporation, a retail management concern in North Plainfield, added, "These are tough times for moderate-sized enclosed regional malls, which need to be up-to-date to compete." He said that as a power center Seaview Square would complement rather than compete with the 1.4-million-square-foot Monmouth Mall, and with newer retail centers like the 10-year-old, 1.4-million-square-foot Freehold Raceway Mall in nearby Freehold Township.
When Seaview Square opened in 1977, it was seen as a "a major benefit to the township because it was constructed on the site of a former closed landfill, ridding us of an eyesore," Mayor Weldon said. It was built by Equitable in partnership with the Goodman Company of Philadelphia. The insurer bought out its partner in 1981.
The mall was successful at first, only to lose momentum when just three of the four planned anchors opened up.. Its downward slide continued as the Monmouth Mall siphoned off shoppers. In 1992, Equitable renovated Seaview Square, but that did not succeed in turning the mall around. In 1996, Stern's and the movie theater closed, spurring many of the smaller retailers to leave.
Last month, Equitable sold the mall. The sale was part of "Equitable's strategy to reduce its equity investments in real estate to a core group of assets," said Mary Beth Lally, an associate at Lend Lease Real Estate Investments in Manhattan, which advises the insurer on real estate.
Mr. Heller of Starwood-Heller said his company was working with township officials on the design of the new center to meet their concerns that it "be extensively landscaped and intelligently done."
Under preliminary plans drawn by Keith Michaels, the company's architect, the two existing anchors will be bookends to the new Seaview Square. In between them, the Target store will rise, as will a two-story retail component housing the smaller stores. The other two big-box stores will be to the north of them where the site significantly rises, enabling all to be visible from the highway.
Mr. Michaels said that the areas around the buildings would be landscaped and that although all the stores would have their own exterior entrances they would be connected by walkways. There will also be a two-story food court that he said would be the center's focal point.
"The concept," he said, "is to thread together all these disparate big pieces to create a community, rather than a power center where each big box is an island onto itself."
Mayor Weldon said community reaction to the project "so far has been positive" because it will revitalize a failing center and be built on recycled land, not pristine property. But there are worries over increased traffic.
To address those concerns, Mayor Weldon said talks were under way with Starwood-Heller to help pay for enlarging an intersection at Route 35, which will be a fourth entrance to the site. He said that the township had received a $175,000 grant from the state for the $300,000 highway project and that he hoped Starwood-Heller would contribute the rest.
Mr. Heller said that his company "knows the conversion will work" because of the initial responses of retailers like Target and Lowe's. When asked if keeping the Seaview Square name would be a deterrent, given the mall's history, he said: "The mall may have been known for all the wrong reasons, but it was certainly known. And when we change it, people will want to see what it has become."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In /Essex, Conn.;
A Colonial Sense of Community Endures

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THE deep coves of the Connecticut River provided the protected harbor that made Essex the region's predominant shipping and shipbuilding port from before the Revolutionary War to the advent of the railroads in the mid-1800's. Situated six miles upriver from the Long Island Sound and safe from its stormy tides, this town of 6,000 continues to bond with the water, but now for pleasure rather than for commerce.
Although some people consider a boat a virtual necessity here, a small house and a well-worn canoe may lie next door to a mansion with a pier and a 60-foot yacht. Since the mid-1600's development has reflected a colonial sense of community, minimizing the number of neighborhoods based on income or architectural style. 
 "People don't put as much value here on how big your house is, what car you drive, or how many things you've acquired," said Terry Smith, a "newcomer" who moved to Essex, about 30 miles east of New Haven, from Oyster Bay, N.Y., five years ago. "If you want to have an extravagant birthday party for your child, you can. But if you want to keep it simple, that's not an issue."
Her husband, Brant Smith, is a senior partner in Smith Hanley Associates, an executive search firm in Manhattan. Like many people, he has been freed from a daily commute by the communications revolution. "I go into New York once a week now," he said. "I enjoy Essex immensely. It has people from every walk of life, and they are heavily involved as volunteers with the running of the town."
Vintage homes lining the narrow village streets have been restored in a low-key style. One reason for the number of such homes, said Donald Malcarne, the town historian, is that "poverty preserves." He explained that when the railroads replaced boats, Essex suffered a long economic downturn. "Those houses are still standing," he said. "Nobody wanted them until they got discovered by Fairfield County and Westchester County and New York City."
Richard T. Weiner, an associate broker at the Mitchel Agency, a local real estate company, said: "Essex is the sort of community people are looking for these days. "Good schools, light traffic, beautiful scenery, no 'cookie cutter' homes or stores, access to the water, and crime is almost nonexistent." There is one traffic light, one resident state trooper and three constables. The volunteer fire department has a roster of 56 firefighters and a new $2 million firehouse.
Talbot's is the only chain store. The local shops along Main Street bear names likeHastings House Asian and English Antiques, the Clipper Ship Independent Bookstore, Debbie's Restaurant and Drugstore, and the Essex Coffee & Tea Company.
"You have to go out about three miles to find a dry cleaner or a supermarket," said Skip Hubbard, the publisher of The Main Street News, the local weekly. Here, the emphasis is on old-fashioned service. For example, Bennie's, a 65-year-old family-owned market, cuts meats to order (no prepackaging), does not mist the lettuce and roasts beef and chicken daily for takeout lunches.
The Town of Essex is made up of three parts. Essex village, which lies along the river, bustles with shops and restaurants. The Town Hall can be found here, plus a number of yacht clubs, marinas and boat launches. Its homes date from the 18th century.
TO the west of the village, in a triangle bounded by Routes 604, 602 and 153, Centerbrook has a number of commercial and light-industrial buildings in and around Essex Industrial Park, but it is also growing as a retail and residential location.
Ivoryton, to the north and west of Centerbrook, was named for the 19th-century Comstock-Cheney factory where most of the world's ivory piano keys were made until plastics took over 50 years ago. The factory has now been converted to a multiuse commercial building.
Of the total of 2,900 dwellings in the town, most are single-family homes. About 65 houses and a couple of condominiums are currently for sale in what is generally characterized as a tight market. Roger Parkman, a broker in Essex office of DeWolfe New England, said: "People coming here from outside want to be in the village or within walking distance, where house prices start in the low $300,000's. Prices in Centerbrook and Ivoryton may be 5 to 10 percent less."
Among the highest-priced homes now on the market is the $1.2 million mansion built in 1830 by E. E. Dickinson, the founder of the witch-hazel distillery that operated in Essex for 150 years (the factory has been converted to mixed commercial uses). Overlooking North Cove and the Connecticut River, the house has 26 rooms and 10 fireplaces.
For people who want a new house, there are three subdivisions available. "At Farm Hill Estates in Ivoryton, 22 one-acre home sites are available and one spec house has been built for $459,500," said Cathy Schellan of Prudential Connecticut Dunham Realtors, which is handling the sales.
At two other developments, Southwinds, off Route 153, and Windswept Ridge, off Old Dobbin Road in Ivoryton, seven houses are available at each, at prices ranging from $320,000 to $550,000. The DeWolfe office in Old Saybrook, Conn., is handling the sales.
Future development may be curtailed if a zoning proposal that would raise the minimum lot size from one to two acres is approved and implemented this summer. "There was not one speaker or letter in opposition at the public hearing," said Peter B. Webster, the first selectman. "It's a major change that will preserve enough good soil for septics and wells."
Weston and Sharon Bray, who now live in Wilton, Conn., with their two children, ages 7 and 9, are moving to Essex, but doing it gradually to accommodate business and family adjustments. "We're concerned about how developed Fairfield County is getting, so we bought a 5,000-square-foot house on the water in Essex," said Mr. Bray, the chief executive of Marketing Drive Worldwide, a global marketing services company with headquarters in Wilton. "We'll move our two children, two dogs, two cats and two birds over the course of three years," he said. "We like the distinctive seafaring heritage of Essex, and the Gris has the best bar in Connecticut."
The Gris (pronounced Griz) is short for the Griswold, a historic 32-room inn and tavern built on Main Street in 1776 and now owned by the three Paul brothers, Doug, Geoff and Greg. The Griswold bills itself as the oldest continuously operating inn in the state, and its taproom, built in 1748 as the town's first schoolhouse, has a domed ceiling made of a clamshell plaster strengthened with horsehair.
Dinner for two with wine, tax and tip can run to $125, and rooms are $90 to $195 a night. At Christmastime, the menu features game -- venison, moose, pheasant and quail -- served by a staff in colonial costumes while diners are serenaded by madrigal singers.
ANOTHER well-known Essex hostelry is the Copper Beech Inn, built in the 1880's by the Comstock family, the co-owner of the piano key factory, as their residence. Most of the 23 rooms in the house and converted barn have Victorian furnishings. A favorite dish in the restaurant is bouillabaisse made with local fish. Dinner for two with wine, tax and tip runs around $120, and rooms are $105 to $175, including breakfast.
The Essex schools emphasize individualized instruction, and the pupil-teacher ratio is about 15 to 1. Essex Elementary School has an enrollment of about 500 students in kindergarten through the sixth grade. From there, students go on to the regional John Winthrop Middle School and to the Valley Regional High School District No. 4, both in Deep River, Conn.
In College Board tests last year students' verbal scores averaged 530 and math scores averaged 523, compared with statewide averages of 510 for verbal and 509 for math. About 80 percent of the 87 graduates in the class of 2000 are going on to college.
"The high school operates on a four-period day with 80-minute classes," said Dr. John Gillespie, the superintendent of the Valley Regional School District No. 4. "This enables students to complete a year's work in half a year and take a greater variety of courses. And it allows teachers more flexibility."
The Essex Yacht Club, the largest of five private yacht clubs, has 40 slips, 70 moorings and a restaurant; its waiting list now runs about a year. Among the numerous marinas are Brewer's Dauntless Shipyard and the Essex Island Marina, which occupies a 13-acre island in the Connecticut River and offers a restaurant, pool and dockage for boats up to 200 feet at $2.65 a foot.
One of Essex's cultural landmarks is the venerable Ivoryton Playhouse, a year-round theater where Katharine Hepburn, Marlon Brando, Tallulah Bankhead, Mae West and other stars have performed.
Baseball, soccer and tennis are available at four town fields and four town tennis courts at no charge. The operation of recreational activities, including instruction, is left to community volunteers. "That's how we keep the tax rate down," said Don Mesite, who volunteers as the chairman of the parks and recreation commission.
