HEADLINE: Subletting: From Stopgap to Cash Cow

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
SUBLETTING of co-ops -- not so long ago a possible indicator of a building's dire financial straits and even, for some shareholders, the last gasp before abandoning their apartments -- isn't what it used to be. For one thing, it's become increasingly profitable.
Take, as an extreme example, the recent sublet of a sublet of a sublet of a sublet. 
 "It started with an original lease of $2,200 a month for a one-bedroom in the East 40's," said Roger Novatt, the managing director of Sumitomo Real Estate Sales. "The people were transferred out of town, and the owner would not let them break the lease. So they sublet the apartment for $2,750."
 "And the same thing happened to the $2,750 people -- a business transfer out of town," Mr. Novatt said. "So they sublet for $3,250 a month."
The apartment is now renting to a fourth tenant for $4,000 a month, with the profits going, after each switch, to the previous sublettor. "It's totally illegal in terms of board regulations, but some buildings just don't pay attention to what's going on," Mr. Novatt said. "The shareholder could rent to a nice, quiet young lady and end up with trapeze artists."
Subletting of sublets, Mr. Novatt added, "is happening all over the city, in fancy buildings as well as walk-ups, but primarily in the Midtown area."
New York City's rental market has become so tight and jarringly expensive, particularly in Manhattan, that subletting is an increasingly alluring prospect for some shareholders -- individual owners as well as sponsors who have retained ownership of numbers of apartments in buildings they converted -- sometimes to the chagrin of co-op boards and resident shareholders.
At the same time, with sales of apartments booming, the availability of units for subletting has dropped, exacerbating the city's housing shortage and further squeezing up rents. "Just five, six years ago when people were unable to sell but could either no longer afford the apartment or had to move, they would sublet," said Stuart M. Saft, the chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums. "It was the only liquidity in the market."
"And because of the large number of these people involved, the boards permitted it," Mr. Saft continued, "because if a board strictly imposed a 'no sublet' policy, they could find themselves voted out of office."
"Now, come forward to 2000, where the market is much stronger and selling is not a problem," Mr. Saft said. "The economics have changed because, as a result of the housing shortage, there are people who want to sublease their apartments as a profit center, a way of producing income."
Though unaware of the sublet-of-a-sublet phenomenon in the boroughs outside of Manhattan, Barbara Frechter, the president of Glenjay Realty in Forest Hills, Queens, can certainly attest to subletting's shift from act of desperation to profit plan.
"In the early and mid-90's, most people could not sell, and a lot of people who couldn't sublet walked away from their apartments, just left them," said Ms. Frechter, a former president of the Long Island Board of Realtors, which includes Queens. "The interesting thing is that people who started out subletting from necessity are now subletting as an investment, because in a lot of cases they are making a profit."
The motive is hardly peculiar to individual shareholders. Speaking as a sponsor with an interest in 1,500 apartments in 30 co-ops in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx, Manhattan, Westchester and Rockland, Susan Hewitt, the president of the Cheshire Group, said a major problem for some buildings is that their sponsors "are making so much money renting that they won't sell their apartments."
"And they are effectively holding these co-ops hostage as quasi-rental buildings," Ms. Hewitt added, saying that she strongly prefers to sell. "Frankly, we're in the business of increasing the value of the apartments in a co-op," she said, "and we feel that's best achieved by increasing owner-occupancy."
The shift in subletting's focus has recast, though hardly dissipated, the contentiousness that has laced the issue since the surge in co-op conversion began in the early 1980's.
There are struggles over where a board should draw the line on when and to whom to rent, and constant concerns about a co-op's quality of life. A point of continuing conflict is the ratio of owner-occupants to renters, and how that weighs against the building's ability to refinance its underlying mortgage and for prospective buyers to obtain loans for individual apartments -- commonly called end loans.
Still heard are charges of favoritism toward owner-occupants over shareholders who need or want to move -- and vice versa. There is also a recent court ruling that sent shudders through co-op boards because it held a board member directly liable for damages in a discrimination case involving a sublet.
And for would-be renters, there is the board approval process, which can rival applying for a mortgage in the intensity of financial disclosure.
Except for laws barring discrimination, a co-op board's policy on subletting is based on what is written in the development's proprietary lease. "There are some buildings," Ms. Hewitt pointed out, "that very self-consciously want to operate with few restrictions, to be analogous to condominiums, which have unrestricted subletting. And there are other buildings that restrict subletting because they want to have 'a family feeling.' "
Mr. Saft of the council of cooperatives said the courts have upheld the right of co-op boards "to limit or not permit subletting at all, or to establish conditions on subletting."
"A co-op board can say, for instance, that you can only sublet if you've lived in your apartment for, say, five years. Or you can only sublet one out of every three years," Mr. Saft said.
THE courts have also ruled in favor of co-ops when it comes to defining who is a guest or a sublettor. "People are going away for the summer or for a year," Mr. Saft said, "and are allowing someone to stay in the apartment while taking the position that that person is a guest, not a sublettor, because there is no fee being paid and no document called a sublease."
"But there are cases that hold that if someone is staying in an apartment and the owner is not there, that person is not a guest but a subtenant," Mr. Saft said, "even if no rent is being paid. People are surprised to hear that."
But it was the co-op boards that were taken aback in April when the Court of Appeals, New York State's highest court, ruled in a case called Biondi v. Beekman Hill House that a board president was personally liable for punitive damages as a result of the board's rejecting an interracial couple for a sublease.
The primary action in the Biondi case was that the couple was denied a lease under circumstances that the courts found to be racial discrimination, and that the board president had acted in bad faith. The couple won, and the president's bid for indemnification through the co-op's insurance policy was denied by the Court of Appeals.
"The underlying problem in cooperatives," said Robert Taylor, a partner in Rovegno & Taylor, a law firm in Forest Hills that specializes in real estate, "is that you need good people to run it, and if there's going to be personal exposure for actions of the board collectively, then it's one more reason why somebody might not want to risk his or her personal finances."
"It also means, as far as subletting is concerned," Mr. Taylor said, "that the boards are going to have to be very careful."
Subletting has always been a balancing act for the boards, primarily over what weight to give to preserving the co-op's sense of community against the immediate financial needs of individual shareholders and, in the longer term, the building's ability to obtain favorable rates when the underlying mortgage has to be refinanced.
By the early 90's, with the co-op market in a downward slide, "some buildings that had restrictions on subletting eased up because of those concerns about abandonment," Ms. Frechter of the Long Island realty board said.
"If a person abandoned the apartment, the bank that held the mortgage was obligated to pay the maintenance," she continued. "But a lot of banks would let the maintenance accumulate, regardless of pleas from the co-op; they would pay it, but not for months."
"In the meantime, the co-op had to make up that difference," Ms. Frechter added, "and the cash flow was definitely hurting."
Ms. Hewitt said that quality-of-life and financial issues often become entangled. "Part of the compelling reason for people to live in a co-op is stability, a feeling that they recognize their neighbors," she said. "And that's particularly important in a place like New York."
For resident shareholders, "sublets are a pain." Ms. Hewitt said. "They hate subletting, because these are the people who don't know not to put pizza boxes down the compactor chute."
It can get worse than that.
Ruth Farrago is the president of the board of Hyde Park Gardens, a 746-unit garden apartment co-op in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens. Ms. Farrago recalls too well some hellish tenants.
"There was an owner who resides in California who hired a real estate agent to sublet his apartment," she said. "The agent sublet without the owner's approval and signed the owner's name on the lease."
For the first five months, no rent was paid. Eviction proceedings started. "But by the time they got to court, the agent had put somebody else in the apartment," Ms. Farrago said, "so the legal documents were no good."
THE second subtenant was no better. "A year and a half later, we were finally able to get the second tenant evicted," she said, "and when the marshal went in to remove the furniture, the apartment had been trashed."
The walls, the floors, the bathroom had all been torn apart; garbage was strewn throughout. "When they lifted up the furniture, roaches just came flying out," Ms. Farrago said.
For the owner living in California, she said, "it was a total loss: no rent; he had to pay legal fees, the cleanup, and he was still responsible to pay us the maintenance."
Struggles over subletting can lead to "something like class warfare," said Ms. Hewitt, whose company has helped bring stability to several financially troubled co-ops in the last decade.
"We're the holders of unsold shares in a building in Yonkers where the co-op had great difficulty getting end loans, both because the market was depressed and because there were questions about subletting," she said.
Eventually, those financial problems lifted. "But the issue lived on," Ms. Hewitt said. "The central dispute at the annual meeting for two years running turned on subletting, with great hostility. The resident shareholders perceived those who sublet as having escaped, or as profiteering off their building. The sublettors claimed their economic right to their investment. Each side invoked moral authority."
Some boards face the sublet disharmony only when they refinance. They find themselves in a bind because, among other things, lenders require that their sublets be brought below a certain percentage.
"This produces all kinds of tensions," Ms. Hewitt said. "Do you grandfather people who already are subletting? Do you distinguish between investors and shareholders who outgrew their apartments? If a board reviews sublet applications on a case-by-case basis, what constitutes hardship? All of these are touchy issues for most co-ops."
Edward Howe, the managing director of the National Cooperative Bank, which has provided underlying mortgages for more than 2,000 buildings in the metropolitan area, said much of that pressure has been reduced in recent years.
"Five, six years ago, if a property was less than 75 percent owner-occupied, it was extremely difficult for the building to get financing and for individuals to get end loans," Mr. Howe said.
Today, if a co-op is 25 percent owner-occupied, financing is "readily available" at about 8.5 percent, Mr. Howe said. And for a building that is 90 percent owner-occupied, the rate is about 7.75 percent -- a three-quarter percentage point difference.
A typical underlying mortgage in the boroughs outside of Manhattan might be $1.5 million, he said, "so the difference would be about $9,500 a year in payments."
"The real difference, however," Mr. Howe said, "is that five years ago, a building that was 25 percent owner-occupied couldn't get financing."
Most co-ops are now "seasoned," pay their bills and are selling units because end-loan financing is available, he said. The current rate for an end loan in a building that is only 25 percent owner-occupied would be about 9.5 percent, while in a building that is 90 percent owner-occupied it would be about 8 percent. "For a $100,000 apartment with an $80,000 mortgage, that's about $1,000 a year difference in payments," Mr. Howe said.
"Five years ago, subletting was really taboo, and it's not the case anymore because the rental market is so strong," he said. "But this could all change again. It's kind of like being married -- one day it's good, one day it's not."
If the pressure is off the boards in these heady times, it is surely on the renter.
PEOPLE have to demonstrate mortgage-level disclosure, and it's driving them crazy," said Douglas Wagner, the president of Benjamin James Associates, a Manhattan brokerage company that specializes in rentals.
The demands certainly vary in the other boroughs, but at least in Manhattan, Mr. Wagner said, "It's worthy to note that when an applicant submits a complete board package, they've also submitted the first month's rent, a security deposit usually equal to two months' rent and some sort of co-op fees, which would include application fees of $200 to $500, nonrefundable, even if they don't get the apartment."
Then, typically, there are annual sublease fees of perhaps $600 to $1,200 that are passed along to the subtenant.
"So just to get out of the gate, the person has put down 30 pages of personal information, rent security and related co-op fees, which usually prohibit them from putting money down on anything else," Mr. Wagner said. "And then they have to wait three to six weeks for the approval meeting."
David Ellingrud, 24, has run the gantlet.
Mr. Ellingrud, an analyst for a management consulting firm, graduated from Dartmouth two years ago and with four friends from school, rented a $5,000-a-month duplex in an Upper East Side brownstone.
Now he is "tired of living like the dorm at school," he said.
Initially, Mr. Ellingrud and one of his roommates began looking for a place to share. "We bought one of those lists where you think you're going to find something and avoid the broker's fee," he said. "We looked on our own, and, I swear, one day we probably visited 40, 50 buildings, no exaggeration" -- studio after studio for $1,800, $2,000.
"But two people in a studio?" he said.
"When we did see a one-bedroom, it was for like $2,200," Mr. Ellingrud said, "and when you go there it's more like a studio where they put up two walls to make a bedroom and a living room where if you were sitting on a couch, the TV would be in your lap."
Then, on his own and working through a broker, Mr. Ellingrud submitted his application to sublet a studio on East 71st Street for $1,500 a month.
"There's a lot of paperwork," he said. "I have a personal information form. You need a letter from your job, which is standard; a lease application form, bank statements.
"Then I needed my W2's for the last two years, my full 1040's for the last two years. I had to complete an asset statement. I had to have my bank certify that the amount of money I had in my account was actually there; had to have a bank officer sign my form. Then I also needed three letters of recommendation; co-workers, friends, that I'm a clean, quiet guy." The package was submitted at the end of June.
Finally, on Wednesday evening, Mr. Ellingrud met with the admissions committee. "I dressed conservatively," he said, "one of my better shirts."
He got in.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
Look Out. Here Come The Checkbook Years.

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WHEN my daughter, Marian, turned 13 in May, I asked her what she wanted for this special birthday. "Anything within reason," I said. She thought about it a bit, then replied, "I want to see a show on Broadway."
That sounded reasonable. 
 Then she asked if she could bring a couple of friends. She also wondered if we could go out to dinner before the show. Finally, shortly before the event, she told my wife that she really didn't have anything appropriate to wear to a night on Broadway.
Reason went out the window. By the time the evening was over, the birthday party cost about $600. I suppose I should be happy that she didn't ask for a pony.
Marian has been a teenager for only a couple of months, but I am already wondering what the next few years will be like. After all, while children are undoubtedly expensive to raise, teenagers are the most expensive. Their clothing costs jump, as do their costs for entertainment and, of course, food. Did I mention birthday parties?
According to recent figures from the Agriculture Department, a family with pretax income of more than $61,900 will spend an average of about $290,000 to raise an only child through age 17, with the heaviest expenses -- $85,000 -- during the teenage years. And that money, of course, just gets parents to the start of the horrific college years.
"Children have many benefits, but they are expensive," said Mark Lino, an economist at the department. "Teenagers are the most expensive because they are very food-intensive, and they have the highest transportation expenses. These are the years they begin to drive."
The average 16-year-old, Mr. Lino said, consumed about $3,000 in food in 1999, compared with about $2,320 for an 8-year-old. When it comes to clothing, he said, parents spent almost $1,300 for the 16-year-old, versus $855 for the 8-year-old.
Jane Distler, 50, a high school teacher in Shawnee Mission, Kan., said she was amazed at what she spends on her 16-year-old daughter, Kate. "I wasn't used to paying $60 for a pair of jeans that looked like they were already worn out," Ms. Distler said. "My husband has sticker shock. We spend about $2,400 in clothes a year."
Then there are the hobbies. Another mom from Kansas, who asked that her name not be used, said she had spent about $5,000 on fencing lessons, equipment and trips for her 18-year-old daughter.
"You take them shopping once a week and you get a little outfit," this mom said. "Then there's the video and DVD rentals, about $15 a week. That adds up. We keep telling ourselves that we would be rich if we hadn't had kids.
"Some weeks it can be overwhelming," she said. "Like the prom: that was a lot of money. You think it's not going to be a big deal, and it snowballs." She said the total bill for prom night was about $570.
Karin Humbolt, the author of "I Want to Be Rich: A Teenager's Modem to Money" (Reynolds Publishing, 1998), says there are ways to mitigate the costs. For one, she said, parents should get their teenagers financially involved in the family. She said a child who works or gets an allowance should be encouraged to chip in, maybe by paying for entertainment expenses. The children should also understand where the family's money is coming from and what it takes to support them.
"I don't think they realize what it takes to get up day after day, punch that time clock and deal with work," Ms. Humbolt said. "Tell them how much it does cost to support the family. The child will be able to relate to that, and understand why he won't be able to afford that $100 pair of Nikes."
I think that is why my daughter understands that we're not sending her to boarding school in Europe for the eighth grade. That surprising request came soon after the Broadway trip. She wanted an adventure, she said, and being an "A" student in Spanish, wanted to immerse herself in another language.
A commendable request, and I admire her maturity, but the school she had picked out, in Switzerland, costs $35,000 a year.
"I don't know how people are doing it, because it's such a struggle and it's so expensive to raise a teenager today," Ms. Humbolt said. "Parents really have to plan. It takes a fortune and six credit cards."
I wonder if Marian would settle for a pony.

HEADLINE: In a Drug's Journey to Market, Discovery Is Just the First of Many Steps

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and JEFF GERTH 

 BODY:
Pharmaceuticals are a risky, but lucrative, business. Drug companies turn scientific advances into life-saving medicines that can generate millions of dollars in sales each day, but the process takes time -- an average of 12 to 15 years -- and money.
Through a recent wave of mergers and acquisitions, the prescription drug industry is increasingly global. But the companies earn most of their profits, and do most of their basic research, in the United States, the last drug market free of price restraints. The industry consistently ranks as the most profitable among Fortune 500 companies. 
 In this election year, with prescription drugs now the fastest-growing component of the nation's health care bill, the political debate is centered on how to help elderly people pay for their medications. So politicians and consumers are taking a close look at the drug industry, a business that closely guards its financial and scientific secrets.
 
Drug Discovery
Pharmaceutical companies spend more than $20 billion annually on research and development, a figure that has nearly doubled every five years since 1970, according to industry data. The industry estimates that the average cost of developing a successful drug is more than $500 million.
The actual cost of developing a particular medicine -- the laboratory equipment, the raw materials, the researchers' salaries, the clinical trials -- is just a small percentage of the $500 million. The rest is the cost of lost opportunity: years and dollars spent on scientific leads that prove fruitless, and research money that could have generated interest had it been invested elsewhere.
The $500 million figure is extrapolated from a 1991 study by researchers at Tufts University. Some experts say the estimate, drawn from confidential industry data not subject to outside review, is inflated.
Companies spend more on drug development -- the D in R & D -- than they do on research. While clinical trials account for the biggest development expense, experts say some development costs, like consulting fees paid to doctors, are more appropriately categorized as marketing than research.
 
Clinical Testing
For every 5,000 to 10,000 compounds the industry screens as potential new medicines, 250 make it to the stage of testing in animals. Of these, the industry says, five enter testing in people, in clinical trials.
The trials have three phases. First, the drug is given to a small number of healthy volunteers to test its safety and establish the proper dose. The second trial tests for effectiveness and looks for side effects in a larger number of patients who have the condition the drug is meant to treat.
The costliest clinical trial is the Phase 3 study, in which thousands of patients may be tested, so that scientists can assess the drug in a diverse population, over an extended period. Depending on the drug and the amount of medical care involved, experts say, a Phase 3 clinical trial can cost $10,000 to $20,000 a patient.
 
The Regulators
For years the drug makers complained that the Food and Drug Administration, the federal agency that regulates medication, took too long to approve new treatments, eating into the valuable life of a patent. That changed in 1992 when Congress passed the Prescription Drug User Fee Act, which enabled the agency to speed drug reviews with the help of industry money.
Between 1992 and 1997, the industry paid the agency $327 million to hire 600 new reviewers. Today, the average drug approval time has dropped to 12 months, from about 30 months before the law was passed. And the number of new medicines the agency approves each year is rising.
But critics say that in relying on drug companies to supplement its budget, the F.D.A. has become too close to the industry. They point to a rash of drugs withdrawn in recent years after serious side effects surfaced once the drugs were in pharmacies.
 
Patenting
Patents, as much as science, are critical to the success of a new drug. A patent is a property right. It confers a government-authorized monopoly for a set period -- in the United States, 20 years from the date the application is filed. During this period of market exclusivity, the patent owner can recover the costs of its original investment.
Patents were not always of paramount importance in medical research; many academic scientists once believed that knowledge should not be treated as proprietary. After Jonas Salk invented a polio vaccine, the journalist Edward R. Murrow asked him who owned the patent. "There is no patent," Dr. Salk replied. "Could you patent the sun?"
And when a Rutgers University professor, Selman Waksman, invented a breakthrough antibiotic, streptomycin, in the 1940's, he patented the drug, but gave away the rights. The result: many companies sold streptomycin, keeping prices -- and profits -- low.
The picture is far different today. Drug companies often derive the bulk of their sales from a handful of top-selling medications, so the pressure to invent the next blockbuster, and maximize its time under patent, is intense. In the industry, this is known as "life-cycle protection"; one way the drug makers protect their products is simply to file more patents.
The F.D.A. keeps a registry of all drug patents. But the agency does not evaluate whether the patents are valid; it simply takes the company's word. So the listing creates a barrier to rivals, which often wind up challenging patents in court.
Drug companies have also fought hard to win patent extensions. In 1995, an international trade agreement pushed back the expiration date of patents. Several companies benefited handsomely from a loophole in that extension.
While drug makers say they need longer patent protection to generate profits for research, some experts say that patent expirations, not extensions, spur innovation. Eli Lilly & Company, for instance, is pursuing new antidepressants now that the patent on its best seller, Prozac, is about to run out.
"The Prozac patent expiration," the company's 1998 annual report said, "is serving as a catalyst to bring greater intensity to everything we do."
 
Generic Competition
Prozac is not the only blockbuster drug threatened by the loss of its patent. In the next five years patents are due to expire on some of the most lucrative drugs in the history of medicine, among them Prilosec, the ulcer medication; Claritin, for allergies; and Zocor, for high cholesterol.
Generics can erode a brand drug's market share within months. A 1999 report by the Boston Consulting Group, which advises the industry, predicted that the average top drug company would lose 30 percent of its sales to generics by 2003.
If the threat of generics creates angst on Wall Street about the industry's profitability, it creates even more inside the companies, where scientists, patent lawyers and business executives are taking a variety of steps to beat back competition.
When a drug produced by a joint venture of Dupont and Merck, the blood thinner Coumadin, faced a generic challenge, the companies hired a battery of lobbyists to press state legislators and pharmacy boards to adopt rules that, in effect, restricted the ability of pharmacists to substitute the generic for the brand drug.
Claritin's maker, Schering-Plough, has taken its lobbying efforts to Washington; it has asked Congress to insert a provision into a spending bill that would extend the drug's patent.
When generic makers tried to sell a version of Taxol, a leading breast cancer drug, Taxol's maker, Bristol-Myers Squibb, sued for patent infringement -- not on the drug, but on the method of delivery, which the company had also patented. Courts in Britain and this country found for the generics earlier this year, but the case is on appeal and there is still no generic on the market.
Fewer than 20 percent of all prescriptions were filled with generic drugs in 1984. That year Congress passed a landmark law, the Hatch-Waxman Act, intended to facilitate generic competition. By 1996 generics had captured 43 percent of the market and were saving consumers $8 billion to $10 billion annually, according to a study by the Congressional Budget Office.
But because generics cost much less than brand drugs, they account for only a small fraction of the industry's total sales. According to the Kaiser Family Foundation, the combined prescription sales of the top 20 generic drug makers in 1998 totaled $7 billion, less than a tenth of those of the top 20 brand companies.
 
Coming to Market
The United States is the last free market for pharmaceuticals: other developed nations control drug prices, as in Japan, Canada, and France, or drug company profits, as in England. So Americans typically pay higher prices for new medications than people anywhere else in the developed world.
How the drug companies set prices, though, remains something of a mystery; they do not discuss their pricing strategies. The drug makers say price is dictated by the high cost of research. But the calculus behind any single pricing decision is complex, and largely shaped by market forces.
Does the new drug offer therapeutic advantages over existing medicines? How big is the patient population? Is there generic competition? Paradoxically, the arrival of generic competition often results in raised prices for their brand-name counterparts, as companies seek to maximize revenue in a shrinking market.
And despite the industry's emphasis on R & D costs, the top drug makers in 1998 spent, as a percentage of sales, three times as much on marketing and general and administrative expenses as they did on research and development, the Kaiser Family Foundation said.
There is no set price for a single drug in the United States: health plans, the government and individual patients all pay different rates, depending on their power in the marketplace. More than three-quarters of Americans younger than 65 have prescription drug coverage; their insurers typically negotiate discounts. But the size of those discounts is kept secret.
Among elderly Americans, who account for 13 percent of the population but roughly one-third of all drug expenditures, it is a different story. One-third of the nation's senior citizens lack drug insurance, and must pay out of pocket for their pills. As a result, they typically pay the highest prices.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: UNEMPLOYMENT;
LOWEST SINCE 1970

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
State unemployment dropped to 3.4 percent in June, the lowest record since the 3.3 percent unemployment mark set in March 1970. The state's record low is 3.2 percent, which was set in January 1970.
The June mark was well below the national unemployment rate of 4 percent and was the largest one-month drop since the state's unemployment rate slipped below 4 percent in March. 
 The tightness of the labor market and its duration set off a warning that New Jersey employers may soon begin to find it so difficult to fill high-technology, high-skill jobs, and will begin toning down their ambitions to expand.
"What has happened with this shortage of labor is that it is now impacting economic output," said James Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers. "It is what would be expected after 97 months of economic expansion in New Jersey: After 97 months, were have essentially run out of labor."
New Jersey employers had 3.931 million people on their payrolls in June, which is actually down 3,500 positions since May, a drop largely attributed to layoffs by the Census Bureau as it scales back its temporary field workers. Manufacturing also fell by about 1,000.
But the unemployment rate is not measured by jobs. It is measured by polls asking people if they are working or looking for work, then comparing those numbers and adjusting the results to project the trend.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
In China, a Management Maverick Builds a Brand

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: QINGDAO, China

 BODY:
AT first, you notice the balloons. Thousands of them, lining the sides of the road from the airport. Tethered at the end of long strings, they bob and weave, the name Haier emblazoned on each side. Then you notice the road signs, which say Haier Expressway.
You pass the Haier Industrial Park, with its sprawling factories and a skyscraper with a sign on the roof that also says Haier. Once in Qingdao, there are still more balloons and billboards. A giant lighted Haier sign twinkles from the far side of the city's crescent-shaped bay. 
 To pay a call on the local Communist Party boss, you go to the modern city hall, where the lobby has been transformed into a showroom for Haier's refrigerators, dishwashers, personal computers, mobile phones and flat-screen television sets.
To say that Qingdao is a company town understates the degree to which a single corporation, the Haier Group, has imprinted itself on the landscape. Qingdao may be most famous as the home of Tsingtao beer. But when you spy the brewery's red, green and blue logo on a sign or storefront, it is a bit like finding an image of Deng Xiaoping in a sea of Mao posters.
Haier's exuberant self-promotion -- even more showy than usual during a recent trade show here -- reflects the ambitions of its chief executive, Zhang Ruimin. In an interview, Mr. Zhang said his determination to put the Haier name everywhere was inspired less by heroic images of Chinese leaders than by the brand marketing practiced by Western corporations.
"Chinese companies have a problem because the label 'Made in China' means low quality and low price," Mr. Zhang said. "In 1996, we started exporting products under our own brand name. We were told it wouldn't work, but we insisted. Now we're successful with the Haier name all over the world."
Indeed, the Haier Group, a sprawling enterprise ultimately controlled by the city government here, has become China's largest appliance maker, with sales of $3.2 billion last year. It is also one of China's largest exporters, selling $1.4 billion of products in 160 countries. This year, it opened a $30 million refrigerator factory in Camden, S.C. -- becoming one of the few Chinese companies to have an American beachhead.
MR. ZHANG'S overseas focus might make sense, given the cutthroat price war raging in China. On July 14, one of Haier's main rivals, Guangdong Kelon Electrical Holdings, warned that its first-half profit would be lower than expected because of the price pressure. With deflation still ravaging the Chinese economy, stores are full of unsold appliances.
But why make fridges in South Carolina when China is much cheaper? Mr. Zhang said he wants Americans to think of Haier as an American company. Designing and making products in the United States, he said, will allow Haier to be more responsive to American consumers.
"In an era of globalization, you can't separate domestic and international markets," Mr. Zhang explained. "We've got to learn how to compete with General Electric and Whirlpool on their home turf. Otherwise, we'll lose the Chinese market."
Such confidence -- not to mention worldliness -- is rare in a Chinese executive. It is even more remarkable from one who spent his career in the parochial confines of the Qingdao municipal government. At 51, Mr. Zhang has become a symbol of how Chinese businessmen can remake themselves to meet the global economy's challenges.
"I would rank him as the Jack Welch of China," said Fred Hu, chief Asian economist for Goldman, Sachs. "In a country that has been dominated by central planning and state control, he really stands out."
T. L. Tsim, a consultant who studies Chinese state enterprises, says marketing like Haier's is crucial to the country's development. "What China needs today are brand-name products," he said. "It takes years of work and millions of dollars of investment."
By creating one of China's first genuine brands, Mr. Zhang himself has become a marquee attraction. He is invited to speak at conferences here and abroad. His views are sought by government officials and journalists. And the story of how he built Haier from the ruins of a state-owned factory has become a legend -- a businessman's equivalent of the Long March.
The short version: In 1984, Mr. Zhang was asked to run the Qingdao General Refrigerator Factory, a lethargic, nearly bankrupt plant where erratically paid, demoralized workers turned out shoddy products. The Haier name, adopted in 1991, is a Chinese approximation of Liebherr, a German appliance maker that supplied technology to the factory in its early days.
Mr. Zhang was not a likely candidate to produce a turnaround. A bureaucrat who missed out on college because of the Cultural Revolution, he worked his way up the Qingdao hierarchy in anonymity. But he also devoured Western management books, which taught him heretical ideas like the unfairness of paying every worker the same wage, no matter his ability.
Early in Mr. Zhang's tenure at the company, a customer complained about a broken refrigerator, prompting the boss to stalk through the factory pulling out 76 defective ones. He piled them up and handed sledgehammers to the workers who had assembled them. At his signal, they all set upon the fridges, reducing them to shards.
That singular act of destruction impressed on employees that poor quality would no longer be acceptable. Mr. Zhang has reinforced the message with an aggressive Western-style quality-control program. "We cannot expect to smash refrigerators every day," he said. "But actually, I think about doing it every day."
Once Mr. Zhang had improved the quality of Haier's products, he set about exporting them to every corner of the world. Starting in developing countries and then to developed markets, Haier now has 62 distributors and 30,000 sales outlets. Its small refrigerators are especially popular in hotel minibars; it has a 25 percent share of the small refrigerator market in the United States.
Haier says its exports and a diversified line that runs to 9,000 goods in 42 categories have allowed it to avoid the downdraft in domestic prices that has afflicted its rivals. Because Haier's shares are listed in Shanghai -- where financial disclosure is not as rigorous as in Hong Kong -- analysts say it is difficult for outsiders to assess the impact falling prices have had on Haier's performance. "It's hard to imagine Haier has escaped it," said Charles Cheung, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in Hong Kong.
HAIER would like to list its shares outside China. But it has put off its plans because of volatile Asian markets and the need to streamline its baffling amalgam of dozens of holding companies and joint ventures.
When Haier does make its pitch, analysts say, it will have to answer some hard questions. First, why is it building factories overseas? For all of Mr. Zhang's explanations, analysts say that it is squandering its advantage as a low-cost producer.
Second, why does Haier need a soup-to-nuts product line? Guangdong Kelon makes refrigerators, air-conditioners and washing machines. Mr. Zhang wants to supply every electrical appliance in the household. Doing that while maintaining quality is tricky.
A few years ago, Haier branched into pharmaceuticals. Mr. Zhang did so because he is convinced that biotechnology will be one of the great industries of the 21st century. But he acknowledged that Haier had struggled so far. "We may fail in that field," he said without a hint of defensiveness.
Risking failure, after all, is the mark of a modern company.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 945 words

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Press Role for a Media-Shy Mogul

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

 BODY:
FEW cities do a better job of smoothing the rough edges of movie moguls and business gladiators than this quaint, impeccably groomed seaside paradise 100 miles north of the shark-infested studio commissaries of Hollywood. The wealthy often come here not to forget who they are, but to take a break from some of the forces that made them rich.
Which is why the recent announcement that the local newspaper, the 145-year-old Santa Barbara News-Press, had been sold by a large publishing company -- The New York Times Company, as it happens -- and acquired by a local philanthropist was received in some circles as a victory of community spirit over the homogenizing influence of a distant corporate overseer. "It has to be quality before the bottom line," said Wendy P. McCaw, the buyer, who paid roughly $100 million. It seemed that an act of public spirit had drawn one of the wealthiest, if not best known, women in America out of her shell. 
 And yet, Ms. McCaw, 48, demonstrated the hard business acumen that she uses to manage a fortune that Forbes magazine has estimated at about $1.5 billion, most of that a product of her divorce from Craig O. McCaw, the telecommunications entrepreneur. When it was suggested in an interview -- she supplied written answers to written questions -- that she may have made the investment for altruistic reasons, she crisply shot down the notion.
"This acquisition fits with my investment philosophy and meets my I.R.R. targets," said Ms. McCaw, using the Wall Street language for internal rate of return. "I don't invest in assets for purely sentimental or other nonbusiness reasons."
Ms. McCaw's acquisition stands in counterpoint to a trend in which large chains have been gobbling up small publications and using economies of scale to wring out higher profits. She has said not only that she will avoid layoffs and leave the newsroom alone, but that she will also explore environmentally sound alternatives to using newsprint made from tree pulp.
THE acquisition will also provide an opportunity to find out just what Ms. McCaw is made of as she cautiously -- so cautiously that an assistant leapt at a photographer snapping a shot of her near her unmarked office on a quiet street here -- steps onto a stage she has long avoided.
She gave a rare personal interview to her own newspaper after the deal was announced, but insisted that no photographs be taken. When she first visited the newspaper after the purchase, she casually strolled the five or so blocks from her office and introduced herself to the staff. But it was on a Saturday, when the offices were all but empty.
Ms. McCaw is an avid jogger and a vegetarian,well known for her divorce from Mr. McCaw. The two met while undergraduates at Stanford, where she was known as Wendy Petrak. She was at his side as he cleverly assembled a nationwide cellular communications empire, which he sold in 1994 to AT&T for $11.5 billion.
The two separated shortly afterward, in January 1995, and then engaged in an expensive divorce battle that ended in her placing business ownership over cash. She became something of a business partner of her former husband, taking large stakes in several companies in which he had invested, including Nextel Communications, in which she now owns 4 percent, according to public filings, and Nextlink Communications, in which she owns a reported 14 percent through her investment company, Ampersand Holdings.
SHE has said she protects her privacy in large part because of security concerns, but in response to a question she added that being a woman was also a factor. When it was pointed out that billionaires from Steve Jobs to Donald Trump lead public lives, she responded: "They are all men -- some of them happen to enjoy the spotlight. I'm not and I don't."
And though she is quiet, she is not anonymous. She formed the Wendy P. McCaw Foundation, which has more than $53 million in assets, to finance some of her favorite projects. These have ranged from returning Keiko, the killer whale that starred in the movie "Free Willy," to the waters around Iceland, to preserving architectural drawings.
Ms. McCaw was so involved in freeing Keiko that in January 1996, when the animal was flown from Mexico to a temporary home in Oregon, she was on board the chase plane.
"Wendy was very personally involved," said David Phillips, executive director of the Earth Island Institute, which managed the project. "She'd come up to see him when we had him in a sort of rehab in Oregon. She has continued to provide funds to help in his eventual release."
He added that when a reception celebrating the journey included platters of seafood, she was incensed.
"What's going on?" Ms. McCaw demanded to know, said Mr. Phillips. "We're supposed to be saving this stuff, not eating it."
Her stewardship of the newspaper could prove a challenge. Most experts agree that the paper is likely to be a reliable if unspectacular investment. It is expected to take in about $30 million in revenue this year and earn pretax income of $4.5 million to $6 million, company officials say.
"We'll have good, steady growth, but it won't be explosive," said Allen Parsons, the publisher.
Or, as Edward J. Atorino, a media analyst at Wasserstein Perella Securities, commented, "It's in an affluent area, but there's limited growth."
Ms. McCaw said she would do well, while respecting the paper's independence.
"I will not have any role in the news-gathering or reporting process," she said. "I would hope that no friend or acquaintance of mine asks me to intercede with the paper; but if they did, I would tell them what I just told you."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 6; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Taxed, Over and Over

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Soaking the Rich Isn't What It Used To Be" (Week in Review, July 16):
You perpetuate a dangerous myth that the estate tax somehow is unique in constituting "double taxation." In fact, every dollar is taxed an infinite amount of times as it circulates through the economy. I pay payroll and income tax on an earned dollar, sales taxes when I spend it and tax on interest earned when I put it in a savings account. When I buy a compact disc, the store, the manufacturer and the store clerk are all taxed on it. 
 Wealthy people pay zero percent on unrealized capital gains (if they have no need to sell their stock portfolios), and 98 percent of estates pay a zero percent rate, so in most cases the wealthy pay zero percent on their money. In most cases, income that is unearned is taxed at a much lower rate than income that is earned by the sweat of one's brow.
 
THOMAS O'BRIEN
Charlottesville, Va., July 17, 2000

PUB-DATE: July 23, 2000

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3470 words

HEADLINE: Polar Opposites? Not Where It Counts;
Warren Buffett Gets All the Attention, But Hank Greenberg Is Posting Better Returns

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
ONE plays the part of the hayseed, the other the quintessential New York tough guy, complete with flinty stare and a vocabulary that might stun the crowd at a hip-hop concert. One loves bridge and jokes that he reluctantly drags himself around a golf course; the other is a bundle of energy whose idea of relaxation is rocketing down a frozen ski trail.
Look deeper, though, and these two men -- Warren E. Buffett of Omaha and Maurice R. Greenberg of Manhattan -- have more in common than what sets them apart. By dint of intellect and Olympian drive, each has built a far-rearching empire that for decades has delivered immense value to shareholders. Each rules his company -- Mr. Buffett at Berkshire Hathaway, Mr. Greenberg at the American International Group -- with imperial authority, in gracious defiance of the conventions of good corporate government. 
 More to the point, Mr. Greenberg, who is 75 and known as Hank, and Mr. Buffett, who will be 70 in August, are giants in the same game. Though both Berkshire, quite famously, and A.I.G., less obviously, have other operations, each is mainly in the insurance business; it represents nearly 80 percent of Mr. Buffett's revenue, and, along with related financial services, nearly all of Mr. Greenberg's. Glamorless? Unexciting? Maybe -- until you understand that both see it as the business of deploying assets to the greatest possible gain. "We think alike," Mr. Buffett said recently. "If you showed us 10 deals, we would probably come to pretty similar conclusions on most of them."
And that makes all the more extraordinary this simple fact: For 10 years, Mr. Greenberg's company has, for investors, been the better bet.
Berkshire, of course, has been a spectacular long-haul investment. A stake of $10,000 sunk into Mr. Buffett's holding-company-cum-investment-fund in 1965 has grown to about $39 million. Built for long-term investors -- Class A shares, never split, now sell for $53,300, a price that discourages trading -- Berkshire has minted many a millionaire and has made Mr. Buffett an investing icon.
Yet an investor who plopped down $10,000 in Berkshire on June 30, 1990 -- a lifetime ago, by today's market standards -- would have had $25,600 less on June 30, 2000, than one who bought an equal stake in A.I.G.: $74,700 versus $100,300. Over five years, the gap is even greater: $10,000 invested in A.I.G. in June 1995 would have grown to $44,100 through June 2000, while the same amount in Berkshire would have grown to just under $23,000.
Mr. Buffett's recent underperformance of both the stock market and his own historical record is no secret. Last year, Berkshire's gain in net worth was less than 1 percent -- the "absolute worst performance of my tenure," he has acknowledged. And he offers his investors little reason for optimism. Unbending in his value discipline, Mr. Buffett says he finds it increasingly difficult to uncover companies or stocks worth buying. Over the coming decade, he says, Berkshire's gains will probably only modestly surpass those of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
Mr. Greenberg makes no such concessions. He has been averaging annual earnings growth of about 20 percent since taking A.I.G. public in 1969, two years after he rose to chief executive; the stock has gone up at about the same pace. As for the future, "I don't see anything that's going to rock that boat," Mr. Greenberg said in a conversation this month at the company's Art Deco skyscraper on Pine Street in Manhattan's financial district.
That may be hubris on Mr. Greenberg's part, and Mr. Buffett's modesty may be misplaced: his protestations of fallibility have often preceded stellar performance. Indeed, the fading of technology stocks this spring and the revival, at least temporarily, of the consumer and financial sectors he favors have helped Berkshire Class A shares rebound about 30 percent from a low of $40,800 in March.
But the long-term numbers don't lie. A.I.G. -- today the pre-eminent American commercial insurer, with operations in more than 130 countries -- has earned comparison to Berkshire as a vehicle for long-term investors. And it is high time, too, to examine Mr. Greenberg's legacy in the same light as Mr. Buffett's.
A.I.G. is not as well known on Main Street as Berkshire. But on Wall Street, said Doug MacKay, a portfolio manager at Oak Associates, a mutual fund company that holds more than seven million A.I.G. shares, "Maurice Greenberg is just legendary."
 
Opposite Styles of Investing
Mr. Greenberg may act like the tough guy, but when it comes to investing A.I.G.'s capital, he turns cautious. The company, which has $268 billion in assets, making it the largest American insurance company, has a classic insurance securities portfolio, heavy with high-quality bonds and constructed to produce steady gains. His acquisitions and new ventures generally amplify the successes of the past.
For his part, Mr. Buffett invests like a riverboat gambler, limiting his market plays to a few big bets and buying up companies with little in common except that they are moneymakers with superb managers and products that he personally likes.
"Berkshire will buy businesses with very volatile earnings if the returns are high enough," said Alice Schroeder, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter who has studied both companies. "A.I.G. wants companies that produce predictable earnings over time."
A.I.G., she added, "likes to have its capital fully allocated at all times; Berkshire is an opportunistic investor."
Trained as an investor, not as a businessman, Mr. Buffett was first drawn to the insurance business in the mid-1960's by the money -- other people's money, that is. The float on premium payments can be put to work earning investment profits until a claim is filed.
Mr. Greenberg is an insurance man from the ground up. An Army veteran of the Normandy invasion, he got a law degree and returned to front-line service in the Korean War. Back in New York in 1952, he walked into the office of the Continental Casualty Company and asked for a job. The personnel manager showed him the door, but Mr. Greenberg tracked down the head of the New York office, who liked his spunk and put him to work as an underwriting trainee. In late 1960, he joined the insurance company that would become A.I.G. as a senior executive. Seven years later, at the age of 42, he became chief executive.
Nothing illustrates the differences between the two men's investing personalities so much as their biggest single acquisitions.
Two years ago, Mr. Buffett moved into the big time in insurance with the purchase of General Re, one of the world's leading reinsurers -- the companies that take on other insurance companies' biggest risks for a share of the premiums.
Most years, reinsurers collect substantial premiums without having to make big payouts; the float can be very attractive. But the risks of Mr. Buffett's investment quickly rained down on Berkshire: big earthquakes in Turkey and Taiwan contributed to an underwriting loss of more than $1 billion at General Re last year.
Still, Mr. Buffett loves the company. It has everything it needs, he says, "to become the world's most profitable reinsurance company."
Mr. Greenberg is no stranger to the wild, caroming fortunes of reinsurance; A.I.G. owns 60 percent of TransAtlantic Re, another global leader in the field. But far from a walk on the wild side, his biggest acquisition -- made shortly after Mr. Buffett bought General Re -- was of a company built to be a safe bet.
That company, SunAmerica, is a leader in variable annuities, which combine mutual funds and insurance and are blazing new sales records as baby boomers fret about retirement. The business itself is one giant annuity for A.I.G., piling up money in long-term investments from customers and throwing off management fees.
"We could have bought a commercial bank," Mr. Greenberg said, "but commercial banks, to us, have more volatility in earnings."
Still, as Mr. Buffett notes, the two men follow similar disciplines in analyzing a deal. Each carefully studies the financials himself, rather than relying on staff summaries. Mr. Buffett is famous for spending days reading annual reports; Mr. Greenberg seldom leaves the office without two big satchels full of papers.
"My weekends are playing tennis and reading," he said. "And on the telephone. That's generally my weekend."
 
Reins, Loose and Tight
As a manager, Mr. Buffett says he tries to keep his hands off Berkshire's companies. But Mr. Greenberg is totally hands-on. As Mr. Buffett puts it, "He knows when the sparrow falls, and he even knows when the sparrow is thinking of falling."
Once a month, Mr. Greenberg assembles his division presidents around a rectangular table in a large, plain room on the 16th floor of A.I.G.'s headquarters. To start "the chairman's meeting," as it is known, he swings his eyes around the room and, like a stern law professor putting students to a test, finally lets his gaze rest on one executive.
That person has a minute or so to rattle off current sales, expenses, profits and any unusual developments. Then, moving clockwise, each of the other subordinates reports. It can be a crisp, charged atmosphere. Mr. Greenberg tells his people that he wants them to be entrepreneurs. And he wants performance.
"If they believe you are doing everything you possibly can, they might accept some performance slippage," said Susan Rivera, the president of an A.I.G. division that sells workers' compensation and other business insurance. "But if you're not performing and it's perceived you're not doing all you can, it is a short-lived life."
Mr. Greenberg often recruits specialists from other fields and teaches them the insurance business -- as long as they are quick studies. He signed up Joseph L. Boren, who spent years in government and business solving pollution problems, to develop new coverages in his field.
Mr. Boren, now president of A.I.G. Environmental, has been attending the chairman's meetings for four years. Mr. Greenberg, he said, is "not denigrating; he's penetrating."
"He doesn't say, 'You must be the biggest dope I've ever seen,' " Mr. Boren added. "But he might say: 'You're alarming me. You don't sound like you're in control.'
"In the scheme of things, you'd rather walk into a meeting and have people say to you, 'How are you today? Did you have a nice weekend?' But that isn't how our business works, which is why our business is so successful."
A few months ago, when A.I.G. acquired an 8 percent stake in Risk Labs, a dot-com start-up in Atlanta, Mr. Greenberg sent in one of his executives as acting chief executive. That is not the Buffett way. Mr. Buffett says that one reason he buys a company is for its management; when he takes newcomers into the Berkshire fold, he leaves the managers alone. That is his plan for Justin Industries, the maker of Tony Lama boots; Berkshire said last month that it was acquiring the company.
Indeed, said a senior executive of one of Mr. Buffett's companies, "if you want to get him involved, you practically have to drag him into it."
But he has ways of letting his managers know what he wants done. Years ago, after he acquired 50 percent of Geico, the discount auto insurer that Berkshire now owns entirely, A.I.G. offered to buy the business.
As John J. Byrne Jr., then Geico's chief executive, tells the story, Mr. Buffett agreed only reluctantly to join him for lunch in Mr. Greenberg's private dining room at A.I.G. Mr. Greenberg and Felix Rohatyn, a friend who was then a senior partner in the Lazard Freres investment banking firm, tried to aim their conversation at Mr. Buffett. "You're looking at the wrong side of the table," he told them. "You've got to speak to Mr. Byrne."
Mr. Byrne felt the chill. The next day he told Mr. Greenberg that Geico was not for sale.
Another time, though, Mr. Buffett showed that he can lose his cool as readily as any hands-on boss. Mr. Byrne had shifted much of Geico's investment portfolio into long-term bonds -- at precisely the wrong moment. Interest rates were starting to rise, which meant that he would not only soon be locked into below-market yields, but that the value of his bonds would be falling.
As Mr. Byrne recalls it, Mr. Buffett invited him to play golf at the Burning Tree Club outside Washington. Rather tentatively, Mr. Buffett started to talk about the economy, and Mr. Byrne defended his decision. As they played, Mr. Byrne could see Mr. Buffett becoming agitated. On the ninth hole, he noticed Mr. Buffett gritting his teeth, the veins in his neck pulsing. Unleashing a furious swing that clipped the top of the ball and sent it dribbling about 14 feet, Mr. Buffett wheeled on Mr. Byrne in a rage. "Only a fool would lend long at this point in time," Mr. Byrne recalls him shouting. "Only a fool."
Mr. Byrne managed to stay on as chief executive. But he immediately hired a specialist to run his investment portfolio.
 
Governance and Succession
If Mr. Greenberg and Mr. Buffett run their companies like owners, it is not without a certain logic. Mr. Buffett owns more than 30 percent of Berkshire's stock; Mr. Greenberg owns 2.2 percent of A.I.G.'s, but he estimates that top management and the board control about 30 percent of the shares. And each is accorded complete authority as the builder of his enterprise.
Of course, each man has aligned things in his favor. In defiance of the norms of governance for public companies, their boards are heavy with insiders. Neither man is interested in hearing about mandatory retirement; both say they plan to go on leading their companies indefinitely.
Mr. Greenberg had to face a few hecklers on such issues at A.I.G.'s annual meeting in May. But their reward for speaking up was chilly glares from other shareholders and employees who had crowded into the modest company cafeteria. As Mr. Greenberg was detailing yet another stellar year and announcing yet another stock split, one protester rose to argue that earnings often suffer at companies with less-than-independent boards. Mr. Greenberg lobbed a soft reply: "Are you sure you're in the right place?" And the room, full of loyalists, chuckled and clucked.
Professional financial analysts tend to melt before Mr. Buffett and Mr. Greenberg, too.
At Berkshire's annual meetings in Omaha, reporters ask Mr. Buffett for autographs; instead of trying to poke holes in his strategies, many securities analysts admiringly quote Buffett aphorisms. When Mr. Greenberg invites insurance analysts once a year to what they refer to as a fireside chat, the questions are gentle. They have all heard the tales of how Mr. Greenberg has called analysts and read them -- and their bosses, who covet A.I.G.'s investment banking business -- the riot act.
"You don't mess around with Hank," one analyst said on condition of anonymity. "He could squash me like a bug."
It is no surprise that such a leader would have dynastic dreams, and Mr. Greenberg intends to keep the future of A.I.G. in the family. His eldest son, Jeffrey, had been regarded by A.I.G. watchers as the heir apparent, but he resigned abruptly five years ago, later becoming chief executive of Marsh & McLennan, the giant insurance broker. Now Jeffrey's 45-year-old brother Evan, A.I.G.'s president, has been designated as next in line to run the company, where he has worked for 25 years.
Apart from the confidence of his father, it is hard to tell, at this point, how well Evan Greenberg might perform. Subordinates earnestly describe his thoroughness and command of the nuances of the business. Some say he is brilliant. But industry executives who know him well are noncommittal.
"As far as I know he's a competent fellow," said Barber B. Conable, a former congressman and past president of the World Bank who is one of six directors on A.I.G.'s 18-member board who are neither company executives nor contractors. "This is not an issue we've been worrying about," he added, "because Hank shows every sign of continuing as the leader."
In any event, Mr. Conable said, after the senior Mr. Greenberg dies, there is nothing to stop the board from choosing whomever it decides is best suited to run the company. Mr. Conable said he once told Mr. Greenberg: "You must understand, your son will be tested by the board at such time as you step down."
At Berkshire Hathaway, Mr. Buffett has installed a seven-member board that comprises his wife, Susan, who lives apart from him in San Francisco; his son, Howard G. Buffett; Charles T. Munger, the company's vice chairman, who has long been Mr. Buffett's confidant; a law partner of Mr. Munger's and two other longtime business associates of Mr. Buffett's.
After Mr. Buffett dies, his wife is to receive nearly all his stock. But she will not run the company; instead, he has designated two Berkshire executives to take his place -- one to handle investments, the other operations. Neither has been publicly named, but there has been speculation that Louis A. Simpson, who is in charge of investments at Geico, would take over the investing side. Buffett watchers mention several candidates for the operations job, with little conviction.
Whoever they are, Mr. Buffett's successors will be hard pressed to preserve Berkshire's unique place in the investment pantheon. The market does not value Berkshire as it would an insurance company, even though that is what it mainly is. Rather, it is priced largely on the performance of its chief executive's stock picks. Whether the cult followers will remain in thrall to Mr. Buffett's successors is anybody's guess.
A.I.G. certainly revolves around Mr. Greenberg -- "If you don't have a relationship with Hank Greenberg, you don't have a relationship with A.I.G.," said an insurance executive who has known Mr. Greenberg for years. But analysts say an A.I.G. without Mr. Greenberg is a surer bet than Berkshire without Mr. Buffett: There are more units, more decision makers, a broader playing field.
 
Comparing the Scorecards
In the meantime, neither Mr. Buffett nor Mr. Greenberg shows any sign of slowing down. Indeed, their business strategies put them face to face more and more, inviting the comparisons that previously were not so obvious. For example, will Mr. Buffett's Geico or Mr. Greenberg's A.I.G. Direct reap the most rewards in the competition for bargain-minded auto insurance customers?
Both are pouring money into advertising and expansion. Characteristically, Mr. Buffett is going for broke; he wants Geico to become one of the giants in the business. Mr. Greenberg wants to grow, too, but earnings in car insurance fluctuate too much to suit him, so he will keep the line from dominating A.I.G.'s portfolio of businesses.
Ultimately, do you bet on the Manhattan tortoise or the Omaha hare? Ms. Schroeder, the Morgan Stanley analyst, finds it difficult to choose. "That's like asking whether to buy a Van Gogh or a Monet," she says.
 
From Rivalry to Cooperation
AFTER decades of rubbing shoulders around the casino tables of finance, Warren E. Buffett and Maurice R. Greenberg have come to admire each other warmly.
"The vibe between us is not competitors," Mr. Buffett said. "The vibe between us is friends." Envious friends, but friends. "I wish I had done some of the deals he's done," Mr. Buffett said, "and maybe he wishes he'd done some of the deals I've done."
Indeed, Mr. Greenberg said, "we have a great relationship."
But things have not always been so rosy. Fifteen years ago, they exchanged verbal punches. Mr. Buffett criticized the way the American International Group, of which Mr. Greenberg is chief executive, used reinsurance, and Mr. Greenberg fired back that Mr. Buffett had "a peanut-sized book" of insurance business -- which was true at the time -- and that he was a fine one to be telling him how to run his company, already a giant in the industry.
But that was a long time ago. Now they are doing business together; A.I.G. is one of the biggest customers of General Re, Mr. Buffett's main insurance holding. And they are keen competitors: TransAtlantic, the big reinsurer that A.I.G. controls, goes after some of the same business that General Re does, and the two titans are pursuing the same customers in their car insurance businesses.
They have collaborated on some joint projects, but their biggest idea -- the attempted rescue and takeover of Long Term Capital Management, the hedge fund that nearly failed in 1998 -- came to nothing. Others on Wall Street beat them to it.
But they're still thinking. "It's logical that we would team up on something," Mr. Buffett said. "We and they have enormous capital resources." JOSEPH B. TREASTER

HEADLINE: Officials Say Skeptical U.S. Plans to Work With Fujimori

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
After harsh denunciations of Peru's recent presidential election, top Clinton administration officials say they do not have enough leverage to force a new vote and will work with President Alberto K. Fujimori while continuing to press for reform.
With less than a week before Mr. Fujimori is to be sworn in for a third term after an election and campaign widely criticized for gross irregularities, administration officials say they will send the American ambassador in Lima, John Hamilton, to attend Mr. Fujimori's inauguration next Friday. 
 Mr. Hamilton's presence will signal "the reality" that Mr. Fujimori "is going to head the government of Peru at least for the foreseeable future, and we acknowledge that we have mutual, bilateral business to conduct," a senior administration official said.
Critics in Congress and human rights groups say the softening of the American stance sets a troubling precedent in a hemisphere where several elected leaders have recently taken steps toward more authoritarian rule.
Peru is perhaps the United States' best-performing ally in the fight against the illegal drug trade in the region, and administration officials privately acknowledged that concerns about maintaining antinarcotics cooperation played a hand in their decision-making.
They also attributed the shift to a number of other factors: resistance from key Latin American governments to tougher action; Mr. Fujimori's ample financial reserves, which would make sanctions less effective; and discomfort with the leader of Peru's opposition, Alejandro Toledo, whom they see as too weak and inexperienced to lead a successful drive to restore democracy in Peru.
Congress eliminated $42 million in aid to Lima last month and the Senate approved a provision to cut off more funds for Peru if the president reports that Mr. Fujimori has failed to make "substantial progress in improving its respect for human rights." But exemptions for counternarcotics and humanitarian help left the actual amount of aid at stake at less than $10 million.
While American officials acknowledged having doubts that Mr. Fujimori is prepared to make key democratic reforms, they say that in the end they decided to follow the lead of the 34-nation Organization of American States, a consensus-driven groupthat has called for negotiations with Mr. Fujimori and has ruled out more forceful action, like sanctions.
In a scathing report on Peru's election, the group's own monitors denounced the harassment of opposition candidates, government control of the media, arrests of would-be voters and the mutilation of ballots in the first round. Mr. Toledo ultimately asked to have his name scratched from ballots in the May 28 runoff, charging he could not get a fair vote.
But at the O.A.S. annual assembly last month in Canada, Mexico, Brazil and Venezuela steered the region toward negotiations with Mr. Fujimori, administration officials said. A high-level O.A.S. delegation then drew up proposals aimed at "strengthening democracy" under the current Peruvian government and appointed an envoy to monitor any progress.
Administration officials said they favored a call for new elections in Peru using the threat of multilateral economic sanctions as leverage. "There's a little bit of uncertainty as to how to proceed," said one State Department official. "The U.S. was hoping the O.A.S. would take the ball and run with it." Instead, the official said, the O.A.S. "has taken new elections off the table."
While withholding some aid to Peru could set back United States efforts to eradicate drug crops and disrupt trafficking, critics of the administration decision say the greater risk is tolerating stolen elections.
"The risk here is sending a message to the rest of the hemisphere that if you cooperate with us on narcotics interdiction, everything else you do including the suppression of democracy is fine," said Representative Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat.

HEADLINE: The World;
A World of Scavengers On the Fringes of Wealth

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
ROBERTO AQUINO, 14, says he finds "false gold" in garbage. A scavenger on Manila's garbage mountain when he is not in school, he specializes in copper wire. On a good day he can earn half as much as his fifth-grade teacher.
Hundreds of people died here two weeks ago when the seven-story-high mountain, loosened by monsoon rains, collapsed on their shantytown. Like their neighbors, they lived here amid the filth and flies and degradation because the living was good. Mostly upwardly mobile migrants from the barren countryside, they were feeding their families and putting their children through school. Like Roberto, they had struck gold. 
 "Say you have a family of four," said Matthew Westfall, an urban development specialist with the Asian Development Bank, which is based here. "The kids go to school part time and pick trash part time. You could get up to 15,000 or 16,000 pesos a month, possibly." That sum, about $400, "puts you above the poverty line," he said.
The people of the dumpsite, which they call Promised Land, are not an aberration. They are part of the changing face of poverty -- a vast population shift taking place in much of the world, from the joblessness and hunger of the countryside to the comparative wealth of the cities. But for most of these migrants, that comparative wealth is found in places like this dumpsite, part of a growing sea of poverty that laps at the edges of small, high-rise islands of urban affluence.
In Asia, where cities of 10 million people or more are spreading as fast as anywhere in the world, this urban landscape is replacing the fields and trees of the villages for an increasing proportion of the population.
Thirty-five years ago, Mr. Westfall said, only one in five Asians lived in cities. Today the ratio is one in three. Twenty years from now, more than half the population will be urban. In 1990, he said, the region's cities needed a total of $38 billion a year to provide urban services like water, sanitation and transport. In 20 years that figure is expected to rise to an impossible $292 billion.
These huge "megacities," groaning with their burden of the disenfranchised poor, will dominate the next century, it is said, the way the nation-state dominated the last century and empires ruled in the century before.
Urbanization, of course, is not just an Asian phenomenon. Nor is the misery of the poor. Garbage mountains rise in Latin America and Africa as well. But it is in Asia, perhaps, with its enormous population pressures, that the issue is drawn most strikingly.
Manila today, for example, has 13 percent of the Philippines' 74 million people but generates 30 to 40 percent of the nation's wealth. Bangkok has 10 percent of Thailand's population but generates 40 percent of its wealth. "People in rural areas have no alternative but to migrate," said Anil Deolalikar, a professor of economics at the University of Washington in Seattle.
But garbage dumps aside, said Naved Hamid, a senior policy planner with the Asian Development Bank, these poor see little of the cities' wealth.
There is no one pattern for urban poverty and therefore no single cure. In China, the pattern is predominantly one of a vast floating population of migrant workers who follow jobs from city to city. In Manila, where many urban services have broken down, it also includes people like civil servants and teachers, whose pay puts them above the poverty line but who often have no alternative to living in the ugliest of slums.
The urban underclass for the most part lives apart from the social and economic structure of its city, invisible to most residents and without the political weight to demand their share of services. So they create their own separate -- though dependent -- economies. Some 80,000 squatters cluster around Manila's garbage mountain, for example. They include perhaps 3,000 scavengers and another 9,000 or so people whose livelihoods depend directly on what urban experts call "the recycling waste chain."
As planners seek new ways to address the growing disaster of urban poverty, the world's millions of slum dwellers find their own ways to survive. The art of scavenging, it appears, is one of the great tributes to human inventiveness. There are children who dive for golf balls in the water hazards of golf courses and there are daring teenagers who scurry for brass shell casings on military firing ranges.
In Laos, people use old bombshells to construct their houses. In America, the urban poor dig for aluminum cans (and cold slices of pizza) in garbage bins.
In Nigeria this month -- in a tragedy that is a companion to the garbage landslide in Manila -- hundreds of scavengers died in an explosion and fire while trying to earn their living by puncturing a pipeline and siphoning off gasoline.
PEOPLE like this not only make a living; they make a home for themselves. The shanties at Manila's dump are hung with flower pots and posters of soccer teams. There are tiny barbershops and ice cream stands. There are births and weddings and school graduations.
Nine people in the family of Jennifer Gino Evangelista died in the landslide, including her parents. Twenty-one survived. None of them want to move away.
In the 1980's, said Mrs. Evangelista, 27, her father brought the family here from the countryside after taking them from place to place in search of a living. "Every year we would move," she said. "We never had a permanent address. We were tourists in our own country."
That homeless life ended here on the fringes of the Promised Land dump.
"This is where we've stayed the longest -- 12 years," she said. "This is where we've multiplied. This is where we've put down roots. So this is our home now."
