HEADLINE: In America;
Fiscal Irresponsibility

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
There is a disturbing, almost willfully irresponsible quality to the giddy rush by politicians to enact huge federal tax cuts without regard to how much of the projected surpluses are real, and with little or no debate about other, better ways in which some of that money might be used.
It's as if very little was learned during those long years of wandering in the debilitating environs of big budget deficits. Now surpluses are blossoming in the midst of a campaign season and the politicians seem determined to devour them with immediate and mindless tax cuts. 
 Forget about taking steps to shore up the nation's infrastructure, or clean up the environment, or do something real about the sorry state of public education, or poverty, or the millions who lack health insurance.
Forget about any of the complex issues that deserve to be debated and that would require some substantial amount of federal financial support. Big tax cuts are on the table, and even bigger tax cuts are being promised. And once these monster cuts become law there'll be very little left for investment in a sounder American future.
According to Congressional Budget Office projections released last week, the non-Social Security surpluses over the next 10 years will be about $2.2 trillion. But that figure is wildly unrealistic. It would be reduced sharply by any slowdown in the economy, and it assumes non-entitlement spending, including defense spending, will grow no faster than the rate of inflation -- a phenomenon that no sane person in Washington would believe.
Analysts at the respected Center on Budget and Policy Priorities have come up with estimates that fit more comfortably with the real world. They noted that when you set aside that portion of the projected surpluses that come from the Medicare trust fund (which, like Social Security, should remain off limits, according to officials from both parties); and when you look realistically at spending already committed to by the White House and Congress; and when you take into account some of the non-Social Security money that most agree will be needed to help shore up the Social Security retirement system -- when you take all of that into account, the surplus available over the next decade falls to just $700 billion or so.
That's the amount that would be available for tax cuts and new spending. If you wanted to improve the schools, or help cover the uninsured, or offer a prescription drug benefit, or whatever -- you'd have to pay for it out of that $700 billion or so, after you deduct whatever tax cuts come out of that same $700 billion.
Candidates from both parties have been less than responsible on this issue. But the Republicans, especially, have gone way over the top.
To get a sense of how dizzily out of whack things have become, all you have to do is consider that George W. Bush's proposed tax cut is $1.3 trillion. There is no way the non-Social Security surpluses projected over the next decade would be able to cover tax cuts of that magnitude.
Tax cut bills passed or about to be passed in this session of Congress (some face a presidential veto) would reduce government revenues by $730 billion over the next 10 years. Not only are the tax cuts being pushed by the G.O.P. excessive, they are in many cases "backloaded," which is to say written in such a way that the biggest portion of the cuts occur after some years have passed. So the proposed elimination of the estate tax, for example, would result in a loss of $100 billion in revenue over the first 10 years, but more than $500 billion over the second 10 years.
This is insidious. We are manufacturing rather than solving problems for subsequent generations.
Modest, affordable tax cuts are fine. But what's more important as the United States enjoys this best of economic times is to take the opportunity to engage some of the big problems we've put off for years because we didn't have the money to deal with them.
There are Americans who, despite the unprecedented prosperity, still are not being paid an honest dollar for a day's work, who still are without health insurance, who still are not receiving a quality education.
Now would be a good time to start bringing them into the prosperous mainstream.

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: The Moral Sense in Estate Tax Repeal

BYLINE: By Alan Wolfe; Alan Wolfe is director of the Center for Religion and American Public Life at Boston College and is the author of "One Nation, After All."

DATELINE: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.

 BODY:
Since the supply-side revolution of the Reagan years, the Republican Party has vigorously advocated tax cuts. The idea seemed to make sense both as policy and as politics. Lower taxes, supply-side theorists argued, would stimulate economic growth, thereby avoiding budget deficits. And the appeal to voters would turn the Republicans into the majority party, for few people would be able to resist the notion that government's money is really their own, best left in their pockets.
The policy behind tax-cutting never quite worked as expected; until recently, deficits plagued the American economy. Neither did the politics. To be sure, Walter Mondale lost badly to Ronald Reagan in 1984 after he talked about raising taxes, but then Americans began to tell pollsters that tax-cutting was not a high priority with them. A program of slashing federal spending -- even shutting government down -- wound up harming the Republican Party's hopes for majority status. Steve Forbes made tax cuts the linchpin of campaigns for his party's nomination and got nowhere. New Hampshire, the most tax-resistant state in America, began to consider an income tax. 
 It therefore seemed to be one more example of political folly when Senate and House Republicans decided to take on the estate tax. First passed by Congress in 1916 to help pay for World War I, the federal tax on estates kicks in when a person leaves assets valued at $675,000 (rising to $1 million in 2005). Because only 2 percent of American estates are taxed, Republican calls for repeal reeked of the party's proclivity to reward its wealthy donors, even at the risk of alienating individuals whose more modest estates would never be taxed.
President Clinton responded by insisting that any tax relief should go not to the very rich, but to those who have fallen behind in these dizzying economic times. Democrats have discovered that when it comes to tax policy, class warfare works; Americans are receptive to the notion that Republicans appeal too much to selfish motives to be fully trusted with the common good.
Yet as the estate tax issue played itself out, both parties found themselves surprised. Democrats, realizing that they are on the defensive, are trying to fashion a compromise that would benefit farmers and small businessmen. Republicans, not used to capturing the moral high ground on any issue, sense blood and would like nothing more than a presidential veto.
One possible explanation of this reversal of fortune is that even poor Americans someday hope to be rich enough to have an estate; these days, after all, anyone owning a house in a desirable neighborhood is already within sight of the tax's minimum. But this assumes that Americans are selfish enough to want to hold on to their money even when they do not make much of it. The problem with this explanation is that because the estate tax is paid after you are dead, you cannot hold on to it. You can, of course, spend it before you die. But once you are dead, there are only two options: It can be left to those you designate, usually your children, or it can be left to everyone in the form of general tax revenue.
The philosopher Immanuel Kant taught that the more just solution would be to leave your estate to everyone; we are obligated to others, Kant believed, irrespective of whether we know them personally. It follows that if you are rich enough to have an estate eligible to be taxed, needy people unknown to you are more deserving of your largess than the few children you happen to have had. But while Americans do not mind being taxed, they do not trust government to do what is right. Uncertain that the money they have earned will go to all, they would rather make sure it goes to some. And who better to pick those to whom it will go than the person who made the money in the first place?
This instinct to leave your own money to your own children cannot be called selfish. Sociobiologists, in fact, would call it altruistic, for in their view the willingness of an organism -- usually a gene -- to sacrifice so that its offspring flourishes is the very definition of altruism. Whether or not one agrees with them, repeal of the estate tax taps into very strong family feelings.
Paying for college illustrates the principles involved. It is grossly unfair that rich Americans can send their children to better universities than those that poor Americans can afford. The unfairness is compounded when the best colleges admit so-called legacies -- students whose parents attended these same colleges. Should we therefore encourage parents to forgo all advantages for their own children, giving the money they save instead to a scholarship fund for any needy students? Or should we be happy that people will go to such lengths to ensure that people other than themselves get ahead, even if those others are related to them by blood?
In a way that makes sense to them, even if it does not make sense to philosophers, Americans who support repeal of the estate tax, like Americans who deprive themselves of vacations in order to send their children to first-rate colleges, are expressing a generous urge.
Repeal of the estate tax gives Republicans the opportunity to speak about solidarity. To be sure, the solidarity that repeal encourages, because it focuses on the family rather than society as a whole, is limited in scope. But it is broader than the extreme individualism of the free-market Republican rhetoric Americans find less than ennobling.
Americans prefer strengthening ties among people they know to the alternatives of either looking out for no one or looking out for everyone. Estate tax repeal corresponds to the basic moral instincts of most Americans. That is why, unlike tax-cutting across the board, it is a winning political issue. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); 

STATE: DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, USA (79%); NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA (56%); 

COMPANY: REPUBLICAN PARTY (84%);

HEADLINE: Deutsche Telekom Deal: Did Barriers Fall in Europe, Just to Rise in the U.S.?

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

 BODY:
Through much of the 1990's, the United States led the world in opening the telecommunications industry to competition.
But as Deutsche Telekom attempts to buy a fast-growing American company, the VoiceStream Wireless Corporation, Congressional leaders sound as if they have not been paying much attention to Europe for the last five years. 
 Spurred by Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat, the Senate is now weighing legislation that would block the German company from buying VoiceStream or almost any other American telecommunications company, because Deutsche Telekom's majority owner is the German government.
And last week, responding to a letter from Senator Hollings and 29 other lawmakers, the Federal Communications Commission chairman, William E. Kennard, said an acquisition of an American telephone company by Deutsche Telekom would face heavy regulatory scrutiny.
But blocking a Deutsche Telekom deal could invite retaliation against American communications companies active in Germany and elsewhere in Europe, and might also run afoul of United States commitments to the World Trade Organization.
Under current American policy, foreign companies are allowed to acquire American communications companies if the buyer is based in a country that is a member of the W.T.O. -- as are Germany and all other members of the European Union. Mr. Hollings's proposal would block the F.C.C. from transferring, for at least a year, a radio license to a company in which a government owns a significant stake, even if it is less than 50 percent. Separate legislation supported by Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, would effectively block acquisitions by such companies on a permanent basis.
At first blush, the reasoning of the Hollings camp seems straightforward: the German government still owns about 57 percent of Deutsche Telekom, and Senator Hollings argues that the government could subsidize unfair competition or use its regulatory power to favor Deutsche Telekom in Germany over foreign rivals.
The fears are not entirely misplaced. Germany, along with most other European countries, has a history of impeding competition. As recently as three years ago, Deutsche Telekom was an arrogant, bloated and overpriced company that depended on regulatory protection.
But those days are over. In the last four years, the German government has been selling off shares in Telekom about as fast as the market could absorb them. In three separate offerings, the government has sold nearly $30 billion worth of shares, and officials have said repeatedly that they intend to continue that process until the government's stake is at or near zero.
More important, the German government has drastically deregulated the country's communications market, savaging Deutsche Telekom's core telephone business.
Since 1998, when the European Union ordered all member countries to open the telephone markets to competition, the German company has lost about 30 percent of its long distance market to domestic and foreign carriers and has been forced to slash some of its rates as much as 70 percent to keep from losing even more.
The process has hardly been perfect. Deutsche Telekom has tried to block rivals by charging them high fees to connect to its network and charging customers huge fees for changing telephone companies. But German regulators have slapped down most of those efforts, with the result that rivals have made big inroads into its revenues and profits.
Last year, Deutsche Telekom's revenues for wired telephone service declined as a result of price cuts and customers who changed carriers, although the company largely compensated for the shortfall through booming growth in its mobile telephone business. But in wireless, too, the company faces an extraordinary array of foreign and domestic rivals.
Earlier this year, for example, Vodafone AirTouch of Britain acquired the German company Mannesmann, which is equal to Deutsche Telekom in the wireless business and is a strong second-place competitor in wired telephone service.
France Telecom recently acquired MobilCom, a growing German provider of local, long distance and wireless services. France Telecom is also part of a group that will bid in auctions for new German licenses to offer advanced, or so-called third-generation, wireless services.
The American communications company BellSouth and the Dutch carrier Royal KPN jointly acquired a wireless network, E-Plus, in Germany recently. And British Telecommunications, Britain's dominant telephone company, owns part of a fourth wireless network in Germany.
Meanwhile, American companies like WorldCom are building fiber optic networks across Germany and the rest of Europe. Scores of new companies, many backed by American investors, are building their own fiber optic networks in Europe to offer high-speed Internet services.
Far from being a heavy-handed ally of Deutsche Telekom, German regulators have more often than not supported its rivals, like Mannesmann, on crucial pricing issues.
In Brussels, the antitrust regulators for the European Union's European Commission have added to the pressure. Trying to force more competition in local telephone service, they demanded that Deutsche Telekom sell off its nationwide cable television network.
To be sure, Deutsche Telekom has tried to retain as many of its old privileges as possible. In selling off the cable network, it insisted on breaking up the nationwide system into nine regions, with the clear intention of preventing rivals from creating a nationwide competitor.
Nevertheless, the German company is not only selling majority stakes in the cable systems but selling them to American companies. Callahan Associates International, a Denver-based company founded by a former executive of the regional Bell company U S West, Richard Callahan, is buying two of Deutsche Telekom's biggest cable systems for more than $5 billion.
Mr. Callahan's plan is to upgrade the cable systems to also offer telephone and high-speed Internet service. Certainly he has experience: While at U S West, he helped start the British cable company Telewest, one of the first cable systems in the world to offer both telephone service and cable television over the same network.
Given the raucous competition in German telecommunications, the talk of a Congressional blockade of Deutsche Telekom in the United States has already set off an alarm at the European Union.
The issue of the German government's majority ownership of Deutsche Telekom could turn out to be moot. In its bid to acquire Voice Stream for $50.7 billion in stock and cash, the company's executives say the government's stake would be diluted from 58 percent to 45 percent as a result of issuing new shares to pay for the purchase.
Wilfried Schneider, a spokesman for the European Union in Washington, said that a Congressional effort to block the Deutsche TelekomVoiceStream deal would violate the 1997 World Trade Organization agreement to open telecommunications markets to private and publicly owned companies.
"We think Congress should prevent this proposal from becoming a law," Mr. Schneider said. "It sets a bad example because it looks like some kind of protectionist move."

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
How Slavery Fueled Business in the North

BYLINE: By BRENT STAPLES 

 BODY:
The German Parliament hoped to discourage a wave of lawsuits -- and close the door on an ugly past -- when it voted to support a fund through which corporations will compensate people who worked as slave laborers in Germany during World War II. But by agreeing to pay reparations, corporations like DaimlerChrysler, Deutsche Bank, Siemens and Volkswagen are tacitly admitting that German corporate wealth rests at least partly on slave labor extracted from Jews during the commission of crimes against humanity.
This has been a big year for institutional contrition, with the Vatican apologizing for misdeeds of the past -- extending back to the Inquisition -- and Swiss banks seeking atonement for appropriating the accounts of Holocaust victims. But in the United States Congress, a bill that would bring about a similar reckoning with regard to two and a half centuries of slavery may never see the light of day. Legislation sponsored by Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan calling for a study of reparations has failed to reach the House floor, even after being submitted to Congress every year for more than a decade. 
 The failure of Congress to take this bill seriously reflects the sense among Americans as a whole that slavery has no economic bearing on the nation as it exists today. But if a 34-year-old lawyer named Deadria Farmer-Paellmann has her way, a broader debate about reparations and the links between modern corporations and the slave economy may be on the way.
A part-time musician and amateur historian, Ms. Farmer-Paellmann attended law school solely to develop a legal argument for reparations. After scouring corporate archives, she has turned up connections between modern corporations and predecessor companies that seem clearly to have profited from the slave trade, in some cases obliquely but often quite directly.
Inspired by the German case, Ms. Farmer-Paellmann is planning to sue a dozen corporations for "unjustly enriching" themselves and has already begun distributing archival records that provide provocative examples of corporate involvement in the trade. The planned lawsuits are novel. But the news articles about her first few discoveries have already broadened public awareness of the extent to which the United States depended on slaves to build the national as well as the Southern economy.
Charles Ogletree, a Harvard Law School professor, is among those paying attention. He says he is considering both litigation and legislation and is helping to plan a conference scheduled this fall on the reparations issue.
Modern-day Northerners tend to view slavery as confined to the Confederacy, thinking of the Northeast as made up of "free states." Americans are for the most part unaware that slavery covered all of the original colonies and their successor states and began to loosen its grip in the North only in the early 1800's, when personal liberty laws went into effect. New York City was a capital of human bondage, with more slaves than any other city with the possible exception of Charleston, S.C.
New England survives in the history books as the hotbed of abolitionism and the home of the crusading anti-slavery novelist Harriet Beecher Stowe. But Ms. Farmer-Paellmann has turned up documents revealing a different New England, one in which corporate founders and respected businessmen trafficked in slaves, even after aspects of the slave trade were made illegal.
One of the most serious offenders was the Rhode Island businessman John Brown, who founded Providence Bank, an early predecessor of the modern FleetBoston Financial Corporation. The Fleet corporate history portrays Brown as a "respected merchant." But Ms. Farmer-Paellmann has unearthed records showing that Brown owned ships that embarked on several slaving voyages and that he was prosecuted in federal court for participating in the international slave trade after it had become illegal under federal law. Records show that Providence Bank lent substantial sums to Brown, and Ms. Farmer-Paellmann suspects that the bank both financed and profited from the founder's illegal slave trading. For its part, FleetBoston contends that incomplete records make a conclusion impossible.
The most disturbing document to emerge so far reveals that the Aetna Insurance Company of Hartford actually insured slave owners against the loss of their human chattel. That Aetna knew the horrors of slave life is evident in a rider through which the company declined to pay the premium for slaves who were lynched, worked to death or who committed suicide. Aetna says that incomplete records forbid its knowing how many such policies were written. After the policy came to light, the company apologized for having been involved in the slave trade.
Ms. Farmer-Paellmann claims to have found similar documents concerning more than a dozen corporations still doing business in this country and has promised to file several lawsuits charging these companies with unjustly enriching themselves at the expense of slaves. Whether or not the lawsuits succeed is almost beside the point. This exercise will have done its job if it reveals to the public the role of slavery in shaping American life. More than a few modern fortunes rest on the suffering of human beings who once accounted for a large portion of American wealth and lived in chains here for 250 years.

HEADLINE: A New Crisis Over Refugees Adrift in Their Own Lands

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 21

 BODY:
From the Caucasus to Kosovo, Congo, Colombia and East Timor, millions of people have been displaced by civil war or ethnic violence. But almost everywhere, particularly in Africa, they struggle to survive without much, if any, international help because they have not crossed an international border and are not, strictly speaking, refugees.
In recent years, the United Nations has been without a coherent policy for helping those victims of war, known to international agencies as "internally displaced people," or I.D.P.'s. Because there is no agency and almost no money regularly set aside for these people, responses to crises have been haphazard and often opportunistic. Some get help, often because they are mixed into refugee populations. Many never do. 
 The leading United Nations relief official, Carolyn McAskie, said this week that she wanted to look for ways to bring existing United Nations agencies into a common effort to pay more attention to this problem. Although she has yet to appoint a director to coordinate that effort, officials say that the job will go to Dennis McNamara, who has most recently been a deputy to the United Nations administrator of Kosovo.
In choosing this approach, rather than designating a new or lead agency to deal with the problem, Ms. McAskie, the United Nations' emergency relief coordinator, has placed herself in opposition to the United States, and particularly its ambassador here, Richard C. Holbrooke.
Mr. Holbrooke, who since visiting Africa late last year has been on a campaign for action on the issue, said this week that he was "skeptical of the so-called collaborative approach." He said American diplomats and aid experts abroad would be asked to report on how coordination is working.
"Let's see the new system at work," he said in a speech to the United Nations Economic and Social Council. "And ultimately, let's see if it makes any difference on the ground."
In an interview, Ms. McAskie said the concept of putting one agency in charge of the internally displaced had been studied. "We have looked at that option very seriously, and we do honestly believe -- and most of the agencies and quite a few of the governments honestly believe -- that that's not necessarily the best answer, partly because I.D.P.'s are so mixed in with the rest of the population that we have to find ways of addressing the war-affected population as a whole."
"I.D.P.s have specific needs, though," she acknowledged. "There's no doubt about it. And we can do better to address that. We've come out with a policy on protection. We're trying to increase the knowledge and awareness of country teams." She said that one of the major hurdles to increased help to the internally displaced has been a lack of money.
Sadako Ogata, who will retire later this year after serving for nearly a decade as United Nations high commissioner for refugees, underlined in a speech in New York last Tuesday that it is more difficult to raise cash to aid displaced people within their own countries than to help other refugee groups.
"We are failing internally displaced people," she said. "By 'we' I mean to include governments, the United Nations system and the broader humanitarian community. The scale of suffering and the human cost are staggering." She said that in Asia, Africa, Europe and the Americas she had seen "appalling examples of forced displacement and misery."
"In many of these situations," she said, "displacement is not merely a consequence of conflict, but its very objective. The governments responsible for protecting the rights and well-being of internally displaced people are often the cause of their predicament as they pursue calculated strategies aimed at changing the ethnic map of the country or gaining control over its economic resources."
The help these uprooted people now get, she acknowledged, "is selective, uneven and, in many cases, inadequate."
On Thursday, Mrs. Ogata appealed for $8.4 million for 300,000 people who have been forced to flee homes in three provinces in Angola, where 1.5 million people have been displaced since another peace agreement fell apart in 1998. The United States has pledged $2 million to the fund.
"Will others follow their example?" Mrs. Ogata asked. "I will be blunt," she said. "Making a real difference for internally displaced people will require a very substantial and sustained commitment of resources."

HEADLINE: Group of 8 Pledges to Help Poor Countries

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: NAGO, Japan, July 23

 BODY:
The leaders of eight industrial nations concluded their annual economic summit meeting in this island resort today with a broad commitment to help poor countries reduce their debt burden and increase their access to better education, health care and information technology.
In a communique issued at the end of a three-day meeting in Okinawa, Japan's southernmost island, the leaders of the Group of 8 promised action on a wide variety of issues, most notably to curtail extreme poverty and the spread of infectious diseases like AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. 
 Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori of Japan, this year's host, said wealthy nations have an obligation to break the "vicious cycle" of poverty and disease faced by poor countries. In addition to Mr. Mori, the leaders of the United States, Canada, Britain, Italy, France, Germany and Russia took part in the conference.
"We commit ourselves to the agreed international development goals, including the overarching objective of reducing the share of the world's population living in extreme poverty to half its 1990 levels by 2015," the leaders said in a statement.
Seeking to bridge the so-called digital divide, a technological gap that separates the world's haves from the have-nots, the leaders agreed to establish a task force to help developing countries reap the benefits offered by new information technologies.
The conference's final 15-page communique, drafts of which had been circulating for days, contained few new initiatives and provided few details on how the leading industrialized nations would achieve their lofty goals, bringing criticism from some human rights groups and nongovernmental organizations that the summit meeting had lacked substance.
The statement did, however, mention the need for joint attention to a number of issues, including the safety of genetically modified foods, research into the human genome, cross-border criminal organizations, the aging of populations in many developed countries and environmental issues like global warming.
The leaders promised to speed up efforts to achieve debt relief for 20 of the most heavily indebted poor countries. A similar pledge was made a year ago at the group's summit meeting in Cologne, Germany, but so far only nine of those impoverished countries have received some relief.
The leaders at the meeting also pledged to jump-start the multilateral trade talks under the World Trade Organization before the end of the year. Last December, the trade organization's policy meeting in Seattle collapsed when officials failed to reach an agreement on the agenda and street demonstrations against globalization turned violent.
The summit meetings are a chance for world leaders to make an impression, and in Okinawa President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia stole the show.
Before coming to Okinawa, Mr. Putin visited the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, and there was widespread interest at the summit meeting in his trip.
At a press briefing today, Mr. Putin said he believed that Mr. Kim was a man with whom the world could do business and urged more contacts with him to help to defuse tensions in the region.
There were widespread fears that, as in Seattle, there would be disruptive demonstrations around the Okinawa meeting after Okinawan police officers arrested a United States marine accused of sexually molesting a 14-year-old island girl. The episode did lead to huge demonstrations by Okinawans, who have long demanded the removal of the many United States military bases on the island.
But the protests, which were held at military bases and at hotels and conference centers used for the meeting, remained orderly, and the police reported no violence.
In a private meeting with Prime Minister Mori, President Clinton apologized for a series of crimes, including sex attacks, committed here in recent years by United States servicemen.
The Japanese government came under sharp criticism, though, for spending more than $750 million to hold this event.
Nongovernmental organizations said that Japan's record expenditure was nearly 100 times higher than the amounts spent at the meeting in Cologne or an earlier one in Birmingham, England, and that the money could have been used to relieve the debt of the world's poorest nations.
Jubilee 2000, a protest group that seeks to reduce the debt of developing countries, said the amount that Japan spent on the meeting could have been used to erase the debt of Gambia or Equatorial Guinea. "The world's leaders have retreated to this remote island of Okinawa and have turned their backs on the poor," the group said.
The Japanese government said that the $750 million included the cost of staging the three-day meeting in Okinawa and earlier meetings of finance ministers and foreign ministers in Fukuoka and Miyazaki. About $300 million of the $750 million was spent on security, which included 22,000 police officers drafted from across the country to work at the meeting.
It has been nearly a quarter-century since the first summit meeting of the world's major industrialized countries was held -- in Rambouillet, France, in 1975.
The meetings were initially intended as informal gatherings where the leaders of the world's richest countries could resolve problems of common concern, like inflation, economic growth and currency crises. The premise was that they could do more together than separately.
But the conferences have evolved in recent years to include discussions of broader political and social significance, including armed conflicts, technology, hunger, health care and other issues affecting the developing world, and to include Russia, which, despite its ailing economy, is a central figure on the world stage.
In his briefing today, Mr. Putin also said he would continue lobbying Washington to abandon plans to build an antimissile defense shield against possible attack from hostile countries like North Korea.
"Putin conducted himself like a true statesman, unlike his predecessor, Yeltsin, who acted erratic and was probably drunk at previous summits," said George von Furstenberg, a professor in economic and financial policy at Fordham University in New York.
"Putin didn't come here looking sad with his hand out begging for loans," the professor said. "He was confident and mature and had a bag of North Korean goodies to share with the group."

PUB-DATE: July 24, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3049 words

HEADLINE: SHIFTING WORKPLACE/A special report.;
Renewed Corporate Wanderlust Puts a Quiet Brake on Salaries

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.

 BODY:
Not long after W. Lee Nutter took over last year as chairman of Rayonier Inc., a big wood and pulp company with headquarters in Stamford, Conn., he called in a top executive, Jack O'Grady, and asked, "Why are we here?"
The reasons, in fact, had peeled away. Modern technology now allowed the company to distance itself from New York's financial markets and still have complete instant communications. More of Rayonier's timberland and mills were in the Southeast, and Jacksonville beckoned with $2.7 million in public subsidies. And, in a booming economy, managers and executives were increasingly expensive. Moving to an office tower here this summer cut executive labor costs. 
 Twenty-eight people transferred from Stamford, but others declined to relocate and 44 men and women, mostly executives, are being hired locally at salaries that are at least 10 percent lower, on average, than those paid in Stamford. In relocating, Rayonier shrank the headquarters staff to 72 from 85. And the new executives expect less. "Salaries in the Southeast do rise more slowly than in the Northeast," said Mr. O'Grady, who is senior vice president for administration.
Companies have been migrating for decades, of course, moving operations both within the United States and overseas for many reasons, including the search for cheaper labor. But since 1996, corporate migration within the country has soared, roughly doubling to more than 11,000 moves a year, according to Site Selection Magazine of Atlanta, the only organization, public or private, to track the phenomenon. At the same time, the emphasis has shifted from factories, the traditional migrants, to every type of service operation, and across a range of jobs, from Rayonier's six-figure executives to call center operators earning $7 an hour.
The increasing restlessness of American business is beginning to be noticed by economists, government officials and industry groups. "Corporate migration within the United States is definitely accelerating," said Allen J. Scott, a geographer at the University of California at Los Angeles who specializes in economic issues. "The booming economy is prodding companies to relocate or expand in new places."
As labor shortages and competition for workers drive up wages in one city, companies have shifted work or have expanded in another location, where the same tasks can be done at lower pay. This movement helps to answer one of the big questions about the recent economy: How has the United States managed to achieve its lowest unemployment rate since the 1960's and yet not experience as much upward pressure on wages as it has during past booms, even when labor markets were not as tight as they are today?
Various explanations have been offered by economists for the failure of labor shortages to give a bigger kick to wages in the record long expansion that started in 1991: weaker unions, the greater use of temporary workers, a minimum wage that has lost value, a flood of immigrant workers, layoffs and job insecurity, global competition. Often overlooked, however, has been the impact of the stepped-up rate of corporate migration, which adds another critical element to the mix.
But if lower labor costs drive the process, technology greases the way. High-speed telecommunications and fiber optic lines, now available almost everywhere in the country, allow a Rayonier to communicate as easily from Jacksonville as from Stamford, and they also allow a great variety of service companies to link operations in different cities, as if these operations were all in one office. In addition, the talent pool is more evenly spread across the country in the 1990's than in earlier generations, said Lawrence F. Katz, a Harvard economist, meaning "you can find similar labor forces and similar amenities in many more places in America."
While technology facilitates corporate migration, so does the growing use of call centers to deal with the public. Many companies use centers to take orders for merchandise, to service credit cards, to handle securities transactions, to give investment advice, to help owners of computers solve software problems, to collect debts, to sell insurance, to help people navigate the Internet. No one has yet counted all the call center operators, not even the Labor Department, but their importance is beginning to rival that of assembly line workers 50 years ago. And call centers, generally requiring only telephones and desk-top computers, are much more mobile than factories.
Mid-sized cities in the Southeast and Southwest are prime targets of the corporate migration, cities like Charlotte, Memphis, Phoenix and Jacksonville. But companies have also been drawn in growing numbers to the Midwestern states or to Maine or Pennsylvania or Kentucky -- to any place, in fact, that offers lower wages and public subsidies. Maine has fewer than 6,000 people making shoes, less than half the number it had in 1985, but out-of-state retailers, banks, pharmaceutical companies, even a newspaper clipping service, have placed operations in the old shoe towns, re-employing workers.
"Companies are searching for pockets of unemployment," said Steven H. Levesque, commissioner of Maine's Department of Economic and Community Development, "and Maine has these pockets."
 
Spreading the Jobs
Mobility Restrains Wage Momentum
The stepped-up corporate migration has spread jobs and living standards more evenly across the country than in some earlier expansions. Rather than expand several of its operations in New York or New Jersey, for example, Merrill Lynch has gradually added 2,000 employees here in Jacksonville, locating them in four imposing pink stone office buildings on a bucolic site in a suburban office park.
For a migrating company, the money saved in labor costs often goes into earnings, helping to explain the extraordinary profitability of American business in recent years, economists say. And by lowering labor costs, corporate migration serves to keep inflation under control. But it also serves as a counterweight to the social benefit of a low unemployment rate. The ability to move almost any kind of work easily gives employers a more powerful response to the demands of their employees for greater pay.
"Not just the greater mobility, but the threat of it helps to hold down wages," Mr. Katz said.
Even so, average hourly earnings have risen faster than inflation in the boom years since 1996, the first time that has happened for so long a stretch since the 1960's and early 70's. But compare the 1990's with those earlier decades and a more complex story emerges. Wages moved up more persistently in the 60's as the unemployment rate fell. In response, the inflation rate also rose more in the 60's than it did in the 90's. Corporate migration has helped, in effect, to hold down labor costs and prices.
Public attention has focused on manufacturers that shift factories abroad, particularly to Mexico and the Far East. But corporate migration within the United States, which dawdled along at fewer than 5,200 occurrences annually from 1980 through 1994, jumped in the late 1990's to more than 11,400, according to Site Selection's research.
The organization's totals cover not only corporate migrations but also the initial investments of newly started companies. Because only the largest start-ups are counted, however, they represent only 10 percent of each year's total, says Jack Lynes, Site Selection's executive editor. The totals, including the start-ups, reached 12,702 in 1999. Before 1995, the high point was 5,686 in 1989, the last full year of the previous expansion.
Responding to a request for data on corporate migration, the American Management Association polled 63 of its chief executives last month, asking by e-mail whether they intended to relocate their headquarters. Forty-two percent said they had either recently relocated or were actively considering doing so.
"You have to conclude that relocating operations is very much on the agenda of corporate America," said Eric Greenberg, the association's director of surveys.
The continuing migration of millions of families to the Sun Belt and the Mountain States serves as a magnet for many companies. The labor force has grown more rapidly in these regions than in the Northeast or Midwest. In Jacksonville, for example, the labor force has been growing at 3 percent a year since 1990, or three times as fast as the national average.
As a result, skilled executives -- accountants, financial analysts, personnel managers and computer specialists -- are finally as easy for Rayonier to find here as they are in the Northeast, Mr. O'Grady says.
"These are people who have moved for the amenities of life," said Edward Glaeser, a Harvard economist, "and in some long-run sense their wages are going to be relatively low because they want to be there."
Rayonier is the 19th large company to move an operation to Jacksonville this year, or expand one here, and the company is still unpacking. Paintings are propped against a wall in the conference room, waiting to be hung. Potted plants will also decorate the room, Mr. O'Grady promises, and out in the lobby the black plastic counter encircling the receptionist's station will soon be changed for a green marble one, matching the green in the new carpet.
Rayonier's headquarters had been in Stamford for 20 years and in Manhattan for 30 years before that. Its new executives in Jacksonville earn $85,000 and up, some as much as $175,000 a year. For that sort of money, Mr. O'Grady said, the pickings are better and the turnover less.
"You have more people competing for our jobs at this pay range," he said. And the quality is better. In the Northeast, you get a personnel executive, for example, with experience only in workmen's compensation, Mr. O'Grady explained. "Here, for the same pay, they also have experience in medical and dental insurance and 401(k) plans. You get a broader experience base."
There are other advantages. Office space is cheaper, and because headquarters is now "closer to the bulk of our operations," Mr. O'Grady said, fewer executives are needed. The company likes to promote from within, but getting promising employees to transfer to Stamford was harder and more expensive than bringing them here is likely to be. Housing costs are less, the climate milder, and the beaches spectacular. The Jaguar football team also figures as a draw in the Rayonier calculation, Mr. O'Grady said.
"I have a new condo here," said Mr. O'Grady, who transferred to Jacksonville himself in the spring, "and I asked my neighbors, 'Where are you from?' and I would bet 80 percent are from other places."
 
Have Jobs, Will Travel
More Places Seen As Viable Locales
Companies that once put down deep roots are also showing up in Colorado, Idaho, Texas, Nevada, Utah, Iowa, Nebraska, Ohio -- just about everywhere.
But the South is still a favorite. People have been migrating to the South for more than a generation, and now their children, those raised and educated in Jacksonville, for example, are everywhere at Merrill Lynch. William A. Bridy, Merrill's senior director in Jacksonville, often recruits graduates of the University of North Florida, whose campus, with 12,000 students, is only three miles away. Recent graduates are among the 25 "profilers" stationed at Merrill's suburban campus.
Merrill developed profiling at its Somerset, N.J., office, using the profilers to build a database of biographical information on new clients for use as a tool in selling more services. The expansion, seven months ago, was in Jacksonville and Denver.
Here a profiler's starting wage of $26,000 is 10 to 20 percent less than in New Jersey, Mr. Bridy said. "There is not the demand for New Jersey wages," he said, adding that if labor costs do rise, Jacksonville will become less attractive. That is beginning to happen in Denver. "The problem you have there is turnover, which is higher than Jacksonville," Mr. Bridy said.
Sometimes the corporate migration is only a few counties away. Pressed by the Big Three automakers to hold down prices, some parts manufacturers are shifting from the Detroit environs to Traverse City and other locations in upstate Michigan, where wages are lower. Principal Financial Group, which manages pension plans for thousands of companies, found that wages were rising in Des Moines, its headquarters city, for the counselors who field telephone calls from people seeking information about their plans or shifting investments. So work has been moved, through computer links, to offices in Waterloo and Ottumwa, Iowa, where wages for counselors with the same skills are 5 to 10 percent lower than in Des Moines.
Burrelle's Information Services is a constant migrant. The company employs nearly 2,000 people who cull newspaper, magazine, video and Internet citations for corporate customers. As wages rose in Livingston, N.J., its headquarters, and business grew, the company added an office in Salt Lake City, then Presque Isle, Me., and most recently in Houlton, Me. -- all in a successful effort to keep the hourly wage of most of the employees below $10.
"The unemployment rate is a little higher in Houlton than in Presque Isle because it does not have an airport and tends to be bypassed by other companies," said Robert Waggoner, chief executive at Burrelle's. "You have to be adventurous in finding new places."
 
Vying for Better Jobs
Towns Try to Draw The Better Wages
While Maine, with an unemployment rate of 5 percent or more in many towns and cities, vies to attract lower-wage jobs -- or any jobs -- Jacksonville is taking a different tack. The unemployment rate here has fallen to 3.1 percent from 6.6 percent in 1992, and with the pressure reduced to bring in jobs, whatever they pay, the Chamber of Commerce and the Economic Development Commission are trying to attract companies with jobs that pay more than $31,000.
Boeing, the aerospace giant, is one beneficiary. Servicing and overhauling aircraft is a growing part of its business, but rather than expand repair centers in Wichita, Seattle or St. Louis, where mechanics earn $20 an hour and up, Boeing has opened a center in Jacksonville. So have Northrop Grumman and Jet Turbine Services. Skilled mechanics, trained in the Navy and mustering out here, sign on for $18 an hour or less.
"You go where the workers are," said Dee Burcham, manager of Boeing's Jacksonville repair center.
The Navy has a big presence in Jacksonville, but part of its complex, Cecil Field, an air station, was closed and turned over to the city last fall. Now the city is leasing hangar space to Boeing and others for the give-away price of $1.50 a square foot.
"We are pump priming," said Paul Krutko, a director of the Economic Development Commission. "Later the rates will go up."
Mr. Burcham, the Boeing manager, whose 55 employees will rise to 120 by January, acknowledges that Cecil Field's subsidized facilities were an important lure. "All we had to do was organize a work force and we were up and running," he said. But he gave equal billing to "the availability of knowledgeable aviation mechanics and electricians" at $18 an hour or less.
They are people like Michael Zipp, 39, who trained in the Marines as an aviation electrician. He joined Grumman in Bethpage, N.Y., in the early 1980's, long before its merger with Northrop. Earning $17.50 an hour, with a wife and four children, he could not make ends meet on Long Island, he said. So he quit in 1988, moved himself and his family to nearby St. Augustine, where Grumman had an operation, and rejoined the company at $10 an hour.
Even at that lower wage, he says, he could finally afford to pay his bills and, for the first time, purchase a home. Only now, more than a decade later, has his wage risen back to its old level of $17.50 an hour. He is aware that people with his skills earn more elsewhere in the country. The starting wage in Wichita, for example, where Boeing also has operations, is $25 an hour, he says.
Why not move? "I'm settled here," he said.
 
Son of Call Center
Jacksonville Chafes At Label, and Jobs
Jacksonville got its start in economic development as a mecca for call centers, thanks to AT&T, which set up a center here in 1983, after the phone company's breakup, to handle queries from shareholders whose stock was split. Inexpensive land drew more call centers, and Florida's status as a largely nonunion, right to work state.
Public subsidies also helped. They still do, although they are angled now toward companies like Boeing and Rayonier, which is receiving from the city a $1.8 million cash grant for bringing its headquarters here and additional "incentives," as Mr. O'Grady calls them, from the state government.
But for all the efforts of the city fathers to bring higher paying jobs to Jacksonville, the call centers still play a dominant role. America Online, Citibank, Bank of America, MediaOne all have a big presence here. "We have gone from being a call center town to wanting to not be called a call center town," said Faye Kullberg, director of human resources for MediaOne.
Few companies employ more people here than a descendant of the original AT&T call center, now part of a company called Convergys, based in Cincinnati. Convergys has 37 call centers nationwide, with 45,000 employees, including 4,500 here. The operators do not mention Convergys; they take on the identity of the companies that purchase its services. A recent client is AT&T Wireless, whose cell phone customers get a Convergys operator when they call an 800 number for help.
But Convergys has not expanded recently in Jacksonville. The pay for call center operators has risen by about $2 an hour in the last 18 months, to between $10 and $12 an hour. Turnover is also rising, and Jacksonville is losing its luster as a suitable site for low-wage call centers. So Convergys opened its newest center in Brownsville, Tex.
"We pay the same in Brownsville as in Jacksonville," said Frank Kelly, a Convergys executive, "but the unemployment rate there reached 14 percent, and we were able to hire very good people. They consider our job to be a white collar job."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CONVENTION;
Philadelphia Ends a Neighborhood's Tale

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, July 21

 BODY:
Sparing the approaching Republican National Convention a civic eyesore, bulldozers are moving in on the last of the 957 sinking homes of the Logan triangle, a stricken working-class swath of north Philadelphia that has festered as an urban disaster for more than a decade.
"The city suddenly told me I had to get out," said Suzette Williams, hurriedly packing a moving van after 30 years on North 11th Street. This is the epicenter of a once vital 17-block neighborhood that is now an inner-city prairie dotted with skeletal buildings and a score of lingering residents of Logan's last stand. 
 The 80-year-old neighborhood's collapse into its own unstable landfill is stark evidence that the vaunted Philadelphia renaissance that is attracting the Republican conventioneers is at least a tale of two cities: the glittering downtown of new hotels and trendy restaurants, and frayed old working-class neighborhoods like Logan, five miles to the north. Residents in poor, predominantly black areas complain that the city leadership has been preoccupied with attracting downtown tourists who stay overnight, rather than stemming the working-class flight of some 250,000 people in the last decade from neighborhoods freighted with neglect.
As the city government hurries to raze the Logan hulks, and even mow the summer weeds on the ghostly 47-acre wasteland, what remains, church and civic leaders are emphasizing, is a gaunt but most inviting campaign backdrop for any venturesome presidential contender who might want to stop by during the convention and speak firsthand to the issue of inner-city housing for the working class and striving poor.
"George Bush should come here and put some meat on the bones of his compassionate conservatism," said the Rev. Kermit L. Newkirk, pastor of the Harold O. Davis Baptist Church.
Initially, city officials had promised to raze all 957 buildings and to compensate and relocate the 5,000 residents within three years. That was in 1986, when the crumbling neighborhood first seized the city's attention with an explosion caused by an underground gas leak. The initial prescription of relocation and redevelopment that was supposed to take 3 years to accomplish is now in its 15th year, having spawned a separate quasi-government agency with its own patronage, retirement benefits and petty scandals.
In recent years, people in this Democratic neighborhood have been courting Republican state officials, some of whom have been responsive and credible, Pastor Newkirk said. His frustration is clear after 14 years of struggling with successive Democratic city administrations over the houses' cracking and sinking as their landfill of ash heaps shifted with saturation from an underground creek and ruptured utility pipes. Federal investigators have also found dangerous levels of lead and are testing for other contaminants.
Advocates for assorted causes like the global economy and gay rights will soon be arriving to take to the streets for the four-day Republican convention, opening on July 31. But only Logan is offering a vivid on-site experience and eyewitness guides through a tortured saga of neighborhood blight, political promises and bureaucratic nostrums.
When the opening gavel sounds at the convention center, Logan will have its own welcoming event.
Handbills and public bus advertising downtown will offer conventioneers graphic photos of the devastation, and pose the question, "What is the Republican response?"
If nothing else, the convention preparations have spurred city officials into faster demolition. "We're getting rid of everything over in Logan; I never want to hear that name again!" an involved city official shouted from his car this week at the Rev. Mary Laney of St. Gabriel's Episcopal Church.
The church serves the surrounding Feltonville neighborhood where, Ms. Laney noted, property values have become depressed and housing sales frozen. This is because of warnings that the nearby problem with unstable landfill and underground piping may be spreading to as many as 4,000 additional houses.
"I'm trapped here," said Michael Brown, a homeowner just outside the officially defined area of sinkage, which some city officials concede was arbitrary in the first place.
He watched Ms. Williams pack for her move from North 11th Street. He stood in front of his own house just 30 feet away and told of the same problems of deep foundation cracks, sewage flooding in the basement and tilting, cracked walls and porch.
"My house is paid for but no one will buy it and no one will put up a mortgage for it," Mr. Brown said, sounding desperate as his horizon grew flatter. "You can't give my house away."
Logan's local leaders underline the news from City Hall that Mayor John F. Street, a Democrat, will be attending the neighborhood welcome, nine months after he campaigned in Logan, promising fresh initiative and $37 million in additional help for the disaster. This would roughly double what has been spent so far. Logan activists criticize former Mayor W. Wilson Goode for his handling of the initial crisis and former Mayor Edward G. Rendell for managing Philadelphia's downtown renewal far more successfully than Logan's.
"But the bulldozing amounts to a victory for us," said Ceci Schickel, chief organizer for Philadelphia Interfaith Action, a regional church and civic association. The group has been working with the Industrial Areas Foundation, a nationwide organization that is trying to make a campaign issue of housing, low wages and other problems of the working poor.
"Politicians are in denial about complicated, massive problems like Logan," said Mike Kecan, a foundation organizer. "Their talk of faith-based solutions is tokenism."
The frustrations in Logan were only compounded last summer when some homes were ruled endangered in the city's predominantly white Wissinoming neighborhood because of unstable landfill. Residents affected by this far smaller problem involving about two dozen homes received relocation and compensation help within weeks.
"I've had nothing but trouble for years trying to get my money," Ms. Williams said after completing her packing. "This is still my community," she said as she departed.

HEADLINE: 40 Percent In New York Born Abroad

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
A human tidal wave has added one million immigrants to New York City in the last decade, propelling foreign-born residents to 40 percent of the population, an analysis of United States Census Bureau figures shows.
That level of immigration has not been equaled for nearly a century. As recently as 1990, the figure for foreign-born residents was 28 percent. 
 The new figures come not from the 2000 census, whose results will not be known until next year. Instead, they are derived from the recently released results of a 15,417-household survey taken in 1999 by the Census Bureau. That study is done every three years to see if housing vacancies are below 5 percent, the legal threshold for continuing rent regulation. Because the sample is large and the bureau conducts the survey, the data are considered highly reliable. They jibe with the census, which is undertaken every 10 years.
"It's really a preview of the full census," said Dr. Andrew A. Beveridge, a Queens College sociologist who analyzes census data.
Although the surge has been evident for years, its sheer size is stunning. "Boy, that is some number -- wow, wow!" said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, co-author of "Beyond the Melting Pot," a 1963 treatise on race and ethnicity in the city. "It's an enriching experience for us," Mr. Moynihan said. "It's wonderful -- I mean, we have to think of it that way. If we think of it any other way, it won't be."
Without immigration, for example, New York's overall population would be shrinking. Instead, the stream of people from around the world is offsetting the loss of city residents to death and relocation to the suburbs and other regions. The result has been a modest net gain of about 130,000 since 1990, to an estimated total of 7.4 million last year.
"Absent immigration, we would be seeing a very different New York, with neighborhood abandonment and depopulation," said Dr. Philip Kasinitz, a sociology professor at Hunter College. Dr. William H. Frey, a demographer at the State University of New York at Albany, said, "These groups are revitalizing and re-energizing these neighborhoods."
Similar flows from abroad are bolstering the population of other major cities across the nation, although New York has had the largest influx. A big difference, however, is that other places have ethnically concentrated immigration, such as the Cubans in Miami, while the new New Yorkers are extraordinarily diverse by race and nationality. "This is a region that is going to continue to be very different from any other areas of the country," Dr. Frey said.
City Planning Commission officials declined to be interviewed about the findings. An agency spokeswoman, Jennifer Chait, voiced caution. "These projections are based on data that is incomplete and inadequate for drawing significant conclusions," she said. "Our expectations are that the definitive Census 2000 data will show a substantial increase in New York City foreign-born population but not to as nearly as high as 40 percent."
But Dr. Beveridge said his figures were actually conservative. The Census Bureau sample showed that 44 percent of heads of households were foreign born. Estimating the figure for the entire city, he reduced the percentage to adjust for factors like children of immigrants being born here. The margin of error is 0.8 of a percentage point, he said. He also noted that the planning agency itself had estimated immigration at 100,000 a year, which in 10 years adds up to one million.
Further, official statistics undercount immigrants who decline to respond because of language barriers, wariness of the government or concern about the legality of their immigration, jobs or housing. Immigration data also exclude native Puerto Ricans, who are American citizens, though it can be argued that by language, culture and geography, they have much in common with immigrants.
Dr. Beveridge's findings were backed by two other experts. Dr. John Mollenkopf, director of the Urban Research Center at the City University of New York's Graduate Center, said, "That's consistent with what other sources, like the current population survey, are showing," referring to yet another Census Bureau sampling. His work on that survey indicates that 54 percent of children through the age of 18 are either foreign born or have foreign-born parents. And Dr. Aristide R. Zolberg, director of New School University's International Center for Migration, Ethnicity and Citizenship, said he used a 40 percent estimate for the immigrant population.
Not since 1910 has New York's percentage of foreign-born residents been so high. That era of immigration, through the halls of Ellis Island, transformed the city and sparked debates over the role of newcomers that still echo today. To house the last wave, a staggering 600,000 dwellings were built in the 1920's. Radicalized newcomers enlivened local politics. And sweatshop exploitation of immigrants, spotlighted by the fatal fire at the Triangle Shirtwaist factory in 1911, galvanized the labor movement.
"We never dreamed that New York would again become a major city of immigrants, but then the immigration laws changed in 1965," said Mr. Moynihan's co-author, Dr. Nathan Glazer of Harvard University.
The latest tide continues unabated into the new century.
Experts say the current wave was accelerated by the enticing economic boom and New York's refurbished image as a safer, cleaner city. And there is the age-old tradition of new arrivals following the footsteps of friends and relatives to ethnic enclaves throughout the five boroughs.
Immigration is as old as the city itself. Back in 1643, when New York was called New Amsterdam, the 500 residents spoke 18 languages.
Major ethnic shifts within the current immigration wave are changing the city's makeup. Dr. Beveridge's estimates show that New Yorkers born in the former Soviet Union, who numbered 81,000 in 1990, had nearly tripled to 229,000 by 1999. Other fast-growing groups include Mexicans, who nearly quadrupled to 133,000 in 1999 from 35,000 in 1990, and South Asians from India, Pakistan and Bangladesh, who more than doubled to 146,000 in 1999 from 67,000 in 1990.
Continuing to climb as a major Hispanic group, the number of Dominicans rose by more than two-thirds, to 387,000 in 1999 from 230,000 in 1990. (The number of Puerto Ricans born on the island dropped 21 percent to 290,000 in 1999, from 367,000 in 1990. Adding those born on the mainland, Puerto Ricans here totaled 744,000 last year, an 11 percent drop from 834,000 in 1990.)
The statistics confirm the changing face of the city witnessed on the streets every day by native New Yorkers, themselves descended from earlier immigrants. Mexican shops are sprouting in western Queens, Middle Eastern businesses now compete with the Greek establishments of Astoria, and very little of Italy is left in Little Italy, where Chinese-Americans are the absolute majority and Hispanics have been jostling for secnd place.
"Gateway to America," says the welcoming sign at Kennedy International Airport in Queens. So many newcomers have stepped off and made their home in that borough that its 167 nationalities and 116 languages make it the nation's most diverse county. But immigration "certainly poses challenges and pressures," Dr. Glazer said. The Queens borough president, Claire Shulman, said: "I'm continually looking for school seats and sites to build, because we are minus 30,000 seats and growing 10 percent a year. The other thing is there really isn't enough affordable housing, which has led to a lot of illegal conversions."
Some experts call for a strategic plan for dealing with immigration. "We need to get out in front and plan and strive to do better," said Michael H. Schill, a New York University professor.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has often voiced support for immigrants. His press office did not return calls seeking comment from him and from the immigrant affairs office on the latest figures.
Immigration has produced tensions. The visiting baseball pitcher John Rocker made his distaste well known. One man paid for anti-immigration billboards, and City Councilwoman Julia Harrison of Queens objected to Chinese and Korean business signs without English translations.
Most experts say that immigrants are a plus for the city. Although many may be dependent when they arrive, Professor Schill said, "that rapidly changes as they move up the ladder and contribute more in taxes than they consume." He added, "Immigrants tend to be very resourceful, or they wouldn't be here in the first place."
Mrs. Shulman agreed: "They're all wonderful. For the most part they're all working; our unemployment is under 5 percent. I go to a lot of graduations, and they're winning a lot of valedictorians and salutatorians and walking away with lots of good scholarships. The vitality, the energy, the chemistry from people all over the world is what makes New York City unique and makes New York City great." She named another benefit to Queens: "Hey, listen, we have the best restaurants in the city."

HEADLINE: CAMP DAVID TALKS AT A CRUCIAL POINT

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: THURMONT, Md., July 23

 BODY:
With stakes mounting as the Camp David summit meeting nears its third week, President Clinton returned to negotiations tonight, and officials suggested that the talks, now centered on the future of Jerusalem, could break apart in the next day or solidify into a deal.
Adding a new aura of gravity to the talks, the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, traveled to Saudi Arabia to ensure Saudi support for Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, in the crucial debate over Jerusalem. 
 The diplomacy by Mr. Mubarak, who maintains the best relations with Mr. Arafat of any Arab leader, was seen by the Israelis and the Americans as an effort to build a wall of Arab solidarity behind the Palestinian leader.
The Americans made it plain through the State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, that the summit meeting would not go on indefinitely and could reach a make-or-break point as soon as Monday.
"We are not here for an unlimited period of time," Mr. Boucher said. The president will be given an immediate assessment, and this will be "very important" in how the talks move, he said.
Privately, American officials suggested that if progress was not made by Monday, it would be difficult to keep going. If the talks moved toward midweek, they added, this would be a sign that things were going well.
At his summer retreat outside Rome, Pope John Paul II entered the Camp David debate, exhorting the summit leaders in his weekly Sunday address to adopt a long-held Vatican position that a special international status be extended to the holy sites in the Old City of Jerusalem.
As important figures on the outside tried to influence the conference, Mr. Clinton left behind the relative calm of an uncontentious economic summit meeting in Japan, and entered what several accounts suggested was a razor-edge atmosphere among the Israelis and Palestinians at Camp David.
To relieve the tensions, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, got some distraction by visiting the Civil War battlefields at Gettysburg today with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright. Mr. Arafat relaxed at Dr. Albright's Virginia farm, where she served him lunch on Saturday.
But these outings were mere interludes in a process that is inexorably building toward a climax. The conference went into its 13th day today, the entire duration of the first Middle East peace conference at Camp David in 1978 under the auspices of President Jimmy Carter.
The Israelis have said Mr. Barak is willing to make concessions on Jerusalem, though it is far from clear that they would be enough for Mr. Arafat. Gadi Baltiansky, Mr. Barak's spokesman, suggested that talks had entered the critical phase.
"It won't take a lot of time," he said. "President Clinton will return to Camp David, and then we will see if there is any point in staying here and going on with the talks, or to pack the luggage and go home."
In Mr. Clinton's absence, the stakes grew in a variety of ways.
In a letter he wrote to Mr. Clinton before the summit meeting was pronounced dead and then swiftly revived on Wednesday night, Mr. Barak stated, according to leaks in the Israeli press, that if the meeting ended with no overall accord, he would walk away even from points he had agreed to.
The Americans have suggested that they may be facing an all-or-nothing outcome and a situation at the very end in which Mr. Clinton will be trying to salvage something from the rubble of a blowup over Jerusalem.
One way of looking at the negotiations as they unfold now, according to this scenario, is comparing them to pushing a rock up a hill. If a full agreement formally bringing an end to the 52-year-old conflict between the Israelis and Palestinians is not achieved, then the progress on some less explosive issues, like the shape of a new Palestinian state and the fate of Palestinian refugees, could be wiped out as the rock rolls back down the slope.
Before Mr. Clinton left for Japan, he and his negotiators, according to Israeli and Palestinian reports, presented some compromise solutions for Jerusalem. They centered on degrees of sovereignty in East Jerusalem for the Palestinians, who claim all of East Jerusalem as the capital of their new Palestinian state.
The principle of the American compromise appears to be virtually full sovereignty for the Palestinians over Palestinian villages in East Jerusalem and what one expert called a "sense of sovereignty" over the Muslim religious sites in the center of the Old City.
The proposals reportedly envision some form of "shared sovereignty" over some of the parts of East Jerusalem adjacent to the eastern part of the Old City.
The reports in Israel say that these are ideas that Mr. Barak has agreed to and that they are concessions that go far beyond what any other Israeli leader has made.
Some of the Israeli accounts of the American proposal -- which is believed to have been amended in Mr. Clinton's absence -- report that a final decision on the status of the Old City, holy to Jews, Muslims and Christians, would be deferred.
The Palestinian reports say those ideas are not sufficient for Mr. Arafat to make a deal. Officials who have been in touch with the Palestinian delegation report that Mr. Arafat is unimpressed by the American proposals. Given the negotiators' agreement not to speak to reporters, it is impossible to know how much those descriptions of a defiant Mr. Arafat are for home consumption or how much they reflect a true picture.
One of the Palestinian negotiators, Abu Mazen, who had left the talks to return home, came back today saying a partial agreement was not in the cards.
A senior Palestinian official, Tayeb Abdel Rahim, was downbeat in a speech tonight at the Egyptian Consulate in Gaza. "The Palestinian delegation has achieved no progress in the important issues of the negotiations, such as Jerusalem, settlements, the return of refuges and borders," he said.
Mr. Mubarak's visit to King Fahd in Saudi Arabia also raised the stakes because the Saudi royal family is the protector of Mecca and Medina, the two holiest Islamic sites, and has a huge interest in the Islamic site in East Jerusalem.
On Saturday, the Egyptian and Jordanian foreign ministers met to discuss the Camp David talks.
Mr. Arafat has often contended that he does not have a mandate from Arabs and Muslims to cede sovereignty to Israel in East Jerusalem and, in particular, over the Muslim and Christian religious sites.
In East Jerusalem, Haram al-Sharif, or the Noble Sanctuary, known to Jews as Temple Mount, is the third holiest Muslim site, consisting of Al Aksa Mosque and the Dome of the Rock. The complex was in the custody of the Jordanian royal family until the Israelis pushed the Jordanians out of East Jerusalem in 1967.
As Mr. Arafat considered what to do about East Jerusalem, he got pressure from another quarter today. The leader of the militant Hamas movement, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, said in Gaza that he would be willing to declare a truce with Israel only if Israel agreed to withdraw completely to the 1967 borders from the West Bank, Gaza Strip and East Jerusalem.
The pope's appeal was based on a longstanding view of the Roman Catholic Church that the Israeli conquest of East Jerusalem and its annexation to Israel was an act of occupation. In February, the Vatican signed an accord with the Palestinians calling for freedom of worship in all holy sites of East Jerusalem.
In his address at his summer retreat, Castel Gandolfo, the pope said, "The Holy See continues to maintain that only a special statute internationally guaranteed can effectively preserve the most sacred areas of the Holy City."
Such international safeguards would "ensure freedom of religion and of worship for all the faithful who, in the region and the entire world, look to Jerusalem as a crossroads of peace and of coexistence," the pope said, invoking the city's "holy places and the three monotheistic religions that surround them."
As he left the White House for Camp David, Mr. Clinton held up his hands and mouthed the words "I have my fingers crossed."
