HEADLINE: Gun Control Groups Use N.R.A. Tactics For Fall Elections

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
After many years of being outspent and outmuscled by the National Rifle Association, the gun control movement has begun the most ambitious campaign in its history to raise money, recruit foot soldiers and build public support for stronger gun laws in preparation for this fall's national elections.
From established groups like Handgun Control Inc., to fledgling ones like the Million Mom March, more gun control organizations than ever before are doing the kinds of grass-roots organizing that has made the N.R.A. so powerful: opening offices across the nation, training volunteers, devising media campaigns and building political war chests. 
 At the same time, wealthy proponents of gun control seem more willing to contribute to the cause. Several major philanthropists, including George Soros, have given millions of dollars over the last two years to groups that are providing intellectual and strategic support to the organizations and politicians who advocate more regulation of guns.
And in just the last few weeks, a handful of anonymous donors have given more than $2 million to two new groups that will use the money to help candidates who support gun control and attack those who do not.
Though the gun control groups will probably still be outspent by the N.R.A. by at least two to one, their voices in this election are likely to be louder than ever before, through television commercials, mailings and news conferences.
"It's not lonely out there anymore," said Joe Sudbay, political director of Handgun Control, which for years was the only gun control group active in elections. "There is a burgeoning sense that the elections are all-important this year."
Fueling this burst of organizing is a newfound confidence among gun control leaders that public support for regulating firearms is as high as it has ever been. Outrage over mass shootings combined with enthusiasm about the Million Mom March in May have helped change the political climate, they say. And the N.R.A. has lost clout, they contend, as evidenced by the defeat of a referendum last year in Missouri to allow people to carry concealed weapons.
"In the 22 years I've been working on this issue, I have never seen the climate as favorable" for gun control, said Peter Hart, a Democratic pollster who works with Handgun Control.
Mr. Hart cites polls showing that the electorate's support for gun control -- always high -- is now also more intense, meaning more voters are making it a top priority. "Education is 1, the economy No. 2," he said. "But then, ahead of foreign policy and ahead of abortion, right there with moral issues and taxes, is gun control."
Still, even the most optimistic of the gun control leaders acknowledge that they cannot match the resources of the battle-hardened N.R.A., whose leaders have promised to spend $15 million on state and federal elections this year, nearly twice as much as in 1996. The group has already raised $8 million this year and has more than $5 million on hand.
Moreover, with its 3.8 million members, three magazines, vast e-mail contact list and national network of affiliated groups, the N.R.A. is bigger, more experienced and better equipped to mobilize its core supporters than the gun control forces.
"Our membership is larger," said James J. Baker, executive director of the N.R.A. political wing, the Institute for Legislative Action. "And our reach extends well beyond our members."
"This is a very important election," Mr. Baker said, "maybe the most important general election in the 20 years I've been here -- for both sides."
Both camps say the sharp differences between the major presidential candidates this year are helping to energize supporters. Vice President Al Gore has called for an array of new restrictions, including licensing new handgun buyers and banning certain inexpensive handguns. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has generally sided with the N.R.A., signing bills allowing people to carry concealed weapons and preventing municipalities from suing gun makers.
Much as the N.R.A. has tried to demonize Mr. Gore in its fund-raising efforts as a threat to Second Amendment rights, Handgun Control has sought to cast Mr. Bush as a pawn of the N.R.A. who would team up with a Congress controlled by Republicans to rescind every major gun law on the books.
In a recent fund-raising letter, Sarah Brady, chairwoman of Handgun Control, wrote: "My friend, if you and I truly want a safer America, we cannot allow George W. Bush to be elected president of the United States. A political disaster of that magnitude would mean four long years of being on the defensive."
Such appeals seem to be working. Handgun Control has raised more than $1.2 million in the last year, three times what it spent in the 1996 campaign. The group intends to spend at least $4 million this year, focusing on about 20 closely contested Congressional races where gun control is an issue. In most cases, it will be supporting Democrats, said Mr. Sudbay, the political director.
Among the Republicans Handgun Control is likely to work against are Representative James E. Rogan of California and Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri. The group has also run advertisements in several cities criticizing Mr. Bush's record on gun control, and plans to buy more air time in closely contested states like Michigan, Pennsylvania and Missouri.
"In swing areas, our mission is to make sure voters, particularly women voters, understand the Bush record," Mr. Sudbay said.
In past campaigns, Handgun Control largely stood alone in the fight against the N.R.A. But this year, it has been joined by at least two new advocates. One is the Million Mom March, the nonprofit group behind the Mother's Day rally in Washington. The group recently created a political arm that has raised $1 million from a single anonymous donor.
The second new group, the Campaign for a Progressive Future, has raised more than $1 million, also from anonymous donors, to spend on campaigns this year, said Steve Cobble, one of its founders.
Both groups organized their fund-raising committees under Section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code, which has allowed them to hide the identities of their donors. But Congress recently enacted rules that will require the groups to disclose the names of future contributors.
The Million Mom March has opened more than 240 chapters in 46 states and expects to be represented in every state by the fall. Those chapters will be able to lobby state legislatures, train volunteers for campaigns and disseminate "voters' guides" evaluating candidates.
Modeling itself after Mothers Against Drunk Driving, the Million Mom March will try to help its allies, and hurt its opponents, by staging emotional rallies featuring victims of gun violence or their survivors. The group plans to endorse a presidential candidate -- almost certainly Mr. Gore -- and will get involved in state and Congressional races.
"Our goal is always to get people who have personal experiences involved in trying to change policy, because they are the most powerful forces," said Andrew McGuire, executive director of the Million Mom March and a former MADD director.
Mr. Cobble, a former adviser to the Rev. Jesse Jackson, said his group would focus on a small number of closely contested Congressional races with stark differences between the candidates on gun issues.
A fourth group, the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence, is considering creation of a political action committee. But at the very least, the group plans to hire political organizers to help mobilize pro-gun-control voters in 10 to 15 tight Congressional races, said Mark Pertschuk, the group's legislative director.
Mr. Soros, the billionaire financier, has led recent efforts by philanthropists to support nonprofit groups pushing for tighter gun laws. Although many of those groups are not overtly involved in politics, they are providing the intellectual groundwork for the political advocates.
For instance, the Funders' Collaborative for Gun Violence Prevention, a year-old group created with matching $5 million donations from Mr. Soros and the Irene Diamond Fund, has helped finance litigation against gun manufacturers and a study of gun-related injuries by the Harvard School of Public Health.
Rebecca Peters, program director for the Funders' Collaborative, said one of her main goals was to overcome what she considered the mistaken but widespread perception that there were already many tough gun laws on the books.
"Policy makers and the public believe that the law is much stricter than it is," Ms. Peters said. "We are funding information which will allow people and policy makers to understand how sparsely regulated this product and this industry are."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Silicon Valley Views the Economy as a Rain Forest

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

CYBERSELFISH
A Critical Romp Through the Terribly Libertarian Culture of High Tech
By Paulina Borsook
276 pages. PublicAffairs. $24.
As high tech spreads outward from Silicon Valley to American society at large and people spend more and more time in cyberspace, the journalist Paulina Borsook steps back to look at the digerati and their view of the world.
Her conclusions: that high-tech culture is ravingly antigovernment, antiregulation and "psychologically brittle," that it manifests "a lack of human connection and a discomfort with the core of what many of us consider it means to be human," and that its view of human nature "reduces everything to the contractual, to economic rational decision making" and "ignores the larger social mesh that makes living as primates in groups at least somewhat bearable." In short, that high-tech culture promotes an Ayn Rand-ian view of the world, where the strong in tooth and claw survive, and the meek and unmarketable perish. 
 Ms. Borsook does not write as a Luddite outsider but as longtime observer of the tech world -- she was a contributing writer to Wired magazine in its formative years -- and she has written a smart, funny and irreverent book. "Cyberselfish" is both an engaging bookend to "Escape Velocity" (1996), Mark Dery's provocative study of cyberculture in the 1990's, and a bracing antidote to the Pollyanna-ish cyber-utopianism of Esther Dyson's "Release 2.0" (1997).
The dominant mind-set in high tech today, Ms. Borsook argues, is libertarianism -- in its many manifestations, from laissez-faire free-market economics to a more virulent form of "anarcho-capitalism." It boasts an ugly, selfish code of behavior and functions as a perfect mirror of the dark side of our "winner-take-all casino society." Many techies also evince an aggrieved, adversarial attitude toward the establishment or, in tech-speak, TPTB, "The Powers That Be." There is a tone of adolescent paranoia reminiscent in equal parts of "The X-Files" and "Falling Down" to many technolibertarian exchanges; a sense, in Ms. Borsook's words, of "testosterone-poisoned guys with chips on their shoulders and too much time on their hands."
Ms. Borsook contends that many of the favorite arguments of technolibertarians come from "bionomics" -- that is, they like to use metaphors drawn from biology to explain economic behavior and endorse a decentralized free-market system. Reduced to a bumper slogan, Ms. Borsook writes, bionomics states that "the economy is a rain forest"; in other words, it suggests that "no one can manage or engineer a rain forest, and rain forests are happiest when they are left alone to evolve, which will then benefit all the happy monkeys, pretty butterflies and funny tapirs that live in them."
This social Darwinism not only fails to afford protection to those less equipped to flourish in the jungle -- those "hypersensitive maladaptive no-commercial-potential individuals" -- but in Ms. Borsook's opinion also fails to ensure the triumph of the best. "It's a dirty little secret in high tech that superior marketing and inferior technology will beat out superior technology and inferior marketing every time," she writes, "and that other factors, aside from Darwinian fitness, determine which technologies and which companies thrive or perish."
Ms. Borsook makes it clear that she shares many of the libertarians' most fundamental assumptions -- "What I most want is to be left alone," she writes. "I don't have that will to power that would ever suggest that I know how to tell other people how to live their lives" -- and she criticizes the United States government for what she calls its "mostly awful handling of free speech and privacy as these relate to technology."
But while she comes down hard on federal efforts to curtail digital privacy, calling them a violation of civil liberties and due process, she is equally tough on those technolibertarians who extrapolate their anger at the feds' stand on cryptography (encoding used for security purposes) to the government at large.
"For the most part," she observes, "the government has made Silicon Valley a fine and dandy, safe and regularized place to make scads of money. A gargantuan infrastructure of suppliers and educational institutions, directly and indirectly subsidized by the government, nurtured the defense-electronics industry, which formed the substrate for today's high tech industry."
She is equally impatient with what she sees as high tech's insular selfishness -- its gonzo, go-it-alone individualism animated, she says, by a crippling blindness to human frailty and imperfection. She argues that techies' love of machines and rule-based programming leaves them ill-equipped to deal with emotions and such unquantifiable things as art, that this is why the digerati often prefer to escape the real world for a virtual one and demonstrate little sense of civic responsibility.
There are passages in "Cyberselfish" where Ms. Borsook's fervor gets the better of her fair-mindedness. Her portrait of a former Reagan speechwriter, George Gilder -- a hero to the conservative wing of high tech just as the former Grateful Dead lyricist John Perry Barlow remains the avatar of its neo-hippie wing -- turns into an angry rant; and her assessment of high tech's philanthropic record verges on the churlish, taking the digerati to task for the sort of donations (often computer-based in nature) that they choose to make.
For the most part, however, Ms. Borsook combines common sense with an old-fashioned humanism to make sense of the current high-tech gestalt. She has done a nimble job of tracing the digerati's libertarian roots in the counterculture of the 60's and the Reaganism of the 80's, and she proves equally adept at exploring the social and political fallout of their cultural ascendance.

HEADLINE: Measure of Equality

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"In Iran, More Women Leaving Nest for University" (news article, July 22) exemplifies what is happening with remarkable speed all over the world. The extent of coeducation is, perhaps more than any other, a measure of the emergence of women with full rights. 
 No other extension of women's rights establishes as clearly as does coeducation that women are fully the intellectual, social and economic equals of men. Coeducation implies acceptance of women at a level of equality very rarely achieved in history before our own time.
It is useful to recall that it was only in 1833 that Oberlin College became the first fully coeducational institution of higher education in America, and that many leading American universities became coeducational only in the last 30 years.
 
LAWRENCE CRANBERG
Austin, Tex., July 22, 2000

HEADLINE: MUSIC REVIEW;
Cantatas At Each Hill In a Year Of Bach

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Conn., July 22

 BODY:
Much of the music world heads for the hills of New England during the summer, and so, in a Bach year, does Bach.
Actually, he is a regular visitor, in concerts of the New England Bach Festival at Marlboro, Vt., among others. But the activity has stepped up markedly this year, the 250th anniversary of the composer's death, with events like the "Bach 2K" concerts this weekend at the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival. 
 The first concert here, on Friday, offered the "Brandenburg" Concertos, with some performers (the Tokyo String Quartet) more surprising in this repertory than others (like the harpsichordist Kenneth Cooper). But alas, that enticing prospect conflicted with a Marlboro concert offering cantatas, as the Saturday concert here also did.
The New England Bach Festival, in its 32nd year, was founded by Blanche Moyse, herself a venerable institution: a founder of the Marlboro Festival 50 years ago and a longtime Bach adept. On Friday she conducted the Blanche Moyse Chorale and the festival orchestra in three cantatas at the Persons Auditorium of Marlboro College.
Or rather, she conducted when needed. In small-scale movements, involving a singer and continuo with, perhaps, an obbligato player, she sat and beamed on the performance.
Yet as frail as she looked, there was no lack of vitality in the performances. Indeed, in the delightful duet "Nun verschwinden alle Plagen" ("Now all torments vanish") from Cantata No. 32, "Liebster Jesu, Mein Verlangen" ("Dearest Jesus, My Desire"), her quick clip nearly outstripped the abilities of her talented fiddlers.
The rich mix of cantatas ranged from the unfamiliar No. 60, "O Ewigkeit, Du Donnerwort" ("Eternity, Thou Thunderous Word"), with its inventive use of duets, to the famous No. 147, "Herz und Mund und Tat und Leben" ("Heart and Lips and Deed and Conduct"), with the "Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring" chorale descending twice. (Bach knew a good thing when he found it.) In addition, Steven Paul Spears, a tenor, sang the "Benedictus" from Bach's Mass in B minor, a bonus enhanced by the flute playing of Paula Robison.
Hyunah Yu, a soprano, was the most impressive of the vocal soloists, with clear, secure tone. Randall Scarlata, a fine baritone, lacked the bass notes occasionally needed.
Ms. Moyse's chorus, 22 strong, achieved what good intentions could. The basic sonority is that of so many amateur groups: fuzzy and unfocused, with little core or bite.
The Norfolk concert on Saturday avoided any such problem by having the four vocal soloists sing the choruses. There being only two choral movements, opening and closing Cantata No. 8, "Liebster Gott, Wenn Werd Ich Sterben" ("Dearest God, When Will I Die?"), this practice may well have been merely an economy of chamber scale.
But it also carries the cachet of advanced musicological thinking; Joshua Rifkin and others maintain that Bach probably had only one voice per part in most of his own choral performances. In any case, it worked well enough here: remarkably so in view of the weakness of individual voices (including a veritable caricature of a countertenor), as revealed in solo numbers.
By far the finest vocalist was Richard Lalli, a baritone, who also contributed the solo Cantata No. 82, "Ich Habe Genug" ("I Have Enough"). His approach seemed a bit dry and reserved at times in this warmest of outpourings, and the addition of ornaments in the repeat of the central aria ruffled the inherent serenity of this lullaby, but Mr. Lalli won the listener over in the end, rejoicing with Bach and the text at the prospect of death.
The Norfolk concerts were dedicated to the memory of Ronald Roseman, an oboist and Bach specialist who worked at the festival for more than a quarter of a century before his death in February. Mr. Roseman took a hand in programming this death-haunted concert, Joan Panetti, the festival's director, said from the stage.
Among other things, he quickly proposed "Ich Habe Genug," as well he might have, with its prominent oboe solos in the first and last movements. As it was, Randall Wolfgang played them ably, and Jennifer Grim was a deft, smooth flute soloist in "Liebster Gott."
The extras here were highly variable. David Connell, an organist, and a brass quintet offered three chorales to start, all well and good.
Less to the point, the guitar virtuoso Eliot Fisk opened the second half with a lute prelude and his arrangement of the Chaconne from Bach's D minor Violin Partita. If the steady tread and the cumulative magnificence of that great movement can be achieved on the guitar, they were not apparent here.
Another brass quintet, partly different (and sorely undercut by trombone playing woefully out of tune), performed a movement from "The Art of Fugue" and another chorale. And the sour notes extended to Ms. Panetti's introduction, with recourse to the hoary myths of these as last works and of dictation by the composer from his deathbed.
Surely, the Bach year should be an occasion to dispel myths once and for all and set the record straight. Happily, a tool is readily at hand: Christoph Wolff's magisterial new biography, "Johann Sebastian Bach: The Learned Musician."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Environmentalists Applaud a W.T.O. Ruling on Asbestos

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 24

 BODY:
A recent ruling by the World Trade Organization that upholds France's ban on Canadian asbestos imports has caught the attention of environmentalists and labor rights advocates, who say it indicates the global trade group may be growing more sensitive to their concerns.
The ruling, which affirmed the validity of a French law prohibiting imports of hazardous materials, is also another blow to the global asbestos industry. Other W.T.O. members might now use the ruling as a precedent to justify similar bans. 
 Asbestos, a fibrous mineral, was once widely used as insulation in buildings, but demand for it has shrunk drastically the last few decades because of scientific studies that show it causes cancer and other diseases.
Severe restrictions on the use of asbestos have been in effect for years in the United States, where billions of dollars in health-related claims by workers exposed to asbestos have long clogged the court system. The European Union, following France's lead, is soon expected to outlaw asbestos.
The ruling by a three-person W.T.O. dispute panel is the first time the Geneva-based trade group has upheld a member nation's trade restriction to protect human health. "It's about time that they supported common sense, not narrow-minded, short-term corporate interests," said Remi Parmentier, a spokesman for Greenpeace, the environmental activist organization. The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions has also welcomed the W.T.O. asbestos ruling as a victory for worker safety.
Both groups, which are prominent critics of the W.T.O., share concerns with a broad alliance of activists who disrupted the W.T.O.'s meeting last December in Seattle with demonstrations accusing the trade group of favoring business interests over the environment and workers' rights.
The asbestos ruling is preliminary and still officially confidential, but word of its contents leaked out in June. The final ruling is expected next month or in September, after both sides submit their comments.
W.T.O. officials have declined to comment on the asbestos ruling because it is not final. The Canadian and French missions to the W.T.O. have also declined to comment. But no interim ruling has ever been reversed in the trade group's five-year history, and it is expected to be confirmed.
The asbestos case was filed two years ago by Canada on behalf of its mining and export industry against France, which had banned asbestos and asbestos products as hazardous to humans two years earlier. Canada has long been a leading exporter of asbestos, most of it mined in Quebec.
Canada had sent nearly 30,000 metric tons of asbestos yearly to France before the 1996 ban, said Denis Hamel, a spokesman for the Asbestos Institute, a Montreal-based trade group.
In arguments at the W.T.O., the Canadians said newer, safer forms of asbestos did not release fibers into the air as older products did. They argued that France could have adopted controls less restrictive than a ban.
It is unclear whether the W.T.O. ruling will lead to restrictions on asbestos by other member nations. Some of the initial approval of the ruling by W.T.O. critics has also tempered a bit.
Lucien Royer, health and safety officer for the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, said the asbestos ruling provided little guidance to how the W.T.O. might rule in similar cases where the safety of an export is challenged because the trade group's dispute-resolution process is not public information.
"How the panels select and incorporate information in these rulings is very, very murky," Mr. Royer said.
Others said the ruling might actually be more confusing than helpful in resolving other trade disputes over health and environmental concerns.
Mr. Parmentier said it was "too early to say whether this ruling will affect other cases or the E.U.'s precautionary principle." He was referring to the European Union's effort to establish a principle to justify bans on imports considered harmful to the environment or public health.
The test of that principle has been at the center of the continuing trans-Atlantic trade fight over hormones in American beef.
The trade organization has ruled that the beef is safe and the union's ban is illegal. But the union says that its scientific studies establish that the beef represented enough danger to human health to warrant not complying with the organization's ruling.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Boeing and Airbus Disclose Over $15 Billion in Orders

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: FARNBOROUGH, England, July 24

 BODY:
The Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie announced more than $15 billion in new orders today at the air show in Farnborough, an unexpectedly large sum that reflected the resilience of the commercial aircraft market.
The value of the orders disclosed by the companies, the world's only two builders of large airliners, far exceeded the $9.4 billion total that was announced at the last major international air show, in Paris, a little more than a year ago. 
 Industry experts had predicted that a boom in orders at the end of the 1990's would turn into a slump by this year. Instead, a rebound in Asian economies and the record United States economic expansion are giving the industry confidence that airlines will keep ordering new planes. Leasing companies dominated the buying announced today.
"The market continues to surprise us," said Jim McNerney, president of the GE Aircraft Engines unit of the General Electric Company.
Boeing won orders from the largest aircraft-leasing companies, the International Lease Finance Corporation and General Electric's plane-leasing arm.
International Lease said that it was buying 40 jetliners valued at a total of $6 billion, and the General Electric division is placing orders for some 74 planes worth a total of $5.5 billion.
Airbus, the European consortium, won an order from the leasing company CIT Group Inc. for 50 planes worth $3.6 billion. It also officially disclosed the first commitments for its 550-seat A3XX "superjumbo," bidding to end the 30-year-old monopoly in the jumbo market held by Boeing's 747.
Airbus said Emirates Airlines signed a memorandum of understanding and made an undisclosed deposit for seven of the aircraft for delivery starting in February 2006, with options for five more. Air France also signed a preliminary agreement for 10 of the planes, with options for 4 more.
Both airlines had already expressed interest in the planes. They carry a list price of about $220 million each, though they will not be included in the Airbus order tally until the company's board authorizes proceeding with the project and firm contracts are signed. Airbus hopes to get enough customers to approve production by the end of the year.
Airbus had 239 orders through June 30 and said it was likely to disclose 200 more during the show. That puts it roughly level with Boeing, which had 322 orders through June 30 and will have more than 430 once it signs definitive agreements with the leasing companies.
The air show was also the forum for regional jet makers to announce more than $6 billion in sales today, mostly for planes made by Bombardier Inc. of Montreal. Embraer, the Brazilian plane maker, announced a $500 million order.

LENGTH: 1212 words

HEADLINE: Shopping the Madison Avenue Of Manhasset (Don't Say Mall)

BYLINE: By GUY TREBAY 

 BODY:
The two blond women with the tousled Frederic Fekkai haircuts were looking at snapshots over customized Cobbs (hold the ham, hold the cucumber, hold the avocado) at Millie's Place, the salads chased by iced tea, two Equals apiece.
"Does she look good or does she look good?" asked the first woman, a 48-year-old grandmother, who asked to remain nameless. 
 "Adorable," said her 50-year-old, anonymity-seeking friend. "So, how was Aspen?"
"Aspen was January. We're just back from Napa. So, are you loving this picture?"
"Beautiful. And what is she wearing?"
"Dior."
"How old is she now?"
"Six months."
This exchange took place at the Americana shopping center in Manhasset, N.Y., on Long Island's North Shore. Please don't say mall, though. The Americana at Manhasset is to "mall" as upper Madison Avenue is to Market Street in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Comparisons don't obtain.
For starters, there are few places in America where a handsome middle-aged woman dressed for a morning of tennis followed by light lunch and some shopping would not appear conspicuous wearing a crocodile Hermes belt ($1,495) over Ralph Lauren microfiber shorts ($95), a Jil Sander T-shirt ($300), a cotton sweater from Lacoste ($155), tan crocodile driving shoes from Tod's ($1,500) and carrying a beige alligator Kelly bag ($7,000). Even the woman's gold Rolex Oyster Perpetual Datejust ($15,900) was worn with the insouciance most folks might associate with a Timex.
But the Americana is not a most-folks destination. It is, as its developer, Frank Castagna, said, the "premiere shopping destination on Long Island." With its limestone facade, designed by the society architect Peter Marino; its swathes of meadow flowers and grasses, arranged by the modish landscape architects Oehme, van Sweden & Associates; its 225,000 square feet of retail space devoted almost exclusively to luxury brands; the Americana has become an alternate Madison Avenue, a mini Rodeo Drive, the parking lot where America's economic steamroller gets its ticket stamped.
"We're an off-the-radar oasis," said Deirdre Major, a spokeswoman for the Castagna Realty Company, although the Americana hasn't quite slipped the attention of Prada, Escada, Burberry, Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan and Max Mara, which all maintain stores there, or of Louis Vuitton, whose Americana outpost averages annual sales "in the millions of dollars," a spokesman said.
The Americana's tenants include not merely such traditional carriage trade retailers as Tiffany & Company and Christofle, but also the members of the luxury pack currently dominating fashion retailing in the United States. Giorgio Armani opened a new franchise there just three weeks ago. Fendi and Hermes are both planning new boutiques for the fall. Hirshleifer's, the venerable retailer specializing in high-end apparel from Gucci, Yves Saint Laurent and Chanel, is undergoing renovation to triple its selling space. And the accessories designer Kate Spade is also in the process of opening a stand-alone shop. It probably says something about a bull market that her location was formerly occupied by a bank.
The Americana, said John Slavinsky, a senior vice president for Vuitton, "is absolutely the best place to have a freestanding store on Long Island, bar none." It doesn't require a business degree from Wharton to understand the rationale for this, when even babies are wearing Dior.
"It's crazy," said Christina Makowsky, the owner of a Northern Boulevard boutique, Georgina, that is what you might call Americana-adjacent. "You can't believe the money people are throwing around these days. It's liquid millions. Even if you're rich, you're poor."
Of the 250 richest American towns recently cited by Worth magazine, 12 in the top 50 are a short drive from the Americana. The average household income of an Americana customer hovers around $125,000, Ms. Major said. But surely, as one shop owner remarked, that is too modest: "Maybe it's the salary for the maid."
Even as Nassau County wrangles with the state for a financial bailout, the Americana delivers Prada platform shoes and Gucci lug soles and Vuitton pastel logo bags to what Kiki Nolan, the manager for Thomas Pink at the Americana, called, "the richest people on Long Island," the ones that "you see at all the charity parties, the grand parties, the famous rich families of Long Island." Plenty of the Americana's customers seem to bypass fame, however, and head straight to rich.
"Communities have changed," said Steven B. Greenberg, of the Greenberg Group, retail consultants whose clients include Gucci. "Long Island's old guard has sold many of those old homes. The land has been subdivided. Instead of one $10 million home, you have a lot of $3 million homes owned by people in their 30's and 40's."
These people don't want to venture to Manhattan, he went on. "They want to buy luxury, but in a convenient setting." Consequently, rents approach $200 a square foot, a price unsurpassed in any suburban setting in America, Mr. Greenberg said. "That's right up there with the top shopping streets in America, but the volumes warrant it," he said. Retailers can realize a return of $1,000 a square foot, he added, although industry journals peg the figure closer to $850. Still, that is triple the average return at a mainstream mall.
It wasn't always so lucrative. "We had a disjointed center," said Mr. Castagna, whose family construction firm also built the Nassau Coliseum and the cell blocks at Rikers Island. When Mr. Castagna bought the land that would become the Americana from the developer William Levitt in 1956, he optimistically incorporated the new center as the Fifth Avenue of Long Island. As it turned out, he was off by an avenue and several decades. Among the early tenants were a Magic Pan and Baker's Shoes.
"At a certain point," he added, "we did a study and discovered that the land was more valuable with no buildings on it. We started a major move then to go in this direction." The direction was luxury. As it happens, the economy was headed that way, too.
And now, "the silent cash register is always ringing, silently," said a former buyer for Federated Department Stores, which in 1996 opened a $100 million specialty wing of its Bloomingdale's satellite at the Roosevelt Field mall to compete with Americana's luxury brands. "You walk into some of the stores," the buyer added, "and they're empty. But they've already done $50,000 that morning, selling sweaters to women who get bored at home and say, 'Let's order some stuff up.' "
The typical Americana consumer, added Lori Hirshleifer Sills, scion of a retailing business begun at the turn of the century in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, "is very high end. She's a 16 year old who comes to us for Gucci belts and accessories, and she's a woman in her 70's who's buying Chanel." She is a woman, said Josh Patner, a co-designer for Tuleh, a label that will soon have its own miniboutique in Hirshleifer's, "with a gorgeous car, a gorgeous home, who loves to look like a woman, and who is married to a man who loves women to look like women." There is one Hirshleifer's customer, Mr. Patner said, who owns "sapphires that match her Rolls." What retailer, he added, could ask for more?

LENGTH: 610 words

HEADLINE: Jakarta Lawmakers Press Leader on Ousters

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 24

 BODY:
A surly standoff between Parliament and its first democratically elected leader dragged on today as more than 200 members rejected President Abdurrahman Wahid's explanation for why he had ousted two popular cabinet ministers.
The members signed a petition demanding that Mr. Wahid go before the House of Representatives again to explain his actions. Mr. Wahid outraged the lawmakers in an appearance on Thursday, when he refused to give an account of the dismissals, saying the House had no right to interrogate him. 
 The action today raises the heat in what has been a long summer of discontent. The president is scheduled to face a pivotal meeting of the People's Consultative Assembly on Aug. 7, in which he is quite likely to face sharp questions about his often turbulent nine months in office.
As the supreme legislative body, the People's Consultative Assembly could remove the president from office. Five hundred of its 700 members are from the House.
Yet, experts said, the lack of viable alternatives makes it highly unlikely that the assembly would oust Mr. Wahid -- at least for now.
But the deeply poisoned atmosphere has stirred fears that violence could mar the meeting next month. The government plans to deploy 29,000 army troops and police officers in this capital.
The tension has also hobbled the economic recovery. The currency, the rupiah, has tumbled 25 percent since January and now trades at levels reminiscent of the Asian economic crisis. Economic policy is paralyzed, as investors wait for Mr. Wahid to reshuffle his economic ministers after the Assembly session.
"Unless Wahid fixes the economy, he can't fix all these other things, because they flow out of people's sense of well-being or lack of well-being," said Gustav F. Papanek, a professor emeritus of economics at Boston University who is advising the government on economic policy.
On Saturday, Mr. Wahid apologized to the House for his remarks and pleaded with lawmakers to lay the matter to rest. But in a sign that his quirky charm is wearing thin, 252 members rejected the overture and mounted a scalding attack on his leadership. "The president should not issue any more baseless or controversial statements, because it could negatively affect the stock market, cause recklessness or confusion or trigger disputes among the public," the legislators said in their petition, which went to Speaker Akbar Tandjung.
Mr. Tandjung said the House would debate the petition after the Assembly had ended its session in the middle of next month. That all but guarantees that Mr. Wahid will remain under siege for the rest of the summer, though few political experts here say they believe that he is in danger of being ousted.
To some extent, the sparks between the legislature and the president are a symbol of how far Indonesia has come. Under the country's longtime leader, Suharto, the House was a rubber-stamp institution that did the president's bidding. Since Mr. Wahid was elected, the lawmakers and the Indonesian people have begun to demand openness and accountability from their politicians.
Mr. Wahid, a Muslim leader with frail health but a whip-sharp sense of humor, began his term with a wide-open style that suggested a break from the past. But in the last several months, his administration has been sullied by charges of corruption and arbitrary rule.
In April, Mr. Wahid abruptly dismissed two respected ministers, Laksamana Sukardi and Jusuf Kalla. In meetings with political leaders, Mr. Wahid has said the cabinet ministers had been tainted by allegations of graft. But he has not produced evidence to support those assertions.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: The Business of Politics;
Corporations Pour Money Into the Political Conventions

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
For Philip Morris, the imminent political conventions are not so much about nominating presidential candidates and building party loyalty as they are about, well, macaroni. Macaroni in the shape of donkeys. Macaroni in the shape of elephants. Macaroni the company plans to hand out to delegates.
This is macaroni with a purpose: to tell the assembled opinion makers and power brokers that Philip Morris is not just a tobacco company and hasn't been for some time, that it also sells other products -- Kraft macaroni among them. 
 For many, conventions have little to do with politics and a lot to do with business -- polishing civic and corporate images, exploiting marketing opportunities, courting influence and turning what has long been an exercise in democracy into a huge corporate festival. The dazzling corporate sideshows put this year's gatherings -- next Monday through Aug. 3 for the Republicans in Philadelphia; Aug. 14-17 for the Democrats in Los Angeles -- in a class with the Olympics and the Super Bowl.
It is not just major corporations like Philip Morris, which has bigger plans for the Republican gathering but is not ignoring the Democratic one. Cities, too, see a chance to bask in the spotlight. Armed with studies putting the economic benefits of playing host to a political convention at $100 million or more, over a dozen cities -- including New York, Indianapolis and San Antonio -- lined up to be picked, offering millions of dollars in local support. This largess comes on top of the $13 million the federal government gives each party to hold its four-day convention. Yet in this headlong marketing rush, many are concerned. Some contend that the economic benefits are vastly overblown, while the risk to a city's image is underrated. Others call the conventions orgies of cash, providing yet another route for corporations to buy political access. Still others say that as conventions have increasingly lost their political role of nominating candidates and rallying the party faithful, corporations have stepped in to fill the vacuum.
"The conventions have become Super Bowls of the influence of money on politics," said Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, a Washington nonprofit group. "These are gala events where the most garish examples of excess appear."
The cities selected mounted all-out attacks to land the events along with promises of raising $35 million to $50 million in local funds for support services, mainly transportation, decorations and civic improvements. Tax-deductible contributions come to each city's host committee as cash or goods -- pagers from Motorola, software from Microsoft, discount tickets from US Airways and UAL's United Airlines.
Local governments kick in cash as well. Los Angeles donated $4 million to close a last-minute gap for the Democratic convention. Philadelphia's effort is supported with $17 million from the states of New Jersey and Pennsylvania and the city government, along with a $20 million letter of credit.
To critics of campaign financing like Mr. Lewis, host committees have become a gray zone -- a way for parties to benefit from millions of unregulated dollars, raised with minimal disclosure and given out of civic pride as well as a desire to help one candidate. Even so, some cities, like Los Angeles, have struggled to raise enough money.
Critics may rage, but cities that have landed conventions -- both now and in the past -- are thrilled. Even also-ran cities like Indianapolis say they benefited. And corporations on both coasts, local suppliers to national brands, are bubbling with enthusiasm about their plans for the conventions.
"This is a fabulous opportunity," said Patrick McGranaghan, the vice president for marketing at Dale Carnegie Training and Associates, which is training thousands of corporate volunteers for Philadelphia. "We are putting Dale Carnegie in front of every major corporation in the Delaware Valley and showing them what we do. It gives them a taste of Dale Carnegie training, and we hope they will come back and ask for more."
Jeremy's MicroBatch Ice Cream, a three-year-old Philadelphia company that recently produced the first beer-flavored ice cream, plans to donate $10,000 worth of its product to the media center, where 15,000 reporters will work.
"We hope it gets hotter than blazes, so people will want something cool and refreshing," said Michelle Peranteau, a spokeswoman. "There will be hundreds of thousands of people descending on our city. That's hundreds of thousands we could turn into MicroBatch lovers."
On a bigger scale, companies like Philip Morris, Motorola, McDonald's and Microsoft have donated money or products, or both. "We welcome the opportunity to showcase our technology," said Norm Sandler, head of government relations for Motorola, which has supplied conventions since 1952 and will play host at a party to honor the House speaker, Dennis J. Hastert, the Illinois Republican.
Philip Morris gave $250,000 to the Philadelphia host committee, but the Los Angeles committee does not accept tobacco contributions. In Philadelphia, where the company will "sponsor" a downtown street to be temporarily renamed for the company, it will join other corporations in giving parties for politicians and delegates and it is giving away lots of food-related products. Besides the animal-shaped macaroni, it plans to stock hospitality suites and delegate "goody bags" with Altoids mints, Toblerone chocolates, Maxwell House coffee, Miller Beer and Philadelphia cream cheese.
"When you are in a business that has some controversial aspects," said Peggy Roberts, the company's director of communications, "it is important to our shareholders and employees that we try and build relationships in venues that are important to us."
In fact, when civic fund-raisers approach corporations, the pitch is often more about business than politics. After all, if a company wants political access, some say, it would be better off giving directly to the parties. "We try to sell it as a marketing experience and not as a political contribution," said Eli Broad, chief executive of SunAmerica and co-chairman of the L.A. 2000 Host Committee. Mr. Broad gave $1 million to the effort, along with $1 million from SunAmerica's parent company, AIG.
Each city has its own reason for seeking the spotlight. For Philadelphia, it is an opportunity to show off a spiffed-up downtown and a new convention center and to promote itself as a place to visit, do business and live. Los Angeles hopes the convention will erase memories of earthquakes, urban rioting and the O. J. Simpson trial and show the world that the city actually does have a downtown.
"We've had fires, rains and floods, everything but locusts," said Noelia Rodriguez, chief executive of the host committee. "Now we've turned the city around, and we believe it's our moment to shine."
Karen Buchholz, president of Philadelphia 2000, added, "Getting this convention is like a seal of approval for Philadelphia."
But for the cities, it is more than civic pride, there is real money to be had.. The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago estimated in a study there would be a direct financial benefit to Chicago of $132 million from the 1996 Democratic convention.
"The hardest thing is to get people to come to your city in the first place," said Geoffry J. D. Hewings, a University of Illinois professor and the study's author. "Hopefully, they will be attracted to it and will come back. And there is a lot of ego associated with these conventions. Lots of people enjoy the nonfinancial benefits of being close to power."
Others say the benefits are overrated and the risks underplayed. Many cities already have a thriving hotel business in August that must be subtracted from any convention revenue. Besides, it is hard to imagine cities like Philadelphia or Los Angeles needing to raise millions to market themselves. And a backlash is possible if baton-wielding police crack down on unruly demonstrators. Cities can have their images tarnished, as Seattle found after the disorder at the World Trade Organization meeting in December.
"Does the convention make people say, 'Gee, I didn't know Los Angeles was there, maybe I'll go visit?' " said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College. "If you have a lame convention and fairly soporific candidates, it seems unlikely you would say, 'Boy, let's go see where Al Gore got nominated.' "
Roger Noll, an economics professor at Stanford University, added, "It seems crazy for anyone to claim that the image of New York or San Francisco or Chicago hinges on getting any of these kinds of events."
Cities that have been convention hosts, or have come close to landing one, disagree. "The event was fabulous for the city," said Susan Golding, mayor of San Diego, which was host to the 1996 Republican convention. "It brings a great deal of public attention and a general feeling that if you can handle a national political convention, well, you can handle just about anything."
Fred Sainz, former Republican convention planner and now head of the San Diego convention center, said cities craved the visibility more than the dollars.
"When reporters get bored with the conventions, as they do, they will write stories about the city," he said. "Larry King going live with the bay and the skyline and sitting there in a short-sleeved shirt in cool August breezes -- that does a lot."
Indianapolis was a finalist for the 2000 Republican convention, and Michael McDaniel, chairman of the state Republican party, said the city had benefited anyway. "We've had bookings in Indianapolis for events just as a result of being a finalist," he said. "They thought they should check us out for conventions. There is no way to put a price tag on that ripple effect."
Still, for all the perceived benefits, raising money is not easy. In the days before the 1996 San Diego convention, the city was about $5 million short, causing a worried Dole campaign to tap its donor list. In Philadelphia, while the host committee boasts of raising more than $40 million, only about $10 million of that is cash from corporations.
And fund-raising problems in Los Angeles have been the stuff of local headlines. Only two months before the convention was to begin, the host committee was still around $11 million short. The city contributed $4 million, and President Clinton came to Los Angeles to raise money, as well as lending his top fund-raiser, Terry McAuliffe, to twist arms. As of early this month, the city was still $4 million short.
As a result, when Ms. Rodriguez, head of the host committee, was interviewed earlier this month, she said Mayor Richard Riordan was in her office. What was he doing there? He was on the phone, she said, asking donors for money.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
BP Amoco wants to sell much more than gas at its new stations.

BYLINE: By Kruti Trivedi 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
BP AMOCO introduced a new model of gas station yesterday, and the least important item for sale is the gas.
The prototype of what will be a nationwide line of new stations, called BP Connect, was outfitted with solar panels, and spiffed up with the new green, yellow and white BP sunburst-shaped symbol. Customers will be able to check the forecast for an impending thunderstorm on a small screen at the pump, buy a bottle of wine and some fresh-baked croissants at a neon-free supermarket inside, or log in to the latest news at an e-commerce kiosk. 
 The decidedly upscale new digs are a launching pad for the company's new $7 million rebranding campaign that aims to reposition BP Amoco, an old-economy gas station giant, into a progressive, environmentally friendly retailer that goes, in the company's own words, "beyond petroleum."
The decision to introduce a new brand image and spruce up its service stations comes at a time when, as gas prices increase, competition for customer loyalty is especially fierce. Not only must BP Amoco deal with the consumers' growing sentiment of hostility toward gas companies, it also has to figure out how to best use its four major brands: BP, Amoco, Arco, and Castrol.
The rebranding campaign was seen by brand analysts as a way of increasing operating margins.
"The retail petroleum business is a dull, boring and uninteresting business in which the drivers of preference are location and price, and brands have not played a very significant role in gas stations," said John K. Grace, executive director of Interbrand Corporation, a brand consulting company. "Because branding has been weak, consumers have a difficult time differentiating among top quality players. These petroleum manufacturers are missing the boat in terms of what role brand can play."
While the price at the pump may be on the minds of most drivers this summer, there is a "growing and large percentage of people who don't go to gas stations for gas," said Peter Dixon, senior partner at Lippincott & Margulies, a corporate identity consulting company owned by Marsh & McLennan.
Indeed, BP Amoco is looking to pull drivers into the stations' stores, where they can buy items that are more profitable to sell than gasoline. While filling their tanks, customers can order a cafe latte that will be waiting for them once they've finished pumping their gas. If they really want to rush, BP is working on wireless technology that will enable them to send in their payments ahead of time.
The goal is to have half of the stations' revenue coming from gas sales and the other half coming from the convenience store, Doug Ford, BP Amoco's chief executive for refining and marketing, told reporters yesterday at a Georgia test site for the new station. Currently, 80 percent of revenue comes from gasoline sales and the rest from retail sales.
"To me this is a real estate business," Mr. Ford said. "We're managing a particular site."
BP Amoco, which analysts say has always been particularly sensitive to brand identity, began discussing branding as soon as its $48.2 billion acquisition of Amoco was complete in January 1999. Both brands needed a face lift: Amoco's stations had kept the same design for the last 20 years and BP for the last 12. The company hired Landor & Associates, a division of Young & Rubicam, to research consumer attitudes toward the stations. Landor found that customers liked Amoco products but thought the red, white and blue stations were too dark. At the same time, they found the green and yellow BP colors appealing.
Sir John Browne, BP Amoco's chief executive, decided that if BP Amoco was going to be recognized as a global brand, it needed to have one strong identity, a company official said.
The advertising to promote the new brand image was created by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, which was named by BP Amoco as its global agency in November. The ads, which focus on BP's role as a green company, will start running in print and on television today. One commercial asks: "Is it possible to drive a car and still have a clean environment? Can business go further and be a force for good?" BP says it plans to spend $25 million a fiscal quarter on its branding campaign.
The first BP Connect stations will open in Indianapolis, Cleveland, and London this year. The second round of station openings will include Chicago, Atlanta, and Sydney, Australia. The prototype was tested in an old warehouse outside of Atlanta because of its proximity to the suppliers in charge of making the new pump with its LCD screen.
The largest BP Connect sites will be 4,200 square feet. They are airy and open: none of the center-aisle shelves are much taller than waist level.
The stores are divided into five sections: a food service section, a beverage section, an impulse-buying section with snacks, a convenience-store section and an Internet section. The lighting changes with each section. The food service section has a warm, golden glow while the milk-and-eggs portion of the convenience section has a flourescent tinge.
Inside the store, the offerings are localized: customers using the Paris station, for example, will be able to find foie gras.
"It sounds to me like what BP has done is that they woke up one morning and said you know something, we're not in the gasoline business, we're in the retail business," said Clive Chajet of Chajet Consultancy, a brand consulting firm. "BP has recognized that their product is a commodity and they are incapable on the product level to differentiate their brand from competitors.' "
But some critics, like Charles T. Maxwell, senior petroleum analyst at Weeden & Company, are not convinced that customers will benefit from some of the extra add-ons. "Maybe this is one stop shopping but I always like to go to a grocery store to buy my groceries," Mr. Maxwell said. "The grease and parts and shout and clatter and spilled gasoline don't go in my mind with matters of food."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Broad Reorganization at I.B.M. Hints at Successor to Gerstner

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: ARMONK, N.Y., July 24

 BODY:
In the seven years since he took over, Louis V. Gerstner Jr. has led a striking revival in the fortunes of I.B.M., the world's largest computer company. Yet Mr. Gerstner, the chairman and chief executive, has decided that what the company most needs now is a good shake-up -- to accelerate its growth and achieve its goal of being the leading supplier of technology and services for the Internet economy.
So the International Business Machines Corporation announced a sweeping management overhaul today that includes the elevating of Samuel J. Palmisano, a senior vice president, to become president and chief operating officer. 
 The move clearly seems to make Mr. Palmisano, 48, the heir apparent to Mr. Gerstner, who is 58. Mr. Gerstner, who joined I.B.M. in 1993, when the company was reeling, has an employment contract that calls for him to remain in charge "at least until he turns 60 years of age," or until March 2002.
In a lengthy interview at the company's Westchester County headquarters here, Mr. Gerstner acknowledged that the announcement was certain to focus attention on the question of succession at I.B.M. But he noted that the elevation of Mr. Palmisano was one of several promotions of younger executives as part of the reorganization.
"A new generation of leaders is starting to emerge at I.B.M.," Mr. Gerstner said. "And certainly Sam is part of that, but so are a lot of other people here."
Besides, Mr. Gerstner noted, he has no intention of stepping down anytime soon. "I'm still here," he said. "I'm not going anywhere, and my job hasn't changed. And the board has not chosen my successor as C.E.O."
"There's not a lot you should read into this about me leaving," he added.
Also today, I.B.M. named John M. Thompson, another senior vice president, to become vice chairman. Under the new setup, Mr. Thompson will guide the company's efforts in such promising new areas of growth as wireless communication, network storage systems, life sciences and Internet software.
Yet Mr. Thompson is 57 and, given the I.B.M. tradition of having senior executives retire around 60, he seems to be a less likely successor to Mr. Gerstner than Mr. Palmisano. Mr. Gerstner praised Mr. Thompson as "a rare talent," and gifted manager of technical workers.
The company also promoted five other executives, all in their 40's.
While Mr. Thompson focuses on the future, Mr. Palmisano will be in charge of daily operations in all the company's product and service businesses. In an e-mail memo to I.B.M.'s senior management team today, Mr. Gerstner wrote of Mr. Palmisano, "Sam has consistently demonstrated the aptitude perhaps most critical to leadership success: He sets tough targets and then meets them."
In the interview, Mr. Gerstner said that the reorganization had less to do with executive succession than with retooling the company's management structure to execute its Internet strategy more effectively.
Indeed, the lingering question about the transformation at I.B.M. under Mr. Gerstner's leadership is whether, despite all the progress to date, the company is moving into that future quickly enough to offset the decline in some of its traditional businesses, like mainframe computers.
In its second-quarter financial results, reported last week, I.B.M. surpassed the earnings estimates of Wall Street analysts, but its revenue declined.
For the I.B.M. success story to be complete, it must deliver growing sales. The key to I.B.M.'s future as an investment, said Steven Milunovich, a Merrill Lynch analyst, writing in a bulletin to the firm's clients last week, is "figuring out if I.B.M. is a new-technology or an old-technology stock," and adding, "It's some of both now."
In Mr. Gerstner's view, the table is set for growth at I.B.M., based on its strategy of being a leading supplier to companies trying to make the transition to e-commerce.
In the second quarter, Mr. Gerstner noted that revenue for its e-business consulting grew 78 percent, that its specialized microchips for cellular phones and other wireless communications are sold out, and that it is straining to keep up with demand for the big hub computers, called servers, that shuttle data from and to Web sites.
The company's e-business strategy, set in place over the last few years, is working as planned, Mr. Gerstner said. "The business is exploding underneath us," he said. "And we need to have a very, very focused execution capability within the company."
He called today's announcement the "third turn of the wheel" in terms of corporate strategy since he took over in 1993. The first stage he characterized as survival, and the second involved putting the e-business strategy in place. The third, he said, is the execution stage. Mr. Gerstner, once a partner at the consultant McKinsey & Company, said that one of the most important lessons he learned there was the crucial "linkage between structure and strategy, and that you really don't implement an effective strategy without a structure that reinforces and complements that strategy."
Yet the shake-up, Mr. Gerstner says, was also influenced in part by an instinctive belief of his about corporate management.
"I am a big believer in forcing change on large institutions just for the sake of forcing change," he said. "The longer an organization stays intact, the less successful it is.
"I've been absolutely convinced that you've got to blow things up and start over again every few years, and that puts a whole new face on people's jobs. It gets people focused externally rather than internally."
The management organization, he said, is intended to "sharply delineate" the two major tasks facing I.B.M.: "the execution of today's e-business strategy, which will be led by Sam Palmisano, and that development -- the rapid development -- of the new e-business world that John Thompson will lead."
Shortly after he joined I.B.M., Mr. Gerstner said that the company, given its dire straits, did not need a grand technology vision for its future -- a comment that brought criticism and ridicule from industry analysts. He said he had been widely misquoted, and what he had tried to emphasize then was that I.B.M. most needed to right itself before gazing toward the horizon.
But there seemed to be plenty of talk about vision at the top today. Mr. Gerstner spoke of Mr. Thompson's job as helping to guide I.B.M.'s "billions upon billions of dollars" of investment in next-generation "intelligent infrastructure" for the Internet -- when vast numbers of devices, including cellular phones and Palm-like hand-held computers, would be connected to the Internet
"Today's networked world is primitive compared to what it's going to look like in three to five years," he said.

HEADLINE: Tax Break Program Is Expanded To Help More Depressed Areas

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
New York State has expanded a program that provides tax credits and other incentives for companies to invest in economically troubled areas, adding zones in which the incentives will be offered.
As a result of legislation authorizing the six new districts, which Gov. George E. Pataki recently signed into law, the state will soon send forms to all its municipalities and counties so that those that want such economic development zones may apply to have areas in their jurisdictions chosen. 
 Even as they report that the state's overall economy is on the upswing, state officials say they expect many applications because not every community has shared in the good times. When Mr. Pataki approved the legislation, he said the expansion "means we can do even more to ensure that every community across New York participates in the state's growing economy."
The measure will increase to 58 the number of zones under the program, which began in 1987 to help communities with high unemployment and poverty. The program was later expanded to aid areas hurt by the closing of military bases and other defense cutbacks.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, which administers the program, said the latest addition of zones was part of an effort to "encourage even more opportunities for job creation" across the state.
Areas that already have such zones include East New York in Brooklyn, South Jamaica in Queens, Port Morris in the Bronx, East Harlem and cities like Buffalo, Albany, Rochester and Plattsburgh. Because of the criteria for the six new zones, three of them are likely to be in rural areas, state officials say.
Under the program, a company receives a basic tax credit of 25 percent of the amount of its investment for locating or expanding a business in a zone, or for investing in building a community facility, like a day care center, in a zone.
The new state budget added millions of dollars in tax credits to the program, the governor's office said, and at least 125,000 people have been employed at more than 2,600 businesses aided by the program. The program's name was recently changed from the Economic Development Zones Program to the Empire Zones Program.

HEADLINE: Back in Business After a Tempest And a Tea Room;
Storm Doomed Eclectic Gallery, But Owner Finds a New Venture

SERIES: AFTER THE FLOOD -- Last in a series.

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

DATELINE: DUNELLEN, N.J., July 20

 BODY:
Bettina DeCaumette wanted the old red jukebox out of the bar, rejecting it in the process of ending one business and starting another. So her bartender and partner grabbed the box from the dusty corner where it had blared out tunes like Bing Crosby's "Too-Ra-Loo-Ra-Loo-Ral" for at least three decades, gave it a shove, rolling it into a small pantry in the back.
"When you're the hostess, you don't make your guests create the ambience," Mrs. DeCaumette said, putting on, instead, a CD called "Chicago Blues." 
 Ten months after Tropical Storm Floyd flooded her out, Mrs. DeCaumette is back in business. But she is not operating her Palmyra Tea Room and Art Gallery, the eclectic restaurant and gathering place she ran in nearby Bound Brook for five years, until Floyd filled it with eight feet of water on Sept. 16.
Because she has yet to find a suitable location to reopen the Palmyra in Bound Brook, about 35 miles southwest of Midtown Manhattan, she has become part owner of the Dunellen Hotel. The hotel is a careworn 14-room Victorian building on Washington Street here, just a few miles east of her old business.
A few weeks ago, Mrs. DeCaumette took over the restaurant and the Rathskeller bar in the hotel's basement, a neighborhood fixture since the mid-1930's.
While the Dunellen is not the Palmyra, Mrs. DeCaumette is grateful to be back in business after months of indecision and financial worries.
"I feel very fortunate because lots of people dream of owning their own place and never have the opportunity," she said recently as she presided over her small staff and a sparse lunchtime crowd in the bar. "I believe it's better to go out and do something, anything, rather than do nothing."
Floyd caused more than $1 billion in damage in New Jersey and brought normal life to an abrupt standstill for those who lost homes and businesses. In Bound Brook, on the banks of the Raritan River, which spilled over during the storm, hundreds of small-business owners like Mrs. DeCaumette had to struggle to resume their livelihoods.
A drive through the town shows that most businesses are up and running, but many storefronts are still empty or boarded up. And those who lived through the flood say the effects linger in ways that sometimes cannot be seen or measured. The town, for example, has been divided by a redevelopment plan. Hundreds of angry residents have filled borough council meetings to express their fears that the plan will require their homes to be condemned to make way for new construction.
Town officials, residents and business owners who suffered losses have spent months lobbying the state and the federal governments for financial assistance, which has come slowly. Last month, Congress appropriated $30 million in emergency public works and economic development money to rebuild stricken New Jersey downtowns.
This is in addition to money the state provided for grants to help individual business owners. Patricia Clark, the policy director for Somerset County, said her county received $5.7 million of that money, much of which is going to Bound Brook's business owners. So far, her office has taken grant applications from 287 businesses, and 257, including Mrs. DeCaumette's, have received them, she said. Mrs. DeCaumette was given $11,150 to get back on her feet, and she may qualify for $2,800 more, Ms. Clark said.
Mrs. DeCaumette was turned down for a $100,000 loan from the United States Small Business Administration. Even with her business closed and no cash coming in for the last few months, she still had to pay about $1,000 a month to creditors, including banks and vendors.
She and her husband, Patrick, and daughter, Celia, survived financially by relying on savings and keeping their living expenses down. Mr. DeCaumette, who had helped with the Palmyra before September, took a job with the Bound Brook office of the Salvation Army, which is still helping flood victims to resettle.
Mrs. DeCaumette said the family had gone through its modest savings and had since stopped eating out and traveling, as well as putting off almost all clothing purchases.
The family has also been helped by friends and family. Mrs. DeCaumette's mother, Aud Frislid, who ran an antiques store two doors down from the Palmyra that was also shut by the flood, helps by taking care of Celia. During the last 10 months, she also housed several of the Palmyra's employees, like Jim Brannon, who is now a bartender at the Rathskeller and part owner.
Still, the flood put a strain on them all. Mrs. DeCaumette spent many sleepless nights worrying about how to restart her business and what would happen to her employees. She said she grappled with depression as she wondered how her family would survive financially. "The emotional toll has been very high," she said.
"It's all stressful right now, but we're starting a new business, so it's normal," she added. "We just have to prioritize more carefully."
For a few months, she argued and fought with her old landlord, Phil Neri, who also owned the space Mrs. Frislid was leasing for the antiques business.
In the end, mother and daughter decided to part company with Mr. Neri over disputes about the rent and repairs to the waterlogged storefront space.
Mrs. Auslid, who lives in a Victorian house around the corner from the old tea room space on Hamilton Street, wants to restart her antiques business in her garage.
As for the Palmyra, Mrs. DeCaumette said she still dreamed of reopening it, but had been distracted from her search for a new site by her involvement with the Dunellen.
Mrs. DeCaumette owns 20 percent of the hotel and 80 percent of the restaurant and bar operation. Mr. Brannon, the bartender, will own 10 percent of the restaurant business. The hotel's majority owner is Evan Carzis, the DeCaumettes' landlord in another Bound Brook business, a spice and tea shop called the Woad and Madder. That shop, which was five months old when the floods came, has not reopened either. Mrs. DeCaumette is seeking the right time to resurrect the tea room.
"We've done as much as we could with Palmyra," she said. "Now we need to wait a little bit. We're watching the situation in Bound Brook very closely. Palmyra is still very much alive in our hearts."
To Mrs. Decaumette, the Palmyra was more than a business, and when it closed, she lost more than a way to making a living.
She started the Palmyra as a small operation that grew to be a popular meeting place that was part salon, part art gallery and part performance space. It also had a bookstore and a restaurant that offered a Middle Eastern menu. Mrs. DeCaumette worked as the chef in the Palmyra's early days, and until the fall was still sometimes the hostess, depending on whether anyone in her staff of 15 was absent. She was there almost every day, arriving about 11 a.m. and not going home until 2 or 3 a.m., after closing and preparing for the next day.
So in Dunellen, she's trying to revive an atmosphere as well as a business.
Many of her old staff members are returning. In addition to Mr. Brannon, there is Margo Frak, 16, who had been a waiter at the Palmyra for only a few months before it was flooded. Ms. Frak, a high school student, walked into the Palmyra once with her art teachers and saw the antique furniture and the artworks on the walls. "I said, 'This is cool,' " Ms. Frak recalled. " 'How can I get a job here?' " Four weeks later, she was hired. Then came the flood.
Another of Mrs. DeCaumette's waiters has been working as a reservations assistant at the Ryland Inn in nearby Whitewater, a business owned by friends, but she coming to work at the Dunellen next month. Mrs. DeCaumette's head chef, Kirsten Hansson, had been working at Trader Joe's, a specialty market, but this month began working at the Rathskeller.
The Dunellen Hotel is strikingly different from the Palmyra. It had been run for 52 years by the same owner, Lawrence Kerwin, whose father owned it before him.
The Rathskeller, with its dark stone walls and red checkerboard linoleum floors, had been something of a neighborhood bar for years, and Mr. Kerwin served light fare in addition to his chicken pot pie and carrot cake.
It had a variety of loyal customers, from people who would plant themselves at the bar most of the afternoon to an after-church crowd on Sundays.
Mrs. DeCaumette will give it something of her own twist, with new music and a menu that will continue to provide the usual bar fare, with gradual additions like a smoked trout salad and onion soup. But mostly, she wants it to remain a neighborhood gathering place.
She marvels at finding herself running a bar in the basement of a rundown hotel built in 1869 in a little town called Dunellen.
"I never in a million years thought this is where I was going to be a year after the flood," she said. "That, on a daily basis, is hard to adjust to."
Still, she's finding out that while adversity can turn a life upside down, plenty of things that were issues before the flood remain issues after it.
So when she was not working, she had time to think about her overstressed life and long hours, and she resolved to strike a better balance between work and family.
"We're working hard for me to set boundaries for the well-being of my family, and my sanity too," she said.
But, while she plans to take at least one day off in her new job, she has so far found herself working almost as many hours as she did at the Palmyra.
Still, she strives for balance and keeps in mind the strange twists that life can bring.
"You just have to be more accepting of the things you can't control and to really be open about where life takes you no matter how goal oriented you are," she said. "You can't determine where you're going to be in five years or even six months. That's the big lesson."
 
After the Flood
This is the last in a series of articles examining the rebuilding efforts by the owners of the Palmyra Tea Room and Art Gallery, who were among thousands of residents and business people in Bound Brook, N.J., whose lives were disrupted by Tropical Storm Floyd.
